Social Science—Latter-day Saint Family Life Preview of the Lessons for 1956-57 Elder John Farr Larson Joseph Smith, the Prophet and Seer of the Lord, has done mote, save Jesus only, for the salvation of men in this world, than any other man that ever lived in it. In the short space of twenty years, he has brought forth the Book of Mormon, which he translated by the gift and power of God, and has been the means of publishing it on two continents; has sent the fulness of the everlasting gospel, which it contained, to the four quarters of the earth; has brought forth the revelations and commandments which compose this book of Doctrine and Covenants, and many other wise documents and instructions for the benefit of the children of men; gathered many thousands of the Latter-day Saints, founded a great city, and left a fame and name that cannot be slain. He lived great, and he died great in the eyes of God and his people; and like most of thie Lord's anointed in ancient times, has sealed his mission and his words with his own blood; and so has his brother Hyrum. In life they were not divided, and in death they were not separated! (D. & C. 135:3). Page 410 LESSON DEPARTMENT HE foregoing excerpt from modern Latter-day scriptures offers a complete and concise summary of the Prophet Joseph Smith's place in the history of the world. It describes vividly the broad scope of his accomplishments within an unbelievably short time. It awakens in every Latter-day Saint a new appreciation for the life of this great leader. One cannot review his service to mankind without concluding that he was inspired of the Lord and divinely called to usher in the dispensation of the fulness of times. All Latter-day Saints are desirous of becoming more familiar with the "wise... Instructions for the benefit of the children of men" uttered by the Prophet. He spoke with wisdom on almost every conceivable subject, and most of what he said was far in advance of the thinking of his day. Some of the Prophet's teachings were directed to God's children everywhere, some to members of the Church only, while still others were spoken to specific groups within the Church. Of special. Interest to members of the Relief Society are his instructions delivered and recorded at the early meetings of the Female Relief Society of Nauvoo, which was established by the Prophet Joseph Smith in March 1842. Sarah M. Kimball reported the Prophet as saying, ""The Church was never perfectly organized until the women were thus organized" (Relief Society Magazine, March 1910, page 129). The Prophet Joseph's exalted concept of women's status elevated them to a new level. His instruc- 411 tions established a conduct pattern for Latter-day Saint women which they have been taught to follow ever since, perhaps not always being aware of the original source of these instructions. His suggested procedures in serving others and in perfecting ourselves are as applicable today as when they were spoken, and coincide with "new" ideas advanced by the modern experts. Latter-day Saint women are better wives and mothers by living in accordance with the teachings given them by the Prophet Joseph Smith. Their family life patterns become greatly strengthened. In speaking to the Relief Society on May 26, 1842, the Prophet advised the sisters of Relief Society, "If I were not in your midst to aid and counsel you, the devil would overcome you" (D. H. C. V, page 21). The social science lessons for the coming year are based upon the Prophet Joseph Smith's teachings to Latter-day Saint women. They are offered in the hope that through their consideration Relief Society members everywhere will increase in testimony regarding the Prophet's mission, and in a desire to improve the effectiveness of their great organization by heeding his timely counsel. 'These 1956-57 lessons are the first year of a course of study designed to strengthen the family, and to consider its problems, position, and blessings in our modern culture. Lesson titles and objectives for the year are as follows: Lesson 1—Joseph Smith's Home Life Objective: To show the influence of the Prophet's early family life upon Early 412 his teachings to the Latter-day Saint women. Lesson 2—A New Day For Women Objective: 'To show that the organization of the Relief Society marked the beginning of a new era for women. Lesson 3—The Key Is Turned Objective: 'To show significant steps in the organization of the Relief Society and the opportunities for service found in its objectives. Lesson 4—Women and the PriestHood Objectives: To show the role and responsibilities of Latter-day Saint women in connection with the Priesthood. RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JUNE 1956 Lesson 5—"Unto the Least of These Objective: To show that salvation is the ultimate aim in all service to the needy. Lesson 6—"'Search Your Hearts" Objective: To illustrate the process of perfection and the necessity of eliminating those traits of character which retard our quest for perfection. Lesson 7—"Be Ye Therefore Perfect" Objective: 'To suggest the importance of acquiring desirable qualities and to show the blessings in store for those who love the Lord. Tlotes on the Jhon of the ahosséns HIS year only one writer not previously represented among the authors of the lessons, is introduced to Relief Society members and readers of the Magazine. John Farr Larson, author of the social science lessons, "Latter-day Saint Family Life,' was born in Taylor, Weber County, Utah, a son of Patriarch James A. Larson and Olive Farr Larson. He is a graduate of Weber College and the University of Utah School of Law, and is a practicing attorney in Salt Lake City at the present time. He is a member of the Utah State Bar Association and is currently serving as chairman of the Family Law Section of that organization. He has been admitted to practice law before the Supreme Court of Utah, the United States Court of Military Appeals, and the United States Supreme Court. In 1938 Elder Larson became affiliated with the Utah State Juvenile Court System and since 1944 he has been Director of the Bureau of Services for Children, Utah State Department of Public Welfare. (This Bureau has administrative supervision of Juvenile Courts, Child Welfare Services in County Departments of Public Welfare, the licensing of Child Placing Agencies and Day Care Centers, and the investigation of adoption petitions for District Courts. ) He is a former President of the Utah Conference of Social Work, the Utah Child Guidance Association, Board of Directors of Salt Lake Community Chest, and is currently a member of the Editorial Advisory Board and_ Professional Council of the National Probation and Parole Association. In 1950 he served as Chairman, Utah Committee, Mid-Century White House Conference on Children and Youth. Elder Larson served in the Eastern States Mission from May 1936 until LESSON DEPARTMENT June 1938. He has always been active in the Church. For many years he served in Scouting and other MIA positions in the Ogden Eighth Ward. He is a former Sunday School superintendent of West Ensign and Canyoncrest Wards, member of the Highland Stake Sunday School Board and superintendency, and for three years a counselor in the bishopric of Canyoncrest Ward. At present he is a member of the Monument Park Stake High Council. He married Ann Clayson in the Salt Lake Temple in June 19309. They are the parents of two sons and three daughters. In April decked in fairy lace; In summer, hung with crimson fruit, A place to hide, a place to loot; A spot to lie and see the sky, And watch cloud-images pass by, To dream as small birds chirp and sing... An orchard is the loveliest thing. Page 414 S; he RS ee y Pla nt Nancy M. Amnstrong E all know that a testimony of the gospel of Jesus Christ is a living, growing thing. All living things need nourishment. When we have a particularly beautiful or rare plant in our gardens We see that it has sunlight and water, cultivation and plant food. In the garden of life, what is more beautiful than a testimony of the gospel? It is indeed entitled to the choicest spot; to the best care and finest nourishment we can provide for it. A testimony draws its nourishment from activity in the work of the Lord, and in keeping his commandments, we give it extra care. John Keats expressed the idea that "A thing of beauty is a joy forever." Surely this is true of a testimony. It is a source of joy to the one who possesses it, and a thing of beauty to all who come in contact with it. When a testimony is in full flowering, it bears many lovely blossoms of good deeds. 'The more bouquets one gives away to others, the more abundantly the testimony blooms. Like othei growing things, a testimony can lie dormant for a period of time, but, if it receives no nourishment, it may wither away. Our first obligation is to see that our own testimonies are receiving all the sunlight and nourishment they need to keep them in full flowering. Our next duty is to feel the responsibility to reach out to some fine sister whose testimony is lying dormant and help her bring it into bloom, so that her garden of life will be rich with the perfume "peace of mind"; the fragrance of every true testimony. 6arly American Hooked Rug Design Elizabeth Williamson AN old quilt pattern [Early American] may be used in a hooked rug design. Are you a willow in my hand— Or instrument... I fashioned at the spring? My slender fingers, satin brown, Are here to tremble at your will; My lips to hold you as my own; My throat to trill at every call; My flesh to cry at what I feel! Play, flute, play wild a song! Play, flute, play! Play low, the cooing song of doves— The owlet's mournful call. Staccato sound of falling rain And hoof beats down the far ravine. Play shrill, the coyote's hungry cry— Echo young ones in their lair. Play sweet, oh, flute, the song of home Beside the hogan fire. Play, flute, play soft a song! Play, flute, play! Play wild, the song of burning thirst; The triumph of the rain; The eagle's screaming in the sky, Her carrion to gain. Play swift, the song of ponies wild— Of hunters at the kill! Master of this flute am I— Rest now, oh, flute, Be still. The Cover: View of Ribe, Denmark, From the Domkirke Courtesy Lind Studio Photograph submitted by Mary G. Nelson Cover Design by Evan Jensen From Near and Sar Thank you for your splendid editorial in the May Magazine ("The Gift for Mother's Day' by Marianne C. Sharp). When I read to my husband: "The most precious gift which children can give to their mother is the knowledge that they are walking the straight and narrow path to immortality and eternal life," he said, "Our children have given you that precious gift." So I copied that paragraph, added a few lines expressing our love and appreciation, and mailed a copy to each of our five children. Humbly and gratefully I can say that they are all busily engaged in Church activities.... I greatly love Relief Society and appreciate being a member and worker in that great organization. 'The Magazine has been in our home since the first volume, and it is also in the homes of our children. —Adena W. Swenson Pleasant Grove, Utah May I express my appreciation of the Magazine. In May 1955, the special feature written by Elna P. Haymond — "Mother" — presented a soul-stirring story about Sister Haymond's Grandmother Doney who came in the Ellsworth Handcart Company in 1856. I was thrilled to read the article, and should like to say that the little daughter born on _ that arduous trip is my mother, Mary Jane Doney Lowe. She is the mother of ten children, nine of whom are living. She, too, fought the battles of life with the weapons of love, faith, and determination. I hope to live that I may be worthy of the heritage she has left us. —Bertha Lowe Johnson Logan, Utah In the May issue of The Relief Society Magazine, I especially liked the frontispiece poem "The Things in You I See" by Dorothy J. A cccccccccennscaresonaesceosscuststancnnsoseccaesaneecrseteswesescensasaecereonteneoeceococrecsionetereracssenvewesesosess Frances C. Yost 428.. 440 Outings and Family Solidarity LaVern W. Parmley President, The Primary Association ECENTLY at a stake conference, one of the leaders said to Brother Oscar A. Kirkham, "After the morning meeting I wish you would take the opportunity to walk home with my son. He is not going to his Sabbath School, and I wish you would have a chat with him." Brother Kirkham, after the meeting, took the chap by the arm, and they started down the street towards home. He thought a very good approach would be to say: "You know, you have a great father. He is a fine man." 'The boy immediately turned and said, "Brother Kirkham, I wish you would talk to my father for me. In all my life he has never been with me to a movie. He has never taken me with him anywhere. I haven't even had a game of checkers with him. I would appreciate it." There are many adults who seem to have attained the dignified state of parenthood without having first passed through the undignified state of childhood. Childhood memories dim with the passing of years, until, finally, all that are left are those of the somewhat idealistic side. Through doing things together, parents learn to understand their child's point of view, and to deal more sympathetically with his natural urges and desires. What all parents really need is a bridge between themselves and their children Page 420 to shorten the gap and bring about family solidarity. Business men, educators, and religious leaders agree that the early home experiences of a child are important factors in his life. 'The question has been asked — "Can a child fail in his life's work because parents have provided him with poor home training and environment?" Executives and personnel experts of leading American corporations declare a unanimous "yes." United States industry says this to parents: "We wouldn't want your son or daughter, if you have failed to train him for successful adulthood." Most industrial leaders believe members of a family should pull together to develop their standards of living. According to Lawrence A. Appley, President of the American Management Association, _Inc., "There seems to be a direct significant relationship between early home environment and on-the-job success." ARENTS ought to build into the minds of their children confidence in their own ability. One business manager, when asked how this could be done, said, "Encourage your child to try a variety of skills, take him hunting and _fishing; teach him the use of power tools; teach him civic mindedness, OUTINGS AND FAMILY SOLIDARITY 421 THE FAMILY HOUR FEATURES A PICNIC AT HOME Members of the Francis A. Madsen family: Seated at the table, left to right: Mary Louise Rawlings (daughter); David Rawlings (grandson); Ben E. Rawlings (son-in-law); Francis A. Madsen (father); Francis A. Madsen, Jr. (son); Susan Madsen (granddaughter); Connie Madsen (daughter-in-law). Standing in the background, left to right: Louise W. Madsen (mother, member of the general board of Relief Society); Richard Madsen (son). Children, seated at the table, in front, left: Scott Rawlings (grandson); Peter William Madsen (son); Michelle Madsen (granddaughter). Community loyalty, church loyalty and build his moral fiber." In an article "Your Children Need Family Recreation," written by Dr. Rex A. Skidmore of the University of Utah, and published in the November 1955 issue of the Children's Friend, we read: It has been said that "the family that prays together stays together.' Some experts have added to this that the family that "'plays together grows together." Case studies show that both of these activities have great possibilities sound family relationships. Some values of the family playing together are particularly important. First, the family usually gets better acquainted with each other. Too many families live at home in name only and are away from each other most of the time. Family recreation can be "loads of fun." Playing with those who are near and dear to one is enjoyable in many respects. Participating in recreational activities establishes a deeper bond, and opens the doors of communication among family members. In developing 422 A picnic seems to be one type of outing suitable for families. Young and old enjoy taking a lunch to a park, canyon, seaside, or other appropriate place where there is an abundance of fresh air and things to do, where the children can romp and expend some of the energies which build up within them. Parents who nag their children at home usually find it easy to let them run, yell, and sing to their "'heart's content'"' in a picnic area. Parents who do not take their whole family on a picnic at least several times during a year are missing a golden opportunity for having fun and strengthening family bonds. Elder Ezra Taft Benson, at a general conference, said: Our homes need the stabilizing influence of a closer relationship between parents and children. Every boy and girl needs the safeguard which an intimate association with mother or father will provide. 'This relationship must be built upon love and mutual confidence. Such an atmosphere can be created as parents plan for recreation and diversion together with their children. An evening spent in wholesome activity; a picnic in the mountains or nearby park; or a project for fathers and sons and mothers and daughters — these will all tend to increase filial affection and love in the home, and strengthen parent-children relations. Time thus spent yields big dividends. Parents in this close association have no difficulty teaching virtue, honesty and industry, the basic principles of our American way of life. There can be no genuine happiness separate and apart from the home. More recreation and more devotion in the home will result in greater family solidarity. Solidarity, as defined in the dictionary, means: "An entire union of interests and responsibilities in a group; community of interests, standards, etc." Children, themselves, feel the necessity of family solidarity, of RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 sharing, working, and playing together in a family group. The question, "What do you think makes a happy family?" was asked of more than 1500 schooi children. Every grade from the second grade to the last year in high school was represented in this study conducted by the New Rochelle Guidance Center. The following are some of the answers given: A thirteen year old boy summed up his answer in these words, "A happy family reminds me of a baseball team, with Mom pitching, Dad catching and the kids fielding with everyone taking a turn at bat." The seven and eight-year-olds focused their answers on the concrete satisfactions of family life: a picnic in the park, the "surprise" daddy brings home, holiday celebrations, the family pet. One said, "Our family is happy because we help each other a lot." The nine-year-olds put their emphasis on relationships in family life: They frequently mentioned family parties and outings, playing games with the family, talking about pleasant things at meals. 'To them happiness meant togetherness. The ten - year - olds generally reached this conclusion: Do your chores, have fun, and go places together. The eleven and _ twelve-year-olds continued to underline the ideas of the younger children but did so more maturely. The happy family is the united family. The most important thing in a happy family is being together a lot. OUTINGS AND FAMILY SOLIDARITY Family solidarity was what each group wanted. 'These young people, so varied in age and_background, agreed with startling unanimity that being together in the family and doing things with all of its members is the very essence of happiness. FS TABLISHING play habits of the right sort is perhaps one of the most important things in character development. 'The president of a stake once said, "Oh, if my father had only let me _ play when I was a boy. If I wanted to play ball or go on a hike, he would say, If you've got more energy than you need, there's the hoe and there's the cornfield.' His attitude towards play activities was that they were a waste of time. Now I feel myself all cramped and bound into a limited space of action. I can't reach out easily for social contacts." There is a great vacancy in that man's life. In the book Recreation in the Home, we read: It is generally recognized as true that right living is not transmitted by merely telling children to be honest and brave and true. Rather it is developed in the individual as a phase of other activities and through the example of parents and children working, playing, and carrying on social life together. Perhaps there is not the same degree of pleasure to the boy who blisters his hands on a hoe handle or exhausts himself in running a mile to chase the cows out of the lucerne patch, that there is when he blisters his hands on a baseball bat and exhausts himself in making a home trun. But there can be pleasure in both if the proper attitude is fixed for both. In any program of family activity 423 there must be socialized co-operation. The tasks allotted should take into consideration the age and abilities of the children. They should give opportunity for individual success and excellence of performance. Individual initiative should not be crushed and the child should be given due credit and praise when the task is completed. Boy Scouts in the family may be given the joy of building the fire, and even cooking the meal for a family outing. The girls may plan and prepare a picnic supper for the back yard. They can set the table and arrange flowers for the centerpiece. If the outing is held in the canyon or park, the younger set can be given the "clean-up" assignment. Scouts, again, can use their "know-how" in seeing that the fire is completely out. Fortunate is the family that works and plays together. A family will be surprised at the enjoyable time that is to be had by spending a vacation at home. Many families fail to explore their own communities and the facilities available for recreation. 'They never visit places of interest that tourists travel miles to see. 'They do not realize that parks and museums are established for their interest and pleasure. There is a world of enjoyment and education to be had in such places. Backyard camping and cooking can be most exciting. A trip to the zoo affords a lot of fun. A bicycle or hiking trip can be exhilarating. Family picnics in the park, or nearby canyons can be real family outings. 'Tours of dairies, printing presses, and other industries can be revealing and educational in value, 424 THE great cry of parents is, "We don't have time." There is just so much time in the world. No one has more time than someone else. 'The difference is, some use it wisely, others waste it. Parents should take time to lay up a store of good family relationships. Such accomplishments will last for a lifetime. 'Time cannot take them away. In a recent issue of a weekly periodical a mother summarized her thoughts about time: My biggest mistake as a mother was a mistaken perspective of time. While our children were growing up, I was under the impression that the major part of my life was being lived while I had them with me. Looking back, I well understand what my beloved grandfather meant when he used to speak of "those few weeks we had the children with us." It is such a short, short time. I don't mean it seems brief; it is brief! For a birthday present a father once gave his son a piece of paper with the following written on it: "To my dear Son: I give you one hour of my time each day, to be yours, and to be used as you want to, without interference of any kind whatsoever. Your Father." Realizing that this father could make a very costly gift to his son, a friend asked, "How did you happen to hit upon the idea of giving such an extraordinary present?" RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 The man answered, "The other day a young fellow, whom I had not seen since he was a lad about my boy's age, came to my office to 'make a touch.' His face and bearing carried the tell-tale marks of idleness and dissipation. 'Robert!' I exclaimed in amazement, 'to see you like this — and you with such a fine father!' "The boy answered, 'Well, I've often heard Dad was a fine man. All his friends have told me so. I never knew him. He was so much occupied with his business, that I only saw him occasionally at mealtimes. I never really knew him,' "That made me think, and think furiously, and believe me, from now on I am going to see to it that my son has a chance to know me. This is the greatest gift a man can give, yet a gift every father owes to his son." Parents must realize how much of the mature years of their children will be spent in seeing the things memory preserves for them. They must guard the space in a child's memory storehouse, so they will have stored up a mighty collection of mental movies which will depict happy family associations. In Elder Mark E. Petersen's book, For Time or Eternity, he says, "It is our faith that the family is a basic unit in heaven. We should be saved as families." Family outings are some of the best tools to use in building family solidarity. Family solidarity built upon this earth will continue throughout eternity. Don Knight SWIFTCURRENT LAKE, GLACIER NATIONAL PARK MONTANA Nleantain Vigil Ethel Jacobson The last light pales on the loftiest rim Long after the valleys are veiled and dim, Then heaven bends in a starry arc Spreading a mantle of tranquil dark. The wind lies hushed in the silvery firs, On soundless wings the great ow] stirs As, in infinity's embrace, Poised constellations wheel in space. The spheres tread out their measured dance.... The stars give way. The sun's swift lance Touches the topmost peak anew At a moment preordained, on cue, Set long before the tremulous light Of dawn first quickened primordial night. Faith needs no sign for all reborning Beyond this miracle of morning. Page 425 The Danish Mission Preston R. Nibley A! The October Conference of the Church, held in Salt Lake City in 1849, Erastus Snow, thirty-one years of age, a member of the Council of the 'Twelve, was selected to open a mission for the Church "in the Scandinavian Countries." Elders Peter O. Hansen and John E. Forsgren were called to accompany him. Elder Hansen was a native of Denmark and had begun to translate The Book of Mormon into the Danish language before leaving America. When these brethren reached England, in April 1850, Elder Snow requested George P. Dykes, an elder laboring in that country, to join them, as he had some knowledge of the Norwegian language; the missionaries then continued their journey and arrived in Copenhagen, Denmark, on June 14, 1850. In delivering their message to the Danish people, they met with almost immediate success and, on August 12, 1850, less than two months after their arrival, Erastus Snow baptized fifteen converts "in the clear salt water of the Sound." A branch of the Church was organized in CopenBy Ewing Galloway, New York - NEW KING'S MARKET, COPENHAGEN, DENMARK Page 426 THE DANISH MISSION 427 Lind Studios Submitted by Mary G. Sorensen GEELS FOREST IN HOLTE, NEAR COPENHAGEN, DENMARK hagen on September 15, following. Other elders arrived in the mission and the work of proselyting was gradually extended to all parts of Denmark. Andrew Jenson, Assistant Church Historian and a native of Denmark, computed in 1930 that 26,656 of his countrymen had joined the Church since the introduction of the gospel in 1850, eighty years previously. During that time, also, he stated, 13,984 of these baptized had "emigrated to Zion." Denmark remained a part of the Scandinavian Mission until 1920, when a separate mission was formed with Elder Carl E. Petersen as the first president. In March 1956, there were 1,875 members in the Danish Mission, located in sixteen branches. Holger P. Peterson is the present president of the Danish Mission. Seventeen Relief Society organizations were reported in December 1955, with 359 members. Ora Irene H. Peterson presides over the Danish Mission Relief Society. A Note: The cover for this Magazine is a View of Ribe, Denmark, From the Domkirke. See also "Recipes From the Danish Mission," page 446. Pretty As a Pansy Frances C. Yost ANDA looked nervously at \\V the clock ticking away the minutes. "Here it is after one. If Vince doesn't come right away to eat, I'll miss Relief Society today." She gently moved the lace curtain at the window and peered down the street, hoping to see the familiar green pickup truck turn the corner. Since Vince had _ started in his own lumber business, it was hard for him to keep regular hours. Wanda didn't want to miss the meeting. She received so much joy and satisfaction and down-toearth education from Relief Society. She enjoyed working in the other organizations, too; but Relief Society was different. It was her meeting. A meeting where she could develop in a_ well-rounded way, as well as serving others. As Wanda watched at the window, the truck slowed up to the curb and Vince, almost running, came to the house. She hurried to the door to greet him. You couldn't be cross with someone who was late when he was working his heart out for you. She swung the door wide for him, and gave him her prettiest smile. "Welcome home, stranger." "Sorry I'm late, honey. Had a customer. Couldn't make it a minute sooner. But I'll eat and run so you can make it to your meeting." Vincent brushed her cheek with a swift kiss as he hurried to wash up. "That's okeh," Wanda replied. She had sort of given up the idea of getting to Relief Society, but in no time at all Vince was Page 428 grabbing his hat, brushing her cheek with a quick goodbye kiss, and gone. Wanda glanced at the clock, a quarter to two. She almost never left the dishes in the sink, but if she did today she could still make it to Relief Society. Untying her apron, and powdering her nose, Wanda whisked on her tweed sports coat and shut the door gently, leaving it unlatched for her girls when they would come from school. As she left her home, she glanced at the home of Granny Crockett who lived next door. Usually they walked to Relief Society meeting together, but Granny Crockett had probably seen Vince's truck, and gone ahead. But we can walk home together, Wanda thought. It was the literature lesson today, given well by Sister Bates. Imagine writing nine hundred poems and fourteen novels as Thomas Hardy did, the ladies sighed! Only too soon, the meeting was over, and the sisters exchanged greetings and well wishes. Wanda Mason and Granny Crockett slowly walked the short distance to their homes together. "You can tell from his poems Thomas Hardy was a man of the soil," Granny remarked. "Such a_ well-rounded _ person, Thomas Hardy was. Imagine, even as a boy, he went around to parties and weddings playing his violin," Wanda reminisced. Then she fell to thinking how Relief Society tipped the scales of PRETTY AS A PANSY values in her life, helping her to shape her outlook and define her goals. She was so engrossed in thoughts of the lesson that she did not remember the dishes in the sink, until she stepped on the porch. Marie and Connie would probably be doing up the dishes right this minute to surprise her. Wanda prepared herself to act really surprised, and lavish them with her praise. But, as she opened the door, the odor of burning meat surrounded her. The girls must be cooking hamburgers. No, it was the expensive ground round steak with which she had planned to make a special new dish. Anger made Wanda rigid at the sight of the very small amount of ground round steak which was left. ER lovely kitchen was a chaos of confusion! A _ greasy griddle, burned almost black, was on the cupboard, and the lovely copperbottom skillet was filled with hamburgers and onions. Wanda glanced through the rooms to see the girls' school clothes draped on the beds, the living room strewn with crumbs, while the television blasted away at high volume. The house Wanda had spent all morning cleaning was in utter disorder. Suddenly Wanda was scolding as rain pours down in cascades. Connie and Marie stood by with startled consternation on their faces. Wanda, realizing she had been too hasty, went to her room and shut the door quickly behind her. Shame at her outburst and discouragement seemed to engulf her. She was disappointed, too. Would the girls never learn? Would they never start to take hold, to keep the house 429 in shape, to think before using up household stores? ~Wanda J said nothing when the children took choice things like nuts, cherries, and olives, but now when they were using the dinner meat for afterschool snacks, that was the last straw. "All morning I've worked in the house and for what?" she asked herself aloud. "I would have been ahead if I had forgotten the house entirely and planted the pansies that are waiting." Wanda put on her gardening things, tied a scarf on her hair, and walked through the house, looking neither to the right nor to the left. On the porch she picked up the pansy plants she had purchased yesterday at the greenhouse and, with the planter fork, left the house, slamming the door almost childishly behind her. As Wanda's hands worked in the tich black soil, she thought again of the poet Thomas Hardy, and the common rural people of whom he wrote. Gradually her mind seemed to grope its way from a soundless sort of fog. RANNY Crockett, next door, sat crocheting on her warm sun porch. She had sat down to rest after the walk from Relief Society. As her hands moved, her mind dwelt on the lesson at Relief Society. She recalled a line from one of Thomas Hardy's poems: "This is the weather the cuckoo likes, and so do I." Suddenly from next door she heard Wanda's voice raised in scolding. "Why land sakes, pretty Wanda Mason went into that house not more than five minutes ago. Won- 430 der what mischief she found her girls into?" Granny said softly. "Harsh words are molded on children's memories forever." Her mind went back to a day, when, as a little child, her mother in heated wrath had called her a lozy dolt. Granny's head, with its hair pinned neatly into a round flat knot at the crown of her neck, shook as if to erase the memory. It was only when she looked up from her crocheting that she noticed Wanda Mason in her garden, setting out pansy plants. Granny laid down her crochet work and, out of the corner of her eye, saw Wanda Mason wipe her eyes with the sleeve of her shirt, as she knelt in the flower bed. Suddenly Granny Crockett remembered the water cress a neighbor had brought her from his last fishing trip. Wrapping a generous portion of the cress in wax paper and going out the back door, she meandered over to where Wanda Mason was setting out her pansies. It wasn't until Granny Crockett was right to Wanda that she noticed the tears falling from her eyes, moistening the soil where she was working. Words seemed inadequate. Instead, Granny Crockett placed her hand gently on Wanda's shoulder. Wanda looked up startled, but, at sight of Granny Crockett, the flood locks broke, and a new flow of tears rushed forth. "There, there, child," Granny Crockett comforted. "I suppose you heard me raise my voice to the children. I'm so dreadfully ashamed. But, oh, Granny, I try so hard to make a real home.. A clean home, and I skimp and go without to plan and prepare nice RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 meals, and the children...." Wanda told Granny everything, how she had found the house, and about the dinner meat used for after-school hamburgers. "Tt is discouraging," Granny Crockett admitted.. "And yet I'd give a lot, if my children were close enough to raid my pantry. I've lived to see three generations, and they all do it sometime or another, and they all seem to come through that growing hungry stage like a blueribbon heifer. I brought you over some water cress." "Why, how nice. You know how we love it in the spring. Thanks so much," Wanda said. "You have chosen a nice assortment of pansy plants,' Granny Crockett said, looking at the plants Wanda was planting. ANDA was pleased. Granny Crockett had a "green thumb," and Wanda appreciated any floral compliment Grann gave her. "I do hope they grow." "They'll grow," Granny Crockett nodded knowingly, "just like those two lovely girls of yours are growing." Wanda, who had placed the last plant in its little moistened crevice and anchored it firmly with black rich soil, shifted herself from her knees to her feet and stood surveying the plants. "Those blooms should be picked, to strengthen the roots. I'll let the girls do that for the table decoration for our supper table." Wanda realized that in her planting, she had also planted every bit of her wrath. "T want you to come and see my pansy bed now, Sister Wanda. Pansies are such choice little flowers. PRETTY AS A PANSY Why, they're almost human when you look straight in their faces. Come." She took Wanda's arm firmly. Together, they walked through the arbor that divided the Mason and the Crockett lawns, and which would be covered with climbing roses in June. "See those tiny pansies peeping through?" Granny Crockett asked. "Once I spaded up a bed because I saw a weed or two. But in doing it, I uprooted the tiny pansies just pushing through. Life's like that. Sometimes we uproot our homes and children to get rid of a weed or two of wrong, that would wither later, on their own. What children really need more than spading, is warm, loving sunshine... The sunshine of a mother's loving smile. A smile that is as dependable as the sun's rays." Wanda realized, with a pang of consternation, that her children had seen her face torn with anger. No wonder they had looked so startled. She secretly vowed to try to keep it from happening again. Lilac dusk was creeping upon them, but Wanda's mind had already taken up its routine. She could make spaghetti and meat balls for supper. 'The family enjoyed the dishes they were used to more than something new and fancy, anyway. 431 And the water cress gift from Granny Crockett would make a lovely cress and hard-boiled egg salad, which would be a treat for Vince and the girls on a spring evening. And she would pull out a cherry pie from the deep freeze, as a sort of celebration of her burying the hatchet, so to speak. "T must hurry,' Wanda said. Her face smiled like the big white pansies which Granny Crockett knew would later bloom in her garden. "And thanks... Thanks for everything!" Wanda added. When she walked into her home, it seemed her own little world had righted itself. The school clothes were put away, the coats hung neatly in the hall, and Marie and Connie were doing the dishes. "We were going to surprise you," they chorused when caught in the act. "What a happy surprise!'" Wanda smiled a pretty violet-eyed pansy smile... Granny Crockett walked through the garden and over the smooth green lawn which sloped to the lily pond. <A bluebird came flashing out of nowhere, and stopped short on seeing her so closely, then flitted away among the peonies beside the garden fence. Granny smiled, all was calm and smooth again. The pansy faces all were smiling faces. Her Hands Luella N. Adams Not shapely white, those precious hands— Deep lined, with labor etched, They helped to build an empire, Those hands that rested not. Kind hands that eased our childish pain We know that we will clasp again. Old Slucson Willard Luce LD Tucson isn't nearly as old as it sounds—or looks. Its crumbling adobe walls seem to have weathered centuries of desert wind and rain. Its warped lumber seems to have been burned brown by the desert sun and sucked dry of all moisture. Its hitchracks appear to have tethered a thousand horses. But all this is make-believe. Old Tucson was born in 1940, created by Hollywood for the movie "Arizona." Built in the Tucson Mountains a few miles west of Tucson, Arizona, the set was constructed to represent the old Spanish settlement of Tucson during our Civil War days. When the film was finished, the movie company moved out and the Junior Chamber of Commerce moved in. They kept the set repaired as a show place for tourists and as a location for their annual 'Tucson Daze celebration held each autumn. Since Tucson is a square dancing center with a dozen or more clubs meeting regularly, the J. C.'s inaugurated square dancing at Old Tucson. These weekly get-togethers are well attended by visitors and natives alike.. Since 1940, the movie companies have moved back to Old Tucson on several occasions. In 1954 they came back for the Cinemascope production of Greer Garson's "Strange Lady in Town." 'They completely remodeled Old Tucson. They covered some of the adobe Page 432 walls with boards. They added second stories to some of the buildings. They built hotels, livery stables, saloons, and a dozen other establishments until you just wouldn't know the old town. And that is quite as it should be since the setting for this new, full-color film was Santa Fe, New Mexico, 7.9) just before the "Gay go's. Most of these buildings are complete — not just walls and false fronts. They are colorful, authentic, and a tourist attracter of the first magnitude. 'Today, however, Wards Saloon dispenses soft drinks, postcards, and other tourist subplies. 'There are other business houses which open and do a landoffice business during "Tucson Daze" and the height of the tourist season. It is said that the set will soon be reconverted back to the original "Old Tucson." Set on a valley floor in the Tucson Mountain Park, the make-believe town is surrounded by giant saguaro cactus. On the east and south the rugged mountain peaks hover over it. There are picnicking areas in the Tucson Mountain Park, and there is the 'Trailside Museum. 'This museum features live exhibits of the fauna and flora of the ArizonaSonora desert. The larger animals include the peccary — or wild hog — mountain lion, wildcat, ocelot, etc. The small animal room in- OLD TUCSON Willard Luce 433 PO te. MOVIE SET OF "OLD TUCSON," TUCSON MOUNTAIN PARK ARIZONA cludes live species of centipedes, scorpions, lizards, rodents, and snakes. 'Trails lead through the botanical gardens where the plants are well labeled. Desert water holes have been so placed as to give the visitor an opportunity to study the desert wild life at first hand. So, even if Old Tucson isn't as old as it sounds, it's an interesting place to visit, especially if you take in the rest of Tucson Mountain Park. > Va cation Grace Barker Wilson The shades are drawn, the doors are closed, And all about an empty look Proclaims a solitary house That somebody forsook. Mrs. Stowe, the daughter of Lyman Beecher, was born at Litchfield, Conn., June 15, 1811. At an early age she manifested a great eagerness for books.... On January 5, 1836, she married Rev. Calvin Stowe, D. D., professor of Biblical History in Lane Seminary, over which her father presided. During Mrs. Stowe's intervals of leisure amidst family cares, she contributed to the periodicals, sketches and short stories.... In 1852... She contributed to the National Era, an anti-slavery paper published at Washington, "Uncle Tom's Cabin" as a serial.... It met with unequaled success, 313,000 copies (in book form) were sold in the United States within three years and a half, and in all, over a million copies, including a German edition prepared there. In Great Britain its sale was enormous. It was translated into twenty different languages... And it was dramatized in various forms.... —Boston Transcript Page 440 OUR "Woman's Sphere" editor is sightseeing and visiting with members of her family in Europe and was privileged to attend the unusually inspirational Latter-day Saints Servicemen's Conference at the Army's Religious Retreat in Berchtesgaden. Minerva Young Bennion, wife of Elder Adam S. Bennion, touched the hearts of the servicemen with her appeal from mothers to these youths. The wives of the West German, French, and Netherlands Mission _ presidents: Bernice O. Dyer, Rachael L. Lee, and Ada S. VanDam gave beautiful talks. The same is true of Sister Bringhurst, whose husband is president of the Bern Temple. E learned how Dutch people are of their Queen Juliana. They love her thrift, her democracy, her schedule of hard work, her excellent and wise motherhood. Besides this, she is "a clever woman." She went all through the University of Leyden with no special privileges or help from anyone. Since the high schools in Holland have eight-year courses, the University work is on a more advanced level, and one is twenty-five (if smart like Juliana) or, ordinarily, twenty-six at graduation time. Proud the Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon ELLE S. SPAFFORD, General President of Relief Society, was awarded an honorary degree, Doctor of Humanities, at the commencement exercises at Brigham Young University, June 1, 1956. In addition to her devoted and _ distinguished service to Relief Society, President Spafford has participated in many other social welfare and humanitarian activities. She became vice-chairman of the Crusade for Freedom in 1952; she has been a vice-president of the National Council of Women since 1948, and attended the meetings of the International Council of Women in Helsinki, Finland, in 1954, as head of the American delegation of the National Council of Women of the United States. She is a director of the American Mothers' Committee. President Spaftord has already received a citation from Brigham Young University as a distinguished alumnus. Page 44] Q—> EDITORIAL ~9 VOL. 43 JULY 1956 NO. 7 Fro ntters T has been said that frontiers are now but half-forgotten realms in the world of history, that their eager, spiritual beckoning, their call to adventure and far places, their promise and their fulfillment will never be known to another generation. It is true that the geographical aspects of the world are fairly well known, having been viewed from the skies, and having been explored even to the lonely outposts by the brave and the venturesome. Nearly all the habitable regions are occupied, and, although some areas are still in various phases of the pioneering stage, still the noontide of seeking the unknown frontier is past. Today we are not privileged to experience the sacrifice, the wonder, and the rejoicing of the quest of a far frontier. 'The wagons are gone, the trails but faintly marked upon the prairie; the mountain peaks are named and mapped, the course of the rivers long discovered. We may feel that in our generation we have lost something of that fearless facing of the future, that undeviating purpose, that great fulfillment that led the vanguard westward. And turned the desert into gardens. Still we need never be without the heritage of the frontier. It is our great legacy from the past to be for us a source of courage and buoyant inspiration, for, though the geographical frontiers have vanished, Page 442 the frontiers of the future forever remain — the undiscovered realms of mind and spirit — individual development and group accomplishment. Along these pathways, there are still mountains to climb and wide and verdant valleys to be cultivated. Much of life is like an ever-beckoning frontier. 'Take the morning, for instance — dawn is forever a frontier, the light of day on a far peak, the joy of waking with the golden hours unfolding. No one knows in the morning what treasures of enlightenment and understanding a day may bring. Its hours are all to be discovered — "if I take the wings of the morning...." A new type of work is a frontier, or a new way of doing a familiar responsibility. A homemaker walks each day in a frontier land, for almost every hour brings some new adventure on the trail of time.. It may be only the planting of the garden, the glory of first bloom, the ripe fruit on a tree. It may be an adventure into designing or home decorating, or perhaps the making of a gift or the planning of a birthday dinner — or something more prosaic. Perfection may be in small units, and often a valley view of life may exceed in contentment the expanse that some far height reveals. How privileged is the woman who sees her children and her grandchildren embark on the frontiers of life. The mysterious world lies all around EDITORIAL the infant — to be explored — the texture of a petal, the satin lining of a quilt, the windowpane — and then all the further. Knowledge breaking upon his consciousness. Wonderful is the frontier of childhood and privileged those who may share and influence that journey which reaches through family patterns into the far eternity. Each picture first seen, all the music heard and learned, are pathways of satisfaction where, in the mind and spirit, one may feel the joy of discovery. Who has fully discovered the treasures along scriptural highways? Each reading and re-reading may become a frontier of spiritual heights. Recall the Proverb, speaking of wisdom: The Lord possessed me in the beginning of his way, before his works of old. I was set up from everlasting, from the beginning.... When there were no depths, I was brought forth; when there were no fountains abounding with water. 443 fields, nor the highest part of the dust of the world (Proverbs 8:22-26). For us in the Church, our own Relief Society, established when Nauvoo the Beautiful was a frontier city, for us the world-wide sisterhood offers a broad and shining pathway into new interests and accomplishments, a journeying into regions of the mind and spirit not known before. For all of us there are illuminating and satisfying experiences in every meeting, every activity — new friends, new thoughts, new knowledge, further enlightenment, and the ever-increasing unity of the sisterhood. Once a poet in reverie asked, "What canst thou find with seeking which hath not long been found?" There is much to be found with seeking which we have not yet experienced, and the place to find our beckoning horizons is still along the far and near frontiers. We still shall find "the heaven for height, and the hills was I brought forth. Notes TO THE FIELD Buying Sexthooks for Relicf Society Lessons ROM inquiries which come to the general board it would seem that some Relief Society officers and class leaders are not acquainted with the recommended procedure for acquiring necessary textbooks for lessons. The education counselor in both the stake and ward should present to the president of the respective organizations, a list of the textbooks which will be needed to teach the Relief Society lessons during the coming season. She should then be authorized to purchase these books with funds from the Relief Society general fund. The education counselors should see that the name of the Relief Society organization is written in each book before giving it to the respective stake or ward class leader for her use. At the end of the course the education counselor is responsible for collecting the books and placing them in the Relief Society library. Where a teacher wishes to purchase her own textbook in order to be able to mark it and keep it after the conclusion of the course, it is recommended that the Relief Society organization should also purchase a textbook: 1. In order that the book may become a part of the Relief Society library; 2. To be available for use by those given special assignments; 3. Because a change of teachers might be necessary during the course, and at that time it might be impossible for the Relief Society organization to purchase a copy of the desired textbook. Education counselors are urged to safeguard Relief Society libraries and to be alert to opportunities of adding to them gifts of Church and other worthwhile books. _> Yea rs Mabel Jones Gabbott Years are but soundless shells beside life's sea, When filled with only days and days, Yet each returns a muted symphony, When crowned with kindly gracious ways. Page 444 Lily Nl Hortnagl Makes Handicraft Gifts for Many Occasions | ee Norton Scott Hortnagl of Long Beach, California, has done many kinds of work, but the "odd" minutes she has spent on her handicraft hobbies have netted her a rich reward and have given happiness to hundreds of her relatives and friends. She has made sixteen star quilts, and each of her children received a star quilt as a wedding gift. She has crocheted many doilies, pot holders, tablecloths, lace for many pillowslips, and hundreds of other items. She has made baskets from greeting cards, has painted tea towels, and has done both hand and machine sewing of all kinds. Her work has won awards at fairs on different occasions, and two years ago she won a first prize for making a man's shirt, which was exhibited at the Arizona State Fair in Phoenix. Mrs. Hortnagl was born in Colonia Dublan, Mexico, and was married to Charles B. Scott in 1910. In 1927 she was left a widow with six children. In Pomerene, Arizona, she served nine years as postmistress, and, supplementing this occupation with janitorial work at night, she made a living for her family. With the help of her thirteen-year-old son, she built a house, using second-hand brick, rocks from the hills, and sand from the creek. She mixed the concrete with a hand mixer. When she was ready for the roof, all the men from the town helped put up the gable ends ready to be shingled. While Mrs. Hortnagl was tacking on the shingles, the Relief Society visiting teachers came. '""Don't come down," they called, "we will give you our message and you can hear from where you are. The message is: 'Beautify Your Homes.' You are setting an example." In 1932 she was married to Lorenz Hortnagl and moved to California. She filled two stake missions and, in 1950, accompanied her husband to Switzerland for a twoyear mission. She has been a visiting teacher since 1910, and for thirteen years she made a one-hundred per cent record without a break. She has twenty-three grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. She has compiled a beautiful "Book of Remembrance' and loves to write. Mrs. Hortnagl says that she hopes she will never be "laid on the shelf." Page 445 Recipes From the Danish Mission Submitted by Mary Kaiser FRIKADELLER (Danish Meat Balls) Y, Ib. Veal 1 grated onion % |b. Pork 2 tbsp. Flour or 1 c. Bread crumbs 2 c. Milk salt and pepper to taste 1 egg Put veal and pork together through a grinder four or five times. Add flour or bread crumbs, milk, egg, onion, salt, and pepper. Mix thoroughly. Drop in frying pan from a large tablespoon and fry over a low flame. Serve with browned butter, potatoes, and stewed cabbage. Ropcrop MED FLODE (Fruit Pudding With Cream) 1% lbs. Red currants % c. Potato flour (or cornstarch) 128 Ibs. Raspberries vanilla 8 c. Water blanched almonds sweeten to taste The foreigner who visits Denmark remembers this dessert mainly because of its Danish name (Rodgrod med Flode) which is almost impossible for him to pronounce. His Danish friends are always greatly amused by his efforts to say it right. It is a popular dish on a hot summer day. Wash the currants and raspberries, add water, and boil. When all the juice has boiled out, remove the berries from the fire, force through a fine sieve or a cloth, and put the juice back into the pot. Sweeten to taste, and thicken with the potato flour or cornstarch, using 4 c. Thickening to every 4 c. Of juice. If potato flour is used, be sure to have juice boiling hot when it is added, and take the juice off the stove while adding the flour. If potato flour boils, the juice will be "long"—a sure sign of a bad cook in Denmark! Add the vanilla. While still hot pour into a glass bowl. When it begins to stiffen, decorate the surface with a pattern of blanched almonds. Serve with sugar and cream. SMORREBROD (Open Sandwiches) There is no doubt that Denmark's open sandwiches (Smorrebrod) are the most famous feature of the Danish kitchen. Strangely enough, they are not found elsewhere, even in neighboring countries. Danish sandwiches have hundreds of variations, and new ones are constantly being composed. From the simple, "flat," four sandwiches that office workers take with them to work and eat at their desks, accompanied by a bottle of milk, they range to the gloriously colored "high" compositions, so generous that three are enough for a meal, eaten at restaurants. In Denmark, we usually make sandwiches with dark rye bread. The bread should be made with the whole grain and should be as firm as possible, so that the slices can be quite thin. Also, white bread can be used, but it should be of heavy texture and may be toasted. Fish is usually the starter, and from there one goes to the meat and salad. Almost inevitably Danes wind up the "Smorrebrod" meal with a piece of buttered white bread on which a good cheese has been placed. Recipes for some typical Danish sandwiches follow: Page 446 RECIPES FROM THE DANISH MISSION 447 AEG 0G SILD (Eggs and Herrings) Spread slices of hard boiled egg on buttered bread and place one or more boned herrings lengthwise on the egg. Decorate with cress. REJEMAD (Shrimp Sandwich) The small Danish shrimps are extremely popular delicacies, and most Danish housewives are virtual masters at peeling them, but it is slow work for the beginner. At restaurants, shrimps are always served peeled, unless the customer specifically asks for unpeeled ones. Put a fresh leaf of lettuce on the buttered bread and top abundantly with cold boiled shrimps. DyrLaEcens NATMAD ("The Veterinarian's Midnight Snack'') Spread spiced lard on a piece of dark rye bread, and put slices of liver paste on top. Pieces of jellied consomme are placed over this, and on top, pieces of slightly salted boiled veal. Decorate with cress. RogueErortT Ost MED AEGGEBLOMME (Blue Cheese and Egg Yolk) Butter a piece of white bread and spread Danish blue cheese — or gorgonzola — in a ring, making a hollow in the center. When eating the sandwich, break the raw egg yolk and spread it across the cheese. Thin slices of radish may be used to decorate this and other kinds of cheese sandwiches. Cooking apples jelly 1 c. Melted butter whipped cream sweeten to taste vanilla dried bread crumbs Peel, core, and quarter apples. Simmer, covered in a little water, until soft. KRINGLE (Knot-shaped Cake) 300 grams flour 2 eggs 300 grams butter or margarine 60 grams dry yeast 200 grams sugar egg and sugar for coating Mix flour with margarine or butter. Stir yeast with a little sugar and put it in the flour together with eggs. Roll the dough at once in two bars. Stir butter with sugar and place it on the bars. Form the bars as a knot, place them in the pan, and let them rise from three to four hours. Coat with egg and sugar. Bake in a hot oven (375°) for about 20 minutes. Note: About 28% grams equal an ounce in avoirdupois weight. For purposes of cooking measurements, it would be reliable to figure about 28 grams to an ounce. C1TRON-FROMAGE (Lemon Sponge Cream) 5 eggs 5 sheets husblas (unsweetened gelatine 100 grams sugar equal to one envelope) juice and grated peel of 1 lemon Whip egg yolks and sugar light and foamy. Add lemon juice and grated peel. Stir soaked, melted, and warmed gelatine in the eggs. Place in a cool place. When it thickens, mix carefully the stiff whipped egg whites in it. Pour into a bowl and set in a cool place until it is completely stiff. Decorate wth whipped cream. Note: If the sponge cream parts into two layers, the yolks and the whites have been mixed too early. Heart's Bounty CHAPTER 2 Deone R. Sutherland Synopsis: Fourteen-year-old Annie Griffith is taken by her father to Salt Lake City at the invitation of the Willams family to live and be educated with their daughter Marie. Annie's family is temporarily living in the mountaims while Brother Griffith serves a mission to cut stone for the temple. Annie, almost in tears, bids goodbye to her father, and is comforted by Parker Josephson, a neighbor and friend of the Williams family. HE days turned into a pattern for Annie Griffith, and she was able to get over the first pangs of homesickness that she had felt. She longed for word of her family, and letters did come whenever anyone from the camp came to the town. She applied herself to her lessons and grew quite proud of the ease with which she sailed through her first Latin grammar. She would be reading Julius Caesar in no time, Professor Peterson said. But her heart sank as the days got crisper, and it was obvious that her father wasn't going to be able to make another trip down until spring. She hadn't really expected him, but the thought that he might, had comforted her at night those first sad days. Annie and Marie ran around the top of the carriage house spreading white sheets to dry fruit on. The apricots and corn were all long safe in the cellar, and the season for preparing for the winter, nearly over. Parker Josephson came out of his house and waved at the girls. He was with his father, and they were on their way back to the Josephson store. Both girls nearly tumbled off the roof trying to wave back. Marie called out, but her Aunt Agnes reproved her _ sharply. "They're on their way back to Brother Josephson's store; you can't delay them for foolish play. Besides, Parker has a great many things to do these last few days, and you girls must leave him alone, so he can get ready without being interrupted by your games and jokes." Marie stood up with her arms akimbo. "Aunt Agnes, what's he getting ready for?" "Now, I have let the cat out of the bag, and we'll never finish our work. It's time for your lessons in less than an hour, and we've too much to do to waste it gabbing." Aunt Agnes set her lips firmly, and Annie and Marie began to work again. Mare broke the silence once, but her Aunt Agnes again stopped her short. It wasn't until they raced back into the house for lesson time, that Marie rushed to her mother with their questions. "Why, girls, Marie dear, Parkers going back East to a university, a college. He's going to prepare himself in mathematics and the sciences so he can come home some day, and help make our own university a place to be proud of. I thought perhaps he might have told you already, Marie, but I suppose he was trying to save your feelings a few more happy days. He has been Page 449 450 such a good playmate for a little girl who had no sisters or brothers of her own. But now you have Annie." "T want Parker," Marie cried, and she burst into tears. "How long will he be gone?" Annie asked. Sister Williams stroked Marie's hair. "About three years, they say. Don't cry, Marie. He'll come back. You have other friends who love you, Marie." Marie looked up. "We can make him a present to take. Oh, Annie, let's make him something special. Only you'll have to do the sewing, because I'm such a dunce at sewing." Aunt Agnes stood in the doorway. "You're a little dunce, because you never finish anything you start. But [ll help you cut out and sew Parker a shirt, if you promise to stay with the project until it's completed." "T will, I will.' Marie danced with joy. "That's a real present he'll love, won't he, Annie?" "Yes, if we can make it nicely enough. I've helped with my brother's shirts at home, but Mama always made Daddy's shirts." "T won't let you make any mistakes." Aunt Agnes smiled at Annie's earnest concern. "You'll be able to handle everything very well, I'm sure." HE week before Parker was to leave, Brother and Sister Williams had a small dinner for him in their home. There had been a dance held especially in his honor at the Church amusement hall, but the girls had had to come home early. Parker had been very fair; he had RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 danced with friends his own age, but had included one dance each for Marie and Annie. Aunt Agnes had thought they were much too young for that sort of thing. The girls had lain in bed and _ talked about the dance after Marie had finally stopped grumbling about having to come home so early. "It won't be the same without Parker,' Marie lamented, turning over and resting her cheek snugly in her pillow. "No," said Annie, "it won't be the same." "Tm glad he's coming to our place last of all before he's to go. Mama and Papa have been friends with his parents before I was even born. Do you think he'll ever come back?" "Of course," said Annie who was lying on her back looking up toward the dark ceiling. "Then [I'm going to wait and marry him then," said Marie yawning. In a moment she was sound asleep, and, finally, Annie turned over and slept also. Sister Williams used her best china, the china Brother Williams had brought all the way from New York, for the special Parker dinner, as they called it. The girls flew back and forth working all day to help get the house shining and the dinner ready. 'There were no lessons that day, which made Marie jump for joy. The shirt was finished and pressed neatly and tied up in a package ready for Parker. "I'll be the one to give it to him," Marie said happily. "Annie should be the one," said Aunt Agnes, "since she did almost HEART'S BOUNTY all the work. You'll never be much of a sewer, I'm afraid, Marie." Sister Williams was brushing Marie's ringlets. "You're so hard on her, Agnes. Marie can give the shirt for both of them. Annie will be right there. He'll know they both did their best." "You'll let me, won't you, Annie?" Marie pleaded. "Of course, it doesn't matter who gives it to him." "You see!" phantly. "Do hold still," her mother pleaded. "We don't have much time to finish dressing, and you're taking all the time with your hair. Look, Annie's ready to go down and help again in the kitchen." Annie had braided her heavy black hair so tightly it pulled at her scalp. Her face was scrubbed until it shone, and the dark blue of her dress matched her eyes exactly. She followed Aunt Agnes back down the long dark stairs to the kitchen and pantry, where the main preparations for the meal were in progTess. Steam covered all the downstairs windows, and it was unbearably warm in the kitchen. 'They dared not open the outside door, because both Sister Williams and Marie were prone to lung congestion. There were beads of perspiration on Annie's brow before it was finally time to serve dinner. Brother and Sister Josephson and two other families had come to the dinner. Though the girls helped with the serving, they also ate at the large, round dinner table. Annie thought she had never tasted such delicious roast beef and Yorkshire pudding. There were so many things to learn, Marie said _ trium- 451 thought Annie. They had not been able to have many elaborate dinners in the mountains. But there were not many years left, and they would all be back together on her father's farm. She would know a great deal by then, she thought. HEY saved the presents until after dinner. 'The families gathered in the parlor for singing, and then came the moment the gitls had decided upon to present Parker with his shirt. Marie's eyes sparkled as she laid it in his lap. He untied it and declared that it was the nicest shirt he'd ever owned. Then he kissed Marie on the top of her head for a thank you, but Annie ran and hid in the kitchen when he came over to thank her, which made everyone laugh. They sang "Auld Lang Syne" and "God Be With You," and then Brother Williams said the evening prayers, with everyone kneeling against the chairs and_ loveseat. Everyone hated to say goodbye to Parker. He was such a lot of fun, and he was very industrious, everyone said. But he would be able to better serve his Church and _people with further education, and he did have a good mind. At dawn the next morning, Marie and Annie ran and hid behind the hlac bushes to watch Parker leave with his father in the buggy. The girls had agreed to say nothing, simply to hide there and watch him leave, but at the last minute, Marie had danced out into the path calling, "Goodbye, Parker, goodbye." He ran over, then, and ordered Marie back into the house before she caught her death of cold. 452 "Goodbye, little Marie," he said. "Goodbye, Annie. Why did you run and hide last might when I wanted to say goodbye?" "T don't know," Annie said, and tried to drop behind Marie. "Here, then," Parker said. "We'll shake hands before I go, anyway." Annie offered her hand while Marie hopped up and down and cried, "You will write to us, won't you, Parker?" "T surely will, if youll answer my letters. Now run back into the house both of you, or Marie's mother will never forgive me. Go on, while I watch. And no sniffling, Marie." Annie turned to follow Marie, but Parker caught her arm again. "Annie, will you still be here when I get back?" "T think so," Annie said without looking at him. "I guess you'll be all grown up then, but I hope you'll be here or not too far away, anyway." Annie tried to draw away, and this time he let her go, but he didn't turn until the big door had closed on both the girls. T was hard for Marie and Annie to concentrate on their lessons. In a few days, though, they felt less as if they had lost their only friend, and began to play again and consider that there would be a time when Parker would be coming back. By spring Annie was well into Julius Caesar and able to read it very well. Professor Peterson had nothing but praise for the results of her serious efforts. Marie would bend her golden head over her RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 book, stumbling on the phrases until her face would grow scarlet. Annie yearned to whisper the answers, but she was far too afraid of the wrath of their teacher. The lessons sometimes ended with Marie in a fit of tears, but, more often, Marie was indifferent. "T never want to be a teacher," she would say petulantly, when her teacher would question her why she was not better prepared. "I'm going to get married." "Do you not think you need to know anything to get married?" Professor Peterson's face would get angry. When Marie's mother sat in the room with them, the lessons went more peacefully. Often two other gitls joined them for special lessons. It was more fun in a larger group, Annie thought, and Marie did better when she wasn't really pinned down to be specific in her answers. In the spring, the girls were told that this year would finish any mathematics they were to have. Marie was delighted, but Annie stayed to talk to Professor Peterson after their lessons. "T feel I know nothing about mathematics," she explained. "I would like you to help me go on in that study next fall. I can't stop now before I've really learned anything." Professor Peterson put his finger beside his nose. "You may continue those lessons. Most certainly." He did not say it, but Annie with her quick mind was a continual delight to him. And now this. Yes, she would make a fine teacher. "The glory of God is intelligence." HEART'S BOUNTY AFTER the snow melted and the earth dried for summer, Annie began to look forward to seeing her father again. She half expected someone to bring a letter letting her know when he might be coming into Salt Lake. One afternoon after she had finished scrubbing the kitchen, the pantry, the porch, and the stairs that led down to the board walk in back of the house, she looked up to see Aunt Agnes (as she now called Marie's Aunt) beckoning her from the window. There was a stitch in her back when she stood up, and she hadn't washed her hands yet, but she went right back up the stairs. She rinsed her hands in the kitchen and Aunt Agnes came to the doorway in some agitation. "Annie, dear, do hurry. There's news of your father in the parlor." Annie never bothered to dry her hands at all. A letter? Here? She ran down the hall toward the front of the house, seeking Sister Williams who must have the letter. "No, not a letter,' Aunt Agnes called, but Annie dashed into the parlor and almost stumbled over her father sitting quietly talking to Sister Williams. He caught her in his arms and kissed her soundly and made her sit down. "Oh, Father," Annie cried, "I was going to impress you so with my lady-like behavior when you came, and now I've spoiled everything." "You did come in a bit swiftly," her father laughed. "But Sister Williams has told me enough to make me very happy and proud of you, Annie." Annie's eyes thanked Sister Williams. It was wonderful to visit 453 with her father again, and get news of her mother and her brothers. They talked of how quickly the year had gone by, and how quickly the next three years would pass, and then they would be back together again at their own farm, north of Great Salt Lake City. Annie would be able to teach somewhere close by, or perhaps stay at home and help her mother. Annie thought that would be wonderful. It was sad to see her father go again in two days, but Annie didn't need anyone this time to help her through the parting, as Parker had helped her the year before. She cried a little in her pillow at night, but woke with a happy heart and a zest for all the things she and Marie were required to do each day. She read the Aeneid the next winter, and began Greek. She had always been excellent in spelling and reading and was doing well, Professor Peterson thought, in her mathematics—for a girl. "You could make a first-rate scholar,' Professor Peterson told her once. "But Marie, you're dawdling all your time and talent away." Marie never heard. She daydreamed, with her curls caught between her pretty hands. "Annie, which trim shall I have on my new dress, the pink lace or the brown?" Professor Peterson stood up in exasperation, and the lessons were over for another day. Annie worked all summer over presents to send to her family. She knitted a warm woolen petticoat and shawl for her mother, and made shirts and socks for her broth- 454 ers and father. Sometimes she was desperate because she felt she might never finish them before the last wagon went up to the little camp in the mountains. There was little time when she was not working or studying or accompanying Marie somewhere. But she did get her bundle completed and firmly packed and sent off with Brother Harris who had his small family up in the mountains, too. Annie felt dull and just a little sad, with her sewing finished and no new project immediately in sight. 'The days were getting cold and sharp when Marie and Annie received their first letter from Parker Josephson. Marie squealed with delight. "Tsn't he kind and thoughtful to include both our names on the letter, Annie? Isn't he wonderful?" He told of the big Eastern university and the pretty countryside, and how much more foliage there was back there than at home. He said he missed everyone very much, but especially the jokes and fun of RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 his two little friends. There was also a long letter to Marie's parents and, of course, mail for his own family and other friends his own age. "We must write him back at once," Marie said. "You can help me with a letter, Annie. Help me think of things to say...." "And how to spell the words?" asked Aunt Agnes briskly. "Yes," laughed Marie. "I'll write the letter. What do you want me to tell Parker for you, Annie?" Aunt Agnes bit a thread with her teeth. 'Marie, maybe Annie wants to write her own letter." "No, that's all right," Annie said, not looking up from her crocheting. "Marie can tell him hello for me." Marie danced off to get the materials for writing from her mother. Annie pressed her lips together firmly and blinked back the sting against her eyelids. It was foolish to be so sensitive. She would have to learn to be less so. Ce Sew a Sunbonnet Marijane Morris iy the women of America were ever to need a common symbol — it could be the sunbonnet. The broad-brimmed bonnets, in some form or another, were always present whenever something really important happened to America. Curiously, however, little information is available on them as a type of headdress. And yet, they have endured through the years and are still a favorite of many women. Those who make and wear sunbonnets today may not do as grandmother did, match them to their dresses, but you can be sure they know their value in warding off the sun's rays and frustrating the insects. Surely, the sunbonnet has earned more than mention in a dictionary. The pattern here is a basic one consisting of five pieces: the brim, the back, the three-fourths inch deep strip sewed to the underside back to be used to gather up the cape, and the two ties. It requires one-half yard of any kind of light-weight material, print, organdy, cretonne, etc.: The brim is made double. The back is gathered to the underside of the brim, and the right side of the brim stitched down on top, as you would attach a collar. Or skirt band. ) ~ Page 455 Sandwiches Rhea H. Gardner Extension Service Home Management and Furnishings Specialist, Utah State Agricultural College The purpose of a sandwich determines the kind and amount of filling to be used, as well as its size. A sandwich can supply most of the needs of a good meal, or it may be a light accompaniment to a salad, soup, or beverage. CHEESE FILLINGS: PIMIENTO CHEESE Locs Cut a sandwich loaf into thin slices. Trim off crusts. Spread each slice with cream cheese pimiento filling. Roll up like a jelly roll. Circle with bacon; fasten ends with toothpick, then broil till golden on all sides and bacon is crisp. Serve at once with a crisp salad. SPECIAL CHEESE Blend together one 3-0z. Package cream cheese, 1 tbsp. Chopped pimiento, 1% tbsp. Chopped olives, and % tbsp. Chopped nuts. SNAPPY CHEESE Wash, dry, and finely chop 1 c. Water cress. Add 3 tbsp. Cream cheese, % tbsp. Worcestershire and 1 tbsp. French dressing. RoQuEFORT SPECIAL Blend 1 small package (3 oz.) cream cheese with 2 0z. Roquefort or blue cheese. Season with % tsp. Grated onion, % tsp. Worcestershire and % tsp. Salt. Spread on bread. Cut. Sprinkle each sandwich with paprika and place under broiler to brown. VARIETY CHEESE SPREAD This easily prepared spread is excellent for sandwiches and hors d'oeuvres. 'The possibilities of seasoning it are endless. 1 pound cheddar-type cheese — any smooth melting cheese may be used. Process cheese is excellent. 1 tall can evaporated milk. Grate cheese or cut in small pieces. Put cheese and milk in top part of double boiler; cook over hot water, stirring constantly just until the cheese melts. From heat and season to taste. Remove It is a good idea to divide the mixture into 2 or 3 portions and season each differently. Each chopped nuts and shredded carrots with % c. Thick sour cream, 2 tbsp. French dressing; 1 tsp. Each salt and dry mustard, and % tsp. Sage. Spread on 8 buttered rolls. Chopped toasted almonds or peanuts, 3 tbsp. Mayonnaise, 3 tbsp. Sour cream, 1 tbsp. Lemon juice, salt and pepper to taste. Mix well. Store in covered jar in refrigerator. When ready to use, spread slices of raisin bread with butter. Mix chunk style peanut butter into as much of the orange mixture as you intend to use.
