Celery salt Selected Data—Annual Report 1055 REEF Society continued to advance in nearly all phases of the program during 1955, its 113th year, according to the activities and achievements reflected in this report compiled from the annual reports of 223 stakes and 42 missions. Many worthwhile and inspiring activities, particularly in compassionate service, were disclosed by the narrative sections of the reports. _. There were 7,213 members added to Relief Society during the year, bringing the total membership to 163,513—a considerable number being young women living in foreign lands to which their husbands have been assigned in the armed forces. 'These young women not only enjoy the benefits of the Relief Society program themselves, but are introducing them to their neighbors among whom they are temporarily living. While the growth reflected in 1955 is commendable, it is less than 1954, and so our goal— every Latter-day Saint woman a member of Relief Society—should continue to receive constant, serious consideration. In 1955, 103,467 Relief Society members participated in leadership activities, bringing opportunity for development to 6,269 more women than were reached by these activities in 1954. The overall average attendance at regular meetings showed a slight decrease, though there was a slight increase in the missions. Theology and testimony meetings continued to enjoy the largest attendance, followed, in order, by work, literature, and social science meetings. We are particularly gratified to see that work meeting, through its varied program designed to meet the needs of all homemakers, old and young, is bringing into the society many young women interested in making their homes attractive and happier. Visiting teacher meetings increased 760 in the stakes and 376 in the missions, and the increase of 163,079 visits to Latter-day Saint families by 4,873 more visiting teachers in 2,617 more districts, reflects steady progress in this vital activity. Compassionate services continued to receive increased attention as indicated by 12,421 more visits to the sick and homebound, and ten more days care of the sick, over 1954. The increase in days care of the sick, while small, is commendable in view of the present trend toward hospitalization. The narrative sections of the reports contained many inspiring and heartwarming incidents of varied types of solicitude and help for the aged as well as for neighbors and friends. All this is evidence that the grand key words of the society as given by the Prophet Joseph Smith — "Said Jesus: 'Ye shall do the work which ye see me do' " — continue to have place and purpose in the hearts of Relief Society members. This is the second year we have received reports on the Singing Mothers choruses. These showed 2,005 choruses in the stakes and missions, an increase of 228, with approximately 30,983 singers, an increase of 3,703 over 1954. These are very encouraging increases in this lovely and satisfying activity which gives added unity, spirituality, and cultural benefits to those who listen as well as to those who sing, and, in addition, brings music into the homes of the participants. Each year sees an expansion of Relief Society's program and influence, not only in the established stakes and missions, but in newly created stakes and in missions in remote lands and islands not heretofore reached, and so our great band of sisterhood gradually is encircling the world. The general board gratefully acknowledges the support of all those who have so unselfishly given of their time, talents, minds, and hearts in advancing the Relief Society program of raising human lives to higher and happier levels. With the sustained loyalty of its devoted workers, Relief Society will continue to do so. Margera 0. Ciekering General Secretary-Treasurer Page 458 ANNUAL REPORT MEMBERSHIP — 1955 334,906 L. D. S. Audio Visual Aids for 1956-57 Mildred B. Eyring Member, General Board of Relief Society HE value of teaching aids and the wise use of them should be understood by all Relief Society officers and teachers. To aid means to help or assist. Any device which does not clarify a lesson or project, attract and hold interest, or assist members in remembering important points, is not really an aid, and should be discarded. New workers in Relief Society, particularly, should read the articles on Audio-Visual Aids which have appeared in The Relief Society Magazine in recent years: January 1953, page 27; Jume 1953, page 418; June 1954, page 400; and June 1955, page 403. The exchange of ideas for teaching aids in stake union meeting is most important. Each ward class leader can give her ideas, and, in turn, will receive many more ideas from the class leaders of the other wards. The stake leader will be there to give her information, wise direction, and counsel to the planning. In the stake conventions this year many suggestions are being given to stake leaders regarding visual aids for this coming year's work. These will be helpful as will be also the written material which is being left in the stakes. Theology — "Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon" 1. Blackboard 2. A growing chart 3. Sheology—Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon Lesson 41—Jesus Instructs the Nephites Elder Leland H. Monson (Text: The Book of Mormon: 3 Nephi, chapters 15-21) For Tuesday, October 2, 1956 Objective: To show the great compassion of Jesus toward the Nephites who manifested such great faith in him, and his love for children. HEN Jesus appeared to the Nephites, God, the Eternal Father introduced him as his Son "~.. In whom I am_ well pleased..." (3 Nephi 11:7). For the Nephites and for us this reestablishes and reaffirms the divinity of Christ. As a God, not merely as a great moral teacher, he gave to the Nephites the Sermon on the Mount, which we studied last year. In this lesson we turn to other instructions which this divine Being, Christ our Redeemer, gave to the Nephites. The Law of Moses Superseded Chnist told the Nephites that he had given to ancient Israel the Law of Moses and that now the law was fulfilled. He said, "... I have come to fulfil the law; therefore it hath an end" (3 Nephi 15:5). He asked that they live the new law which he had and would give unto them. "Behold," he said, "I am the law, and the light. Look unto me and endure to the end, and ye shall live..." (3 Nephi 15:9). The Sheep of Another Fold Jesus then told the Nephites that they, and the other lost tribes of Israel, had been separated from those at Jerusalem because of the iniquity that existed among the Jews. He informed them that they were the sheep of another fold that he mentioned to the Jews. And verily I say unto you, that ye are they of whom I said: Other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they shall hear my voice; and there shall be one fold, and one shepherd (3 Nephi 15:21). He further told them that there was still another fold that should hear him (See 3 Nephi 16:1-3); and announced that he was going to visit them. (See 3 Nephi 17:4.) Jesus instructed the Nephites: And I command you that ye shall write these sayings after I am gone, that if it so be that my people at Jerusalem, they who have seen me and been with me in my ministry, do not ask the Father in my name, that they may receive a knowledge of you by the Holy Ghost, and also of the other tribes whom they know not of, that these sayings which ye shall write shall be kept and shall be manifested unto the Gentiles, that through the fulness of the Gentiles, the remnant of their seed, who shall be scattered forth upon the face of the earth because of their unbelief, may be brought in, or may be brought to a knowledge of me, their Redeemer. And then will I gather them in from the four quarters of the earth; and then Page 477 478 will I fulfill the covenant which the Father hath made unto all the people of the house of Israel. And blessed are the Gentiles, because of their belief in me, in and of the Holy Ghost, which witnesses unto them of me and of the Father. Behold, because of their belief in me, saith the Father, and because of the unbelief of you, O house of Israel, in the latter day shall the truth come unto the Gentiles, that the fulness of these things shall be made known unto them (3 Nephi 16:4-7). Jesus also said that the land was given to the Nephites, the seed of Joseph, for their inheritance: Verily, verily, I say unto you, thus hath the Father commanded me — that I should give unto this people this land for their inheritance (3 Nephi 16:16). The Savior then perceived that the people were weak and could not understand all the words which the Father had commanded him to speak to them at that time, so he counseled them to go to their homes and "... Ponder upon the things which I have said, and ask of the Father, in my name, that ye may understand..." (3 Nephi 17:3). Jesus then said he must go to his Father and also to show himself to the lost tribes of Israel, but as he looked at the multitude, he saw they were in tears and their eyes seemed to implore him to stay with them a little longer. Healing of the Sick The Savior spoke, "... Behold, my bowels are filled with compassion towards you" (3 Nephi 17:6), and he instructed them to bring any sick, lame, blind, halt, maimed, or otherwise afflicted to him. RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 And it came to pass that when he had thus spoken, all the multitude, with one accord, did go forth with their sick and their afflicted, and their lame, and with their blind, and with their dumb, and with all them that were afflicted in any manner and he did heal them every one as they were brought forth unto him. And they did all, both they who had been healed and they who were whole, bow down at his feet, and did worship him; and as many as could come for the multitude did kiss his feet, insomuch that they did bathe his feet with their tears (3 Nephi 17:9-10). Jesus then commanded them to bring their little children. He stood in the midst of them and commanded the multitude to kneel and he prayed mightily to the Father:. And the things which he prayed cannot be written, and the multitude did bear record who heard him. And after this manner do they bear record: The eye hath never seen, neither hath the ear heard, before, so great and marvelous things as we saw and heard Jesus speak unto the Father; And no tongue can speak, neither can there be written by any man, neither can the hearts of men conceive so great and marvelous things as we both saw and heard Jesus speak; and no one can conceive of the joy which filled our souls at the time we heard him pray for us unto the Father (3 Nephi 17:15-17). Blessing Little Children The two thousand five hundred people who were assembled were overjoyed. When Jesus: witnessed their great faith he told them his joy was full. As he spoke to them he wept, and "... Took their little children, one by one, and blessed them, and prayed unto the Father for them. And when he had done LESSON DEPARTMENT this he wept. Again" (3 Nephi 17:21-22). The Savior then asked the multitude to look at their. Little ones, and, as they looked, angels came down, and encircled the little children, and ministered unto them. Institution of Sacrament Jesus instituted the ordinance of the sacrament among the Nephites. The disciples were told that they must partake of the sacrament in remembrance of Christ's body and blood that it should be a testimony unto the Father that they would always remember him. 'They were promised that if they would do this, his spirit would always be with them, and that it would show their willingness to do that which Jesus had commanded them. Jesus instructed the Nephites to pray always, saying:. Ye must watch and pray always lest ye enter into temptation for Satan desireth to have you, that he may sift you as wheat (3 Nephi 18:18). And as I have prayed among you even so shall ye pray in my church, among my people who do repent, and are baptized im my name. Behold I am the light; I have set an example for you (3 Nephi 18:16). He instructed the disciples further that if a man is unworthy to partake of the sacrament he should be forbidden. However, he should not be cast out from among them, but be ministered to by them and be prayed for. 'Then, if he repents and is baptized, he should be received by them and be given the sacrament. If a man would not repent they were still to continue to minister to him in case he might return and. Repent. Which, if he 479 did, and came to the Savior with full purpose of heart, the Savior would heal him and the people would be the means of bringing salvation to him.. (See 3 Nephi 18:28-32.) Jesus then "... Touched with his hand..." (3, Nephi 18:36) the twelve disciples, giving them power to bestow the Holy Ghost. He then departed from them and ascended into heaven. Bestowal of Holy Ghost Word soon spread among the people that Jesus would appear on the next day. On that day, the twelve disciples appeared before the assembled group. 'The assembly was so large that it was divided into twelve groups, over each one of which a disciple presided. 'The disciples prayed that the Holy Ghost should be given unto them.. Nephi went down into the water and was baptized.... And he baptized all those whom Jesus had chosen" (3 Nephi 19:11-12). When they came up out of the water "... The Holy Ghost did fall upon them..." (3 Nephi 19:13). Angels came down and ministered to the disciples. While this was taking place "... Jesus came and stood in the midst and ministered unto them" (3 Nephi 19:15). Jesus went a short distance and prayed as follows: Father, I thank thee that thou hast given the Holy Ghost unto these whom I have chosen; and it is because of their belief in me that I have chosen them out of the world. Father, I pray thee that thou wilt give the Holy Ghost unto all them that shall believe in their words, 480 Father, thou hast given them the Holy Ghost because they believe in me; and thou seest that they believe in me because thou hearest them, and they pray unto me; and they pray unto me because I am with them. And now Father, I pray unto thee for them, and also for all those who shall believe on their words, that they may believe in me, that I may be in them as thou, Father, art in me, that we may be one (3 Nephi 19:20-23). After Jesus had finished praying, he commended the disciples on their faith, saying:... So great faith have I never seen among all the Jews; wherefore I could not show unto them so great miracles, because of their unbelief.... There are none of them that have seen so great things as ye have seen; neither have they heard so great things as ye have heard (3 Nephi 19:35-36). Jesus then commanded the multitude and the disciples to arise and cease praying, but he admonished them to pray always in their hearts. Jesus miraculously provided the sacrament and:... He brake bread again and blessed it, and gave to the disciples to eat. And when they had eaten he commanded them that they should break bread, and give unto the multitude... He also gave them wine to drink... (3 Nephi 20:3-5). The Gospel in the Latter Days The Savior advised the Nephites that in the latter days the gospel should be preached to the Jews and that they would accept it. "Then," he said, "will the Father gather them together again, and give unto them Jerusalem for the land of their inheritance" (3 Nephi 20:33). RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 That the people of the latter days might be. Fully aware of the time when these events would occur, Jesus gave the Nephites the sign of the Father's work. "... This is the thing which I will give unto you for a sign," he said, "for verily I say unto you that when these things which I declare unto you, and which I shall declare unto you hereafter of myself, and by the power of the Holy Ghost which shall be given unto you of the Father, shall be made known unto the Gentiles that they may know concerning... This my people who shall be scattered by them... It shall be a sign unto them, that they may know that the work of the Father hath already commenced unto the fulfilling of the covenant which he hath made unto the people who are of the house of Israel" (3 Nephi 21:2, 7). Jesus further told the Nephites that a great work should be accomplished at that time and that there would be many who would not believe it "... Although a man shall declare it unto them" (3 Nephi 21:9). Concerning the Gentiles in that day, Jesus said: "Yea, wo be unto the Gentiles except they repent..." (3 Nephi 21:14). On the other hand, he pointed out, if they would repent and "... Hearken unto my words..." he would establish his church among them:.. And they shall come in unto the covenant and be numbered among this the remnant of Jacob, unto whom I have given this land for their inheritance (3 Nephi 21:22). Jesus was deeply concerned over the Gentiles and the Jews of the last days when the record of the Ne- LESSON DEPARTMENT phites should come forth amongst them. He stressed the importance of the sacrament in the lives of the Nephites, informing them that it would help them to remember him, that it would be a witness unto the Father that they did remember him. He also was grateful unto his Father that the disciples had been given the Holy Ghost as a companion. The Savior's emphasis upon the sacrament and upon the bestowal of the Holy Ghost, indicates the great importance of these ordinances. Sometimes, however, partaking of the sacrament becomes so routine in our lives that we do not derive the full benefit from it. Only as we live worthily and meditate upon the meaning of the sacrifice of the Savior and the covenants we 481 take, can we get the full blessing that accompanies proper participation. After we have been baptized and confirmed and have received the Holy Ghost, we must continue to be faithful, to live the gospel, if we are to have the Holy Ghost and its influence to direct our lives. Questions on the Lesson 1. What miracles did Jesus perform among the Nephites? 2. What did Jesus say about the latterday Gentiles? 3. What did he say about the latterday Jews? 4. Discuss the importance of the ordinance of the sacrament. 5. Discuss the significance and blessings attached to the bestowal of the Holy Ghost. Visiting Seacher Nessages— Book of Mormon Gems of Truth Lesson 41—"Yea, Wo Unto Him That Shall Deny the Revelations of the Lord and That Shall Say the Lord No Longer Worketh by Revelation..." (3 Nephi 29:6). Leone O. Jacobs For Tuesday, October 2, 1956 Objective: To show that faith in continuous revelation is essential to a testimony of the truth of the gospel. ONTINUOUS revelation is the foundation stone upon which The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is built. It was also by means of this principle that the Church was restored in these latter days. When the Father and the Son appeared to Joseph Smith in 1820 that principle was reaffirmed in modern times. Many people discount divine revelation entirely, saying such belief is purely mythical, that the scriptures are only unproved tradition. Others say that revelation is no longer necessary, that God gave all the instructions needed for the welfare of mankind, in ancient days. But Latter-day Saints "... Believe all that God has revealed, all that He does now reveal, and we believe that He will yet reveal many great 482 and important things pertaining to the Kingdom of God" (gth Article of Faith). There are certain fundamental principles and commandments in the scriptures which apply to all ages. Other revelations may apply only to particular circumstances. It was necessary, for example, for the Lord to instruct Moses day by day, in the flight of the children of Israel from Egypt. The resurrected Christ told the Nephites: Behold, I say unto you that the law is fulfilled that was given unto Moses. Behold, I am he that gave the law, and I am he who covenanted with my people Israel; therefore, the law in me is fulfilled, for I have come to fulfil the law; therefore it hath an end (3 Nephi 15:45). Brigham Young was given revelation concerning the westward march of the saints to the Rocky Mountains, etc. Guidance is definitely needed from God in all ages and for different circumstances. It would seem inconsistent for anyone who believes in the Bible to reject the principle of continuous revelation, for surely a just and loving God, who is "the same yesterRELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 day, today and forever" would not reveal his will to Noah, to Abraham, to Moses and others, yet leave later generations without contact. Many people inquire, "Do the Authorities of the Church receive revelations today?" Certainly they do. Revelations are received currently for the welfare of the Church as a whole. Because they do not appear in book form as do those in the Doctrine and Covenants, for example, does not mean they are any less important or authoritative. In a recent address on the subject of revelation President Stephen L Richards stated:... The secret of life is to. Build on the old, the tried and the true.... Now revelation is the foundation. I know of nothing else so solid and dependable... « Revelation has generally come to us through the prophets, although the greatest and most important of all revelation came directly from the Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of the Eternal God.... Modern day scripture or revelation has the same validity with even more direct proof of authenticity than does ancient scripture. Both emanate from the same source... We know the right through revelation So, my brethren and sisters, learn the revelations and live by them. They are true. (Deseret News, Church Section, July " 1955, pp. 2-3). Work Meeting— Food Preparation and Service (A Course Recommended for Use by Wards and Branches at Work Meeting) lane 1—Lunches and Sandwiches Rhea H. Gardner For Tuesday, October 9, 1956 HEN one meal a day must be carried to work in a lunch box, the homemaker has a real challenge to meet, for into that lunch box must go foods that will provide a fair share of the day's needs and be so inviting, satisfying, and healthful, that the worker or LESSON DEPARTMENT school child will keep physically and mentally fit. Whatever the packed lunch lacks in providing a third of the day's nutritional needs should be met in the other two meals. With the use of thermos jars, in which can be carried warm soups, stews, or other main dish foods or refrigeratorchilled beverages, the task of preparing a tasty and well-balanced packed lunch meal is greatly simplified. With the improved food wrappings one is now able to include in the packed lunch crisp strips of salad-type vegetables, with the assurance that they will stay refrigerator crisp until eaten. Glass jars or colorful plastic containers with tight-fitting lids—in which can be carried well-chilled fruit, baked custard, or other desserts, are a further help in giving the meals you pack, the same high rating as your other meals. Because sandwiches are so often a mainstay in the lunch box, it is especially important that they be prepared with care, imagination, and a thought of what they will taste like three to five hours after they are prepared. The imaginative sandwich maker today keeps her sandwiches right at the top in appetite appeal. In addition to enriched white and whole wheat, she also uses raisin, bran, French, rye, and nut breads for variety. She uses a wide variety of sandwich fillings and tries always to include two different kinds of sandwiches in each lunch box meal. She combines ingredients for sandwich fillings with a thought for 483 contrast in flavor, color, and texture. Bland fillings are sharpened with lemon, custard, ketchup, sauces, and pickles. Crunchiness is added by crisp bacon, nuts, cucumber, celery, carrots, or shredded cabbage. Fillings which lack color are enlivened with chopped pickle, pimiento, olives, sweet peppers, or parsley. The skilled sandwich maker creams, but never melts, the butter she uses; then spreads it out to the very edges of both slices. She is generous with sandwich fillings, making them as thick as one slice of bread. Each sandwich is neatly and securely wrapped to prevent drying out of the bread. She wraps clean, crisp lettuce leaves in waxed paper to be added to the sandwich just before it is eaten. She includes in every lunch an element of surprise — some fresh fruit, a piece of favorite cake, candy, cookies, or other dessert. In many instances, the home freezer is the sandwich maker's best friend. A variety of sandwiches can be prepared and kept in the freezer for two or three weeks, but no longer. Frozen sandwiches wrapped two to a package in moisture-vapor proof wrappings, not waxed paper, thaw in about three hours and are still refrigerator cool. They should be eaten soon after thawing, however, since frozen food deteriorates quickly after thawing. Whether the packed lunch is to serve as a main meal for a working man, for a school child, or for a dainty refreshment at a social function, it deserves all the care and interest you can give it both for your sake and the one who will eat it. Note: See "Sandwiches," by Rhea H. Gardner, page 456, in this issue of the Magazine and "Packed Lunch Suggestions," zine, October 1952, page 669. By Hazel Stevens, The Relief Society Maga- of iterature—Shakespeare in Our Lives Lesson 1—Why Shakespeare? Elder Briant S. Jacobs (Textbook: Shakespeare Major Plays and the Sonnets, by G. B. Harrison, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1948) For Tuesday, October 16, 1956 Objective: To understand the reasons for Shakespeare's greatness and appreciate his contribution to our lives.... Thyself and thy belongings Are not thine own so proper as to waste Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee. Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike As if we had them not.... ERE English literature to be compared to the universe, Shakespeare would be the sun, about which all others circle to feel the warming influence of its outstanding glow. To bask in Shakespeare's life-giving zest and gusto, to be quickened by the sheer cleanness and precision of his words, to be awed by his wisdom and justice as he shares with us his probings deep into the human heart and the mysteries of mortality — in these realms of highest adventure Shakespeare is our supreme guide and spokesman, and has been for centuries. Time has proved him moral and true; his virtues reveal him as brilliant and just; his selfless humility proclaims him worthy of the sustained love of mankind. None of our writers has received more love or deserved more, than he. Love cannot be commanded or forced, it must be earned, usually by giving oneself to others. Shakespeare has given himself to others so abundantly that rarely are we Page 484 Measure for Measure, I. 1.30-36 fully aware of our debt. For centuries he has been the most widely quoted man in our culture, surpassed only by the Bible. Actually he constantly places more words in our mouths than any of us realize. "Brevity is the soul of wit" (to quote Shakespeare), and well-turned phrases are so rare because so few mortals have ever been able to put the nub of the matter into a few memorable words. Best proof that Shakespeare is the master phrasemaker of the language is to cite a few of his contributions to our everyday language which after centuries still survive. For how many of the following have you ever expressed gratitude to Shakespeare? There's something in the wind (Comedy of Errors); play fast and loose, out of the question (Love's Labour's Lost); single blessedness, the course of true love never runs smooth (Midsummer Night's Dream); halcyon days (I Henry VI); paint the lily, elbow room, cold comfort (King John); what's in a name? A fool's paradise (Romeo and Juliet); my own flesh and blood, it's a wise father that knows LESSON DEPARTMENT his own child (Merchant of Venice); merry as the day is long (Much Ado About Nothing); too much of a good thing (As You Like It); he has eaten me out of house and home (II Henry IV); give the devil his due, tell the truth and shame the devil, hearts of gold, the better part of valor is discretion (I Henry IV); wear my heart on my sleeve, a green-eyed monster, a foregone conclusion, who steals my purse steals trash, loved not wisely but too well, the seamy side of life (Othello); a lean and hungry look, an itching palm, it was Greek to me, a dish fit for the gods (Julius Caesar); flaming youth, in my mind's eye, the glass of fashion, as easy as lying, cudgel thy brains, the primrose path, it smells to heaven, something rotten in Denmark, method in his madness, every dog will have his day (Hamlet); every inch a king, the wheel is come full circle, more sinned against than sinning (King Lear). Merely because these now common expressions are Shakespeare's is not to justify them. Instead let us say that, while all of us use them today, essentially they are his, and are included here solely to illustrate the fecundity of his verbal powers. Actually we should ignore these "old saws" and invent our own. Would that we could! Would we were Shakespeare! Attempts to Know Shakespeare From 1623, when the First Folio edition of Shakespeare's plays appeared, up to the present, at least 120 men have dedicated their mature years to editing Shakespeare's works, criticizing the texts, relating his plays to their sources, determining the order in which the plays were written, etc. The first Shakespeare societies appeared early in the nineteenth century; today they are everywhere. Special Shakespeare collections are prized possessions of the wealthiest, largest li- 485 braries in England and the United States; in the United States, the largest and most famous is the Folger Library in Washington, D. C., an entire institution dedicated to Shakespearean scholarship. So thoroughly has Shakespeare been counted, compared, explained, analyzed, paraphrased, quoted, searched by X-ray and ultraviolet light that no one can doubt his greatness, since he has survived this deluge triumphant. When many of our best minds for centuries have dedbicated their lives to him, what remains for us to do or claim to do? J. W. Mackail gives us the only sane and true answer: The best approach to Shakespeare is to read him.... It is easy, and common, to read too much about him (Approach to Shakespeare, page 5). To be known, then, Shakespeare must be read and heard. Yes, we possess him in some degree, since it is impossible for a literate, attentive person in our society to escape hearing him being constantly quoted. We have studied him at school in our youth, and, occasionally, we may have read him for our own pleasure during maturity. All members of our western culture beyond early childhood know of Shakespeare, in varying degree; not quite as many know him. Many of us feel that we would like to know him "if we just had the time." On a more mature level, let us grant the fact that all of us have time for what we most enjoy. Inasmuch as we now have time to enjoy Shakespeare — the next two years of the literature lessons have been dedicated to introducing him — our immediate challenge is to convince ourselves 486 that he yields a rich enjoyment which eminently deserves our attention, our effort, and, most precious, our time. 'The more we read Shakespeare the more each of us, no matter who we are' or whatever our background, must come to realize that in every page of Shakespeare there is joy and truth and insight which will immediately enrich our day-to-day existence, if only we will be among those who will give him ear. If we will each day share with ourselves and our families only one or two of his great thoughts or piercing insights into human frailty, then we will understand as never before why his audience constantly increases in size and loyalty. Why Study Shakespeare? One reason may be that time has proved his greatness, has proved his visions and values to be true. If we study him as the greatest dramatist, because some of our greatest critics have so proclaimed, we know we shall not be wasting our precious time and effort. But, valid and popular as this approach may be, in part it robs us of the privilege and pain of making our own judgments. Let us ask ourselves the following questions: Why have millions of people read Shakespeare. Of their own choice, and attended his plays? How has he fed the timeless, basic hungers of multitudes of people, from all walks of life? How can anything more than three hundred years old be considered great in our modern, scientific, efficient world? Word Magic As we have already seen, Shakespeare's words give such pleasure that many of his phrases have beRELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 come part of our living language. The longer we read him the more we marvel at the aptness and cunning of his words. 'The fecundity of his imagination seems inexhaustible. Sometimes we even come to feel that his ability to portray a soul, or catch an essence of place or mood solely through words reveals almost supernatural powers. 'To witness such word dexterity makes us more humbly aware of man's infinite though mortal capabilities. As an example, consider his effortless skill in using the commonest household incidents to reveal the deeper, hidden truths within us which are often felt but seldom expressed. How very apt is his comparing the spilling of concealed guilt with one's attempt to carry a pan brimful: So full of artless jealousy is guilt, It spills itself in fearing to be spilt. Hamlet, IV. 5.19 Such a comparison provokes us into deep thought, itself its own delight, since it frees us from our constant, exclusive concern with the surface trivia of life. If he wishes us to experience the turmoil of human suffering, his words bring us the aged King Lear wandering afield during storm, nearly grief-crazed over the treachery and selfishness of his daughter:. Tears his white hair, Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage, Catch in their fury, and make nothing of; Strives in his little world of man to outscorn The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain, King Lear III. 7-11 In other passages Shakespeare is less violent, really gentle and warm, ay LESSON DEPARTMENT A Perry Picture When it suits his purpose to be so. For example, to be ".., as vigilant asa cat to steal cream" (I Henry IV, IV.2.65) brings almost a smile to our faces. Since a cat has no moral standards, Shakespeare _ reminds us pertinently of this part of the cat's basic nature, while vigilance is a qualifying word of sufficient mildness to merit so warm and domestic a comparison. Self-Revelation One of Shakespeare's most substantial rewards is that, more forcefully and intensely than any other writer, he reveals us to ourselves; he "holds the mirror up to nature" and helps us see ourselves as we really are. 'This he can do because he "has the most comprehensive soul," the most searching eye, the sharpest pen. Although he does not provide 487 Copyright 1902 STRATFORD-ON-AVON — THE HOME OF SHAKESPEARE all the answers, he uses the method of poetry and art — intuition, insight, metaphor, rhythm, subtlety — to help us see all things as they really are. Probably his supreme gift is his intense zest for life, possible only if preceded by a probing, recording curiosity about everything in life: nature, society, ourselves, our God. Because Shakespeare felt this straining tug of his own monstrous curiosity and obeyed it, he feels and thus soothes our own. See. Ing truth in his created world, we can then better see it revealed in ourselves. As William Hazlitt has observed: Every single character in Shakespeare is as much an individual as those in life itself.... His characters are real beings of flesh and blood.... How well indeed we come to 488 know more of ourselves from the following random quotes: He jests at scars that never felt a wound. Romeo and Juliet, II.2 How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is To have a thankless child!... King Lear, I, 4 That which in mean men we entitle patience Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts. Richard HU, 1, 2: Smooth runs the water where the brook is deep; Henry VI, Ill, I I had most need of blessing, and "Amen" Stuck in my throat. Macbeth, II, 2 Thus conscience does make cowards of us all, And thus the native hue of resolution Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought, Hamlet, III, 1 The Prince of Darkness is a gentleman. King Lear, HI, 4... No, 'tis slander; Whose edge is sharper than the sword; whose tongue Outvenoms all the worms of Nile; whose breath Rides on the posting winds, and doth belie All corners of the world: kings, queens, and states, Maids, matrons, nay, the secrets of the grave This viperous slander enters.... Cymbeline, III, 4 True Morality How beautifully reassuring it is that our heritage has chosen for its supreme spokesman William Shakespeare, a man so intelligent and sensitive, so aware of every phase of humankind, so unbiased and sympathetic in his depiction of things as they are, so strong and gentle and wholesome, in a word, so comprehensive and universal. How many other candidates we RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 have had for the office of Greatest English Poet, writers sometimes partially blind to the goodness of man and nature, writers calloused by cynicism and despair, or writers who refuse to face life's great spiritual and moral problems but would rather escape in glib shallowness or frivolity or sensation! For how many have illicit love and adultery been cause for jest; how many have seen cruelty and pride and hypocrisy and yielding to animal desire and faithless self-interest, as the inevitable state of man. But Shakespeare is none of these. As Coleridge has seen in all his wisdom: Shakespeare has no innocent adulteries.. Ho virtuous vice; he never renders that amiable which religion and reason alike teach us to detest; or clothe impurity in the garb of virtue. Shakespeare's characters depict the basic truths of mortality and immortality in and of themselves, without seeming to be pious, sanctimonious, or "preachy." His truths never seem "tacked-on," or sugarcoated moralizing pills slipped down our throats when he has popped our mouths open; instead, his truths are the very essence of things as they are. Because he is excited by all phases of life, he discusses everything, and holds nothing back. Because he has vowed to hold the mirror up to all of nature he presents every human evil and weakness, but his greatness is that, without posting little moralizing signposts (which would weaken and mar his larger effect), he subtly suggests to us that what he speaks of as evil is evil. For example, when anyone mentions the word luxury but leaves LESSON DEPARTMENT it untagged, without any slanting adjectives, how are we to know whether that person regards luxury as good or bad? But when Shakespeare personifies luxury as "the devil luxury, with his fat rump and potato finger" (Troilus and Cressida, V.2.55), it is difficult for us to refrain from identifying so vigorous an image not only with the immediate character who speaks it, but with Shakespeare's own opinion. To define this as his over-all attitude toward luxury seems further justified when we find him speaking elsewhere of luxury in similar tone; for example, in The Merry Wives of Windsor, Falstaff is caught and chided by the fairies in his attempt to steal a man's wife: Fie on sinful fantasy! Fie on lust and luxury! Lust is but a bloody fire, Kindled with unchaste desire, Fed in heart, whose flames aspire, As thoughts do blow them, higher.... V.5.97-102 Again, after reading the following (lI.3.153-171) on pride, a revealing aside from Troilus and Cressida, how much more subtle and personal does Shakespeare make pride than if he had merely tacked on the wall such a proverb as, "Pride goeth before destruction," a widespread custom in Elizabethan homes. Ajax and Agamemnon have been lamenting Achilles' pride. Note particularly the cunning Shakespeare employs to tell us that Ajax is a proud man, and about as awkward in selfanalysis as the rest of us. Speaking of Achilles, Ajax says, "Is he so much? Do you not think, he thinks himself a better man than I am?" 489 Agam. No question. Ajax. Will you subscribe this thought and say he is? Agam. No, noble Ajax. You are as strong, as valiant, as wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable. Ajax. Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not what pride is. Agam. Your mind's the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the fairer. He that is proud eats up himself. Pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle, and whatever praises itself but in the deed devours the deed in the praise. Ajax. I do hate a proud man as I hate the engendering of toads. Nestor. (aside) And yet he loves himself. Is it not strange? How superbly Shakespeare's tone herein accomplishes what might well have been his two objectives: first, to give a body or form to his own emotional attitude toward pride; and second, by Ajax's smugness ("How doth pride grow?') and by Ajax's own vigorous image of pride (" as I hate the engendering of toads") to illustrate in Ajax the very quality which he condemns. Shakespeare subtly forces us to realize that pride is not a vice which occurs only in others. He does not strongly denounce it in Ajax, as Ajax resembles the rest of us. And Shakespeare seems to say, "Inasmuch as we are all in this business of life together, let us then act as brothers, and tolerate each other in our human weaknesses." Shakespeare has been many things to many peoples; so he must be to each of us. But whatever else he may or may not be, read him, that he may then be allowed to remind you that all men become brothers when, in compassion, they share 490 the great binding experiences of life: pain, sorrow, laughter, death. It is in these tender times that all men shrug off their surface badges of distinction and understand one another, and this great unifying truth does not come to an end with the termination of either mortality or death. Why does Shakespeare deserve a constant rereading? 4. Should the purpose of a writer be to "hold the mirror up to nature" or should. He select and omit, to make the mirror reflect only the lovely in life? Social Sctence—Latter-day Saint Family Life Lesson 1—Joseph Smith's Early Home Life Elder John Farr Larson For Tuesday, October 23, 1956 Objective: To show the influence of the Prophet's early family life upon his teachings to the Latter-day Saint women. OSEPH Smith established a_ pattern, both of opportunity and of obligation, for Latter-day Saint women which has been followed and built upon by the succeeding Presidents of the Church. His teachings regarding Latter-day Saint women came as inspiration from the Lord, after long years of preparation for his calling. 'The Prophet's early family life undoubtedly played a most important role in influencing this preparation. In the life of the Prophet's mother we find exemplified the virtues which should characterize a true Latterday Saint. A glimpse into the Smith household will help us to appreciate more fully the development of the Prophet's lofty concepts regarding woman's sphere, which are to be discussed in the lessons to follow. Family Background Joseph Smith, Jr. Was born the fourth child in a family of eleven. His parents, Joseph Smith, Sr. And Lucy Mack Smith, descended from substantial New England stock, the Smiths having been "honorable farmers" and the Macks "industrious land owners." His parents were chosen to fill very important missions in helping to establish the Church in this dispensation. The parents were well-to-do at the time of their marriage, and for a few years following, but, because of the fraud of a trusted agent, a large indebtedness was imposed upon them, which not only wiped out their entire holdings but burdened them for many years to come. T' A series of misfortunes followed. The story of how this family moved from place to place overcoming adversity and wrestling with poverty, is one of hard work, sacrifice, relAll references in this lesson, unless otherwise noted, are from the mother of the Prophet Joseph. See History of Joseph Smith By His Mother, Lucy Mack Smith, as edited by Preston Nibley. LESSON DEPARTMENT sourcefulness, courage, and great faith. Through it all, the parents seemed sustained by a deep spirituality and absolute trust in God which had characterized their familics for generations and which were readily absorbed by their children. Their trials and hardships resulted in even greater humility, strength of character, and family solidarity than they had heretofore known. The Smith children learned at an early age to be industrious and dutiful, sharing alongside their parents the responsibilities of their pioneer life. In this superior home Christian virtues were taught and _practiced. Family prayer, Bible reading, and thoughtful meditation by the fireside were the order of the day. Kindness and consideration were their watchwords. 'The parents instructed the children in reading and writing, since they "had, in great measure, been debarred from the privilege of schools." So impressive were their evening family gatherings, that on many occasions neighbors joined to partake of their spirit. On one of these evenings, soon after the family began singing, a couple of little boys came in, and one of them stepped up to Samuel and whispered, "Mr. Smith, won't you pray pretty soon? Our mother said we must be home by eight o'clock, and we would like to hear you pray before we go" (Ibid., page 189). Often repeated in the family circle were the prophetic declarations made by members of both the Smith and the Mack families prior to this time, which were to be fulfilled by the Prophet's mission. Lucy Mack's brother, Jason Mack, had believed: 491... That by prayer and faith the gifts of the gospel, which were enjoyed by the ancient disciples of Christ, might be attained.... He was also of the opinion that God would, at some subsequent period, manifest His Power as He had anciently done—in signs and wonders (Ibid., page 9). One of the Smith ancestors had been impressed to say that a Prophet would be raised up within the family to perform a great work on the earth. The familiar accounts of other spiritual manifestations to family members combined to produce a spiritual sensitiveness and belief in divine power, which were undoubtedly a preparation for the family's acceptance of the Prophet's mission. Family Acceptance of the Prophet's Message The assurance that his father would accept his story was given Joseph by the Angel Moroni on the morning of September 22, 1823. This was the morning after the angel appeared to the Prophet in his bedroom to instruct him regarding the sacred record he was to translate. He was sent from the field by his father when he seemed ill. As he went home, the angel appeared and asked him why he had not told his father that which he had been commanded to tell. Joseph replied: "I was afraid my father would not believe me." The angel answered, "He will believe every word you say to him." And, just as the angel had predicted, his father not only believed him, but charged him to follow every instruction given him by Moroni (Ibid., page 79. See also Pearl of Great Price, Joseph Smith 2:29-50). The interest of parents in the 492 worthy activities of their children and faith in their accomplishments are real factors in attainment. The support of the Prophet by his parents, and by his brothers and sisters, stimulated him in his calling. The entire family openly received Joseph's message. In fact, they were so eager to hear more that the eldest son, Alvin, who always exhibited great anxiety over the plates, suggested they arise early, complete their work, and leave time for long evenings to listen to Joseph. The Prophet confided what he had been permitted to reveal, cautioning them to keep his words within the family circle. The Prophet's mother beautifully describes the family during the days which followed: From this time forth, Joseph continued to receive instructions from the Lord, and we continued to get the children together every evening for the purpose of listening while he gave us a relation of the same. I presume our family presented an aspect as singular as any that ever lived upon the face of the earth—all seated in a circle, father, mother, sons and daughters, and giving the most profound attention to a boy, eighteen years of age, who had never read the Bible through in his life: he seemed much less inclined to the petusal of books than any of the rest of our children, but far more given to meditation and deep study. We were now confirmed in the opinion that God was about to bring to light something upon which we could stay our minds, or that would give us a more perfect knowledge of the plan of salvation and the redemption of the human family. This caused us greatly to rejoice, the sweetest union and happiness pervaded our house, and tranquility reigned in our midst. During our evening conversations, Joseph would occasionally give us some of the most amusing recitals that could be RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 imagined. He would describe the ancient inhabitants of this continent, their dress, mode of traveling, and the animals upon which they rode; their cities, their buildings, with every particular; their mode of warfare; and also their religious worship. This he would do with as much ease, seemingly, as if he had spent his whole life among them (Ibid., pp. 82-83). Prophet's Dependence Upon His Parents Each child derives great strength, ability, and character from the love, advice, and close association of his parents. The Prophet Joseph Smith was no exception. He leaned heavily on the support and counsel of his parents, both before and after the organization of the Church. The bond of affection between them grew stronger as they shared the many responsibilities involved in his mission. One instance is cited to indicate that Joseph desired to include them in his joys as well as his anxieties. Upon completion of the translation of The Book of Mormon, Joseph asked his parents to join him at the Whitmer home. The evening was spent in reading the manuscript, and the following morning "after attending to the usual services, namely, reading, singing and praying," Joseph and Oliver Cowdery, David Whitmer, and Martin Harris, went to a nearby grove to engage in prayer, after which they were shown the plates by an angel. (See D. H. C. I, pp. 52-57.) When Joseph returned to the house, he threw himself down beside his mother and exclaimed: Father, mother, you do not know how happy I am: the Lord has now caused the plates to be shown to three more besides myself. They have seen an angel, who has testified to them, and they will have to bear witness to the truth of what LESSON DEPARTMENT I have said, for now they know for themselves, that I do not go about to deceive the people, and I feel as if I was relieved of a burden which was almost too heavy for me to bear, and it rejoices my soul, that I am not any longer to be entirely alone in the world (History of Joseph Smith By His Mother, Lucy Mack Smith, page 152). The Prophet always showed deep gratitude for the influence of his parents. This is shown by the following entry in his Annals made in October 1835, when the Prophet visited his father for several days, attending to him during an illness: Waited on my father again... All this day with my heart raised to God in the name of Jesus Christ, that He would testore him to health, that I might be blessed with his company and_ advice, esteeming it one of the greatest earthly blessings to be blessed with the society of parents, whose mature years and experience render them capable of administering the most wholesome advice... We called on the Lord in mighty prayer in the name of Jesus Christ, and laid our hands on him and _ rebuked the disease. And God heard and answered our prayers — to the great joy and satisfaction of our souls. Our aged father arose and dressed himself, shouted, and praised the Lord (D. H. C. II, page 289). "Mother Smith" There were many sterling qualities in Lucy Mack Smith which endeared her to her family and the people about her. She was by nature refined, cultured, and dignified. She was kind and courteous, and, because of her sympathetic understanding, she was of great comfort as she ministered among the sick and distressed. The Prophet had ample opportunity to see her strong leadership in action, first in the home, then in the community, and afterwards among the women of the 493 Church, and must have felt the need for others to emulate her spirit of service and her deep spirituality. Her life was not an easy one, but at no time did she question the hand of the Lord. In fact, she seemed to have a talent for turing adversity into a blessing. At one time the entire family, except the parents, was struck with typhus fever. It was at this time that Joseph developed a leg infection and underwent a most painful operation. After these experiences, she wrote: Having passed through about a year of sickness and distress, health again returned to our family, and we most assuredly realized the blessing; and indeed, we felt to acknowledge the hand of God, more in preserving our lives through such a tremendous scene of affliction, than if we had, during this time, seen nothing but health and prosperity (History of Joseph Smith By His Mother, Lucy Mack Smith, page 58). Early in her married life, when seriously ill, she had promised the Lord if he would restore her to health, she would devote the remainder of her life to him and her family, and this she did consistently. She had great faith in the power of the Priesthood and was always ready to sustain her husband and sons in their respective Church assignments. On many occasions when the men of the household were absent, she adroitly handled intruding enemies to prevent their obtaining The Book of Mormon manuscript. Mother Smith was an effective missionary, not only by means of her good life, but in actually expounding the principles of the gospel. Her years of experience were invaluable to the younger mothers of the Church, and they looked to her for wise counsel and sound judgment. Her capacity to love was unlimited. Not only did she shower her own children and husband with affection, but she extended the same devotion to those who married into her family; she welcomed the Phophet's wife, Emma, from the time he first brought her to the Smith home as a bride. There was always a strong affinity between them. Not every mother is called upon to be the mother of a prophet, but the challenge of establishing a righteous home life, one that will carefully develop those traits of character so well developed in the Prophet, is an incentive to Relief Society members everywhere. Every child, if properly nurtured in the home, will be better equipped to respond to calls of leadership which may come to him—whether in the Church, the community, or the nation. Deseret News Press Phone EMpire 4-2581 31 Richards St. Salt Lake City 1, Utah RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—JULY 1956 Fae Vlodorn Cookery FENNEL (FoEnicuLtum Dutce) Elizabeth Williamson WE ET fennel is an annual herb, not usually included in the kitchen herb gardens, but once started it becomes an old standby, often seeding itself. Fennel needs a sunny exposure and will grow tall (two to four feet high) and feathery. It makes a pretty background in the garden. Originally fennel came from the Mediterranean area. The Romans used it as a vegetable. They also dried the leaves and extracted the juice from the stalks. The juice was used for eye medicine and for stomach disorders. Fennel is still commonly used in Italian cookery. The early English used the extract in drinks supposed to make obese people lose weight and become thin. The most common American use of fennel is for a sauce to be used with boiled fish. It provides a sharp and unusual flavor. If you have never tried this herb, you will experience a new thrill in herb cookery. It is also good with white beans, salads, soups, and sauces. The dried seeds are used in seasoning pickles, cake, and cookies. 'The stalks are good for eating raw. ORSON PRATT PARLEY PRATT From the writings of Orson & Parley Pratt 1. Berry Wherever you were born, that land shall be Home to your heart—beside the rolling sea, In mountain country or the wandering plain, A part of it shall stay with you, remain To color sunrise or the day's bright close; Your mind can feel it there, emotion knows No other background that can give you peace, That sure sense of belonging, heart's release. If you should wander far from climbing hills, Or from a rock-bound coast where water spills The foam of mounting waves upon the sand, If you should leave the rolling, green-spread land, No matter where you go, it follows you, Like treasured dreams forever breaking through The round of time, and you will feel the lack, The haunting need of it that calls you back. Luacine Savage Clark, wife of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., died August 2, 1944. Relief Society was one of Sister Clark's major interests from the time she was eighteen. She used her many fine leadership abilities and other talents freely in Relief Society service. She is remembered as the author of an operetta, of poems, and delightful stories for children. Edith Grant Young, wife of Elder Clifford E. Young, Assistant to the Council of the Twelve, passed away August 20, 1947. Sister Young, a daughter of President Heber J. Grant, was well known for her beautiful voice and musical abilities which she was always willing to use for the service and enjoyment of others. She was a loyal supporter of the women's work of the Church.
