Sharp, President Belle S. Spafford, and Counselor Velma N. Simonsen. Left to right: a beautiful hand-painted plaque showing trees native to the continent of Australia; a unique lamp in the form of a ship's wheel, made of different woods with a shade painted with Australian scenes and animals; a Koala bear; and a second interesting plaque which pictures the life of the Australian aborigines. Picture on the opposite page (left to right): President Belle S. Spafford, Counselor Marianne C. Sharp, and Counselor Velma N. Simonsen. President Spafford holds an unusual lacquerware tray decorated with blue pearl inlay sent by the Okinawa District Relief Society of the Northern Far East Mission. In the center is an exquisite Meissen vase, an example of the famed porcelains of Germany. The artistic vase is a gift from the Relief Society of the East German Mission. The beautiful table in the foreground is a gift of the Samoan Mission Relief Society. It is made of five native Samoan woods, and the center of the table is formed by an intricately engraved brass tray of Fijian art. Page 511 The East German Mission Preston R. Nibley HE East German Mission, which comprised the provinces of Mecklenburg, Saxony, Brandenburg, Pommern, Schliesen, and East and West Prussia, was formed in August 1937, with Elder Philemon Kelly as president. President Kelly presided until January 1, 1938, when he was succeeded by Elder Alfred C. Rees. President Rees presided until July 30, 1939, when he was succeeded by Elder Thomas E.. McKay. President Joseph Fielding Smith and Mrs. Smith visited the East German Mission in July 1939 and held meetings in Konigsberg, Berlin, and Chemnitz. Ominous threats of the great World War II, in August 1939, caused the First Presidency to request that all American missionaries should leave the East German and West German Missions. The supervision of their exodus, of their gathering at Copenhagen, Denmark, and their subsequent return to the United States, was the task of President Joseph Fielding Smith, who established headquarters at Copenhagen. During the great war, which broke out in all its fury in September 1939, the activities of the East German Mission were directed by 'Thomas E.. McKay, by correspondence from Salt Lake City. By Ewing Galloway, New York ZWINGER NATIONAL GALLERY OF PAINTINGS DRESDEN, SAXONY, EAST GERMANY Page 512 THE EAST GERMAN MISSION 513 ae By Ewing Galloway, New York STATUE OF GOETHE AND SCHILLER, WEIMAR, EAST GERMANY At the close of the war, Elder Ezra Taft Benson of the Council of the Twelve, visited Berlin, as a representative of the Church, in March 1946. His work was largely that of bringing relief to the suffering members of the Church, many of whom were behind "the Iron Curtain." In November 1946, the East German Mission was again organized, with Elder Walter Stover of Salt Lake City as president. He established headquarters in Berlin and began the work of reconstructing the mission, amidst the ruins of war. Hight districts were formed: Erzgebirge, Zwickau, Berlin, Thueringen, Dresden, Leipzig, Schwerin, and Chemnitz. Much difficulty was experienced by President Stover in visiting the members in the Russian Zone. President Stover was released in June 1951 and was succeeded by EIder Arthur Glaus. President Glaus was succeeded in November 1953 by Elder Herold L. Gregory, who presides at the present time. Ninety-seven Relief Society organizations were reported in December 1955, with 3,727 members. Mary Ethel EF. Gregory presides over the East German Mission Relief Society. Note: The cover for this Magazine is a view of the Havel River, Berlin, Germany. | See also "Recipes From the East German Mission," page 528. The Gift of Love Rosa Lee Lloyd EGGY Rockwood put a heapP ing bowl of cereal in front of her little son, seven-yearold Juddy, and listened while his daddy questioned him as they drank their fruit juice. "What would you like for your birthday next week, Juddy? Name anything less than a ride to the moon and we'll consider it." Juddy swallowed hard and put his spoon down without tasting his cereal. "Two things!" he said fiercely. "Two things I can't have!" "Hey, fellow!" Bill chided him. "Don't be a defeatist. How do you know you can't have them before you ask for them?" "T know," he repeated. "I know I can't." His little chin squared off stubbornly, but not before Peggy had seen his lip quiver and his eyes blink hard. Her blue eyes shadowed tenderly as she shook her head at her husband. He must not scold Juddy now. She had known that something was troubling him, but she realized that scolding him or teasing him would only make him freeze up and keep his secret from them. "All right, Son," Bill agreed. "You can tell your mother later. Right now let's see if I can eat more cereal than you can. Yesterday you beat me. Remember?" Juddy picked up his spoon, smiling at his dad. They are so much alike, Peggy thought, her heart swelling with love for them. 'They had the same smooth brown hair, pensive brown Page 514 eyes and wistful, sensitive mouths contradicting the firm square line of their chins. They were all she had in the world, because her parents had both been killed when she was three and there were no aunts or uncles or grandparents, only an insurance policy that paid for her at the Service Center until she was old enough to make her own way. Then she had met Bill and he was an orphan, too. No wonder having each other and Juddy was always a miracle to them. After breakfast Juddy took his football out to the back garden, and Peggy watched him from the kitchen window. He waved gaily as Bill backed the car out of the garage and headed for the highway. 'Then he slumped down in a dejected heap on the lawn and stared wistfully at the big house next door. | had been very lonesome since his little friend Warren Hodge from across the street had gone to visit his grandmother in Colorado. Watching him now, Peggy was quite sure she knew one of the things he would like for his birthday. That was to roller skate around the wide veranda that encircled the big house. Mrs. LaRue's house, with its southern architecture, its draped windows, had a wide, inviting veranda that none of the other houses on Hill Street could afford; the kind where guests strolled in the purple twilight before one of Mrs. LaRue's famous Newburgh dinners; the kind of veranda a little boy would dearly love to whiz around on his roller skates. THE GIFT OF LOVE But, of course, Peggy told herself, with a proud lift of her shortclipped blond head, she couldn't permit Juddy to ask Mrs. LaRue if he could skate on her veranda the way he did before she moved in last spring. You simply couldn't ask a woman like Mrs. LaRue for a favor, especially when she had treated him as though he must not intrude in her life of parties and long week ends with her guests from all over the world. Peggy nibbled her lip as she put the breakfast dishes back in the cabinet and thought about Mrs. LaRue and her big house. It was an old house, Bill had told her, built about thirty years ago by the Cornwall family who had later moved to California. It was the only house on Hill Street for many years, until a real estate company built a row of modest little houses on each side of it, and she and Bill had bought one of them last spring. The big house had then been vacant and Juddy had had a grand time roller skating on the veranda. He had come to think of it as belonging to him. Bill had forbidden him to skate on the sidewalks and streets because they were too steep and the traffic was very heavy on the crossroad below. The path around their own house was graveled, so there was now no place for him to skate, since Mrs. LaRue had bought the house. Peggy remembered how she and Juddy had watched the men unload the huge vans of furniture. Then a car had come with the servants, and a week later Mrs. LaRue herself had arrived. Peggy's lips folded in as she thought of her first sight of her 5a5 new neighbor. Juddy had been on the curb, and she had been sitting on her own front steps when Mrs. LaRue drove up alone in her lengthy blue and cream-colored convertible. Her dress had been blue, too, the color of the car, and her stole was honey-dyed mink. Peggy thought, as she glanced quickly away, that her hair was too black and her mouth too red and her skin too satin-smooth—as though she was afraid to smile for fear it would crack. However Juddy had smiled at Mrs. LaRue and run toward her, impulsively. "Hello," he had called, his eyes beaming friendliness. "I'm Juddy. I live over there. That's my mother on the steps." Mrs. LaRue had turned to look at him, but her hand had gone nervously to her throat. "Oh, no!" she had said almost to herself. "I didn't think there would be children living close." Then she looked at Peggy and tried to smile. "T only meant...." her voice stumbled. "Well — I really don't know what I meant. Please forgive me. I'm very tired." HE had hurried into the house and Juddy had run to his mother and thrown his arms around her. His eyes had been dark question marks as he looked up to her. "She's tired," Peggy had soothed hini. "Maybe she has driven a long way." "But I liked her," he insisted. "I liked her face." What could Juddy see to like about her face? Peggy had asked herself. 516 "Why?" she had questioned him, pressing his head against her breast. "Because she has a sorry face," he had answered, slowly. "It made me sorry, too." "A sorry face," she had repeated wonderingly. Juddy often hit upon the very word to describe something that eluded her. "T wish she liked me, Mama," he added over a sigh. "You must make her like you, Juddy," she had told him. "You must show her you can be a good neighbor by staying in your own yard until you are invited over there. And don't yell when you are near her windows. When you meet her give her a friendly smile, but don't try to make her notice you. Just be a good little boy and she will like you in time." But a month had gone by and still Mrs. LaRue hadn't been friendly to Juddy nor to her or Bill. And there were times when Peggy was sure that Mrs. LaRue deliberately turned her head away when she saw Juddy playing in the driveway. "We won't bother her," Peggy had told Bill. But they were unhappy to have a close neighbor who avoided them. OW Peggy looked out of the window again, but she couldn't see Juddy anywhere. She shrugged her shoulders determinedly. She must not worry about him so much. No, Peggy thought again, they couldn't live Juddy's life for him, but they could give him a happier life than either she or Bill had had, a life filled with love and surrounded by happy people. It bothered her because Juddy wanted, so terribly, for Mrs. LaRue to like him. RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 She felt anger mounting in her. What did Juddy see in Mrs. LaRue that made him so eager to have her notice him? She and Bill had always hovered over him and guarded him and tried to give him everything a little boy could want. But, lately, nothing they did seemed to answer a longing in him, Peggy was dusting the figurines on the mantle when the front doorbell rang. She smoothed her apron and hurried to answer it. She caught her breath sharply. Juddy, looking guilty and pale, was standing there beside Mrs. LaRue who was holding his football in both hands! Her blue satin housecoat was buttoned crookedly as though she had put it on in a hurry. There was a great smear of dirt across the housecoat as though she had been pulled through a mudpuddle! "He was out there in the street," she said tightly. "I saw him from my window. He shouldn't play in the street. You should know better. A car was coming so I ran and pushed him." "She fell down," Juddy added in a small voice. Mrs. LaRue's lips trembled and she bent her head. Peggy squeezed her eyes shut. Juddy had been playing in the street! She reached yearningly for him. "How awful!" she breathed. Thought he was in the back yard." The two women looked at each other. She's all shaken up, Peggy thought, with a twinge. That was a bad fall. "He might've been killed," Mrs. LaRue choked. "Don't you young a | THE GIFT OF LOVE mothers realize how dangerous it is?" Peggy couldn't breathe as she stared at Mrs. LaRue whose darkly beautiful eyes were deep with fear and shock. Juddy lifted his hand and brushed the dirt from her housecoat. "'T'm sorry," he murmured. "T only went after my football. It bounced when I ran." "Juddy!"" Peggy scolded. "Your Daddy will be very cross. You know you're not to skate or play in the street!" "Daddy said not to skate in the street," he protested. Mrs. LaRue looked down at him, ~ reproachfully, but there was something in her eyes almost like flowers growing under ice. "If you have to skate..." her voice loosened a little, "you can use my veranda in the mornings. Anytime from eight till twelve. You'll be safe there." Juddy's eyes were almost too big for his face. "Gee, thanks!" he "Thanks, Mrs. LaRue. Nice." Before Peggy could thank her, Mrs. LaRue brushed past Juddy and hurried down the steps, but his eyes followed her until she had disappeared through her front door. EGGY felt weak and trembly as she went slowly back into the house and took down Juddy's skates from the high shelf in the closet. How could she ever repay Mrs. LaRue? What could she do for a woman who had everything in the world and didn't need the friendliness of her neighbors? Peggy was determined to show her gratitude grinned. You're real 517 to her. Maybe if she baked a pie or one of her real fancy jelly cakes, it might be acceptable. Then she remembered that Mrs. LaRue had a cook and a maid and was noted for her delicious dinners. But Juddy didn't question what he could do to show his appreciation. Peggy watched from the window as he put the skates on the lawn beside the rose arbor. 'Then he reached up and picked the prettiest pink rosebuds and, carefully holding them in his little hand, he walked determinedly up to Mrs. LaRue's front door and rang the bell. Peggy turned away from the window, squeezing back the tears. She couldn't bear it if Mrs. LaRue refused the roses or sent him away without a word or even a smile. But a few minutes later she heard the rhythmic grind of his roller skates as he whizzed around the veranda, and it was music in her heart. She must think of some way to show Mrs. LaRue how grateful she was. THE summer days sped by. Juddy skated in the mornings and played in his own back yard in the afternoon with the neighbor children. Peggy waited patiently for him to talk about Mrs. LaRue and how she liked the flowers he took her each morning, but he didn't mention her. He seemed to have a precious secret that he didn't share with anyone. | She and Bill decided to respect his silence, but Wednesday when they were having sandwiches and milk together at noon, she asked, as though the thought had just occurred to her: "Shall we invite Mrs. 518 LaRue to your birthday party Fnday?" Juddy took a bite and chewed it a long time. 'Thoughtfully. "Let me ask her, Mama," he said at last. "She talks to me now. Every morning. But she might be busy that day," he added with a deep frown. The next night Peggy was surprised to hear him crying in his bedroom. Bill had gone in to say goodnight and hear his prayers and she had heard them talking in low tones and then Juddy began to cry. After awhile Bill came out with his brows puzzled together and his mouth pulled down into that funny way when something disturbed him. "Beats me!" he sighed, lounging in the chair beside her. "I can't understand my own son. There's something on his mind, Peg. But he won't tell me. Do you know what it is?" Peggy shook her head. "No, I don't, Bill. Id tell you if I did. He's been so happy the past weeks skating on the veranda." "Yeah. He loves that. But there's something else. When I listened to his prayers — well — guess what he said? He told the Lord he didn't need any toys or new clothes for his birthday. Then he said that the Lord already knew what he really needed because he'd asked for it all summer." Peggy's eyes met Bill's. "What could he want that's so important?" she questioned. "What does he need that we can't give him?" Bill unwound his long legs and stood up. "Beats me!" he repeated. "T'll bring home something for his party RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 tomorrow. Say! Do you think he might want a pet of some kind? A puppy or a kitten or even a snake?" Peggy shook her head, smiling. "No. He said it was something we couldn't get for him." Y three o'clock the next afternoon the garden was crowded with children who had come to Juddy's party. Peggy thought she had never heard such a rowdy group. She glanced apprehensively at Mrs. LaRue's windows, hoping the noise wouldn't bother her too much. "We'll cut the cake early and serve the ice cream," she told Alice who had come to help her. "That will quiet them." Alice smiled back in her knowing way. "For awhile," she said. "You can't stop a whirlwind, Peg." "No," Peggy agreed as she watched the tumbling boys showing off to the little girls who squealed with delight. "But we can stuff them so full they can't squeal." "What time is Bill coming?" Alice asked. "Any time now," she answered. "T hope he's here when Juddy opens his presents — oh, here he is now. Hi, there, Mr. Rockwood. You're just in time for the main event. Help us get them toned down so we can serve." Bill tossed his hat on a chair and took a whistle from his pocket. His eyes sparked up. "Dave Grant at the office gave me this to use this afternoon. Said he always uses one at his children's parties." He gave a long shrill whistle, then THE GIFT OF LOVE two short ones, and the children turned to listen. "All of you sit down on the lawn," Peggy called. "Because we don't have enough chairs...." Her voice trailed off and she stood there silent with astonishment. Mrs. LaRue was walking down the graveled path. She looked lovely in a white linen dress with a tiny bunch of flowers pinned at her waist. Her dark eyes had a bright new glow, and her lips curved gently as she smiled at them all. She doesn't have a sorry face any more, Peggy thought. "Come in," Peggy finally spoke, hurrying to Mrs. LaRue, catching her hands in her own. "Juddy will be so pleased." Peggy looked around the garden for him, but he was already leaping toward Mrs. LaRue. "Here, Daddy, come quick!" he called. "Here's a surprise for us on my birthday." The children sat very still, looking at Mrs. LaRue as Juddy took her hand and pulled her gently inside the garden. "T hope you won't mind," she smiled at Peggy and Bill. "You see — Juddy told me what he wanted most for his birthday. So I told him if I decided to come I would make his wish come true." She bit her lip and drew a deep breath. Peggy felt her own heart beating up in her throat. Mrs. LaRue's voice was low and sweet like a lullaby. "Juddy has been praying for a grandmother," she said. "So I have come to tell him that I will be his grandmother." The garden was suddenly hushed in a kind of quiet glory. Peggy 519 heard the distant whistle of the four o'clock train in the valley below. Bill cleared his throat, and she heard him say in a husky voice: "That's mighty nice of you, Mrs. LaRue. We surely do appreciate it and everything else you've done for Juddy." "We surely do," Peggy managed. "We'll always love you for it." Juddy beamed up at Mrs. LaRue. "See?" he said. "I told you they would. I told you they needed me to have a grandmother like Warren and all the others have. Boy! Am I lucky!" Mrs. LaRue touched his head. "Tm lucky, too, Juddy,' she murmured. "I have a nice warm feeling that I haven't had for many years. Not since...." Her eyes met theirs with a brave steadiness. "Not since I lost my own little son in an accident on the highway. I couldn't bear to look at children after that. It hurt so. But Juddy made me notice him. He wouldn't give up." Peggy bent her head. She was so ashamed because she had misjudged Mrs. LaRue. That's what happens, she thought, her throat aching, when you merely look at the outside of people and don't know what is in their hearts. But Juddy had seen into her heart and loved Her. "Now look," Bill was suggesting, in his deep, capable voice, "Juddy, it's your birthday so you can cut your cake." "Not me," he shouted, reaching for Mrs. LaRue. "I want everyone to see my grandmother cut my cake. Boy, does she cut the big pieces! You'll see, Daddy. She knows what kids like!" Vacation Mecca on the Rio Grande Nell Murbarger NE of the newest and least 8) known of our nation's playgrounds, Big Bend National Park, lifts above the dry plains of Western Texas like a miracle island in a sea of grass. Slashed by deep, spectacular gorges, softened by flower-filled canyons, and shaded by the bold summits of the Chisos Mountains, here is a vacationer's land of delight! More than four centuries have passed since Cabeza de Vaca _ became the first white man of modern times to look upon this strange mountain empire along the Rio Grande, but only in recent years has the Big Bend country become readily accessible to motorists. Chief factor contributing to that end was the paving of State Route 227, leading south to the park from U. S. Highway go, at Marathon. After dipping and winding for eighty miles through a rough, volcanic region, Route 227 reaches its southern terminus in a scenic, pleasantly wooded cove, at the foot of high Casa Grande Peak. In addition to park administrative offices, here are provided a few tourist cottages, a postoffice, store, cafe, gasoline station, and campground — a road's end cluster of buildings which represents the largest settlement in a land area larger than Massachusetts! Even more remarkable is the fact that only rods from the village lies the borderland of a wild empire virtually unchanged from the time of the exploring Spaniard Cabeza de Vaca — an area still picturesque and unspoiled by civilization. Situated in a great elbow of the Page 520 Rio Grande, 300 miles southeast of El Paso, Big Bend National Park ranges in altitude from 2000 feet on the river flats to more than a mile and a half above sea level in the Chisos, and even midsummer finds temperatures singularly pleasant in the headquarters area and higher elevations — the mercury seldom rising above eighty-seven degrees. In winter, the Big Bend country enjoys the advantages of a latitudinal position nearly 400 miles farther south than Los Angeles; and although flurries of snow may fall on the highest summits, temperatures in the middle-to-lower elevations remain pleasantly warm, with healthful dry air and bright sunshine. Next to climatic factors, one of the chief matters to consider in choosing a suitable vacation spot is the question of keeping occupied —the business of "what to do?" In that connection, it seems only fair to issue a word of warning: the Big Bend is still undeveloped along lines of both plushy elegance and hurdy-gurdy cheapness. Persons whose vacationing pleasure depends upon luxurious accommodations and proximity to golf courses, dance halls, moving picture theatres, and midway-type amusements, will find other resort areas more to their liking. Conversely, those whose greatest vacationing pleasure lies in the association with nature, in hiking, horseback riding, amateur exploring, sightseeing, photography, and plain, ordinary relaxing in an atmosphere of peace and quiet, will find VACATION MECCA ON THE RIO GRANDE Nell Murbarger 521 LOOKING DOWN JUNIPER CANYON FROM TOTEM ROCK, BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK, TEXAS here an all-season vacation land unlike any other in the United States. GURE footed saddle horses are available for rent at reasonable rates, and from the vicinity of headquarters, a network of safe-hiking and horseback trails fans out through beautifully wooded canyons to many places of interest and spectacular viewpoints. One such trail (restricted to hikers) leads to Totem Rock, near the high, exposed summit of Lost Mine Peak; another foot and horse trail leads to "The Window," a perpendicular rock slit commanding a view of thousands of acres of wild land on both sides of the Rio Grande. Persons ambitious enough to undertake a full-day's horseback ride will find a worthy destination in the South Rim; while packmules and burros are available for overnight, or even more extensive trips. Nature lovers in almost every category will find any of these trips productive of myriad delights. Quail 522 and wild doves add their plaintive notes to the wild concert led by mockingbirds and warblers, and the patient bird watcher even may be favored by the sight of a rare hooded oriole or blue-throated hummingbird. More than 200 species of birds have been catalogued here. March to June finds a dozen species of cactuses flaunting their vivid blooms on rocky knolls; April is the month when Spanish daggers (yuccas) lift their spikes of creamy white bells; and with June and July, the tall heads of the century plants burst into golden glory — their flower stems several times taller than a man! Even late autumn finds the canyons a massed delight of wild flowers and ferns. Forest trees found in the park include Arizona cypress, Douglas fir, Ponderosa and Mexican pinion pines, alligator-barked, and weeping junipers, Texas madrones, maples, and several species of oaks, and, in these environs, more than sixty species of animals make their homes. Inviting one-day side trips easily accessible in the family car, include a thirty-five-mile jaunt to Santa Elena Canyon, where the Rio Grande winds tortuously through a gorge, eighteen miles in length, with rock walls rising sheerly on either side to heights as much as a quarter of a mile above the river! One. Wall of this fantastic gorge stands in Mexico — the other in the United States. A short way down river is Boquillas Canyon, of comparable depth; and Mariscal, deepest and most spectacular of three river-hewn slits. En route to Santa Elena Canyon, the autoist may include side jaunts to the old ghost towns of 'Terlingua RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 and Study Butte. For more than fifty years one of the nation's major sources of mercury, Terlingua once boasted the largest population of any mining town in Texas. Only a few old buildings and mine dumps remain. Another interesting side trip may be made into the Grapevine Hills, a weird region of balanced rocks, picturesque stone formations, and strangely eroded spires. Other points of interest in the park include a fossil deposit which has yielded a wide variety of prehistoric marine life, including oysters thirty inches in length, clams four feet across, and a_ forty-five-foot stone crocodile. Long before the coming of American explorers and_ settlers, superstitious Spanish folk had applied to these mountains the name "Chisos," meaning "phantoms" or "ghosts." Although doubtless inspired by the long, gauzy, cloud streamers, which so often wrap about the rock-crowned summit of Casa Grande Peak, it isn't at all difficult to invest that word with a meaning less materialistic. After spending a few days and nights in this still, brooding land of great heights and dark depths, it becomes strangely easy to imagine a figure of the long-ago shuffling along the Lost Mine trail, or sitting under the friendly pines looking out across the jumbled wilderness of the Sierra del Carmen to the distant mountains of Mexico, ranged tier upon blue tier. Neither is it difficult to imagine the former inhabitant watching the serrated peaks as sunset clothes them in crimson and gold, soon blended to royal purple and darkened, at last, to a soft robe of midnight velvet. Page 525 OQ EDITORIAL 9 VOL. 43 AUGUST 1956 She Priceless Gift of Peace ON the evening before the crucifixion, the Savior stood in the midst of his eleven faithful disciples who had unswervingly followed him for about three years, albeit with little understanding of his role as the Savior of the world. Heavy with impending events waiting for fulfillment, Jesus looked upon those whom the Father had given him out of the world and in love bestowed a parting gift on them—a gift which awaits each one today, if he will but accept it. While still one with them, Christ promised: Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid (John 14:27). As with all gifts from the eternal worlds, this gift must be earned to be possessed, but it is offered freely to all. Every Latter-day Saint wonian may possess this peace deep in her soul, which will constantly guide her through the shoals of everyday living to a rock-fast haven in which she guards her knowledge of the love of her Eternal Father for her, and of the mission of his Son, her Savior. Through righteous living, she may comfort herself with the words and live the injunction, '... Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid." Although the atomic age has Page 526 brought a new fear into hearts, and peace in the human soul is _ badly needed, women of all times and ages in the world's history have been tried and tested, and the blessing of peace has always been of greatest value. A wife and mother is at times sorely tried. When disagreements and misunderstandings arise, her emotions and feelings may become almost desperate. It is then she should recall the words of the Savior promising her peace, and pray and work with herself. When she humbles herself and takes the guidance of the spirit—then this gift floods her being and her heart becomes calm and unafraid. If a Latter-day Saint woman takes the time, when her feelings are sore, to sit down and read the scriptures, that also helps to bring calmness to her. Peace again may be banished from her heart when sickness strikes her family; however, by recalling the words of the Savior in his great hour of anguish, "... Not my will, but thine, be done" (Luke 22:42), and by placing implicit faith in the Lord, leaving the outcome to him, a woman may regain peace within her soul. What mother is there that does not need the "peace... Which passeth all understanding" as she tries to lead her children in the path of righteousness? It is a fact that when a mother's heart is worried EDITORIAL and troubled, when household cares press heavily upon her, and other responsibilities almost overwhelm her, then her actions and words will reflect the state of her inward feelings for "... Out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh" (Matt. 12:34). Think of the difference in the words of advice from a mother whose heart is full of uncertainty, fear, worry, and dissatisfaction, with the guiding words which come from a mother whose 527 heart is untroubled, unafraid, and at peace. Such a wise mother looks beyond her anxieties of the moment, household pressures, and multiplicity of duties, to keep ever foremost in her heart the great goal of an eternal marriage and the eternity of family relationships dependent upon righteous living. Living for this goal, the gift of peace radiates within her soul. —M. C. S. Grandfa ther s Wagon Enola Chamberlin Here is Grandfather's wagon In which he crossed the plains. It weathered the drought of the desert, It weathered the mountain rains. But with houses crowding together, It is only in the way— How long can the wagon weather The indifference of today? She Art of Worthwhile Waiting Pauline Henderson He' wonderful it would be if, at the end of our life, we could add up all the hours, days, and years that we have spent just waiting for something, and be allowed to add them to our total span of life! To say "I hate waiting," however, is to say in effect, "I hate living," for while we wait, life is going on and we are growing older. If we believe that life is good and worthwhile, then it must naturally follow that life is too precious to waste even one minute in the state of bored frustration that to most of us is synonymous with waiting. How many times do we say, "If I only had more time to read!" and then, the next time we are forced to sit and wait, spend the time in mental condemnation of the waiting instead of reading. I know a woman whose wide knowledge astonished me because I knew that she had had only a grade-school education and was the busy mother of a growing family. Then one day I saw her collection of paper-backed books by well-known authors. "T always carry one with me in my purse," she told me, "to read when I have to wait for a bus or at the dentist with the children, or anyplace." Yet it is not necessary to read in order to benefit from these brief periods of waiting. We hear much talk today of the too fast pace we are living. We are told that we hurry too much—telax too little. But even the fastest paced life has its periods of enforced waiting, time which is generally spent in a state of acute impatience that only increases the tension of our lives. How much more profitable it would be to use this time for relaxation —a sort of mental unwinding —a time to let go—to meditate — yes — even to pray, for it is not necessary to be on one's knees in order to pray effectively. Most of us, at least once in our lives, are faced with a period of prolonged waiting. Perhaps it is for the promotion that will bring us greater secunty — or the return of good health after a time of illness — or the agonizing waiting for the return of a loved one who is away. These are the times that wrench our souls, when frustration builds up within us to a high point, as we wait to reach the culmination of our desires. We spend our time in a state of suspended animation, and each day becomes merely a deary succession of hours to be lived through as quickly as possible. What a shameful waste of this wonderful gift of life! The time that we must spend in waiting is an integral part of our lives — time that, once wasted, will never come again — a time to be lived and enjoyed and made the most of — not wasted in idly marking time. When a situation reaches the point when there is nothing more to be done except wait, then we are automatically released from the necessity of doing anything about it. The struggle is ended, and we are free to give ourselves to something else and let time itself take over. This is the time to take on something new — preferably something as unrelated to the thing we are waiting for as possible. 'That course in music that we have always dreamed of taking someday, or the hobby we have always wanted to pursue —or best of all—seek out someone less fortunate than ourselves and lend a helping hand. If we will spend our waiting time in such a manner, we will be almost surprised to find one. Day that the waiting has ended — our dream has become a reality, and we are ready to enjoy it with a fresh outlook and a new sense of values. Page 530 A Rose Without a Shorn Irene McCullough OLLIE heard the door slam as Jim left the house. What's the use, she thought, he's all wound up again, and when he is that way everything I do is wrong as far as he is concerned. She was too angry to cry. She felt all tied _ up inside. If only she could discuss her problem with someone, it might help. It would be useless to talk to her mother. She invariably took Mollie's part and Jim did not stand a chance. Aunt Margaret was just as bad. There was Millie, across the street, but she had so many cares of her own, it would be unfair to burden her with any more. Besides, she did not want her affairs discussed around the neighborhood. Suddenly she thought of Aunt Rachael. Aunt Rachael never gossiped. She was over eighty years old, and the town had practically grown up around her. She had had many ups and downs in her life— mostly downs — and yet she had come through smiling. Surely she could advise her. Mollie hurriedly cleaned up the house and started out to see Aunt Rachael. It was just a short distance, and the cool, damp air felt refreshing against her flushed cheeks. "Come in and sit down," called out Aunt Rachael as soon as Mollie opened the door. "It's so nice to have someone drop in and chat with me. I don't get out as often as I used to." Mollie could not hold back her pent-up emotions any longer. She dropped into the nearest chair and burst into tears. Aunt Rachael did not say a word — just let her sob it out. "Oh, Aunt Rachael, I'm sorry; I'm really ashamed to act this way." "That's all ght, dear, that's all right. It's just nature's way of easing the pressure when you are overtaxed. Now, what's troubling you?" "It's Jim — he is so cross and irritable lately that I can hardly stand it. No matter how hard I try, I don't seem to please him. Maybe I never was meant for him; maybe he is tired of me; maybe I should leave him; maybe...." "Maybe," interrupted Aunt Rachael, "he is working too hard. I heard he got the contract to put in the new road down in Fairview. They say that is a pretty tough job." "He has been working hard, Aunt Rachael. It's nearly impossible to get dependable help nowadays, and every time he leaves the job, something goes wrong. He never gets home until late and has to leave early in the morning." "Ruth came in to see me yesterday." softly said Aunt Rachael, artfully trying to change the conversation. "She said she had just been over to see your new living-room set and that it was the prettiest one she had ever seen." "It is beautiful. I didn't want Jim to buy it because I felt it was too expensive, but Jim could see I Page 53] 532 preferred it, so he had them send it out." "T want to run in and get a peek at it myself as soon as I can,' said Aunt Rachael. "These new sofas are surely attractive. But, speaking of Ruth, she looked so tired and thin yesterday, I couldn't help feeling sorry for her." "She does look worn out," replied Mollie. "Her husband is a good-natured man, but he can't seem to hold down a job for long. Ruth tends the neighbors' children, takes in sewing and does all her own work. No wonder she's tired and thin." UNT Rachael sighed, then began slowly and thoughtfully: "T think I understand her problems pretty well. You know Frank, my husband, was the kindest man that ever lived, but he just could not seem to get out of low gear. I decided to leave him once. I had three children then, and John, the eldest, was only six years old. We had one of the best farms in the valley, but our farm never produced as much as the neighboring farms. Fach time it was our turn to irrigate, we lost a portion of the water because Frank was always late opening up the headgates. We could have raised twice as many chickens, pigs, and cows as we did, but Frank never seemed to get around to it. But he could always find time to sit down and tell the children stories, or whittle them a whistle or a flipper, go fishing or pick berries with them. I had scolded him so much about his inability to get things done that I was beginning to have an awful disposition." Aunt Rachael leaned back in her RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 chair and seemed to be looking back through the years. "One day I decided that we could no longer go on the way we were. I put on my bonnet and went to see mother. She lived about a mile down the road. Mother was one of the first pioneers to settle in the valley. Her life had not been an easy one. She had _ walked across the plains in 1854. She lost her first three children with diphtheria. Father was away from home a great deal of the time, and mother had to shoulder the responsibility of the farm and home. I walked into her living room and sat down. I told her I was going to bring the three children and come home to live; that I just could not struggle with Frank's careless ways any longer. She listened until I had finished my story, then took me by the arm and led me out onto the front porch and said: ""Rachael, you married Frank for time and eternity. You go straight home and don't come back. You will never live to find a rose without some thorns.' Without more ado, she walked back into the house and closed the door. "T walked slowly down the steps and toward home. I thought about Frank. Would I trade him for anyone else I knew? I couldn't think of a soul I would rather have married, even a very ambitious one. How about the children — would they want to leave their father? They went to him for everything. It was Frank who took time to hear their tales of woe, bind up a stubbed toe or cut finger, and comfort and advise them. When they were sick, it was Frank who got up at A ROSE WITHOUT A THORN night and watched over them with 533 "Mollie, you will never find a rose without a thorn." tender care. 'They didn't call for me—they called for Frank. It dawned on me that I, too, had my thorns. Surely I could fill in for the weaknesses in Frank as he was filling in for me.... When Frank died the meetinghouse was filled to overflowing — everyone loved him. He was the kindest man that ever lived, and I miss him more every day." Aunt Rachael's trembling old hand wiped a tear from her eye, then she managed a smile and said, Mollie got up and went over and kissed Aunt Rachael goodbye and hurriedly left for home. The children would soon be there for lunch and maybe Jim would run in for a sandwich. With a thankful prayer in her heart, and a new humility, Mollie spoke softly to herself: "T, too, never expect to find a rose without a thorn, nor am I one,' and she resolved to be a more understanding wife and count her blessings. A Sribute to the Singing Mothers Myree Daugherty pyoNezers of singing voices came to my ears, struck the chords of my heart, and penetrated the very depths of my soul. I thought it was a choir of angels, but I was here on earth, and angels do not dwell on earth. The singing continued and grew in volume. The words sent messages of love, of beauty, of adoration and praise. They spoke of mercy, of contentment, happiness and joy. And then faces began to take form before my eyes, and, gradually, one face became familiar. It was the face of a beautiful woman. She was singing, but it was different from most singing. The song was coming from her innermost heart; around her face seemed to shine a heavenly light. Behind her appearance, I could see a life of hardships and anxious moments, but, also, rising high above I could see courage, strength, faith, prayers, and finally success and peace of mind. And then I recognized the face to be that of my dear Mother, and then I knew the singing was coming from a group of angels. Yes, they were angels on earth. God had sent them here with a special callang and responsibility, and they have and still are fulfilling their duties in a complete way. They are here always to give us strength, and love, and courage. Srimming Celia Luce I trimmed my hollyhock plants. I could almost imagine them shuddering as I cut off long stalks of seeds. I could almost hear them saying, "I have done my share of work, and now you are trimming it all away. I will have the job to do all over again. Please stop and let me rest. I have done my share." But I went right on trimming. Untrimmed hollyhocks become dead sticks. I don't want dead sticks in my garden. Trimmed hollyhocks send out shoots in all sorts of new directions and start to blossom all over again. They stay young and vigorous until the killing frost, at last, finishes their work in the fall. I, like the hollyhocks, need trimming. I need to forget past deeds and look only to the future. I must see what new and interesting directions I can find for my efforts. Above all, I must keep busy in work that matters, I want my mind to stay young and vigorous, too. I never want-to become a dead stick. The midnight landscape Lightens, brightens, shimmers and glows, A silver rose! Unfolding in petaled bloom. Josephine Johnson Laker Specializes in Useful Hobbies OSEPHINE Johnson Laker, seventy years old, of Freedom, Wyoming, has enriched her life with hobbies and has contributed much beauty to the lives of her friends and relatives. 'Any hobby that gives happiness is a worthwhile hobby, but a useful hobby is a two-fold blessing," says Sister Laker, "and, anyway, I love variety." Quilting is a favorite hobby for Sister Laker, and she makes quilts in intricatepieced designs, in applique patterns, and in unusually beautiful quilted motifs on plain colors. Her "Flower-Basket" quilts have been much admired, and her ''Four-Flower"' quilts are beautifully designed in harmonizing tints on plain backgrounds. In one year, her sixty-ninth year, she made a quilt for each one of her five children. Sister Laker is an industrious "green-thumb" gardener, and she grows flowers indoors and outdoors, experimenting with seedlings and cuttings, and finding the best varieties suitable to the climate of beautiful Star Valley that is her home. She paints pictures, and is skilled in all the household arts. For many years she has been active in Relief Society, serving as a visiting teacher for twenty-two years, and assisting in lesson work, quilting and sewing projects. Triptych Vesta N. Sutherland Synopsis: Annie Griffith, whose father, with his family, has been called on a mission to the mountains to cut stone for the temple, is living with the Williams family in Salt Lake City, and is being educated with Marie Williams under the direction of a private tutor. Both Annie and Marie are very much interested in a neighbor, Parker Josephson, who leaves to attend an eastern university to learn to be a teacher of science. A farewell dinner for Parker is given at the Williams home, and Annie and Marie give him, as a going-away remembrance, a shirt which they have made. Both the girls are lonely after Parker has left, but they continue their studies, and finally a_letter arrives from Parker, addressed to both of the girls. HE next two years passed | quickly. Marie's seventeenth birthday was celebrated with a party in the Williams' home. Both girls had put their hair up. Annie, reluctantly, because Marie insisted. "Annie is content," Marie exclaimed, "to stay looking like a little girl for the next ten years." "It's not that," Annie said. "I just don't think it matters too much." "Matters!" Marie exclaimed. "Look in the glass and see how much it matters!" Annie had to admit there was some change when she looked at herself. The dark, soft, full wings of hair exposed the high cheekbones and the soft firm line of her chin. It made one notice the soft curve of her mouth and how wide and large her dark blue eyes were. Marie looked older, too, but she had always looked more mature for her age than Annie. Marie's father lamented that, in place of his two Page 538 little girls, two young women had come to stay. "Oh, do you really think so?" Marie had exclaimed happily, but Annie had felt a moment of sadness. She hadn't wanted to grow up away from her own family, but now she had, almost. The young people insisted Annie sing at Marie's party. After she had sung favorites that Marie's mother had taught her and Marie, she sang Welsh songs her father had taught her as a little girl. 'Then she protested she would sing no more and went out into the kitchen to help. Aunt Agnes came out of the pantry and patted Annie on the cheek. "You are a very extraordinary young lady, Annie. You should live in no one else's shadow." "Why, I don't," Annie said. Marie flung the door open. "Do hurry, Annie, they're waiting for refreshments. Oh, Annie, you sing so beautifully. If only I could do half the things you can do." "You can," Annie said. Marie sat on the window sill. "I can't. I can't sing as well, I can't play the piano as well, I'm not as smart, I can't sew as well; but I have the prettiest hair in the whole valle 'thd coat Agnes cleared her throat sharply. Marie twirled her skirts a little, watching them billow. "Annie says I am prettier than anyone, and you're always saying my heart is good." Annie laughed at her while Aunt Agnes struggled with indignation at HEART'S BOUNTY such vanity. "Well," Aunt Agnes finally sputtered, "if it comes to beauty, Annie'll make the boys stand on their hands soon enough. If you look twice at Annie, the second glance is worth a dozen of Miss Marie." GISTER Williams reproved Marie for being so anxious to run over to see Parker. "He has to visit with his family, first, Marie. We'll see him soon enough. You girls saw him come. I told him you were home working on our dresses. We should have made you go with us. He looks older, too. I don't think we could play tag with him anymore, if we weren't too grown up ourselves." There refreshments would be served. The music was lively and quick; the happy sound of a violin rose above the voices, and Annie's heart beat faster just hearing it. Everyone arrived on time, because no one wanted to miss any of the fun. Parker and his parents stood close to the door, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 greeting everyone while the music warmed up. Annie nodded her head quickly, while Marie's voice tinkled on. Parker did look older and steadier. But the little quirk about his mouth that told you any moment he might laugh, was still there. And he was as kind as ever. Annie moved on quickly, because people pressed behind her, and, under his eyes, she became all of a sudden very disconcerted. Marie's voice was in her ear. "Oh, Annie, I'm so glad Papa made us go with him and Mama. If I had gone with the Johnson family, Parker would have been terribly jealous over Billy Johnson, and it would have ruined everything. Just think, I have the first dance with Parker. Won't people be nodding their heads over that!" She tapped an impatient toe, while her skirts rippled like soft waves. The hall was soon filled with people, and Marie and Annie found themselves dancing all the sets. Annie thought how much her family would enjoy this party. Her parents loved dancing and were never - too tired to join in whenever music could be found. Annie felt as if she were floating instead of dancing to the music. It was so much fun. HEART'S BOUNTY She saw Parker start toward her twice, but both times she was claimed and had danced away before he reached her. Finally, the exhausted musicians had to take a rest, and the refreshment table began to be very busy. Annie dropped into a chair on the fringe of the crowd, while Samuel Taylor stood in line to bring her some refreshments. She had offered to help, but had been told it wasn't quite time for her turn. Annie smoothed her hair, which had become loosened with the dancing. At that moment Parker Josephson dropped into the chair beside her. "I suspect someone has already gone for something for you?" he asked. "Yes," Annie smiled. "IT thought you were going to save me a dance?" "Yes." "The very next one, then," Parker said. "Yes." Was that all she could say? Annie bit her lip. "Professor Peterson was saying just now that you'll make a wonderful teacher. Just another year here, isn't it?" ARKER looked at her too closely; it made even her simplest remarks difficult. "He's very kind, I'm sure." "Sister Williams says you're...." "T'm sure there can be nothing more dull than the extolling of my virtues, Parker." "You know you were difficult to know before I left, but now you're grown up, I'm afraid I'll have to begin getting acquainted with you all over again. You said you'd write, and you never did." Sail "You were just joking that day." "No more than when I told Marie she might write. She wrote me dozens of times." "Now you're teasing, as if we were still two little girls."' Annie stood up. "I really ought to find Sister Warner. I promised to help with the punch." "You can't go now." Parker pulled her down gently to the chair again. "See, the dancing is beginning. Besides, there's Sister Warner completing a set. There's no escape, you'll have to stay here beside me." Parker laughed at the color which was mounting in her face. "I always did like a girl who could blush," he said. It was a few minutes before the dances straightened into good sense for Annie, and she felt more composed. Parker was much too forward. But, perhaps, he felt more like a brother to Marie and herself, and that accounted for everything. Still, to be sitting beside him like this all this time and no one coming up! Though, of course, how could they with the dancing going on? There was poor Samuel with her punch at last, but he was stranded across the floor now. Marie would have loved being here. Oh, she thought remorsefully, where is Marie? Marie should be the one here certainly. She scarcely nodded when Parker murmured something about the skill of one of the dancers. She excused herself as soon as the music paused, not waiting for Parker's reply. She found Marie in the front hall by all the coats. "Where have you been?" Annie asked. "Shshsh," Marie whispered. ""Billy Johnson is simply wild with jeal- 542 ousy, because Parker danced with me first. He made me come out." "Not outside?" Annie grasped her arm. "Oh, no, just to the stairs. He's made me promise him the last dance, and I don't know what to do. I'm sure Parker will ask...." "Girls, girls." Aunt Agnes came from the kitchen. "They need your help now with the punch. Hurry, girls." Marie scowled and followed Annie to the end of the hall where the tables were. "Tl help you," Parker said, taking a huge pitcher from Annie. He had followed her to the tables. "I've still a dance to claim," he smiled. His hand brushed hers as he took the pitcher. NNIE. Bit her lip at her blush while Parker appreciated it. Then he was very serious and business-like, and insisted on helping tip up the big tubs that held the punch. Both Marie and Annie danced again with Parker, and then, because Marie was dancing the last dance with Billy Johnson, Parker insisted Annie dance it with him. "T could die," Marie whispered. "He's only dancing with me because he can't dance with you." Marie's face brightened. Then she sighed, "Papa's mad at me, anyway, for dancing so many times with Billy, but Billy does insist so." Marie danced off, and Annie turned to face Parker. "Sister Williams was saying you have just another year with them, and then your father and mother will be returning home." Parker looked at the heavy dark RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 hair and pale, smooth brow, but Annie's gaze remained downward. Annie found it an effort to meet Parker's eyes, and it made her very provoked with herself to feel so helpless. After all, he is going to marry Marie, probably; maybe even before I leave, so it is ridiculous to be so fainthearted about looking into another person's eyes, she told herself. Marie and Billy whirled past them. '"Marie's a very lovely dancer, isn't she?" Annie yearned to have the assurance with which Marie abounded. "She is, indeed," Parker smiled at her. Annie felt suddenly tired. She thought for a moment about the soft feather tick at home. "What is it?" Parker was asking. "Why have you withdrawn? The party isn't over." "Yes, it is," Annie said, and indeed the music was no longer playing. She made her way through the people to the Williams with Parker just behind her. After the dismissal prayer, Parker took her hands to say goodnight. Surely, he must feel them tremble, Annie thought. Then Marie came up suddenly with her wrap, and Parker had to help her with it. Marie and Annie returned home with the Williams. Everyone remarked what a_ nice party it had been. Annie fell silent. There were too many things to sort out in her mind and heart. She knew she could never, never, be disloyal to Marie whom she loved as a sister. She closed her eyes and pulled the robe more closely about her. The night was very cold.
