NOTES FROM THE FIELD 547 clea ) LESSON D N DEPARTMENT Sheology—Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon Lesson 42—Christ's Ministry Continued Elder Leland H. Monson (Text: The Book of Mormon: 3 Nephi, chapters 22-30) For Tuesday, November 6, 1956 Objective: To show that strict adherence to the Gospel Plan is necessary for eternal life. The Prophecies of Isaiah | spent considerable time discussing the scriptures with the Nephites. He told them to search the words of Isaiah saying, "".. A commandment I give unto you that ye search these things diligently; for great are the words of Isaiah" (3 Nephi 23:1). Jesus further quoted the prophecies of Isaiah, assuring the people that his kindness should not depart from Israel, that his covenant to his people should not be removed (3 Nephi 22:10), that no weapon directed against them should prosper. Addition of Samuel the Lamanite's Prophecy After Jesus had expounded all the scriptures unto them which they Page 548 had received, he said unto them: "... Behold other scriptures I would that ye should write, that ye have not." He said to Nephi,... Bring forth the record which ye have kept." After "... He cast his eyes upon them..." Jesus pointed out that the prophecies of Samuel the Lamanite that "... Many saints... Should arise from the dead, and should appear unto many, and should minister unto them... At the day that the Father should glorify his name in me..." (see 3 Nephi 23:6-9) had not been written in the record. So it was written as he commanded. Malachi's Words Given Jesus commanded also that they should write the words which the Father had given to Malachi. (See LESSON DEPARTMENT 3 Nephi chapters 24 and 25.) After they were written, then the Lord expounded them. These words of Malachi include the law of tithes and offerings and foretell of the coming of:... Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord; And he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers, lest I come and smite the earth with a curse (3 Nephi 25:5-6). The Savior told the people:... These scriptures, which ye have not with you, the Father commanded that I should give unto you; for it was wisdom in him that they should be given unto future generations (3 Nephi 26:2). Savior Expounds All Things From Beginning And he did expound all things, even from the beginning until the time that he should come in his glory — yea, even all things which should come upon the face of the earth, even until the elements should melt with fervent heat, and the earth should be wrapt together as a scroll, and the heavens and the earth should pass away; And even unto the great and last day, when all people, and all kindreds, and all nations and tongues shall stand before God, to be judged of their works, whether they be good or whether they be evil— If they be good, to the resurrection of everlasting life; and if they be evil, to the resurrection of damnation; being on a parallel, the one on the one hand and the other on the other hand, according to the mercy, and the justice, and the holiness which is in Christ, who was before the world began (3 Nephi 26:3-5). Mormon tells us:... There cannot be written in this book even a hundredth part of the things 549 which Jesus did truly teach unto the people (3 Nephi 26:6). Jesus taught the people:... For the space of three days; and after that he did show himself unto them oft, and did break bread oft, and bless it, and give it unto them (3 Nephi 36:13). He wrought many mighty miracles among the Nephites and:... He did teach and minister unto the children of the multitude of whom hath been spoken, and he did loose their tongues, and they did speak unto their fathers great and marvelous things, even greater than he had revealed unto the people; and he loosed their tongues that they could utter.... On the morrow... The multitude gathered themselves together, and they both saw and heard these children; yea, even babes did open their mouths and utter marvelous things; and the things which they did utter were forbidden that there should not any man write them (3 Nephi 26:14, 16). From this time on the disciples began "... To baptize and to teach as many as did come unto them; and as many as were baptized in the name of Jesus were filled with the Holy Ghost" (3 Nephi 26:17). Jesus Christ Names His Church As the disciples were gathered together "... United in mighty prayer and fasting" (3 Nephi 27:1) after having preached to the people and baptized them, Jesus appeared in their midst and asked: "... What will ye that I shall give unto you?" (3 Nephi 27:2). Because of disputations among the people concerning the name of the Church, the disciples asked that he tell them ",.. The name whereby we shall call this church..." (3 Nephi 27:3). Jesus' answer was direct and final: 550 And how be it my church save it be called in my name? For if a church be called in Moses' name then it be Moses' church; or if it be called in the name of a man then it be the church of a man; but if it be called in my name then it is my church, if it so be that they are built upon my gospel (3 Nephi 27:8). The Gospel Defined Jesus, then, told the Nephites he had given to them his gospel, and defined the gospel for them: Behold I have given unto you my gospel, and this is the gospel which I have given unto you — that I came into the world to do the will of my Father, because my Father sent me. And my Father sent me that J might be lifted up upon the cross; and after that I had been lifted up upon the cross, that I might draw all men unto me, that as I have been lifted up by men even so should men be lifted up by the Father, to stand before me, to be judged of their works, whether they be good or whether they be evil— And for this cause have I been lifted up; therefore, according to the power of the Father I will draw all men unto me, that they may be judged according to their works. And it shall come to pass, that whoso repenteth and is baptized in my name shall be filled; and if he endureth to the end, behold, him will I hold guiltless before my Father at that day when I shall stand to judge the world. And he that endureth not unto the end, the same is he that is also hewn down and cast into the fire, from whence they can no more return, because of the justice of the Father. And this is the word which he hath given unto the children of men. And for this cause he fulfilleth the words which he hath given, and he lieth not, but fulfilleth all his words. And no unclean thing can enter into the kingdom; therefore nothing entereth RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 into his rest save it be those who have washed their garments in my blood, because of their faith, and the repentance of all their sins, and their faithfulness unto the end. Now this is the commandment: Repent, all ye ends of the earth, and come unto me and be baptized in my name, that ye may be sanctified by the reception of the Holy Ghost, that ye may stand spotless before me at the last day. Verily, verily, I say unto you, this is my gospel; and ye know the things that ye must do in my church; for the works which ye have seen me do that shall ye also do; for that which ye have seen me do even that shall ye do (3 Nephi 27:13-21). Jesus also informed the 'disciples that men would be judged out of the books, but he made it known to them that "... All things are written by the Father; therefore out of the books which shall be written shall the world be judged" (3 Nephi 27:26). The disciples were informed by Jesus that they were to judge the Nephites, and that his joy was great, even unto fulness, because of them and the generation then alive. He pointed out to them, however, that his heart sorrowed for the people of the fourth generation:... For they are led away captive by him even as was the son of perdition; for they will sell me for silver and for gold, and for that which moth doth corrupt and which thieves can break through and steal (3 Nephi 27:32). Disciples Granted Their Desires It was then that Jesus turned to his disciples and asked, one by one, "... What is it that ye desire of me, after that Iam gone to the Father?" (3 Nephi 28:1). Nine of them said: "... We desire that after we have lived unto the age of man, that LESSON DEPARTMENT our ministry, wherein thou hast called us, may have an end, that we may speedily come unto thee in thy kingdom" (3 Nephi 28:2). Jesus commended them and promised them that when they reached the age of seventy-two that they would find rest with him in his kingdom. Turning to the three remaining disciples he asked: "... What will ye that I should do unto you, when I am gone unto the Father?" (3 Nephi 28:4). Recognizing the sorrow in their hearts "... For they durst not speak unto him the thing which they desired," (3 Nephi 28:5), he said:... Behold, I know your thoughts, and ye have desired the thing which John, my beloved, who was with me in my ministry, before that I was lifted up by the Jews, desired of me. Therefore, more blessed are ye, for ye shall never taste of death; but ye shall live to behold all the doings of the Father unto the children of men, even until all things shall be fulfilled according to the will of the Father when I shall come in my glory with the powers of heaven (3 Nephi 28:6-7). Mormon was forbidden to name these three disciples in the record. He knew their names, however, and he had seen them and they had ministered unto him (3 Nephi 28:26). Mormon knew also that they would minister unto many others in the future, unto the Gentiles, the Jews, the scattered tribes of the house of Israel, and that they would perform a great and marvelous work among them. After the three disciples were granted their wish, they were "... Caught up into heaven..." where they "... Saw and heard un- 551 speakable things." (See 3 Nephi 28:2-8, 12, 36.) Later when they taught the people the gospel and were persecuted for it, the prisons could not hold them, pits could not restrain them, furnaces did them no harm, and when they were cast into dens of wild beasts, they received no harm, so great was their power. Mormon's Warning to Those Who Deny Chiist Mormon, near the end of Third Nephi, warns all those to whom this record would come not to spurn the words and works of the Lord. ".. Behold," he wrote, "at that day, if ye shall spurn at his doings he will cause that it shall soon overtake you. Wo unto him that spurneth at the doings of the Lord; yea, wo unto him that shall deny the Christ and his works! Yea, wo unto him that shall deny the revelations of the Lord.... Yea, and wo unto him that shall say at that day, to get gain, that there can be no miracle wrought by Jesus Christ; for he that doeth this shall become like unto the son of perdition, for whom there was no mercy, according to the word of Christ!" (3 Nephi 29:47). Gentiles Called to Repentance Mormon also advised the people in the last days not to "... Spurn, nor make game of the Jews, nor any of the remnant of the house of Israel..." (3 Nephi 29:8) for the Lord would keep his covenants to those people. Nephi further stated:... That when the Lord shall see fit in his wisdom, that these sayings shall come 552 unto the Gentiles according to his word, then ye may know that the covenant which the Father hath made with the children of Israel, concerning their restoration to the lands of their inheritance, is already beginning to be fulfilled. And ye may know that the words of the Lord, which have been spoken by the holy prophets, shall all be fulfilled; and ye need not say that the Lord delays his coming unto the children of Israel (3 Nephi 29:1-2). Mormon concludes Third Nephi with advice to the Gentiles of this day: Turn, all ye Gentiles, from your wicked ways; and repent of your evil doings, of your lyings and deceivings, and of your whoredoms, and of your secret abominations, and your idolatries, and of your RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 murders, and your priestcrafts, and your envyings, and your strifes, and from all your wickedness and abominations, and come unto me, and be baptized in my name, that ye may receive a remission of your sins, and be filled with the Holy Ghost, that ye may be numbered with my people who are of the house of Israel (3 Nephi 30:2). Questions on the Lesson 1. How did Jesus define the gospel? 2. What scripture did he give to the Nephites? Why? 3. What did Jesus say regarding the house of Israel? The Jews? The Gentiles? 4. Why are Jesus' words about Elijah important? 5. What did Malachi say about tithing? 6. What did Jesus say about the name of the Church? 7. What does "'sanctified by the reception of the Holy Ghost" mean? Visiting Seacher Mlessages— Book of Mormon Gems of Truth Lesson 42—'Pray in Your Families Unto the Father, Always in My Name, _ That Your Wives and Your Children May Be Blessed" (3 Nephi 18:21). Leone O. Jacobs For Tuesday, November 6, 1956 Objective: To point out the blessings that come from family prayer. ERHAPS there is no single activity in the home which results in richer blessings than does that of family prayer. If parents would only realize the rewards of this activity they would be very faithful in its observance. President Heber J. Grant said of family prayer: I am convinced that one of the greatest things that can come into any home to cause the boys and girls in that home to grow up in a love of God, and in a love of the gospel of Jesus Christ, is to have family prayer (Gospel Standards, page 25). Families which start the day by kneeling down together in prayer receive a spiritual uplift. As each individual goes forth to his day's duties he carries with him the knowledge that the spirit of the Lord has been entreated to attend him. He goes out with the backing of his entire family, and, added to this security, is a feeling of conf- LESSON DEPARTMENT dence that he may have God's help throughout the day. Then, at the close of the day, for the family again to kneel in humility and thanksgiving brings peace to family members and a desire to continue in righteousness. If feelings have been hurt or errors committed, individuals may not feel like praying; but Brigham Young has said of such an attitude: It matters not whether you or I feel like praying, when the time comes to pray, pray. If we do not feel like it, we should pray till we do.... Let no person give up prayer because he has not the spirit of prayer, neither let any earthly circumstance hurry you while in the performance of this important duty (Discourses of Brigham Young, pp. 44, 46). Some families encounter difficulty in finding a convenient time for all members to participate in family prayer. 'This should never be a cause for neglecting this commandment. One exemplary family found the solution to evening prayers by setting the alarm clock for 7:00 P. M., which was the signal for all to assemble before any member left for an evening appointment. Think what a safeguard these prayers 553 would be to young people! Surely prayer is a protecting shield against the enticements of Satan. Many have testified that the thought of their families kneeling together in prayer asking the Lord to protect them from harm and evil, has saved them from yielding to temptation and making serious mistakes. When loved ones are far from the home circle, the prayers of the family are a sustaining influence. It means much for them to know that their families are praying for them regularly at home. 'They may even visualize the exact hour when prayers are being said and the faces of their loved ones engaged in this sacred practice. In a day when divorce and juvenile delinquency are alarming, family prayer can be a strong influence in preventing these sad situations. Family prayer cements family ties, it generates harmony and love, and teaches unselfishness. Hearts are mellowed, tempers softened, and problems dwarfed through seeking divine aid: More things are wrought by prayer Than this world dreams of. "Morte D'Arthur," Tennyson Work Mleeting— Food Preparation and Service (A Course Recommended for Use by Wards and Branches at Work Meeting) Lesson 2—Casseroles and Leftovers Rhea H. Gardner For Tuesday, November 13, 1956 CASSEROLES play an important role in meal planning. A casserole may be prepared two or more weeks before it is to be served, if it Sot is stored in a home freezer; or a day or two if it is stored in the refrigerator. A good casserole has qualities that make it distinctive and give it character; for instance, the meat should be cut in pieces large enough to be readily identified, and vegetables should be chosen that will combine well with the protein food that is used. In addition to flavor, it is important to think also of color and texture. Precook fresh vegetables only until they are about half done so they will not be overcooked when the casserole is ready to be served. Many frozen vegetables, such as peas, corn, and green beans, may be added while still icy. Never mince vegetables, except those used primarily for seasoning. Whole rings of carrots, or if they are small and garden fresh, whole carrots, whole or half lengths of string beans, clusters of bright green broccoli or snowy white cauliflower give character and appetite appeal to a casserole dish. Sutble seasoning is a goal every good cook strives for and is especially important in casseroles. Casserole dishes are best prepared in low, flat baking dishes rather than in deep, smaller ones. Casseroles that are too deep are not likely to be cooked thoroughly. Much of the attractiveness of a casserole dish is created in the topping, and there should be some of the topping given with each serving. Casseroles are excellent for outdoor meals. For your picnic parties, choose those that carry well. Because a high percentage of foods used in casseroles is comparatively soft and not particularly colorful, make sure that you include garnishes, relishes, and salad foods RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 that are crisp and colorful for the balance of your menu. To make a casserole for freezing, prepare it according to the regular recipe, but do not add the topping. If you plan to use it within a week or two, cover the casserole with waxed paper, aluminum foil or a bowl cover before placing it in the freezer. A moisture-vapor-proof wrapper or freezer tape to seal the lid to the dish is necessary when the casserole is to be stored for a longer period of time. When the casserole comes out of the freezer, add the topping and it is ready to bake after it has reached room temperature. Casserole dishes are just one way to use leftovers. Croquettes, meat pies, sandwich fillings, stews, stuffed peppers, meat loaves, chowders and soups are other ways in which leftovers may be attractively prepared. The same rules as those reeommended for making a good casserole should be followed. If much of the roast or boiled meat you plan to use is in tiny bits, grind it and, with the use of a binder, such as a thick sauce, crumbs or eggs, form it into balls or in a loaf. Always add one or two fresh vegetables when making a stew or meat pie. A change of seasoning can do much to make an "old dish" taste fresh as "morning dew." Leftover vegetables may be creamed and served as a sauce over a cheese or fish souffle, noodle ring, or croquettes. If you do not plan to use leftovers soon, put them in suitable containers in your freezer or the coldest part of your refrigerator until you can use them. Decide while the LESSON DEPARTMENT food is very fresh: (1) Is there enough to be served by itself or must it be combined with other foods? (2) Can it be cut in regular pieces or is it so broken that it must be chopped or ground? (3) Is it 955 moist enough to be palatable or must it be served with a sauce? (4) What ways of serving it will be best? Once you have made these decisions, you will be ready to make the best use of your leftovers. Note "Casserole Recipes" by Rhea H. Gardner, page 534, in this issue of the Magazine. OLiterature—Shakespeare in Our Lives Lesson 2—Shakespeare's World Elder Briant S. Jacobs (Text: Shakespeare Major Plays and the Sonnets, by G. B. Harrison, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1948) For Tuesday, November 20, 1956 Objective: To present the customs, beliefs, and conflicts of Shakespeare's life and world, which were ready to be given harmony and artistic form by his emerging genius.* Ripeness is all. HE late Elizabethan period is probably the richest in all English literature, primarily because Shakespeare and his fellow-dramatists stated in such glowing words the conflicts, hopes, and fears of their most exciting age. During preceding decades and centuries the theater itself had been molded into the magnificent art-form which was ready for Shakespeare's guiding hand. Under his touch it flowered into one of man's most powerful devices for communicating his inner self. King Lear, V, 2. 2 If Elizabethan man had had no burning inner struggle or dream, the theater, polished and_ poetic though it may have been, would have lacked material of sufficient stature, since the essence of great drama must be great conflict. The time was ripe for the emergence of some great spokesman for the English soul. 'The theater was ripe. Also ripe were the great themes it was to celebrate: reason vs. Intuition, superstition vs. Learning, religion vs. Science, puritan vs. Pleasure-seeker, monarchy vs. Rebels, ani- "Note to Class Leaders: In order to understand the writings of Shakespeare better, this lesson explains briefly in two sections: "The Ordered Universe," and "Conflicting Doctrines to 'Ordered Universe'"'—different beliefs in vogue at the time of Shakespeare. It is not intended that this material be considered in greater detail than it is presented in the lesson. 556 mal man vs. Angelic man, good vs. Evil, selfishness vs. Selflessness, individuality vs. Tradition, order vs. Chaos. But in order to understand why the Elizabethan air was so heavily charged with conflict, we must first examine the traditional belief of the "ordered universe," and the threats emerging to challenge this belief. The Ordered Universe Throughout the Middle Ages one of the unquestioned commonplaces had been Aristotle's viewpoint that "God and nature create nothing that has not its use." The general belief was that God's over-all purpose in creating all nature and the universe was to glorify himself, and that the best way to glorify him was to know him. It was believed this could best be accomplished by studying the two great books which God had given man for this very purpose, "the Bible, and the book of the universal order of things, or of nature," as Ramon Sabunde wrote in his Natural Theology, about 1425. Central to both the natural and the divine orders, indeed the bridge between the two, was man who, by his own free will, could make of himself either angel or beast. And as man was created to serve God, so all nature was created to serve man. According to this belief, man, then, created in the image of God was key to the entire universe; indeed, man was but a tiny model of the universe. Man must be studied and known, as must every phase of nature. Since God is perfect, so must man and nature be perfect, both in themselves and in their inter-relationship. 'To know perfecRELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 tion, therefore, God's perfect works must be studied. This "ordered universe" also governed nations and men as well. 'The "Primary Law of Nature" instilled in man various lesser laws which he must obey: to worship God; to obey parents and civil government; to rear and educate children; to give equal liberty to all; and to hurt no man. The same natural law considered kings the rightful rulers of England, since a king was servant of the greater law which reigned above. Within the English commonwealth were recognized four orders of men, each self-contained and content to abide by his own law; namely, gentleman, citizen, yeoman, and laborer. Three levels of order—man, the civil body or state, and the universe —were all believed to be inter-related, and that the law could not be broken in one realm without causing chaos in the other two. Because they thought the movements of the planets governed the lives of men, astrology was not considered black magic, but as an established revelation of the will of God. Ulysses stated the concept in Shakespeare's Troilus and Cressida: The heavens themselves, the planets and this center, Observe degree, priority, and place.... But when the planets In evil mixture to disorder wander, What plagues and what portents, what mutiny, What raging of the sea, shaking of earth, Commotion in the winds, frights, changes, horrors, Divert and crack, rend and deracinate, The unity and married calm of states Quite from their fixture! Oh, when degree is shaked, Which is the ladder to all high designs, The enterprise is sick!.... LESSON DEPARTMENT A Perry Picture Take but degree away, untune that string, And hark, what discord follows!.... I. 3. 85ff. In this ordered view man was perfect and all the universe, too, if man but kept his station and obeyed nature's law. Conflicting Doctrines to "Ordered Universe" A contrasting doctrine had appeared with John Calvin's Institutes of Christian Religion, published in 1536, perhaps the most influential book of the Protestant movement. Calvin stated that, because of Adam's fall, man was "'a shapeless ruin, partly ruined, partly corrupted..." whose will did not perish but "was so enslaved by depraved lusts as to be incapable of one righteous desire." 'Thus in Adam's fall the order of nature was reversed, and so the body ruled the soul. Since man was considered fallen creature, 557 Copyright 1901 SHAKESPEARE'S HOME, STRATFORD-ON-AVON, ENGLAND nature was no longer to serve him; instead, the elements, beasts, birds, and plants, were now ready to offend him. Here we see the basic conflict in the nature of man, one which all Elizabethans felt and knew. On the one hand, man was thought of as perfection and the center of the universe; on the other hand he was a corrupted animal, ruled by his own appetites, living on a vile planet. But, even though fallen, man was so important that the Son of God came to earth to save him, and man could maintain order by fulfilling God's principles of grace and redemption. But while the Elizabethans were aware of their "ordered existence," they were forced with increasing urgency to acknowledge four threats to it. (1) Copernicus (1473- 1543) had dared suggest that the sun, not the earth, was the center 558 of the universe, a view later substantiated by Galileo (1564-1642) who, with the first telescope, found rough craters on the moon, thus proving that, at least, some celestial spheres were not perfect orbs. (2) The Italian Machiavelli's most bitterly hated book, The Prince (1513) had defied the concept of a just, God-governed order for people by naming, instead, self-interest, craftiness, power, fear, and unscrupulousness as the actual tools which every sovereign used to insure his personal dominance. (3) The French satirist Montaigne's Essays (1580) had presented man as lower than the animals, since, unlike man, animals never waged organized warfare against their own kind. (4) Even more devastating had been the well-known writings of Francis Bacon (1561-1626) who had never attacked the concept of an "ordered universe": he had ignored it. He had held it to be man's duty to separate scientific from religious or moral knowledge. Instead of conjecturing about intangible mysteries, he believed it was man's duty to learn the secrets of the natural world about him, that he might put them to use for his own benefit. (For much of the preceding discussion | am deeply indebted to Theodore Spencer's excellent work, Shakespeare and the Nature of Man, New York: The Macmillan Company, 1943, Pp- 30-44-) In addition to these intellectual and scientific forces, Protestantism itself preached the new and stern doctrine that, henceforth, no intercessor or middleman was to stand between man and God; now man must be responsible for his own actions. 'This religious independence was as basic to the Elizabethan RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 age as was the emerging political liberty, and was as eagerly sought. Whenever men have shared their mutual hopes, fears, joys, and hungers, then they have most nearly become brothers. How fully the Elizabethans predicted modern man in their own great hunger to hear their own thoughts expressed in words! Shakespeare, then, through the Elizabethan stage, fulfilled this hunger, thus linking together men of that time, and of all time henceforth. These great conflicts in the religious, philosophical, and scientific beliefs of the Elizabethans were bound to have their influences on the writings of Shakespeare. Shakespeare's Life Shakespeare was born in 1564 at Stratford-on-Avon, a rural metropolis some eighty miles west and north of London. His parents were solid, middle-class people, his father a glove maker who was, at one time, mayor. His mother was the daughter of a local farming family tich in lands. Shakespeare must have attended the local grammar school, which had Oxford graduates as headmasters, and which gave him a solid acquaintance with important books, notably the Bible and the Greek classics. Actual proofs of how he spent his early years are sparse, but we do have record of his marrying Anne Hathaway when he was in his eighteenth year, she in her twenty-sixth. Some four years later he went to London, leaving his wife and three children in Stratford. By 1592, when he was twenty-eight, he had established in London a reputation as an actor and outstanding playwright. It is not known why his LESSON DEPARTMENT wife remained in Stratford during the next twenty years, but it is known that, not too many years after Shakespeare left Stratford, the local Puritans became sufficiently strong to pass an ordinance forbidding the performance of any plays. In London Shakespeare _ prospered. He became part owner of a playhouse, 'The Globe, and wrote all the plays for a company of actors who stayed together for two decades, and, under James I, came to be known as "The King's Men." Duting his life there he wrote thirtysix or thirty-seven plays, a sequence of sonnets, and two long poems. He invested his money in the second largest house in Stratford, bought the tithes of the local parish as an investment, and was one of the wealthiest landowners in the district. In 1611, after writing his final play, the highly successful The Tempest, he retired to Stratford, where he lived the life of a respected country gentleman until his death in 1616. His detailed will directed most of his property and lands to be given to his daughters and sister. He left money to several friends in Stratford and to actorfriends in London to buy memorial rings, and to his wife he bequeathed his second-best bed, a sign neither of bitterness nor of affection since she was entitled to one-third of all his property and use of the house as long as she lived. To us, the most interesting part of his will, as it reveals Shakespeare's belief, reads as follows: I commend my soul into the hands of God my creator, hoping, and assuredly believing, through the only merits of Jesus Christ, my Saviour, to be made partaker of life everlasting. (Burgess: The Bible in Shakespeare, page 113). 5D Shakespeare's London "The spacious times of the great Elizabeth" were in Elizabethans' hearts and on their backs, not in their physical London. Roads were little more than mudbogs, and the recently invented carriages were so awkward and rough that most people still travelled horseback — that is, if they travelled at all. Less than a mile square and still surrounded by its medieval wall, London bulged with about 200,000 people living in crowded, squalid quarters, with great noise from carts, wagons, coopers, potmakers, and shopkeepers rushing forth constantly yelling, "What do ye lack?" On the streets everywhere hawkers chanted, "Small coals!" or "Hot peas!" or "Hot, fine oatcakes!"" Porters sweated under their burdens in the narrow, crooked streets choked with filth, while open sewers, which were constantly a hazard to travel, carried off the garbage and refuse left in the streets until it rained (though human waste was carried off to sea in barges). No one bathed, but the rich used perfume to sweeten their persons, even as scents were used in homes to counteract the smell of mildewed, rotting rushes which were used as floor coverings. Rats and vermin bred freely in the large slums, and the plague was an annual summer visitor. If, during the hot, damp plague season more than thirty persons died in a week, the playhouses were closed temporarily, and, for at least two summers in Shakespeare's time, the plague forced the closing of the playhouses during the entire season. The centers of trade, gossip, and community life in the city were the innumerable taverns and the more 560 A Perry Picture RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 Copyright 1908 INTERIOR, ANNE HATHAWAY COTTAGE than one hundred churches, since there were no newspapers or public gatherings other than church meetings and entertainments. 'lhe entertainments such as _ cock-fighting, bull and bear-baiting, cards and dicing, and plays had been outlawed by London's "puritanical" city council. But, nonetheless, all were licensed over the city council's heads by "Good Queen Bess," who sensed the growing independence of her subjects and the influence French and Italian fashions had had upon the many English noblemen, merchants, foot-soldiers, and sailors who had travelled the continent. She felt that her subjects deserved the right to entertain themselves, and that the crown should make a profit on such activities. 'True daughter of the Renaissance that she was, She loved music and dancing, and constantly defended play production on the grounds that where else could actors keep in practice for her royal command in her palaces at regular intervals, particularly during the Christmas season? In 1485 thirty years of civil war had ended, and the Tudor line of kings, climaxed by Henry VIII, had built a strong, unified England; but the fear of anarchy and mob tule was ever in English hearts. 'The English defeated their great enemy, Spain, by sinking her Armada in 1588, but a more successful Spanish invasion was forever imminent and greatly feared. Drake and Hawkins pillaged the Spanish Main, while other daring Englishmen sank a Spanish fleet in the Bay of Cadiz and then sacked and burned the city. During Shakespeare's lifetime England was ever at war, first with Spain, then France, then Ireland. Before the Elizabethan era fur- LESSON DEPARTMENT ther independence had come to Englishmen who became freed from domination of the Roman Pope when, in 1534, Henry VIII had created the Church of England, with himself at the head. The printing press had put the English Bible into all men's hands, and books, which became increasingly common, were read, not for pleasure or amusement, but as the main source of finding out the how and why of the "brave new world" everywhere unfolding in wonder and vigor about their dreaming, almost giddy heads. And presiding over all, loved for her gentleness, her strength, and her balanced wisdom, was Queen Elizabeth, (1533-1603), confidently leading her people and personifying the qualities they held most dear. That island of England breeds very valiant creatures. 'Their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage... And the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming-on, leaving their wits with their wives. And then give them great meals of beef, and iron and steel, they will eat like wolves and fight like devils (Henry V, HI. 7. 150-162). Thus Shakespeare in his plays proved his intimate knowledge of his fellow countrymen. His great success was not by chance, since he knew so well what they loved and hated. The Elizabethan Englishman was intensely patriotic, dressed most lavishly, loved display of words, action, dress, music, and dance. He loved rough sports: gambling, bulland-bear baiting, and, above all, the drama. He was coarse and brutal, and loved to witness hangings, of which it is said more than three uundred took place each year in London alone. Young men brawled in the streets day and night, hardly 561 considering themselves "men" until they bore the scars of swordplay. At night London was a terror to the honest and older people. With no police force, citizens were appointed as constables, but their hearts were not in it, and gangs of rogues, rowdies, and thieves roamed the night city at will. The Maturing Shakespeare While the young Shakespeare made it his business to give in his plays what London wanted, we can still trace his maturing by his growing contempt and hatred for brutality, indecency, infidelity, coarseness, and any taint of uncleanliness. Nor were these the only qualities of his mind: constancy, bravery, courage, loyalty, love in the home, he esteemed; while cowardice, cruelty, usury, slavery, hypocrisy, he roundly condemned. And so we see this gallant definer and defender of our heritage strenuously at crossfire — with himself, his world, his past, and his future. He was the typical Elizabethan mind and heart. Thus, for the Elizabethan age, man was potentially an angel, yet rotting in his grave; sensitive to the most ornamental poetry and loving vocal music so fully that everyone could "bear his part," yet hungry for gory spectacle in theater, war, and tortures both animal and human; patriotic to the core, yet extremely touchy of individual rights and wary of exploitation or slavery; hungry for facts, for practical knowledge, yet still believing "there might be something in" ghosts, witches, and superstition; eager for personal wealth, yet indifferent to, if not disdainful of the suffering poor forever surrounding 562 him — the list might be extended, even swollen, almost to infinity. These traits are those of adolescence. The young in heart have ever felt the appeal of spectacle, speech, sparkle, and spirit. Particularly in the first half of his career Shakespeate wrote to young audiences, of young audiences. Actually, he wrote of a young nation to a young nation — one which has never been bounded by time, for the young in heart are always with us. The Elizabethan age was youth, incorporating within itself all its inner fears, insecurities, grandiose dreams, weaknesses and hopes. And, just as surely, Shakespeare was RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 mouth, and heart, yes, soul, for this most sparkling, hectic age. Thoughts for Discussion 1. How do the hopes and conflicts of Shakespeare's England predict those of our day? 2. Why were Elizabethans so hungry for drama? What great needs did Shakespeare's plays fill for his contemporaries? 3. Discuss Shakespeare's being both "country lad" and "city slicker" as preparation for his becoming the universal playwright. 4. In view of London's squalor and brutality, how can you justify calling the Elizabethan age one of spaciousness and nobility? Social Science—Latter-day Saint Family Life Lesson 2—A New Day for Women Elder John Farr Larson For Tuesday, November 27, 1956 Objective: ginning of a new era for women. HE organization of the Relief Society by the Prophet Joseph Smith came at a time when the status of women was limited legally, socially, and economically. It was significant because it recognized women as responsible adults and heralded the beginning of a series of events which elevated women to their present position. Today's women enjoy blessings and opportunities not afforded their sisters in 1842. The restoration of the gospel brought clearly into focus the worth of each soul in the eyes of God. The teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith to the women of the Church were consistent with this concept. NevertheTo show that the organization of the Relief Society marked the beless, they embodied a different attitude towards women from the one that was at that time generally accepted. An analysis of the limited status of women generally, at the time of the organization of the Relief Society, brings into sharp contrast some of the rights and _privileges women now take for granted. Legal Status of Women in 1842 Married women of the 19th Century, particularly in the first half, had little recognition, as individuals, in the legal sense. The early basic law of all states, except Louisiana, had its origin in the English common law. The common law is said to: LESSON DEPARTMENT. Comprise the body of those principles and rules of action... Which derive their authority solely from usages and customs of immemorial antiquity, or from the judgments and decrees of the courts recognizing, affirming, and enforcing such usages and customs, and in this sense particularly the ancient unwritten law of England (I Kent Commentaries 492). In the United States it is that body of rules and principles as established and determined in England at the time the various states adopted it. Many of its principles have been changed by statutes and constitutional provisions in the various states, but, except as it has been changed, it is the law today. As we study the common law we should recognize that only broad principles are here treated and that minor variations possibly existed in some states. An unmarried woman at common law had capacity to contract and perform other legal acts, equal to that of a man. When she married, her position as a separate, "competent" individual disappeared, and she was reduced to the legal capacity of "'slaves, idiots and infants." In theory, when a man and woman married, they became one person and that person was the husband. The entire legal existence of the wife merged into that of her husband. In her own capacity, a married woman could not, with validity, (1) sign a contract, deed, note or check; (2) acquire or dispose of property without the consent of her husband; or (3) sue or be sued. All personal property of the wife, whether acquired before or during marriage, became that of hei hus- 563 band. Personal property is generally property of a personal or movable nature such as money, jewelry, furniture, etc., as opposed to real property, such as land, which is of an immovable character. A_husband was in the position, legally, of being unable to give his wife a present, since while attempting it he simultaneously vested himself with its title. Upon death, the husband's personal property (including that acquired from his wife), generally went to his estate. She was permitted to keep her "paraphernalia'" which included articles of wearing apparel, and personal ornaments, suitable to her rank and degree, but even these, except her clothing, could be taken to satisfy her husband's debts. Similar harsh rules were applied to the wife's real estate. 'That acquired prior to her marriage became subject to her husband's wishes. He could sell or mortgage without her consent. He was entitled to the rents and crops from her land and had no duty to account to her for money received, since it was his money. Real property acquired by the wife before her marriage, not sold by the husband, went to her upon his death. If the wife were employed to act as a midwife, as a seamstress, or in any other capacity, her husband was entitled to her pay. A New Hampshire judge in 1830 described another aspect of the common law when he said the wife:. Was considered to be so entirely under_ the power of the husband, that she could, in no case, make what in propriety of speech is called a will (Marston Vs. Norton, Superior Court of New Hampshire, 5 N. H. 205). 564 A mother's right to her children was inferior to that of her husband and is illustrated by a decision of the New York Supreme Court in 1842: The question then is, which of these parents, the father or the mother, has the best title to the custody of the child? The opinion of the court has been repeatedly expressed, that by the law of the land the claims of the father are superior to those of the mother (Mercein Vs. The People ex rel. Barry, 3 Hill (N. Y.) 399). In that day women were not given the privilege of voting in political elections, a right now cherished by all freedom-loving people. Until recent years, a woman who had citizenship status before her marriage, lost it upon marriage to an alien. Other Problems of the Day There were other problems and conditions facing the women of the Prophet's day: the ever-present disease, infant mortality, the absence of educational opportunities, the short life span, and extremely poor working conditions for women who worked. Few labor saving devices were known to them. Great physical exertion was generally required of them in their homes. Widespread suffering existed in the country as a result of an economic depression. Public charity was then limited to poorly organized efforts which were meeting only a fraction of the need. 'Those in need were often treated as criminals. Latter-day Saint women of this period were considered, in the eyes of the law, as having a status and capacity similar to that of other women. The conditions they faced RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—AUGUST 1956 were not unlike those of other women. However, they had _ blessings not enjoyed outside their circle and problems uniquely their own. 'The eatly history of the Church is full of episodes in which superior women suffered abuses of all kinds from enemies of the Church and were constantly facing an uncertain future. Always there were skeptics who ridiculed their belief in the divine origin of the Church and the revealed principles of the gospel. Some were subjected to the grossest of indignities. Many stood by while their husbands were cruelly treated by ruthless mobs. The Changing Trend From our vantage point in _history, in looking back to the plight of early 19th Century women, we wonder why men and women advocating principles of fair play didn't literally rise up and demand that something be done. The present rights of women came only after a long series of events directed against the unreasonable _ restrictions of the common law. At first only small voices were heard to object, and those not in concert. Later, as the chorus against the injustices grew, one by one the discriminating provisions disappeared. The organization of the Relief Society was at the very beginning of a trend of legislative, judicial, and other significant changes which gave to married women a status as individuals and by which they were liberated from the harsh and often cruel dogmas of the common law. It recognized women as capable, responsible adults. 'The teachings of Joseph Smith concerning their role in community betterment, self- LESSON DEPARTMENT improvement, and service to others, significantly enlarged women's sphere. Today, most of the injustices of the common law are gone. 'Their removal was a victory for equitable principles. 'The changes were made by men who curtailed their own interests and rights through an appeal to their sense of justice. In the last half of the 19th Century organized effort brought results for those seeking a more enlightened attitude for women. The rights of women became a frequent subject of discussion and the names of Lucy Stone and Susan B. Anthony, great leaders in the cause, became invitations for debate. At the wedding of Lucy Stone and Henry Blackwell, a statement was read suggesting how strong they felt about the status of women. (Henry Blackwell became distinguished in the movement to abolish slavery.) 'The wedding statement, in part, reads as follows: While we acknowledge our mutual affection by publicly assuming the relationship of husband and wife, yet, in justice to ourselves and a great principle, we deem it a duty to declare that this act on our part implies no sanction of, nor promise of voluntary obedience to, such of the present laws of marriage as refuse to recognize the wife as an independent, rational being, while they confer upon the husband an injurious and unnatural superiority, investing him with legal powers which no honorable man would exercise, and which no man should possess (Lucy Stone, Pioneer of Woman's Rights, page 16s). Following the above they then enumerated their specific objections. The National Woman's Suffrage Association was organized in 1868. Starting in Illinois in 1861, when the first "Married Women's Act" 565 was passed, a series of statutes and constitutional provisions were enacted, by which the common law restrictions upon the right of married women to contract, sue and be sued, acquire, hold and convey property in their own right, were removed. The right to. Vote was given to women in this country only in recent times, the 19th Amendment to the U. S. Constitution having been ratified on August 26, 1920. Latter-day Saint women, who significantly have always enjoyed an ecclesiastical voting privilege, enjoyed political suffrage rights as early as 1847, when Utah was still Mexican Territory. The right to vote conferred by a state or territory was actually first exercised by Utah women in February 1870. Because of their political experiences and their privileges locally, the women of Utah became active supporters and effective, conspicuous figures in the National Woman Suffrage movement, and sent delegates regularly to the National Suffrage Conventions to lend support to this great cause (A Centenary of Relief Society, 1942, page 67). President Brigham Young was aware of the influence of our women when he said on one occasion: Now, sisters, I want you to vote, because you are the characters that rule the ballot box (Widtsoe, John A.: Priesthood and Church Government, page 87). Not only have the legal and political rights of women been extended but women today are achieving recognition in most fields of human activity. For instance, in some states a married women is vested with a right to one-third of all property owned by her husband { during the marriage, but the husband does not have a corresponding interest in his wife's property. A wife, in these states, can convey her property without her husband's concurrence. It is not so with the husband, whose wife must join in his conveyances. Most states now give women, by statute, a preferential right to the custody of children in divorce cases. It is not the purpose of this lesson to suggest that there is or should be absolute equality between men and women. As we study the role of women in the Church, in succeeding lessons, it will be apparent that men and women are each important in the eyes of our Heavenly Father. 'Their assignments are so distinct and different it is obvious that neither occupies an inferior position to the other. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow seemed to have some understanding of the relationship and interdependence of man and woman when he wrote in "The Song of Hiawatha": As unto the bow the cord is, So unto the man is woman; Though she bends him, she obeys him, Though she draws him, yet she follows; Useless each without the other! The Gospel Plan is designed to stimulate the individual in personal attainment. The Prophet Joseph Smith, in his inspirational talks to the Relief Society, set forth in detail how the women of the Church, through service and _ obedience, might attain the choicest blessings LESSON DEPARTMENT of our Heavenly Father. Some of those teachings, suggesting ways by which women may grow in faith and perfection in God's kingdom will be discussed in future months. True Latter-day Saint women, grateful for their heritage, fully aware of their status in an enlightened society, are eager to learn of their responsibilities for service to their families, their communities, and their God. Some are weighted with the beauty Of gay honeysuckle vines; Others strut around the premises, So very pompously, And some roam aimlessly like one Absorbed in memory. Some look neat, clean, prim, and tidy, White and scrubbed, each board in place. Others sag dilapidated, Bowed and cowed, bent with disgrace. Some formidable, unfriendly, Guarding vast estates with pride, But without a squeaking, swinging Gate that some wee tot could ride. Best of all, I like the fat ones, Fat with robins, girls and boys; Those not built to fence out friendship, But to fence in homely joys. Ceeecsesccscsecscssesssscsesscseesecesscscececscnsesensesensenscaensvasessareanssesee $70 Courtesy Z. C. M. I. Photo Reflex Studio PRESIDENT DAVID O. McKAY A Happy Birthday to President David ) McKay Mildred C. McKay [' is a pleasure to wish President David O. McKay a happy birthday, and an honor to be asked to pay a tribute to a father-in-law whom I love. I realize his greatness, his life of service, and his dedication to the Church, but I shall not write of these. Instead, I want to mention some of the little things that endear him to our family. Even a few words about President McKay must include Sister McKay because to us, as Papa Dade and Mama Ray, they exemplify ideal parenthood. There is graciousness in the way they include their sons-in-law and daughters-in-law in the family. We are all their children. It is just a little thing, but flattering, to have Papa Dade say, "Have you met our daughter Mildred and our son David L.?" They both love children, and the greatest event in the family is a new baby. When they visit the hospital to welcome a new grandchild, Papa Dade, with a twinkle in his eye, always greets the new mother with, "Many happy returns of the day." President McKay's thoughtfulness includes all ages. Our daughters are tall, and when they were at that adolescent age of all arms and legs, their grandfather never said, "My, how tall you are getting," but always, "What a queen you are becoming!" "A happy home is a heaven on earth" is one of President McKay's favorite comparisons. We all feel the love in his home, and know that he wants that same sweet spirit in the homes of his children. In the family gathering, Christmas Eve, after the carols are sung, Papa Dade always says, "And now sing 'Love at Home.'" I believe that he asks us to sing that song so that we will remember "Kindly heaven smiles above, when there's love at home." Page 5/3 Fueling the Flame of Testimony Bertha S. Reeder President, Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association LADDIN of Arabian Nights fame secured an old battered lamp of magical powers. By its aid he acquired great wealth. He bought a magnificent palace and became influential in his country. A wicked magician determined to gain possession of the lamp. He knew human nature very well; he bought bright new lamps and went to the palace, offering "new lamps for old." Aladdin's wife, knowing nothing of the magical powers of the old lamp, gladly exchanged it for the new one. Aladdin's palace, wealth, and influence vanished overnight. Each youth in the Church has within himself, waiting to be lighted, the fire of testimony, worth far more than any Aladdin's lamp. Once it is lighted, no one except himself can take its powers or blessings away from its possessor; but unless it is kept trimmed and fueled it may go out — because the owner has been careless. How this fire is lighted is a serious and difficult matter. Any fire to be lighted and made to burn has a pattern that must be followed. There must be tinder, kindling, fuel to keep the fire going, and a match to fire it. The tinder for a testimony must be laid by the parents, neighbors, teachers, and officers of the various units in which the young person moves. Oliver Wendell Holmes said that if you want to educate Page 574 hedrin, a man of wisdom. Someone you should begin with his grandmother. 'Thus heritage plays an important part in the life of anyone who wishes to gain a lasting testimony. Other things being equal, parents with a testimony impart that feeling for belief to their offspring. But we cannot stop with inheriting a good background in which to grow and develop a testimony. The tinder of inheritance may be there, but fuel for the flame must be added by the person who wishes to gain a testimony. 'There is no substitute for hard work and study in order to gain knowledge and truth. No magical powers can give youth a testimony, no Aladdin's lamp can make it glow. There have been only one or two cases where a testimony came as a bolt of lightning, bringing conviction instantaneously. 'The conversion of Saul of 'Tarsus was one such instance. Yet—as we consider all of the facts in the case, were there not preparation and study and work on Saul's part before conversion came? Saul, both a Jew and a citizen of Rome, born in cosmopolitan 'Tarsus, studied under Gamaliel, one of the SanIt was Gamaliel who said when Peter and the apostles were called before the council:... Ye men of Israel, take heed to yourselves what ye intend to do as touching these men.... FUELING THE FLAME OF TESTIMONY And now I say unto you, Refrain from these men, and let them alone: for if this counsel or this work be of men, it will come to nought: But if it be of God, ye cannot overthrow it; lest haply ye be found even to fight against God (Acts 5:35; 38-39). Even if misguided Saul fought against the Church, his training had been such that he recognized the truth of the miracle when it occurred. The youth of Zion also have been taught correct principles — the tinder has been laid on which they may build. When eight years of age, they have been baptized and confirmed members of the Church. With the confirmation came a great blessing: the Holy Ghost was given:. Even the Comforter, which showeth all things, and teacheth the peaceable things of the kingdom.... Which manifesteth all things which are expedient unto the children of men (D. & C. 39:6; 18:18). HE Holy Ghost affords the match which will light the testimony of young people. But they must be taught the power of this Personage of Spirit; they must have strong leaders who realize the importance of being true followers of God the Father and Jesus Christ his Son. 'True leaders will add to that which parents teach their young folk. Both will teach the true meaning of prayer, because it is through prayer that we come in close touch with our Eternal Father. Prayer becomes the compass that charts a true course back to our Father in heaven. Leaders help young people realize that our Father is a Personage such as we are, 575 and that he is interested in our welfare and eager to give us our blessings, if we but ask them from him. As Jesus said: If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children, how much more shall your Father which is in heaven give good things to them that ask him (Mt. 7:11). A boy in the service felt ashamed to kneel in prayer before his companions. He felt that they would deride him. So he would crawl into bed and then offer his prayers while lying down. One night he could stand it no longer. He knelt down by his bed and offered his heartfelt prayers to his Father in heaven. When he arose, he expected that the others would mock him. Instead, his companion said, "I am glad you are a boy who believes in prayer as I do." One must live with prayer to gain a testimony of the truthfulness of the gospel. 'The first thing in the morning a youth should offer up a prayer for the day ahead; and the last thing at night he should offer up his prayer of gratitude for the day's activities. He should pray without ceasing, if he wishes his life to reach the heights. He should add to his prayer, works. As the Lord revealed to the Prophet, there is no end to what we should learn: And as all have not faith, seek ye diligently and teach one another words of wisdom; yea, seek ye out of the best books words of wisdom; seek learning, even by study and also by faith (D. & C. 88:118). Teach ye diligently and my grace shall attend you, that you may be instructed more perfectly in theory, in principle, in doctrine, in the law of the gospel, in all things that pertain unto the kingdom of God, that are expedient for you to understand; Of things both in heaven and in the earth, and under the earth; things which have been, things which are, things which must shortly come to pass; things which are at home, things which are abroad; the wars and the perplexities of nations, and the judgments which are on the land; and a knowledge also of countries and of kingdoms— That ye may be prepared in all things when I shall send you again to magnify the calling whereunto I have called you, and the mission with which I have commissioned you (D. & C. $8:78-80). This comes as a commandment to all youth — as to all adults. The entire world is the object of a missionary program. Those who wish to participate in this conversion program will need to know the countries and the histories of countries, having understanding and love for all peoples, and adding that to their testimony of the gospel, which will bring added enlightenment to these peoples. HROUGH a. Study of these things which the Lord has commanded us to learn, we shall come to know truth. Joseph Smith revealed "... Truth is knowledge of things as they are, and as they were, and as they are to come..." 93:24). He said, furthermore, "... The truth abideth forever and ever" (D. & C. 1:39). Young people need to know the truth. As Jesus said, "And ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free" (John 8:32). If they seek the truth, young people will find that their testimony will be firmly founded. 'They will not then be swayed by every wind that blows, by every new fad that sweeps by them, by every disaster that may overtake them. They will weigh and consider, pray, and seek wise counsel, and they will come to know of a surety that this is the true gospel, re-established by our Eternal Father for the development and joy of his children. Thousands of our young people know that the Church is true, but sometimes they feel to follow the example of Aladdin's wife: they trade old lamps for new. They sell their precious heritage for a "mess of pottage," even as Esau sold his birthright to Jacob for food. A testimony is a precious thing; it grows by constant feeding, just as a flame must be constantly fueled in order to continue to live. It is interesting to watch a testimony grow in a young person's heart. When World War II was at its height, a chaplain in the service was assisted by a young woman who had been appointed his aide. Every Sunday morning he brought her to Sunday School. It wasn't long before a spark began to kindle. She attended sacrament meetings and firesides, upon invitation. Soon she began to seek the truth and ask questions. Arrangements were made for the missionaries in the area to hold classes with her. Since the young woman's mother had passed away several years before, the girl seemed to desire companionship and understanding. A year of study and investigation passed, and then she came one night to the mission headquarters and applied for baptism. She was very humble and had a firm understanding of the gospel, which she had acquired by study and prayer. She was bap- 576 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 FUELING THE FLAME OF TESTIMONY tized and confirmed a member of the Church. Since that time she has been married in the temple, is doing the work for her kindred dead, and living a good Latter-day Saint life. F I were a young girl or boy at the very threshold of life, I would resolve to have a plan or goal to follow in building that life; no great building or bridge or organization has ever been built by blind opportunism. I would not want to leave to chance the kind of life I wanted to build for myself. Although I could conceivably draw the plans for my life, after all, a person in his teens is not very well qualified for such a task. Surely such an important job would require the hand of a master architect, and I would want the very best, one who knows more about me and my possibilities than anyone else. Is such an architect available to young people in the Church? One such Architect is our Heavenly Father. He has drawn up for all a plan of salvation: the gospel of Jesus Christ. Obeying the blueprint of the principles of the gospel: attending sacrament meetings, paying tithing, keeping the Word of Wisdom, keeping the Sabbath day holy, serving 577 others, living by prayer, I would learn to know and trust in my Heavenly Father. Obeying these principles, I would go forth confidently to build my life, realizing as any builder must, that the end product will depend upon no one else but me, the builder, I would guard my actions, my thoughts, my time, so that I would build a good life, one in which a testimony could flourish and burn brightly all the days of my life. I would be alert to grasp every opportunity to improve myself, seeking help from many sources. 'l'o do less than my best in building my life according to the gospel plan revealed in these latter days, would be to let down myself, my parents, and my Father in heaven. The real goal in mortality is the achievement by righteous living of an eternal life in our Father's kingdom. By living a clean, chaste life through prayer, by study, by observation of the principles of the gospel, I would build a testimony that will endure through all the eternities to come. I would not exchange old lamps for new—but would find the fire of testimony lighting my path into a lifetime of happiness here and everlasting life hereafter. Mlother-Sculptor Mabel Law Atkinson How patiently she works with living clay, Molding with willing, tender hands and heart — Each pliant form, no thought of self or pay; But praying that the finished works of art Reflect the Master, and as time unrolls, Be flawless temples for immortal souls. Flygare, President of the Scandinavian Mission, with headquarters in Copenhagen, wrote a letter to Albert Carrington, President of the European Mission, at Liverpool, under date of November 20, 1875, in which he stated that two Elders had been sent from Sweden, to preach the gospel in Finland. "Two Swedish Elders have been sent to Finland, to open the gospel door for that nation. I have had very encouraging news from them; they have had a chance to hold meetings and the power of God has been greatly manifested in their behalf" (Millennial Star, XXXVII, 708). These two first missionaries to Finland were brothers, Carl A. And John E. Sundstrom, members of the Church from Sweden. Converts were made and the first baptism was performed on May 7, 1876, "in the vicinity of Nikolaistad." Four persons were baptized during the year 1876, and in December a branch was organized at Nikolaistad — the first branch in the mission. Other elders were sent to Finland in the years following and the missionary work was extended. Great difficulty was experienced by the missionaries on account of the severity of the laws. One law was to the effect From the Finnish Travel Bureau Submitted by Hertense B. Robinson LAKE SAIMAA, EAST CENTRAL FINLAND A Paradise for Boating and Fishing Page 578 THE FINNISH MISSION 579 From the Finnish Travel Bureau Submitted by Hortense B. Robinson A FINNISH SAUNA (BATH HOUSE) IN WINTER Bath houses are situated on the seashore or on lakes or bays, and are typical of Finland. A hot steam bath followed by a swim in either summer or winter is a favorite recreation. That when teaching the gospel they could not stand up; they were forced to remain seated. The number of converts grew slowly; in November 1890, the combined membership of the Church was thirty-five, including three elders and two priests. President Ezra Taft Benson of the European Mission visited Finland in July 1946 and at Larsmo rededicated the land to the preaching of the gospel. Finland remained a district of the Swedish Mission until it was organized as a separate mission on September 1, 1947, with Henry A. Matis as president. President David O. McKay and party visited the Finnish Mission in June 1952, and held a mission-wide conference at Helsinki. President Matis presided in Finland until December 1954, when he was succeeded by Phileon B. Robinson, who presides at the present time. On March 31, 1956 there were 613 members of the Church in Finland, located in fourteen branches. In December 1954, thirteen Relief Society organizations were reported, with 221 members. Hortense B. Robinson presides over the Finnish Mission Relief Society.
