Yost County Fair Book carefully, but she thumbed through the Women's Division again: Needlecraft, Sewing, Canning, Baking, Remodeling, Arts, Crafts, Painting, and Sculpturing. Why, the highest prize of all was given in the field of sculpturing. Perhaps it was for encouragement. Romaine remembered that the needlecraft, baking, and sewing booths were overcrowded with fine displays last year. Every housewife sewed and baked and did handwork, Romaine thought, but almost no one seemed to sculpture. "What I could do with a prize like that!" Romaine said aloud. She fell to dreaming. She remembered her high school days when she had carved a tiny horse and colt from an ordinary bar of laundry soap. Miss Rembrant, the art teacher, had wanted her to enroll in an art school after graduation, but instead, she had married Sam Wuthrich of Swiss decent, as soon as Romaine and her mother could assemble a suitable trousseau. Romaine had then turned her artistic talents to homemaking. She looked about the home she had made. Surely she hadn't wasted her talent. Her home showed good taste. The entire house was attractive, though frugally furnished. Why she had refashioned the old cheerless kitchen until it resembled a Currier and Ives print, fragrant and wholesome. Page 580 R 'coms had read the entire Romaine had done lots of sewing and baking, and made flower arrangements for the fair. In all, she had taken seven blue ribbons for her homemaking accomplishments. "This year will be different." Romaine doubled her fist with determination. "This year someone else can take the blue ribbons for pies, petticoats, and petunias. I'm going out for higher stakes, the sculpture prize." Romaine knew if she were to have a piece of sculpture lovely enough to enter in the county fair, she must start working on it now. She had been making figurines from the children's clay for years, and she had tried her hand at whittling wood. But, to enter the contest, she should have something of size with which to work. Romaine remembered again the horse and colt she had carved from a bar of laundry soap. Good white soap was fine to work with, but you couldn't buy soap in a big brick. Could she make it? "That's what Pll do. Tll make a batch of soap this very day!" Sheer perseverance registered on her face. There wasn't time this morning to go to the store for lye, but her neighbor, Mrs. Barnes, had all sorts of things on hand. Things she hardly ever used. Would she have some lye? Romaine hurried next door to the Barnes' home. Mrs. Barnes, always obliging, mounted a kitchen stool and peered into the cupboard above the sink. Sure enough, from SOMETHING ARTISTIC the most remote corner, she drew forth a can of lye. "Thanks," Romaine said. "Tl get you a can the first time I go to the store. I must rush now. I left the little children alone." ACK in her own kitchen, Romaine sat down to read the directions on the lye can for making soap. "What are you doing, Momie?" The children hovered about her, Karen eight, and the younger boys, Kim and Kent. Romaine knew she just couldn't make soap with the children around. The two basic infredients for making soap, lye and grease, were far too dangerous to work with around children. "Look, Karen," Romaine spoke to her little daughter as if she were grown up, "if you'll keep the little boys outside in the yard until I call Pll make those doll clothes you want, after everyone is in bed tonight. Keep them busy and happy in the sand pile, but don't let them wander out of the yard. I've just got to make a batch of soap this morning." "Soap!" Karen was only eight, but she knew the importance of soap in keeping two little brothers and their clothes clean. She hustled the little boys out the back door. "Come, brothers, Sissie will show you a new sand pile game." "Bless her heart!'" Romaine smiled, watching Karen herding her little brothers like a hen clucking over her chickens. "I must remember to make the doll clothes tonight, even if I'm dead tired." Romaine locked the screen door to assure herself uninterrupted privacy while she worked. 'The 581 recipe on the can called for six cups of melted grease, five cups of water, and one can of lye. Well, she had everything, if she had enough grease. She saved all her grease drippings, and she had quite a little suet trimmed from steaks and roasts. Still, when melted, it wouldn't make six full cups. Romaine remembered the old home-cured bacon. Why they had had it two years or more. And no one in the family would eat it. Just the thing for my soap, thought Romaine, and she hurried to the deep freeze in the utility room, where she had tucked away the old bacon. Romaine watched the grease bubling and melting on the electric stove. 'The directions on the lye can said the grease should be eightyfive degrees. She would use her candy thermometer to test the temperature. When the grease was slightly beyond the melting stage, the mercury reached eighty-five, so she removed the kettle from the electric burner. Romaine poured five cups of cold water in her earthen crock, the directions had cautioned against using any galvanized container. Then, donning a long-sleeved shirt of Sam's and a pair of work gloves, and taking a long-handled wooden spoon, she carefully stirred in the lye.. She had heard that dry lye was comparatively harmless, but moistened lye was deadly. She kept her head turned and refrained from inhaling or letting the fumes get in her eyes, as she stirred it until the lye was thoroughly dissolved. OMAINE cleaned off the grease from the thermometer and tested the lye solution. The mercury quickly raised to seventy-five degrees. It was amazing that cold water and lye could reach such a temperature. But Romaine knew that even a cold solution of lye was not cold. In fact, it was hot and dangerous! And the hot grease was dangerous! She hoped the children would not come in now! She would be glad when she was through working with grease and lye. Soon she could miraculously turn them into white, lovely, sweetsmelling soap! Slowly, Romaine poured the six cupfuls of hot grease into the lye solution, stirring continually, yet very gently, lest the grease and lye separate. It took about five minutes of stirring, after the last cup of grease was poured in, for the solution to become a thick honey-like substance. She knew then the chemical process of lye-eating-grease had taken place, and in the doing the whole was transformed into soap. Romaine sighed with relief. She had finished the dangerous task with no interruptions from the children. Now she must hurry and clean up the mess. She rinsed the lye can in hot water, lest some particles of lye might remain and some little person get it out of the trash can. As she cleaned the utility room, she planned a quick nutritious lunch for the children and Sam. Soon she heard the children coming and unlatched the screen door. "Momie, is the soap 'bout done?" Karen asked. "I'm so tired watching them." "You're a good girl. All of you come in now and wash for lunch." a 6) Re is OMAINE opened her eyes to such a morning as Utah has on a rare and perfect day. It was the hushed moment before dawn. Somewhere in the mist-shrouded valley a cock crowed lustily. "No wonder I'm tired," Romaine sighed to herself. "Besides the regular routine, I made doll clothes until twelve o'clock last night, and a batch of soap in the morning." Remembering the soap, Romaine bounded from the bed, and _ grabbing a robe, almost ran to the utility room. She had turned the crock upside down last night, inside one of the sinks. Now she gently lifted the crock, and looked at the nice round mound of white soap. It was beautiful, and this very afternoon, while the children slept, she would start carving her figurine. As Romaine went about her morning tasks she thought of Cyrus Dallin, the sculptor, and the immortal statue of the Angel Moroni, high upon the Salt Lake Temple. She thought of the pictures of the figure of David, carved out of stone by Michelangelo. Vividly, in her mind's eyes, she saw what had once been a block of stone miraculously turned into head, body, and limbs, each seemingly able to move. Why Michelangelo had even been able to show sadness on David's face. While she washed the breakfast dishes and Karen dried the knives and forks, Romaine pictured in her mind the gentle curves and indentures she would make when she started carving her soap figurine. "There, we're through with the dishwashing," Romaine — spoke sweetly. "Karen, you go tidy your room. Make the bed real well, 582 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 SOMETHING ARTISTIC and T'll do the bunk beds in the boys' room." Romaine's hands were busy smoothing sheets and bed clothes, but her mind was prematurely busy, carving a soap figurine. "Momie, come and see." Kim and Kent rushed into the bedroom, and were swishing her skirts. "We have a surprise! Come see the surprise!" 'They hurried her to the utility room. "Look, Momie, we helped you. We cut the soap in bars," they chorused. "It's all ready for washday." "Yes, darlings, the soap is all ready for washday." Romaine managed to keep her voice calm while her heart thudded. She hurried from the house, lest the children see the tears she could not control. Later, she would gather up the crudely cut bars of homemade soap, and store them away for washing. Outside, the birds sang in the hedges and trees, or darted over helds on either side of her. Neither her children nor the birds knew that her hopes and dreams had been cut in pieces by several gashes of a butcher knife. ASHDAY and ironing day came and went, but Romaine could think of nothing but having something lovely to enter in the sculpture division at the county fair. There wasn't any more grease to make soap and, anyway, it was too dangerous to repeat with the children always underfoot. Then one morning Sam came in from milking and said, "Romaine, the hay is all up, and there's a little time now, I think I'll borrow a 583 mixer and get some cement and sand mixed, and pour the forms and floor for the chicken coop." Romaine looked at Sam as he stood in the doorway. Sam wouldn't be classed as handsome, but he certainly was attractive, even in work clothes, with his shock of thick dark hair and his features lean and sharply defined. What had he said? Pour cement for a coop. Why! Why! Romaine's mind was revolving like a second hand. She remembered that Miss Rembrant, her art teacher, had told of a man in Florida who did all of his carvings in cement. Not hardened completely, just set-up cement. If Sam poured the cement for the coop now, she could use some of it and carve her figurine for the fair! "What do you think about going ahead with the cement now?" Sam asked again. "Sam, I think that's a wonderful idea, pouring the cement now, I mean." Inwardly Romaine's heart was pounding with excitement, but she thought it best not to bring up her plans about the leftover cement. She and Sam had many things in common, but one of them wasn't a love of art. Sam, seeing the sparkle and excitement in her eyes, put his arms tenderly around her. "Gee, honey, I knew you wanted a chicken coop, but I didn't know it meant this much to you. I'll get things around right away." The clock was nearing the lunch hour when Sam finally had the floor of the coop perfectly level. Romaine had walked out to see how the work was coming along, and had taken her crock to fill with the remains from the mixer. The children were running ahead of her. "Why don't you let the little ones put their hand prints along the side, Romaine?" Sam asked. He was tired, but he had the satisfaction of knowing his was a good job well done. "Oh, chorused. Romaine stooped over the wet cement and_ started placing little hands on the surface. "Bill Martin wants to use this mixer this afternoon,' Sam called to her. "T'll take it to him right after we eat lunch. Guess I better wash it out before we go in the house." He reached for the nearby hose. "Wait!" Romaine ran to the mixer with the crock in hand. "I, I want some cement!" She ducked her head into the mixer, trying to salvage the last of the cement. "Look, honey, will you move so I can clean this thing up?" In his haste, Sam pushed her gently aside and turned the hose into the mixer. Romaine stood, empty crock in hand, and watched enough cement for two nice figurines washed away. She dared not look at Sam lest her face register a spark of hatred. She turned on her heel and went to the house. The house was dark, after being in the bright sunshine, and to Romaine it seemed a refuge for her grief. She told herself over and over, it was her own fault. She should have told Sam of her dream. She should have let him know what she wanted the cement for. But goodie!" the children things closest to the heart are often the hardest to share. "Are we going to raise chickens, Momie? Are we going to raise chickens to lay eggs?" The children pressed at her heels, leaving her no privacy. HEN Sam entered the door, she studied his face. No, he didn't know how deeply he had hurt her. His face showed only that he had had a hard day's work crammed into one morning. Romaine realized that mixing, pouring, and leveling cement all alone was hard labor. She served the dinner. If it killed her, she would never let Sam know what that little dab of leftover cement had meant to her. Sam and the children ate like hungry miners. Romaine nibbled at her food. She wasn't hungry. Inwardly, she complimented herself on being quite an actress, for nobody seemed to have the faintest notion that incased in her being was a broken heart. The children took their naps and Sam went to his work. The hours straggled on. Romaine knew that Sam was truly a wonderful husband and father, but, even so, she did wish that she could inject just a trifle of her artistic appreciation into him. Then, at last, it was night, and Romaine was listening to the little children saying prayers, and tucking them between clean, white sheets. Afterward, she gave a sigh and stretched herself out on her own bed. Later, she would get up and join Sam in the living room, and read or sew buttons on little play clothes, but, nght now, she would 584 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 SOMETHING ARTISTIC close her eyes and rest. It had been a long, weary day, but it was not physical exhaustion which had depleted her. Romaine had an early breakfast ready and waiting on the table for Sam when he came in from the milking. As she waited, she looked at the calendar hanging on the wall. She had circled the county fair, which was just two weeks away. She wondered what kind of pie she would enter this year. Last year she had taken the blue ribbon with a luscious raisin cream pie. Perhaps her hot mince pie would tickle the judges' palates. And the apple struddle which she had experimented with, why that would be a fine entry in the original recipe division! And she could enter Karen's coat in the made-over sewing division. Romaine picked up the fair book for further inspiration, but all she could see was the sculpturing, with the highest prize of all. "You dreamer!" She chided herself aloud. "Who's a dreamer?" Sam asked, coming through the doorway with a sack on his shoulder. She didn't need a sack of flour. "Sam Wuthrich, what on earth have you there?" Romaine asked, staring at the sack as he stood it up behind the kitchen door. "Bought this late yesterday, when I was in town, but didn't take the time to unload it," Sam answered. "And, pray tell, what is it?" Romaine asked again. "Honey, this is what they call sandcrete. 'here's a whole fifty pounds of it. It sets up like stone, they tell me. Real good for carving, which you like to do, if it's still sort 585 of wet. I'll bet if you tinkered with it you could do something real pretty. Now I'm not busy today, and if you'll fix up a picnic for us, ll take the children to the zoo and the park. Better throw in some wading togs, and we'll make a day of it." "But, Sam!' Romaine was too amazed to speak. She couldn't remember a day when she hadn't had the children hovering around, except when she was in the hospital with a new baby, and that time she went to help her father, when he was ill. "You can have the day to do as you please, honey. And I don't mean washing and ironing, or wallpapering and painting, something relaxing!" Sam nodded toward the sandcrete, standing in the corner. The words Romaine wanted to express seemed to form a big lump in her throat, but Sam seemed to read them as clearly as if they were written in the air. "Do you think," Romaine's voice was almost a whispered prayer, "that I can carve it?" "Of course you can carve it!" Sam replied with conviction. "You've had years of experience molding bread and pies and meat loaf. And when you get it finished, it'll probably take the sweepstakes ribbon at the county fair." Romaine's face lighted up with a heartwarming smile. Sam looked at her and saw a new inner beauty. He drew her to him and kissed her fully and completely. Romaine had to take deep, steady breaths, lest she glitter too much with happiness. Life was truly a thing of beauty! Bulbs for Winter Blossoming Dorthea N. Newbold Garden Editor, Deseret News - Salt Lake Telegram HE dreary days of winter can be brightened with a display of colorful, fragrant blooms of bulbs. Forced into flowering ahead of their usual blooming period, an early springtime can be enjoyed at close range by the apartment house dweller, or by the occupant of city or country home. Hyacinths, tulips, daffodils, crocuses, and paper-whites can be forced into early flowering in your window garden, providing a few basic rules are followed. For example, on daffodils you may have seen the leaves and stems form beautifully, and the flower buds begin to swell, but there the growth stopped, and the flowers never developed. This condition is termed bud blast or blasting. The main cause is lack of enough roots in the pot to enable the bulbs to carry out the full possibilities of flowering. Diseased bulbs will act in the same manner; but it is possible to buy excellent quality, disease-free bulbs. Early planting, to allow time for the proper development of a root system, is of prime importance. This period varies somewhat with each different kind of bulb. Simplest to grow are those bulbs which will flourish in pebbles and water. Possibly the best known of these varieties are the snowy paperwhites. The yellow Soleil d'Or and the white and yellow Chinese sacred lily are also good subjects for Page 586 growing in water. 'These are all classed as polyanthus daffodils, and successful flowering should be the tule, but unsatisfactory results are seen too often. First, secure firm top-size bulbs, as soon as they come on the markets. Store in a flat in a cool room until the last of October. Use containers deep enough to allow the bulbs to be set firmly in pebbles with two inches or more of space below for roots. Fill the bowls with water, room temperature, to one-half inch above the bottom of the bulbs. Thereafter keep the water level fairly constant at the base of the bulbs. You will need to add water twice a week. Add a piece of charcoal to keep the water sweet. A shaded shelf, either in a_basement or utility room, where the temperature does not rise above fifty-five degrees Fahrenheit, is the best place to keep daffodils while the roots are forming. The main items to watch during the rooting period are to keep the water at the desirable level, to keep the bulbs in a dark, cool place, and to provide ventilation. _ After three weeks, use a pencil carefully to push aside the pebbles to see if the bottom of the bowl is well filled with roots. When the bowl is full of roots, the daffodils can be brought into light. Avoid direct light until the foliage turns green. Then give as much sunlight BULBS FOR WINTER BLOSSOMING Dorthea "Newbold POTTED TULIPS as possible to promote quick growth, which will mean shorter, sturdier stems. For longer lasting blooms, remove from the sunlight as the flowers open. HE tender French Roman hyacinths can also be grown in water. These bulbs produce blooms that are a blue, white, or rose-pink. The bell-shaped blooms are not as closely packed along the central spike as are the bells of the Dutch hyacinths, but they are a lovely addition to the indoor garden. Allow them to make roots for about eight weeks in the same cool, dark place you have provided for the paper-whites. The familiar Dutch hyacinths are easily grown in special hyacinth glasses, but are difficult to manage in bowls of pebbles. The hyacinth glass is quite tall, and has a cupshaped top which holds the bulb. 587 Only enough water should be used to keep it touching the base of the bulb. Refill the glass as needed. Dutch hyacinths must be stored in a cool dark place, and usually it takes about twelve weeks for the bulb to fill the lower part of the glass with roots. Then it will be three or four more weeks growing in light before the large bloom opens. To be sure that the stems and leaves are sturdy and strong, place them in strong sunlight as soon as the foliage has turned green. While there are only a few bulbs that can be brought into flower by growing in water, there are many that can be forced in soil. Regulation-type clay pots, bulb pans, and glazed pots may be used successfully to grow the bulbs. Whatever the type of container you select, the soil and method of growing the plants remain the important part. You will need two parts good top soil and one part leaf mold or compost. Mix in enough sand so that the mixture crumbles in your hand when moist. Place an arching piece of broken flower pot over the drainage hole. For drainage material, use about a one-inch layer of small pebbles. Fill in with the potting mixture to the level at which the bulbs will rest. Of course this will vary according to the size of the bulbs. After the bulbs are placed, add more soil, making it firm as you work. Leave about one inch of space at the top to allow room for watering. HE early spring bulbs, grape hyacinths, crocuses, and snowdrops can be forced into blooming indoors. Plant the bulbs in shallow Photograph submitted by Dorthea Newbold A SPRINGTIME WINDOW IN WINTER pots with the bulbs half an inch apart and barely cover them with soil. They should be left in a cool dark place for eight weeks. Water every five days. They may be brought into the light early in January or February. Provide a moist, cold, storage place for tulips, daffodils, and hyacinth bulbs while they are filling the pots with roots. Place the pots in either a well-drained cold frame, or in a shallow trench. Dig the trench twelve inches deep and place a four-inch layer of cinders in the bottom for drainage. Place the containers in and fill in around the pots with peat moss or sharp sand. Add a covering of sharp sand, and cover with leaves or straw. 'This mulch makes it easier to get the bulbs out during the winter. Twelve weeks is a safe period to allow for the root-making processes. 'Then bring the pots into the house and place in a temperature of about fifty degrees. Remove any soil which may be clinging to the pale new shoots. Water plants enough to keep the soil moist, and, as the growth increases, more water will be needed. Water should be at room temperature. As soon as the foliage has started to spread, and the stems are well started, move the plants into bright sunlight. If you can keep the room temperature at sixty degrees, you will have much better results with the bulbs you are forcing. Always turn the plants so that they will grow evenly, and not be one-sided from drawing to- 588 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 BULBS FOR WINTER BLOSSOMING ward the sun. These directions are for all bulbs grown in soil. Tulips may be planted one-half inch apart and with just the tips of the bulbs exposed out of the soil. Water liberally before setting pots in the storage place. Some varieties which will force include: Brilliant Star, Prince of Austria, Price Carnival, General DeWit, Apricot Yellow, Ibis, and White Hawk. All of those listed above are the single early tulips. 'The double early tulips are not recommended for forcing. Others recommended are: Krelage's 'Triumph, Van der Erden, White Sail, Weber, John Gay, William Pitt, Red Pitt, William Copeland, Rose Copeland, Crater, and Princess Beatrix. Daffodils should be planted with the tips slightly above the soil in the pot. Water thoroughly and set in storage. If they are planted in late September or during October, then the first pots can be started into active growth by the middle of January. It takes about four weeks 589 for the plants to flower after being brought out of storage. 'Try these daffodils: Carlton, Early Perfection, Golden Harvest, Helios, King Alfred, Magnificence, Rembrandt, Scarlet Elegance. Dutch hyacinths are possibly the best liked of all the potted bulbs. Set a large bulb in a four-inch pot, or five bulbs can be set in an eightinch bulb pan. The tips of the bulbs should be out of the soil. Water thoroughly after planting. Store for at least eight weeks. When they are brought into the house, the new tips of growth will be blanched. Keep in indirect sunlight and in a fifty-five degrees Fahrenheit temperature until the leaves turn green. 'Then they can be given direct sunlight. They will flower in a seventy-degree temperature, but the flowers will be much better quality if they are grown in a lower temperature. Forcing varieties which are highly reeommended include Bismarck, L'Innocence, and Pink Pearl. > Autumn Sidings Elsie McKinnon Strachan Now migrant, feathered folk make noisy talk; Beneath my sill, their chatter Punctuating dawn; till, flight plans made, With a whir, they scatter. Page 590 TWENTY women are Members of Parliament in India's lower House of the People. In India a bill has recently been passed _permitting wives, widows, and daughters to inherit family property and to dispose of it as they see fit. This is a great forward step in the area of women's rights. Many men fought the proposition, but Nehru said, "I believe that if any great advances are coming to India, they will come largely through the women of India." ERMAN women still live up to their reputation for industry. All spring and summer, grandmothers, wives, and daughters have been working in the fields. Many young women are employed as translators in business firms. Many act as guides for foreign-speaking people. As a rule their English is excellent. Then, there are teachers and journalists. A surprising number of physicians' and dentists' signs bear women's names. 'Two German women physicians are on the staff of the United States Army in Frankfurt. HEN the medical school in Vienna first opened its doors after the war, a large number of Viennese women were among those who gained admittance. Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Page 591 DIT ORIAL a, VOL. 43 SEPTEMBER 1956 'And Shey Shall Seach Sheir Ghiliren c O one can rear a child today without often despairing over the little time that the child is in the home in his waking hours, especially after he enters school. Activities of all types are continually pulling and diverting his attention from the home. Section sixty-eight of the Doctrine and Covenants gives some instructions from the Lord to Latter-day Saint parents to guide them in the proper rearing of their children. 'The commandments are focused on training children before they reach the years of accountability, emphasizing the vital import of those first eight years. By the time children are to be baptized their parents are expected to have taught them " the doctrine of repentance, faith in Christ the Son of the living God, and of baptism and the gift of the Holy Ghost by the laying on of the hands..." (D. & C. 68:25) A love for his Lord and Savior should be a life-sustaining force rooted deep in a child's soul, never to perish. He should be carefully taught so that he understands that the Savior died for him and he should know the love Jesus showed in dying for him. 'The added knowledge of the nearness and dearness of his Heavenly Father to him at all times, as exemplified by his sending his Beloved Son into the world to die that everyone may go back to his heavenly home, may be recognized and expressed by the child in his prayers. Page 592 The soul of a child is so perfect that to enter the kingdom of heaven one must become as a little child. Childish faith, as one grows older, however, may shrivel if a mother does not continually see to it that it is constantly nourished. Family and individual prayers, family hours, reading of the scriptures together, attendance at sacrament meeting, at Sunday School, Primary, and, later, the Priesthood quorums and M. I. A., foster faith. Where a mother encourages her children's attendance she is nurturing their faith. Her own acceptance and example in supporting Church activities foster a kindred spirit in her children. Sometimes a mother fails to evaluate blessings at their true worth. 'This may be illustrated by the value placed by one mother on that great blessing to be married for time and all eternity in a temple of the Lord. She seemed to weigh eternal progression in a balance against the wearing of immodest clothing; and the clothing outweighed the eternal balance wheel. Her daughter had not been taught a true perspective, and she did not have a temple marriage. Another mother found it pleasurable to fritter away her time rather than to devote herself to the Church organizations. Her knowledge of the gospel shrank as she filled her mind with non-essentials. Another mother gave her services only to the community, which EDITORIAL crowded out and became pre-eminent over any effort on her part to build up the kingdom of God. Her daily living pattern shadowed the way for her daughters, who gradually lost interest in the ward activities and became inactive. Nevertheless, no woman is in a position to judge another. Only an all-wise Father can judge. It behooves every Latter-day Saint woman, however, to seek by loving, understanding persuasion and effort, to impress eternal values on her thoughtless sister and, at all 593 times, to set an example of righteousness in humility. The Lord must be pleased with the mother who always has time for loving attention, painstaking care, and faith-promoting unfolding of the great plan of salvation as a precious gift to her children. The early telling and living of gospel principles nurture the seeds of faith in her children and give to them sustenance until each child grows, by faith, his own tree of saving knowledge. —M. C. S. Bowles Let your life be like a bud— Unfold with petals rare Tinted and shaped in God's design To become a woman fair. Be Honest with Yourself Healthy, Happy. Lucky You! LUC is the youth who has learned that health, success, and happiness come with clean living. Lucky is the youth who has learned that some things should not be touched or tampered with... That some things should be left alone. Lucky is the youth who learns this lesson early in life, from parents and from the teachings of the Church — and who doesn't have to learn it the hard way. Page 594 HEALTHY, HAPPY, LUCKY YOU! 595 Health and happiness and success are what our Father in heaven wants for us. And that is why he has given us commandments to keep — and not for any other reason. Health and happiness and success are what our parents want for us. And that is why they give us counsel and commandments — and not for any other reason. We have one mind and one memory — and it deserves to be clear and clean. We have one earthly body which must last for a lifetime. Our Maker planned it that way. He knows what is good for us. He knows what will give us health and happiness and success and peace inside ourselves. 'That is why he has told us how to live; that is why he has told us to leave some things alone. Lucky you; you don't have to learn everything the hard way. Lucky you; you can learn early from those who love you. Lucky you; you don't have to pay a painful price for learning how to live — you don't have to learn too late. Be smart. Be clean. Be virtuous. Be healthy. Be happy. Whitefish, burbots, or perches 5% c. Water 2 tbsp. Salt 5% c. Or 3 lbs. Rye meal or ¥% Ib. Fatty pork partly wheat flour 3% tbsp. Butter or fat Knead dough well; it may be solid, but not very hard. Roll out dough into oval shape on a board sprinkled with flour; let the rolled-out dough remain a little thicker in the middle. Put scaled and cleaned, absolutely dry fish in a high heap on the rolled dough that has been sprinkled with flour, alternating layers of fish with layers or slices Page 596 RECIPES FROM THE FINNISH MISSION 597 of pork fat; salt each layer. Put the fish into pasty always with heads and bones, only clip fins with scissors. Cut big fishes into pieces. Liver, roe, and milt are also used for the pasty. Also miscellaneous fish or lake breams' heads may be used for the pasty. Fold coat of dough from two sides over the heap of fish and join the ends with water into one seam. Rub the pasty with rye flour and put it immediately into hot oven. When the pasty has formed a crust and becomes a little brown, brush the flour off from the surface of the pasty and rub the pasty at short intervals with a slice of pork fat. Let the pasty bake in a slow oven from five to six hours, which makes the fishbones perfectly soft. Near the end of the baking process the pasty may be wrapped into a moist towel or parchment paper, if you want the coat of the pasty soft. Thus wrapped, let the pasty mature in the oven for awhile. Serves 4. The "Kalakukko" pasty is served warm or cold, with butter, potatoes, and milk (or sour milk). RUTABAGAS IN CASSEROLE 2-4 Ibs. Rutabagas milk water, salt sugar to suit taste 2 tbsp. MamMIl An Easter dish in Finland, made of rye meal and malt 8-10 qts. Water 6 tbsp. Ground orange peel " Ib. Malt 4% Ibs. Rye meal 7 tsp. Salt Mix into two quarts of the water, one-quarter of the malt and a little rye meal. Sprinkle a thick layer of malt and rye meal on the surface, cover the kettle well, and leave it in some warm place for one hour. 'Then stir the meal and the water in the kettle so that they mix and add some more water. Sprinkle malt and meal on the surface, cover the kettle and let the mixture sweeten for about one hour. Continue this process until all the water and malt have been used up. The last portion of water is added boiling. So much meal should be used that "Mammi" resembles thin porridge; add seasoning and cook "Mammi' for awhile, stirring 'all the time. Beat it until it is quite cool. Fill small casseroles half-full and bake "Mammi" in a comparatively hot oven for about three hours. Boxes, instead of casseroles, made of birch bark give more flavor and are best. Serve "Mammi" cold with cream and _ sugar. Serves 6. Helps for Accompanists Roy M. Darley Assistant Tabernacle Organist [Address Delivered in the Music Department Meeting of the Annual General Relief Society Conference, September 29, 1955] HE subject given me to discuss this morning is of vital concern, for it is universally important in every meeting of the Church. The music rendered at the beginning of a Church service influences the spiritual level of the meeting that follows. The organist is the first to indicate the commencement of the Church service with the organ prelude and is also the last to exalt his listeners with the postlude. As a Relief Society organist, you hold a position as important as that of any other organist in the Church, and your preparation should be as careful and thorough as it would be for any other meeting. Keeping in mind that the prelude creates the spiritual setting for the meeting, use great care to select and master appropriate music. Use the prelude to improve your talent; make it an opportunity to perfect technique and registration, so that it becomes a song of praise to our Father in heaven. Careful consideration in selecting repertoire for your meetings will result in your raising the standards of your musical endeavor and, in turn, raising the standard of our Church music. You could use your monthly leadership meeting to good advantage by having the organists from each ward bring their very best preludes to leadership meeting and exchange suggestions for good prelude music. Eight organists conPage 598 tributing two prelude suggestions in leadership meeting would result in organists of that stake having sixteen preludes; in other words, enough preludes for four months' use. 'Title, composer, and publisher are important items in furnishing adequate information. As an organist, you are the righthand aid of the chorister. Remember, there can be only one head to any organization, and in Church music that is the chorister. Wise is the conductor who will bring the organist into her planning of the music. 'There is a joy in working together. On occasion, you will have the opportunity to play an organ solo. Use this as a challenge, a new goal to reach, an achievement to accomplish. Have the organists bring two or three favorite solo suggestions to leadership meetings. The organ solo is something very special and should have melody, beauty, and should fit into the spirit of the meeting. Avail yourselves of any and all opportunities to improve your talents. The Church provides excellent training through Church organ classes — a Course I and a Course II at $5 per course. Avail yourselves of this opportunity to join a class, for you can accomplish a great deal in this period of study. In working on preludes, solos, and hymns, the registration chart which follows has been designed to help HELPS FOR ACCOMPANISTS you with registration on the Baldwin, Connsonata, and Hammond pipe organ. As you will notice, a soft, mezzo forte (medium loud), and forte (loud) registration are given for all of these organs. This chart ORGAN ENSEMBLE REGISTRATION 599 is designed to give general helps and suggestions and in no way does it mean there are not other excellent registrations to be found. We trust they will guide you in your study of the instrument. Still the greatest luxury that came into our lives was the pink box of chocolates... The one with the picture of the laughing Gibson Girl on top. It was Mama's habit of economy that made the night of the chocolate box such a shining memory. It was Saturday night. Mama had put on her good broadcloth coat, her plumed hat, and her inherited fur piece. "You may go to the store with me and carry the shopping bag," she told me. We left the other six children playing cylinder records on an old music box. I can see Mama now, walking down the boardwalk of the mining town in her high-buttoned shoes. The general store, a two-story rock structure in the middle of town, stood with smoke-darkened houses huddled around it like frightened puppies. Whenever Mama entered the store, the miners would pause in their loud laughter and remove their caps. Mama was very pretty. I thought she looked like Pearl White standing there with her plumed hat held high above her slim, straight shoulders. She bought our Saturday night supplies, carefully inquiring into the price of each item. My tongue felt dry when she asked for the regular package of Kickapoo Indian worm lozenges. Mr. Graham put everything in S INCE then we've had a player the shopping bag and said the bill was two dollars and fifteen cents. Mama started to pay him, when she saw the box of chocolates on the shelf. It was a big box with a pink bow and gold letters. 'There was a picture of a beautiful girl on the top. Mama just kept looking at it. It seemed as if she were remembering the days before all the children, when Papa could afford to bring home candy and flowers. It seemed as if she wanted to forget for a moment, that Papa's job was long on work and short on pay and that the forty-hour week was far in the future. She kept staring at the box of chocolates. Mr. Graham said, ""That's a right nice box of candy for only a dollar." Mama stood fingering the coins in her small knitted purse. She looked around the store. I knew she was figuring how much flour or calico a dollar would buy. Suddenly, her pretty cheeks were crimson to her hairline as she saw the miners watching her. She laid the money on the counter. "T'll take the candy," she said, with a sidelong glance at my shining face. CUR feet had wings as we carried the groceries up the incline to our house. "Wait until you see what Mama's got," I called as I bounded through the front door. Out of the mesh shopping bag came the shining box. Large-eyed children whispered, "However did you get it, Mama?" Page 601 both loved and regretted spending that dollar. It was likely her one cherished extravagance in the long years of having and rearing children. This I know, no other chocolates were ever so creamy, so sweetly brown, and so long to be remembered. I can't forget the silken luxury I felt every time I looked at the pink box on Mama's sideboard. However drab the house, the town, or the day—the Gibson Girl smiled, the gold letters sparkled, and neighbor children were impressed. The box stayed with us almost as long as Mama did. It moved with us from one small town to another through Papa's years of railroading. It always went with "the careful things," like Mama's heirloom dishes. "MOTHER IN HER PLUMED HAT" — and most prosperous years. With the abandon of an heiress used _ held in turn, paper dolls, valentines, Looking back now, I know Mama _ est wisp of a wedding veil. It love letters, and, finally, the sheer- Littl Boy Reading a Book Evelyn Dorio I there a more wonderful sight anywhere than a little boy reading a book to himself? Listen to the chuckling sound he makes! It isn't included in the musical keyboard, because no one ever captured it long enough to place it properly. It isn't quite a sharpened flat sound nor yet a flattened sharp sound; it isn't in proper fifths or ninths; yet it is a most natural sound — that reading chuckle! The reading chuckle is different from the shout of football or baseball; diffcrent from the "peanut crackling" of the Wild West matinee, or the "roof-raising ha-ha"' of television. No, indeed, the reading chuckle is rather elegant in parts, an educated sound! " Close observation reveals that the reading chuckle begins with a mild "H'm, h'm, and then adds up toa slur of "h'mmmmm, h'mmmmm," as a boy keeps chasing words across the page. Then the whole chuckle may disappear except for the background of bubbles that float out of his open mouth. The boy now turns the page and opens his eyes wider the better to devour the words! "Hey! Heyeyeyey!"" he warns the hero who is scrambling from paragraph to paragraph. The boy adds a piccolo whistle and "Yeeeeeow! Yeeceowowowow!" This means danger to the hero, and the boy switches on a little red counterpoint beneath his voice. "He, he! Ho, ho!" he pipes from the top of his head (where little boys always hoard their favorite squeaks!) and then a broad and yellow-colored "Ahahahah!" which blows directly out of his relaxing lips, tells you everything came out all right. Notice, next, the reading position a little boy assumes while he's reading a book to himself! It's a jackknifed and two-story-sprawl position! First the book is over his head, then his head is over the book. Or the book's forward, no, it's backward, no, it's two-way animation! Now the book's an incompleted forward pass over his ears, and then it's a straight pitch, unless it could be behind the catcher! Now he slaps down the book or maybe slaps his own tummy in the tumult! So that when he groans "Oh, chohoh!" you can't tell whether it's for his tummy or for his book! 'Then he'll surprise you by settling down to the forward look: elbows anchored, book anchored, mind anchored. But don't miss that special star-spangled face a little boy wears while he's reading a book! You can observe this best, if you speak to him. "It's bedtime, Son!" you say. But he doesn't really hear you. He may look at you, all right, but through a pair of clear and sparkling marbles, and he doesn't see you at all, even in the electric light. You feel as though you're talking to a star; as though you're disturbing a new star. There isn't a more wonderful sight anywhere than a little boy reading a book to himself! _ Gatentions and Actions Celia Luce WE see only the actions of other people, but we judge ourselves by our intentions. Our intentions are usually much better than our actions. We could improve our world if we would take the trouble to find out the intentions of others, and consider their actions in the light of their intentions. And how much better a person I might be if I would take myself to task for my actions, and be very sure that they are my best possible effort. Page 603 Meeting Objections in Selling the Reliof Society agazine Clara Love Magazine Representative, Granite Stake (Utah) [Discussion Presented in the Magazine Department Meeting, Annual General Relief Society Conference, September 29, 1955] HE Magazine representatives have a specific mission. We are striving to place in the homes of the people in our wards and stakes The Relief Society Magazine. We must also help the women to receive full benefit from it. The Magazine must be read, or it cannot fulfill the purpose for which it is published. This may not be an easy task, but if we value our calling and have a love for the work we are doing, we can accomplish much. If the Magazine means much to us and we enjoy reading it, then we can encourage others to do the same. We should know what our Magazine contains and be prepared to tell others about it. We must know the worth of it and what an influence for good it can be in the home. We want to make friends for our Magazine, and so each visit we make should be a pleasant and happy experience for those we contact and for ourselves. When we meet our subscribers we should be interested in them. Ask if they are receiving their Magazine and how they are enjoying it. Always have something interesting to pass on whenever the opportunity presents itself. We will meet objections from time to time, and so we must prePage 604 pare ourselves as best we can to meet them. One objection: I haven't time to read. If we have a little advance information about the family we are to visit, and know something of their interests, their needs, and, possibly, a little about their Church activities, this might help us in our approach. Perhaps we discovered that poetry was the thing a certain woman was most interested in. Let her see what our Magazine has to offer along these lines. Thumb through the pages and point out just how many poems each issue contains. Offer to leave one of the Magazines with her for a few days, so she can more fully enjoy the reading of the poems. Appeal to her in other ways. Every woman loves to receive a new and interesting recipe. Choose one that you particularly enjoyed and share it with her. If you have tried the Chicken Casserole that is in the September 1955 issue of the Magazine (page 596), tell her what a hit it made with your family and suggest she try it. You might ask if she is keeping the Magazine in a place where it can easily be picked up, maybe on a table close to her favorite chair, where, during the day, when she MEETING OBJECTIONS finds a moment to relax she can have her Magazine handy and read something from it. She might enjoy reading just before she retires. If her Magazine is on the night stand next to her bed, it will be easy for her to pick it up and read a short story that will only take five or ten minutes. If she continues this practice, her Magazine will prove valuable to her, and she will want to read it. In the course of her reading she might find an interesting article that some member of her family would enjoy reading, too. She could leave the Magazine open to this particular page, and, when the opportunity presented itself, without any fuss in trying to find the page or even trying to find the Magazine, there it would be for her to give to the interested members of her family. NOTHER objection: We Have an Excess of Magazines. How can we arouse this person's interest? First of all, be interested in the publications she now has in her home. Compliment her on the fine choice of reading material she has selected. Then let her see your Magazine. People like to see what they are buying. Be enthusiastic about it. Point out some of its fine features. For example: the attractiveness of the cover, the quality of the paper, the clear and readable print, and the limited but high type advertising it contains. All mothers want their families to enjoy the best books and magazines so they can cultivate good reading habits, and so we know she will want to include our Magazine in her collection. 605 I was talking to a young mother last week, and in the course of the conversation she told me that her son had come home from school with the assignment to bring a copy of the Preamble to the Constitution to class next morning. It was too late to get to the library; she had looked through all the current magazines she had, but was unable to find it. Suddenly she remembered attending a Relief Society class and the lesson was on the Constitution. She recalled that they all recited in unison several times the Preamble. She immediately gathered her Magazines together and in just a few minutes she found what she was looking for. She hadn't been too interested in the Magazine before, but this little incident aroused her interest enough so that she began reading the material contained in the Magazine. She was delighted at what she found, and I know that The Relief Society Magazine will have preference above the other magazine from now on in_ her home. Another objection: Why Not Have One Church Magazine? This might be a fine idea, but think how hard it would be to carry this large book to our meetings and, inasmuch as the Relief Society lessons are in the Magazine, it would be necessary to take it. Don't you think our present Magazine is a much better size? It is small enough so that it can be easily tucked into our purses, and wherever we go, we can always have good reading material at our fingertips. How privileged and blessed we are to have a Magazine of our very own, edited and published by inspired women who bring to us the gospel ideals along with the counsel and advice we need in our daily living. Think how difficult it would be for a child to handle such a large book. If he has to thumb through several pages to find the section he is interested in, naturally the pages become soiled and possibly torn; some could even be torn out and lost, and then the magazine would lose some of its value, and, as most women take pride in keeping their Magazine clean, so it can be bound for future reference, it would lose its attractiveness and value. Another drawback would be the expense of compiling and mailing such a book. It could be possible that we would not be able to afford this type of publication. Another thing, three or four members of a family might want to use the magazine at the same time. Father might need it to get a little information for his Priesthood lesson; Johnny might need it because he must give a talk in M. I. A.; Mother would just have to have it to prepare her Relief Society lesson! You can see this could present quite a problem. I can't afford it is another objection we hear from time to time. Have we ever stopped to consider just how little the Magazine actually costs? For twelve and one-half cents a month we can have the finest reading material available delivered directly to our homes. Where else can one find such value for so little? With a little planning, we can save our money very easily. We could obtain a small dime bank and each month place ten or fifteen cents in it, and in this way our money would be ready for our Magazine representative when she calls for our renewal. When the Magazine was first published the price of the publication was $2. This was really a lot of money to those women, but they worked and struggled to earn the price of the subscription. Today, we receive our magazine for $1.50. How wonderfully blessed we are! One sister keeps a little glass jar handy, and every time she finds a penny or a nickel on the floor, into the little jar it goes. In a short time, with little effort, and no extending of her budget, she has the money for our Magazine. We must have a goal and our goal must be high. We must labor diligently to reach it. If we are successful in reaching our goal, let us not stop, but always have the incentive to do just a bit more. We must never be satisfied, but always have the desire to climb higher and higher. Again, let us consider our calling an important one, and as we go from door to door, our first interest should be to make a friend for the Magazine and a friend for Relief Society, and always keep uppermost in our mind, that we buy our Magazine to read. Time travels in divers paces with divers persons. I'll tell you who Time ambles withal, who Time trots withal, who Time gallops withal, and who he stands still withal. Heart's Bounty CHAPTER 4 Deone R. Sutherland Synopsis: Annie Griffith, whose father, with his family, has been called on a mission to the mountains to cut stone for the temple, is living with the Williams family in Salt Lake City, where she is studying, with Marie Williams, under the direction of a private tutor. Light-hearted Marie is an_ indifferent scholar, but Annie makes a fine record in all her studies. Both girls are interested in Parker Josephson, a neighbor, who has been for three years in an eastern university studying to be a teacher of the sciences. Marie has assumed that she is the one whom Parker loves, and that they will eventually marry, but at Parker's homecoming party, it is Annie whom he seeks out. HE arrangements for Parker to teach at the University were completed. He made frequent excuses to come over to the Williams home, and he greeted Marie and Annie warmly when he happened to meet them outside. Marie always hurried to see him while Annie darted away. Both girls rode with him to Sunday School when Sister Williams was indisposed, and Brother Williams had another meeting to attend. But Annie was very careful to avoid giving Parker any opportunity to speak to her alone or to see very much of her. Then, suddenly, there was something in the air that the adults knew about and hadn't told the girls. Annie laughed at Marie's curiosity. 'Then Parker came over one evening, less than two months Page 610 after his return from his studies in the East. He talked very quietly to Brother and Sister Williams. "Yes, it is true," he told them. "The Church has called me on a three-year mission to the Hawaiian Islands." Marie and Annie had been sitting very quietly in the window seat, but Marie jumped up. "Oh, no," she cried, "you can't go; you've just come back from being away. It isn't fair." "Now, now, Marie," liams soothed her. "Marie, Parker has been honored and blessed to receive this call. There is no question about whether or not he is going. He is here to tell us simply that he is going." Brother Williams cleared his throat. "Tll miss you all doubly now," Parker said. "It seems I haven't been at home long enough to get acquainted all over again this time. Were you going to say something, Annie?" "We'll miss you, Parker. Marie and I have surely. Annie stumbled and could not go on. "Of course you must go," she finished. Marie tossed back her head. "Of course it's all right for you to say that, Annie," she blurted out. "You're not going to be waiting the next three years for him to come home. Well, if you go, Parker, maybe I won't be waiting either." Sister WilI know " HEART'S BOUNTY Parker blushed to the roots of his hair. "Why, Marie, I wouldn't dream of asking such a thing from such a lovely young girl as you. I'm sure you'll do the right thing. Please don't make any threats. I'm going on a mission, and any personal life I have must be left behind." Marie ran from the room, and Sister Williams followed _ her. Brother Williams shook Parker's hand and told him not to worry. Annie said goodbye and tried to slip by, but Parker begged her to wait a moment. "IT hope you have not misunderstood anything by what Marie has just said; I never...." "T have misunderstood nothing." Annie could not loosen her hand. "Annie, Annie," Parker mutrmured. Then he squared his shoulders. "I have no right to say anything to you at this time." "No, you have not," Annie flared briefly, thinking of Marie upstairs crying her heart out. "You just said you were leaving your personal life behind." "You know I am doing what is right," Parker urged. "Yes," Annie answered oa: "Marie isn't quite as strong. "Where will you be when I come back?" "T don't know — with my_parents," Annie said. "But Marie can write, for most certainly I will come to your wedding." This time she was free and almost to the door before Parker could say, "That's what I really want—you to come to my wedding." ARKER Josephson left on his mission to the Hawaiian Islands. 611 Marie cheered up almost immediately. "It is better not to be really promised to a person in this situation," she told Annie. "If I were, I'd have to miss all the fun this winter." "There're lots of other fish, you mean," Aunt Agnes remarked dourly. Marie laughed, "That's not what I meant, but you wouldn't want me to miss the dances and parties with the other young people, would you?" "Not to be thought of." Aunt Agnes dropped a peeled potato in the salted water. Annie stood by the window watching the snow fall. This was to be her last winter with the Williams. She really shouldn't let herself think about it, for her emotions were now so mixed up. She would be so happy to be with her family again and to see her brothers every day, but now she was sure she would be homesick for the Williams, her second family. The time had passed so much more quickly than she had dreamed it would, when she had run after her father's wagon that early dawn almost four years ago. She and Marie had grown up together. She had never had a sister, and now she had had one she was going to lose her. She looked at Marie with affection. She was like a gay butterfly haphazardly helping Aunt Agnes with the dinner. Annie decided she'd better get busy herself and quit mooning at the snow. After all, her family would be living close enough to Salt Lake City so there would be visits sometime. Annie and Marie both received letters from Parker Josephson, though the mail took such a long time coming the letters were months old before they heard. Annie hid her letter away with another older letter and refused to think about it. Marie read her letter aloud to the family and showed everyone who called. Parker obviously wrote with affection and high regard for her. There was no question but that Marie regarded Parker as belonging to her. Annie felt she had no right to think of Parker, and did not answer this letter as she had not answered that other letter. Nevertheless, there were many nights when Annie watched the shadows on her window, waiting for sleep to come, while Marie lay curled up like a ball, her dimpled fist tucked beneath her sheet, oblivious to everything. Professor Peterson gave Annie a lovely scroll indicating the years' study she had completed, and commenting on her unusual abilities as a student. But the biggest surprise was yet to come. "The Walter Academy has_selected Annie as a teacher for next year. It is a great honor for a girl as young as she." Professor Peterson beamed at Sister Williams. Marie squealed with delight. "Annie, you won't have to go away, after all. You'll stay in Salt Lake City. You can even live with us, if you don't have to live at the Academy!" Sister Williams smiled with relief. "Annie, my dear, we won't be losing you after all. You'll still be able to visit your parents occasionally, but you'll have all the comforts that you have been used to." ANNIE thanked Professor Peterson; her mind was in a turmoil. This was a way, an opportunity for her future, most certainly. But what of her parents? After all these years, surely they would be disappointed if she didn't return to their home with them. Sister Williams saw the hesitation in her eyes. "Annie, dear, of what use could you be to your parents on a farm? You can be so much more use here in a lovely school. Think of the privations your father's farm has to offer a brilliant, lovely girl who is prepared with a fine education to teach in one of the best educational establishments available. There is no question, my dear, but that you must accept this opportunity." "There is no question but that I'm thankful for this opportunity, and that I am indeed tempted to accept it without question, but I must counsel with my parents before I can give any definite decision." Annie forced herself to consider the possibility that she would not be able to accept it. "There, there." Professor Peterson wiped his brow. "I'm sure there is no unreasonable hurry. Of course, if you must wait until you have seen your parents, then you must. I will find out what reasonable length of time I can obtain for you before you decide. It is, after all, only a month or two until your father moves his family down from the mountains." That night Annie buried her face into her pillow. 'There was another reason she yearned to remain in Great Salt Lake City. A reason she must not admit even to herself. 612 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 HEART'S BOUNTY She got up and found Parker's letter in her little trunk. It was too dark to read it, but she knew the words off by heart. "Annie, you are the one I am counting on seeing when I return. May all the blessings of heaven go with you." These two lines in a long letter recounting the wonders of his mission and the blessings he was _ receiving day by day had emblazoned themselves on her mind. But what of Marie? Her heart's tumult slowly subsided. She was faced with important decisions that she must make soon. She knelt by her bed until thoroughly chilled but, comforted, she felt enough at peace to sleep. ITH the coming spring, Annie's parents moved from the mountains with their sons to their small farm north of Great Salt Lake City. Brother Griffith took his family straight there, so they might begin repairs and start work. The first necessary trip to Salt Lake came shortly after, when he came to the Williams' house to take Annie home. The long hours of work repairing their home and barn had made her father seem more weary and older than Annie expected. But she greeted him with a surge of joy. How could she wait to see the rest of her family? "We'll start right off tomorrow morning. I expect you don't have much to pack?" "Why, Father, I have a whole trunk of things. Brother and Sister Williams have been most generous." Annie smiled at him. "We've no better friends in the whole world. It must be a sad 613 wrench to your heart to be leaving them. But I've wonderful news to cheer you up. I have been to see the Davis family on my way down. Old Sister Davis is starting a school for the children in Davisville, and I've told them all about you. There's no question but that you can teach there next year, and it will be not such a long ride that you can't stay at home, though if the snow gets too bad in the middle of the winter, you may, on occasion, sleep in the old Davis home where there's plenty of room. But you'll be able to help your mother now, and _ that will be a real comfort to her. Oh, she'll be surprised at the young lady I'm bringing home. She's not been so well this last year. 'This mountain living has taken its toll of her health, no question." Annie buried her face in her father's rough coat. "T''ll be ready in the morning. I'm a fast worker, you'll see." After her father had gone, Marie cried out that Annie was silly not to have, at least, mentioned the other offer to her father. But Sister Williams told her to hold her peace. "Annie knows what she must do," Sister Williams said firmly. "There'll be too much work, I'm afraid, for your family on the farm." Annie straightened her shoulders. "They've been counting on me to help, Sister Williams. I'm glad you see how it is; why I couldn't hesitate to go home." She put her arms around Sister Williams' shoulder. "How will I ever be able to say goodbye?" Aunt Agnes abruptly tried to leave the room, but not before Annie had kissed her also. "It will be almost more than I can bear to leave you, Aunt Agnes, for truly, if you were my real aunt, you couldn't have been a better friend to me." Aunt Agnes buried her face in her apron. "Annie, Annie," came her muffled voice. "We'll miss you, my girl." HE ride home was beautiful, though the wagon floundered in ruts and jerked them unmercifully. Spring hovered in the valley. Willows budded green, and birds sang on and on. The house was much, much smaller than Annie remembered, and the farm truly looked abandoned and in need of much work. Her father was already more than anxious to be home to start on the planting. Long before they reached the house, the boys and her mother had seen them coming and came running to meet them. The soil on their farm was rich and dark, and Annie and her mother soon had vegetables pushing upward in straight, green rows. They worked on the house, more often than not alone, since the boys and their father spent every spare moment in the fields. There was little music except on Sundays for the Griffith family that year. Annie looked at her hands, which had browned and hardened from the hard work. She was often too exhausted to do more than wash her face. "It's a shame, Annie, for you to have to work so hard. You will be too tired to teach in the fall.' Her mother, exhausted, had had to let Annie take over the heavy scrubbing of the clothes. "Nonsense," Annie exclaimed, "I can rest all winter. 'Teaching won't be difficult; it will be fun." To herself, however, she vowed to get out some of her books. She thought she must be forgetting everything she had ever known. The long ride to the Davis home where the school was held, was beautiful in the fall, but it soon became apparent that Annie could not continue using the small wagon, as it was often needed by the Griffith family. She began riding her horse, which, as winter came, floundered through the drifts, but always brought Annie safely to school. The long ride and the care of the rooms where the school was held, began to wear on Annie, and the teaching itself proved much more strenuous than she had imagined. She had sixteen children in almost half as many grades, and all her inventiveness was soon put to use to keep them all working at the same time. Her brothers and some of the children and she chopped the wood for the two stoves in the two rooms that they used, and often Annie stayed after the children had gone home to clean the rooms for the next day. As the days grew shorter, it was more often than not long after dark before she rode up the lane to the Griffith house. Her father worried about Annic because, as he expressed it, "Annie, you were slim before, but you're like a willow-wand now." And Annie worried because she was unable to relieve her mother as much as she had during the summer of the heavy household work. It was in November that Annic received a letter from the Williams family. The letter from Marie she 614 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—-SEPTEMBER 1956 HEART'S BOUNTY read first of all. It was full of blots and dashes, but the import sprang from the page. Marie was to be married to Billy Johnson at Christmas time! Christmas time had been chosen especially so that Annie would be free to come for the reception. For Marie could not be married unless Annie was there. Of course, the whole Gniffith family was invited. Annie was to stay with them, and if there wasn't room for the whole family there, the others could stay at friends' homes who would be happy at the privilege of having them. "Annie," the letter concluded, "you can't possibly know how happy I am!" Annie sat at the kitchen table and re-read the letter. There was no mention of Parker Josephson. "Of course you must go. They are your second family, and Marie has been a true sister to you." Annie's mother pushed more wood into the stove. "Perhaps we all can go, but, if not, at least you and Papa will make the trip. Let's see, December twenty-second. You can even make it home again without any trouble at all in time for Christmas. If you leave the day after the reception, you'll have an extra day in case you are stopped anywhere by heavy snow." Annie nodded her head. It would be wonderful to see the Williams again, but she could not think of Marie as married. Marie seemed so young, but, perhaps, she seemed so because they had always treated her so. Her heart couldn't still its excited pounding. One thing spoke itself again and again to Annie. Marie was not going to marry Parker. 615 Annie and her father made the trip quite comfortably to Salt Lake City in December. This was one of the few winters when the snow was not heavy, and the team made good time all the way. Marie overwhelmed Annie with her bubbling excitement. They had had a dress made for Annie, as she was to stand up with Marie at the reception. Annie protested that she had brought her good dress the Williams had been kind enough to have given her the year before, but Sister Williams insisted with such gentle firmness, that Annie decided it would be bad taste not to yield to her pride at such a time. Once she had seen the dress, there was no question of pride. The dress was yards and yards of pale blue sky with a creamy cloud of tucked lace at the throat. Slight alterations were made to give the bodice a perfect fit. "Annie, you've lost almost an inch at the waist," Aunt Agnes exclaimed disapprovingly, with her mouth full of pins. Annie slept in their old room with Marie the night before the marriage in the Endowment House, and the reception which was to follow in the evening. Marie wanted to talk and talk about her beloved Billy, but Annie had strict orders that Marie was to go to sleep at once and get her rest. "You should see the beautiful crystal the Josephsons have given me," Marie exclaimed. Annie waited. "Sister Josephson said that Parker would want his little sister to have a beautiful gift. Her very words. Parker was always so wonderful to us. We both had such silly crushes on him. Do you remember, Annie, when he...? "Marie, dear, I promised your mother not to talk, but to let you sleep." "That's all right, Annie; anyway, you're not talking, I am. Then I'll go straight off to sleep. What was I saying?" "Something about Parker?" Annie lay staring into the darkness. "Remember how [I always insisted I'd marry Parker when I grew up. It's funny when you really grow up, you find out that you don't decide whom you're going to marry in such a cold-blooded way. I fell in love with Billy. Annie, remember how mean I used to be to him when we were little. He says now I'll have all time and eternity to make it up to him for teasing him so. Oh, I want to be the best possible wife. I know I've been terribly lazy and inefficient as a girl at home, but I'm going to be a real wife to Billy. Do you believe I can be, Annie?" Annie slipped out of her warm covers and took Marie's hands in her own. "I know you can, Marie. I know you can." 'Then she kissed her goodnight, and the two girls fell asleep at last. HE day of Marie's wedding was to remain a blur of excitement for Annie. The house had been polished until it shone and was redolent with delicious odors. The dark, heavily fruited wedding cakes made one's mouth water. But still women continued feverishly to prepare for the reception—last minute flower arrangements, the chairs (many borrowed), the candles, the gowns. 'Through it all Marie clung to Annie. "I want you near me, Annie. You've always given me some of your strength." The trip downtown to the Endowment House at last commenced. There was a difference in Marie as soon as the ceremony was actually over. As Marie back at home rested in her room for the reception, Annie sat by the window quietly. Marie did not need her now. Annie had seen her come out of the Lord's House with her arm in Billy Johnson's. Solemnity of wifehood for all eternity rested upon her. Billy Johnson had grown up considerably since Annie had noticed his early infatuation for Marie, and Marie's constant teasing had nearly broken his heart. His chin was firm now, and his slight build had filled out. How well he looked in his black wedding-day suit! His square shoulders would prove a helpful companion, but not a crutch. Billy took Annie's hand at the reception. "I have no words proper enough to thank you for the friendship you've shown Marie. I hope our home will be as much yours in the future as the Williams' has been in the past." Annie only could cling to both their hands for a moment. At last the waltzing began. 'The drawing room and dining room floors shone like mirrors in the light from the chandeliers. Bully and Marie led the first waltz. Only then did he seem the old Billy to her. He had lost none of his grace on the dance floor. Marie's face was pretty as a flower, and there were bursts of applause as they circled the room. 616 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 HEART'S BOUNTY Again the evening blurred for Annie. Someone had put a cup of punch in her hand, and she tried to sip it. She wasn't prepared for such festivities, for such a wonderfilled day, for saying goodbye to the girl Marie. A i HE day after the reception the Griffiths started home. Again they were able to make good time, though this time the back of the wagon was loaded with supplies and packages, many of which were Christmas gifts from the Williams and other friends. 'They unloaded the wagon after the boys were safely 617 in bed, since some of the gifts were Christmas surprises for them. Sister Griffith caught Annie's hand and held her a moment after their family prayer. "Annie, I almost dreaded tonight. I thought you might come back dissatisfied or unhappy with your hard life here, but you have a sweet peace in your face tonight. Your father and I appreciate that, Annie. You are a dear, good daughter." I have peace in my heart also, Annie's thoughts sang to herself as she kissed her mother goodnight. Peace in my heart. (To be continued) <> Shis Ys September Zara Sabin It was springtime on the Devon Downs... We rambled in the rain, scarce knowing And not caring, that the grass Crushed by our feet, was lush and sweet; That buttercups and daisies flecked The meadows where we passed. You took my hand to lift me from the stile; Then, hard arms held me and I turned My glowing face to meet the old And timeless question which was asked And answered as I raised my head. Clear, across the world, We heard the vesper bells tell out the hour... Suddenly the air was cold. A lone lark sang, as it soared away, A sad and lonely roundelay.... Our close-pressed lips clung closer yet And with more than rain our cheeks were wet. Spring's fires linger like a slow-burning ember... Linger and haunt me, though this is September! | Margaret C. President Nettie P. Smoot reports this historic event: " "The Spirit of God Like a Fire Is Burning' has served as the opening song for two historic Relief Society meetings in Nauvoo. In 1842, this grand hymn was sung as the opening song of a meeting in which the Relief Society was first organized under the direction of the Prophet Joseph Smith. And now, many years later, it has again been used to open a meeting of Relief Society sisters. This event is deeply significant, for it makes the first time in over a hundred years, yes, the first time since that cold winter evening when the Mormon settlers were driven from their Nauvoo homes, that there has been a Relief Society organization in this historic city.
