Monson (Text: The Book of Mormon: Fourth Nephi) For Tuesday, December 4, 1956 Objective: To show that peace and happiness come to individuals and nations through living the gospel of Christ in unity. Church of Christ Flourishes N Fourth Nephi, Mormon who abridged the Plates of Nephi as The Book of Mormon, which we know, summarizes in four pages the history of the Nephites and Lamanites from about 35 A. D. To 321 A. D., a period of about two hundred and eighty-six years. Details concerning their religious, social, and political life were eliminated. 'The original history of the period under discussion was written by four prophets: Nephi, son of the disciple Nephi; Amos, son of Nephi; Amos, son of Amos; and Ammaron, brother of Amos. Ammaron "... Being constrained by the Holy Ghost..." (4 Nephi 48) hid all the sacred records "... Up unto the Lord..." (4 Nephi 49). Page 624 All Things Had in Common Nephi, son of Nephi, one of the disciples of Christ, was historian from about 34 A. D. To 111 A. D., a period of about seventy-six years. It was a period of righteousness which resulted in peace and_ happiness among the Nephites and Lamanites, who became a united people. The ability to unite was a result of their having transformed their lives by living the gospel Jesus had taught them. "... Every man," wrote the historian, "did deal justly one with another. And they had all things common among them; _ therefore there were not rich and poor, bond and free, but they were all made free, and partakers of the heavenly gift" (4 Nephi 2-3). It resulted in a period of great growth and development. The peo- LESSON DEPARTMENT ple rebuilt many of the cites that had been destroyed at the time of the crucifixion of Jesus on the eastern hemisphere, including the great city of Zarahemla. They were not able to rebuild all of the cities, however, because some had been covered by water. "... 'The people of Nephi did wax strong, and did multiply exceedingly fast, and became an exceedingly fair and delightsome people" (4 Nephi 10). And they did not walk any more after the performances and ordinances of the law of Moses; but they did walk after the commandments which they had received from their Lord and their God, continuing in fasting and prayer, and in meeting together oft both to pray and to hear the word of the Lord (4 Nephi 12). With a united people serving God by doing that which was just, the disciples of Jesus did many marvelous works; they healed the sick, raised the dead, made the lame to walk, the blind to see, and the deaf to hear, "... And in nothing did they work miracles save it were in the name of Jesus" (4 Nephi 5). Two Hundred Years of Righteousness When a hundred years had passed away, "... The disciples of Jesus, whom he had chosen, had all gone to the paradise of God, save it were the three who should tarry; and there were other disciples ordained in their stead..." (4 Nephi 14). Fourth Nephi, impressed with the blessings God had given his people, wrote: And it came to pass that there was no contention in the land, because of the love of God which did dwell in the hearts of the people. 625 And there were no envyings, nor strifes, nor tumults, nor whoredoms, nor lyings, nor murders, nor any manner of lasciviousness; and surely there could not be a happier people among all the people who had been created by the hand of God. There were no robbers, nor murderers, neither were there Lamanites, nor any manner of -ites; but they were in one, the children of Christ, and heirs to the kingdom of God. And how blessed were they! For the Lord did bless them in all their doings; yea, even they were blessed and prospered until an hundred and ten years had passed away; and the first generation from Christ has passed away, and there was no contention in all the land (4 Nephi 15-18). Amos, son of Nephi, in 111 A. D. Became historian and kept the records in his father's stead. He was historian for eighty-four years. Summarizing what Amos engraved on the plates of Nephi, Mormon wrote:. And there was still peace in the land, save it were a small part of the people who had revolted from the church and taken upon them the name of Lamanites; therefore there began to be Lamanites again in the land (4 Nephi 20). This is all we know about this great people during this period of time, 111 A. D. To 194 A. D. Amos, Son of Amos, Keeps the Record Upon the death of Amos in 194 AD., his son Amos became the keeper of the record "... And he |also| kept it upon the plates of Nephi' (4 Nephiig). During the one hundred and twelve years he served as historian (194 a. P. Through 305 A. D.) "... The people had multiplied, insomuch that they were spread upon all the face of the land, and that they had become exceeding rich, because of their prosperity in Christ" (4 Nephi 23). But wickedness crept in among them in the form of pride, "... Wearing of costly apparel, and all manner of fine pearls, and the fine things of the world" (4 Nephi 24). To get gain..." (4 Nephi 26). Members of the iniquitous churches soon "... Did persecute the true church of Christ, because of their humility and their belief in Christ; and they did despise them because of the many miracles which were wrought among them" (4 Nephi 29). (4 Nephi 30) came forth unharmed. Degeneracy Among Nephites Increasing wickedness among those who did not belong to the true Church of Christ led to a great division among the people in 231 Av. The first group, the Nephites, included the Nephites, Jacobites, Josephites, and Zoramites. Among them were the "... Three disciples of Jesus who should tarty..." (4 Nephi 37). The second group, those who rejected the Church of Christ were called Lamanites, Lemuelites, and Ishmaelites. "... 'They did not dwindle in unbelief, but they did wilfully rebel against the gospel of Christ..." (4 Nephi 38).... And they were taught to hate the children of God, even as the Lamanites were taught to hate the children of Nephi from the beginning (4 Nephi 39). They soon exceeded in number the Nephites and "... Began again to build up the secret oaths and combinations of Gadianton" (4 Nephi 42). And the Nephites "... Began to be proud in their hearts, because of their exceeding riches, and become vain like unto their brethren, the Lamanites" (4 Nephi 43), which brought to the disciples "... Sorrow for the sins of the world" (4 Nephi 44). By 300 ap. "... Both the people of Nephi and the Lamanites had become exceeding wicked one like unto another" (4 Nephi 45). The robbers of Gadianton flourished and "... Spread over all the face of the land; and there were none that were righteous save it were the disciples of Jesus.. / (4 Nephi 46). The people had gold in abundance, and "... Did traffic in all manner of traffic' (4 Nephi 46). Ammaron, Keeper of the Record It was at this time that Amos died and the record was given to his brother Ammaron. Ammaron, fifteen years later, constrained by the Holy Ghost, buried the records in Hill Shim and instructed Mormon concerning the plates. During the two hundred and eighty-six years covering this period, the people experienced peace and prosperity and the Church flourished as long as they were living the commandments of the Lord and dealing justly with one another. Then they fell from the heights of 626 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT happiness to the depths of wickedness when pride and other evils developed among them. We know God rules in the affairs of men and nations cannot sin with impunity because when they become ripe in iniquity their sins destroy them. Mormon concludes the Book of Fourth Nephi with the words about the record: And he [Ammaron] did hide them up unto the Lord, that they might come again unto the remnant of the house of 627 Jacob, according to the prophecies and the promises of the Lord. Visiting Seacher ITlessages— Book of Mormon Gems of Truth Lesson 43—"But Charity Is the Pure Love of Christ, and It Endureth Forever; and Whoso Is Found Possessed of It at the Last Day, It Shall Be Well With Him" (Moroni 7:47). Leone O. Jacobs For Tuesday, December 4, 1956 Objective: To stress the great importance of developing charity. UCH has been said and written concerning charity, but Mormon's definition, as recorded by his son, Moroni, is clearly expressed. We are deeply moved by Mormon's earnest appeal that his people seck this divine attribute, and we reahze how diligent we, too, should be in cultivating this quality. If charity is the pure love of Chnist, or even might we say if it is the kind of love that Christ has, then nothing could be more precious than its possession! Surely if we love Christ with a pure love and thus acquire the kind of love he has, all will indeed be well with us. Mormon reminds us that to gain faith and hope one must first be meek and lowly of heart, and in order to be meek and lowly of heart, one must have charity. Paul the apostle tells us that of the three—faith, hope, and charity— charity is the greatest. It seems, then, to be one of the paramount qualifications for a righteous life. Paul's inspiring discourse on the subject of charity always stirs within us an appreciation for this virtue. 'l'o quote in part: Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things (I Cor. 13:4-7). In order to possess the pure love of Christ, we cannot be calloused to the needs of others, nor unmindful of rendering any loving service. Charity is unselfishness and a willingness to forgive. It is the underlying principle of the Golden Rule. Giving of our substance to those in want is just one phase of charity, and the giving must be performed ungrudgingly to be worthy this word. It is possible for one to comply with the letter of the law, and yet be lacking in charity. The spirit of the law of charity covers all who possess it with a mantle of compassion. Mormon tells us, if we have not charity, we are nothing — our words, our deeds, our offerings — none are acceptable unless clothed with charity. Charity is the dominant theme of the Relief Society, and it is expected that members of this organization abound in feelings and works which are characteristic of this quality. Visiting teachers, particularly, are commissioned to exercise this blessed attribute in their visits. Said Jesus, "Ye shall do the works which ye see me do." These are the grand key words of the Relief Society as declared by the Prophet Joseph Smith.. Wherefore, cleave unto charity, which is the greatest of all... (Moroni 7:46). By so doing it shall be well with us. Work MM leeting— Food Preparation and Service (A Course Recommended for Use by Wards and Branches at Work Meeting) Lesson 3—Party Refreshments Rhea H. Gardner For Tuesday, December 11, 1956 WHOLESOME party refreshments should do just what the name implies; they should refresh those who partake of them. They need not be elaborate, highly decorative, nor unique in composition. Simple foods, prepared tastefully in attractive ways, and served in an atmosphere that is unhurried and undisturbed, do more to make refreshments refreshing than all the elaborate details. Before planning — refreshments, therefore, it is important to thoughtfully consider: who will attend the party; what time of the day will the refreshments be served; how much time can I afford to give to the prepreparation, and the preparation just prior to serving time; and 628 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT healthwise, what will my guests enjoy most? A gracious hostess knows that there is an attractive way to serve everything, and that all foods could be party foods if prepared and served daintily and at the right time and place. In planning her party, she thinks first of the pleasure of her guests. One hostess served the birthday party guests of her five-year-old son, cream tomato soup sprinkled with finely chopped parsley and animal cutouts of cheese-flavored biscuit dough. For dessert, she cut the tops off oranges, scooped out the center, then refilled them with diced fresh fruits. The fruit basket was topped with a small scoop of ice cream and a maraschino cherry. If your guests are teenagers, who never seem able to get quite enough to satisfy their ravenous appetites, plan to serve hearty dishes. Plenty of good tasty food means more to them than the daintiness of it. | As we grow older, our needs for food decrease, and our ability to digest some of them becomes somewhat of a problem. It is at this age that many party-goers almost dread the time to come when refreshments are served. In many cases they are too rich, too hard to digest, and just plain-too-much. The time planned for serving refreshments must also be given consideration. If you plan to serve a complete meal, notify your guests of it and plan the serving time as near the time of regular meals as possible. Note: issue of the Magazine. 629 Choose refreshments that are to be served after ten in the evening, except to teenagers or persons with exceptionally hearty appetites, that are light calorie-wise and easy to digest. Miudafternoon refreshments seldom need to consist of more than one or two items, both of which should be more refreshing than filling. The time needed for last-minute preparation of refreshments is important. Too often, hostesses spend the greater part of the party time in the kitchen or hurrying back and forth. Plan refreshments that will require a minimum of last-minute preparation. Beverages are usually important for party refreshments. Choose a kind that will help to give balance to the rest of the meal. A cup of rich chocolate is almost a meal in itself. A too-sweet or too-sour punch served with a too-sweet dessert is not in good taste. The dominating flavor of any fruit drink should be the natural fruit flavor. Punch made from a blend of fruit juices with little or no sugar added, makes a refreshing drink. In many instances, the only beverage that is needed is clear, cold water. Apply the same rules in planning refreshments for your party as are recommended for regular meals. Don't be afraid to personalize your refreshments by doing something different. Make entertaining a challenging, refreshing experience by serving refreshments that your friends haven't thought of. Whatever your refreshments may be, make them truly refreshing. "Refreshments for Entertaining," by Rhea H. Gardner, page 608, in this ol iterature—Shakespeare in Our Lives Lesson 3—Shakespeare's Poetic Power Elder Briant S. Jacobs (Textbook: Shakespeare Major Plays and the Sonnets, by G. B. Harrison, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1948) For Tuesday, December 18, 1956 Objective: To feel more profoundly the peculiar power and mystery of Shakespeare's poetry that we might read his works with enlarged understandings and hearts. New approach to Shakespeare has been the major contribution of 20th century scholarship. It holds that plot and character are important but secondary: the dramatic intensity of the play itself is best sensed in the dense verbal texture of the words as spoken by Shakespeare's characters. 'The emotion lying deep within the situation is evoked by the words, not by plot or character, which themselves come to the reader through Shakespeare's poetic concentration and imagery. We cannot remind ourselves too often or earnestly, then, that Shakespeare the poet, is the very heart of Shakespeare the dramatist. To understand Shakespeare we must constantly work downward from the surface of his poetry, phrase, image, and symbol. In his words lies the key. The Nature of Poetry Macaulay says, "By poetry we mean the art of employing words in such a manner as to produce an illusion on the imagination, the art of doing by means of words what the painter does by means of color." Page 630 Hallmarks of poetry are brilliance, freshness, power, condensation. It has a high singing all its own which can no more be defined than denied, as in: When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise. Merchant of Venice, V. 2.3 These beautifully simple lines catch the tranquil silence as only lovers of nature can hear it. Likewise it is the words which reveal Macbeth's. Fears that Duncan, whom he is to murder, had lived so meek and clear a life as king that:... His virtues Will plead like angels trumpet-tongued against The deep damnation of his taking-off. And pity, like a naked newborn babe, Striding the blast, or Heaven's cherubin horsed Upon the sightless couriers of the air, Shall blow the horrid deed in every eye That tears shall drown the wind. Macbeth, I, 7. 18-25 Again, this passage itself embodies Macbeth's eloquent fear in exalted, LESSON DEPARTMENT A Perry Picture BIRTHROOM, SHAKESPEARE HOUSE, STRATFORD impassioned imagery. Note the similarities between such a passage and one of Shakespeare's best sonnets: Let me not to the marriage of true minds Admit impediments. Love is not love Which alters when it alteration finds, Or bends with the remover to remove. Oh no! It is an ever-fixed mark That looks on tempests and is never shaken. It is the star to every wandering bark, Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken. Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks Within his bending sickle's compass come; Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks, But bears it out even to the edge of doom. If this be error and upon me proved, I never writ, nor no man ever loved. Sonnet 116 Here Shakespeare blends together into a perfect oneness—concise statement (first sentence); play on 631 Copyright 1903 words (love-love, alters-alteration, remover, remove); simile Love is mark, or star; not a fool); personification (Father Time with his sickle); intellectual wit-turn (last couplet). So skilled is Shakespeare's craft that we are scarcely aware of what blends the whole together; namely, rhythm (it is the star to every wandering bark); and thyme (at the ends of alternating lines: minds-finds, love-remove, mark-bark, shaken-taken, etc). Yet each blender, each part, though definable on the surface, speaks to something deep within us, something which can be expressed in no other way. In Shakespeare's sonnets we find some of the best and purest poetry in our literature. Yet, for those familiar with these poems, careful attention is required when they are Copyright 1924 A Perry Picture WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE reread. For those experiencing them for the first time, they may seem difficult. Here the standard recipe holds: read and reread aloud, then to oneself, relating each difficult line or image to that which precedes and that which follows, until its relation to the whole becomes apparent and the poem as an artistic unit "jells"' into completeness. At the risk of stating the obvious, let us then paraphrase the above sonnet, realizing as well that the entire poem is the only acceptable summary of itself. The theme of the poem is love's constancy despite adversities and the ravages of time. "Marriage of true minds" makes love a spiritualized blending of like forces rather than a physical union. That love is not true which changes when it finds in the lover changes or flaws not at first apparent, or which— instead of resisting one who belittles or removes charm or beauty from the beloved—actually joins with the remover in the very process of taking away. By contrast, true love cannot be shaken by tempests; it is the star which guides every small craft at sea as the mariner sights the star and records its height in appreciation and trust, disregarding the detail of whether it is a star named or unknown. Though Time's sickle harvests rosy lips and soft cheeks, it can never harvest love, which is not Time's lackey or fool, because true love is not changed by Time's passing, but remains unchanged until judgment day. Should any skeptic succeed in proving this view of love false, he must also disprove the obvious fact that I (Shakespeare) have just written this poem, or, more impossible, prove that no man has ever been in love. Equally famous, and _ perhaps somewhat easier to understand on first reading is sonnet 55: Not marble, nor the gilded monuments Of princes, shall outlive this powerful thyme. But you shall shine more bright in these contents Than unswept stone, sluttish time. When wasteful war shall statutes overturn, And broils root out the work of masonry, Nor Mars his sword nor war's quick fire shall burn The living record of your memory. 'Gainst death and all-oblivious enmity Shall you pace forth. Your praise shall still find room Even in the eyes of all posterity That wear this world out to the ending doom So, till the judgment that yourself arise, You live in this, and dwell in lover's eyes. Besmeared with 632 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT Herein the theme is the immortality of love, preserved not in the beloved, nor in stone monuments, but hereafter in the sonnet itself as well as in all lovers' eyes. Shakespeare's beloved will be immortalized in bright memory by the sonnet, while gilded monuments or monuments scarred by time's neglect will have passed on. Neither war nor the fires of war shall destroy the loved one who shall prove victorious: over death and indifferent fate, to be praised by all posterity. Note the accumulative power Shakespeare achieves by repeating the letter s in the following lines: But you shall shine more bright in these contents Than unswept stone, besmeared with sluttish time. The image in the last line is irresistible, largely because Shakespeare chose exactly the right words working in harmonious combina-- tion of visual and aural image until it registers forcibly on our inner self as the bulky, awkward paraphrase or a more literal rendering never could! Note also how much force is contributed to the following line by the key word wasteful, which, in turn, blends in alliterative harmony with When and war; likewise in the next line the two strong words are the noun broils and the verb-adverb root out. "Living record of your memory" is a combination far more powerful than any of its key words spoken separately. Thus poetry gives a charm, a delight, and a penetration to intuitive, perceptive depths of the mind such as can come from no other experience in life nor from any other art- 633 form. These preceding examples are poetry, all containing the same material—words—and_ appealing to the same object. They speak of the deep-smouldering fires and unconscious realities within us all which are so rarely acknowledged and fed as only the greatest poetry can feed them. As we have just proved, the texture and resonance of true poetry is undefinable, yet two tools are common throughout: condensation and imagery. Often these are the same. Poetic Imagery Just as Shakespeare is useful on the common level of our normal small-talk, so he becomes indispensable whenever a larger emotion or conflict or characterization is to be communicated. To effect these miracles in words, Shakespeare uses imagery, composed of metaphor and simile, which are two forms of comparison. Metaphor simply says one thing is another: "Our bodies are our gardens" (Othello I. 3. 324). Simile is a figure of speech in which like or as is always present: "His nose was as sharp as a pen" (King Henry V. II. 3.17). Here lie some of poetry's most powerful tools. The poet's most vigorous, creative impulse finds expression in metaphor, which not only gives fresh expression to his inner self, but, by his new association, he endows dead objects with life, animals with human traits. Conversely, on every hand his images reveal truths or likenesses which ordinarily lie dormant beneath the shallow levels on which we live. Metaphor deals in wordmagic, for it goes beyond or below our logic or reason to appeal to other realms and values in us, we know not why or how. As L. C. Knight states in his Wheel of Fire: The Shakespeare world is not the world we see, but it is... The inner world we experience, the world we live and fear.... Excerpts From Plays To illustrate Mr. Knight's point, let us examine various images from the plays, reminding ourselves that, literally, a play is only a certain combination of words which is unique within itself because it obeys its own inner laws; for reasons not to be expressed, a metaphor within a play is "right"; and this "rightness" occurs frequently in Shakespeare. Analyze and communicate, if you will, the following famous image from Troilus and Cressida: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back Wherein he puts alms for oblivion. IIT. 3. 145-146 The first thing we learn about experiencing this image is that, in order for it to speak to us, we must give it our complete concentration. Here Shakespeare's words mean so much more than they say: is he telling us that hypocritical Time will accept our bribes which we childishly believe will guarantee our being remembered, while actually only darkness lies ahead? Regardless, we'll agree that such. A marvelous image provokes us to project our thoughts into realms as difficult to acknowledge and solve as our own personal tensions. Food is useful to Shakespeare in defining moral qualities, as when he has a character in As You Like It point out that, though "honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar," yet "to cast away honesty upon a foul slut" is "to put good meat into an unclean dish" (IH. 3). Such a comparison sings in Our memories; we see it in our mind's eye. Again his comparison deftly sums up the heart of truth. While we must constantly be aware that we must not be nearly so concerned with what Shakespeare made his poetry out of as what he made it into, it is nonetheless interesting to observe how many characters and fields of knowledge he had to know intimately in order to create the following images. Consider Lear's terrible description of his daughter Goneril: Thou art a boil, A plague sore, an embossed carbuncle, In my corrupted blood. King Lear, II. 4. 226 Juliet, awaiting Romeo, finds her vigil wearing: So tedious is this day As is the night before some festival To an impatient child that hath new robes And may not wear them. Romeo and Juliet III. 2.28 "Love comforteth, like (Venus and While sun-shine after rain," Adonis), Love is: like a child, That longs for everything that he can come by. Two Gentlemen of Verona III. 1.124-125 Foolish love is: like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse, And presently, all humbled, kiss the rod! Ibid., I. 2.58, 59 634 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT And how deceived is Othello when he speaks of his beloved Iago as "an honest man" who:... Hates the slime That sticks on filthy deeds. Othello, V. 2. 148 | How tender is young love as spoken by Juliet: how fully her imagery gives expression to her emotion: Give me my Romeo; and when he shall | die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, | And he will make the face of heaven | so fine That all the world will be in love with | night, And pay no worship to the garish sun. Romeo and Juliet II. 2. 21-25 | But for sheer power, and expres- | sion of the surging vitality which is Shakespeare's greatest enduring gift, nothing compares to the violent images of the near-maddened King Lear as he wanders grief-crazed in the open fields during a storm, which but prepares us for Lear's own terrifying outbursts of pain as he defies nature to rival the intensity of his own heart-struck injuries. Listen as Lear speaks: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage! Blow! You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout Till you have drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks! You sulphurous and thought-executing fires, Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts, Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder, Smite flat the thick rotundity o' the world! Crack nature's molds, all germens_ spill at once.... Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire, Spout, rain! King Lear, III. 2, 1-8, 14 635 Seed Whasic 2, LADIES THREE PART CHORUSES. LDS BUSINESS COLLEGE Branch of Brigham Young University 70 NORTH MAIN SALT LAKE CITY Were the most vivid images or words to have been underlined, almost a solid black line would have been necessary. But three seem most piercingly to communicate Lear's defiant frustrations: a) "You sulphurous and thought-executing fires.' Who can react to raw, open blaze other than emotionally? B) "Smite flat the thick rotundity 0' the world!" This image gives to Lear's wrath the stature, the vast cosmic power of thunder so potent as to flatten the curved, thick earth; c) "Rumble thy bellyful!" Rumble contains within itself the very sound it defines, while bellyful is not so much vulgar as expressing a rude, healthy awareness of reality which no synonym can begin to approximate; the two words together in their aural and visual images crescendo to the point of fury and contempt which Lear felt. Spit! Spout! In their staccato brevity further drive home the climax-nail with Thor hammer-blows. All in all, this passage contains the essence of ravaging, naked fury—not done with scenery, nor costume, nor brassy sound-effects, but with words. Shakespeare's Songs To end on a calmer note, we should recall that Shakespeare live in the golden age of English music when almost everyone played an instrument, just as all of us now play the radio or TV, and hired musicians played for patrons who were at the barber's: The man that hath no music in himself, Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds, Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils. The motions of his spirit are dull as night, 636 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT And his affections dark as Erebus: Let no such man be trusted. Merchant of Venice, V. 1. 83-88 Shakespeare's music is best expressed in Romeo and Juliet and, excluding the sonnets which contain some of our most exquisite poetry, in the songs from various plays: "Who is Sylvia?" (from Two Gentlemen of Verona, IV. 2. 39); "Spring" and "Winter" (When Icicles Hang by the Wall) (from Love's Labor's Lost, V. 2. 904); "Under the Greenwood Tree (II. 5); and "Blow, Blow, 'Thou Winter Wind" (from As You Like It.) The Tempest contains almost enough music to justify likening it to a symphony. For evoking a mood of eerie mystery nothing can surpass: Full fathom five thy father lies, Of his bones are coral made, Those are pearls that were his eyes. Nothing of him that doth fade But doth suffer a sea change Into something rich and strange. Sea nymphs hourly ring his knell: (Burden.) Dingdong! Hark! Now I hear them—Dingdong, bell! The Tempest, I. 2. 396-404 Shakespeare loved nature as he loved music. The two are combined in one of his best-loved lyrics, also from The Tempest, which for simple beauty and gentle peace, is unrivaled: Where the bee sucks, there suck I. In a cowslip's bell I lie, There I couch when owls do cry... After summer merrily. Merrily, merrily shall I live now Under the blossom that hangs on the bough. Why do Shakespeare's images and comparisons tell us more about ourselves than we can ever know otherwise? > SOCIAL SCIENCE LATTER-DAY SAINT FAMILY LIFE No lesson is planned for December in this department, due to the holiday season. > Sie Gow, oP Gane Rising Mildred Higgins E are told in the Doctrine and Covenants that we should arise early, that our minds and bodies may be invigorated. I am, by nature, an early riser. To slip quietly out of bed while the rest of the family lies sleeping in the early morning hours, is the privilege of a mother. It is my privilege, and I am eternally grateful for it. I dress hastily and walk through the back door into our yard. The air is so filled with the songs of birds that they seem to be trying to outdo each other in praising their Creator. The green leaves are lightened by the far-reaching rays of the sun which is not yet above the horizon. The air at this hour is so fresh that I can scarcely breath deep enough to do it justice. At their very best are the roses — suspended perfectly in the crosscurrents of rising dew, descending sunlight, and the crisp but gentle breath of the morning itself. They, like the honey- 638 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—SEPTEMBER 1956 THE JOY OF EARLY RISING suckle, send their lovely aroma heavenward in praise of their Creator. It seems as if the earth itself is saying; "This is my most perfect hour — drink of it, for it is a tonic which will carry you through the heat of the noonday with a light step and a joyful heart. Now go into the midst of those who love you and minister to their needs, rejoicing and starting this day right!" Looking upward at the clear blue of heaven, my heart holds a prayer of gratitude and petition that I might not mar the remainder of a day that begins so perfectly. That, instead, I may be granted the wisdom to enhance it somewhere along the way. Much has been spoken and written about the place of the woman in a home to make her home a haven of rest for her returning husband and children. It seems to me that something may be said about the joyful responsibility that a woman has in the morning — to help her family face the day with high courage and a splendid faith. Many hundreds of years ago King Lemuel had something to say about this in his praise of a virtuous woman. One of his statements reads like this: "She riseth also while it is yet Hg and giveth meat to her houschold. (Proverbs 31:15). —<- Flower of Light Eva Willes Wangsgaard My father walked at chore time Within a flower of light; A lantern's smoky petals Befriended him at night. Berry How many autumns past my heart has yearned With restless hungering for any trail That wandered off where maple fires burned, Beneath October's amethystine veil. This urge to go, though tempered in the spring, And lulled to sleep when summer walks the land, Besets my heart with constant bickering The moment autumn shows its golden hand. No hill that lifts a torch against the sky But I would climb the bronze trail to its height, No winding lane where windblown leaves now lie But I would follow it in happy flight. There is no cure for wandering, I know, Except to heed its magic call—and go. Lukei 691 Subscription Price: $1.50 a year; Charity Never Faileth George H. Mortimer President, New York Stake HE apostle Paul would disagree strongly with the oftheard adage that nothing is certain but death and taxes. And rightly so, for he was inspired to instruct the saints in Corinth that "Charity Never Faileth." Charity is a composite of qualities or attributes which everyone who desires to live in accordance with the principles of the gospel of Jesus Christ must earnestly strive to acquire. 'Their acquisition is predicated upon an understanding and proper application of the divine laws governing human relations which must be obeyed in order to obtain this blessing. Conscious, prayerful, and devoted striving toward this goal is one of the most rewarding pursuits in life, for it assures us the most favorable and successful results of all our worthy activities. The approach to all our problems by the path of charity is as Paul states "a more excellent way" than any other. It is particularly appropriate for the sisters in the Church to meditate upon the way of charity, not only because the slogan of their Relief Society is Charity Never Faileth, but more importantly because they, by teaching and by example, exert the predominant influence in shaping the thought and response patterns of young children through their close association with them in the home, the school, and the Church. Page 644 Let us consider the attributes of Charity as Paul lists them. Charity Suffereth Long. 'The quality of long-suffering is that of long patience of offense. 'There are not many people who pass through life without being subjected to offenses of greater or less degree. Some of them may arise in the home — a wayward child, an inconsiderate parent or brother or sister. 'They may arise in school — an undisciplined pupil, an unfair teacher, cheating classmates. 'hey may arise in business — people who take unfair advantage in dealings, an ambitious co-worker who stoops to every device to gain advantage, a tyrannical boss. Instead of meeting the offenses in kind, as most people impulsively tend to do, the more excellent way, the charitable way, is that outlined by the Savior of not resisting the wrong, of turning the other cheek, of giving the cloak to him that sues for the coat, of going the second mile with him who compels you to go the first, of loving your enemies and praying for those who despitefully use and persecute you. 'Thus patience of offense, which leads to peaceful human relations, contrasts strongly with the spirit of avid and aggressive defense of every right and privilege, which leads to contention. "Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God." CHARITY NEVER FAILETH Charity... Is Kind. Kindness is the quality of gentleness. It goes beyond good will toward others, which is benevolence, and embraces the actual doing of good to others, which is beneficence. It characterizes the compassionate service of the Relief Society. Not only is kindness the quality which endears one to others in this life and motivates giving meat to the hungry, drink to the thirsty, shelter to the stranger, clothing to the naked, and visiting of the sick and imprisoned, but it will be, as the Savior so impressively taught, a factor which determines who is admitted to the kingdom of God and who is cast into the kingdom of the devil. Charity Envieth Not. 'To envy is to feel discontent at another's possessing that which you want. It is not the desire for good things and the righteous striving to acquire them for use in doing good to others that is inconsistent with the charitable approach to life's problems, but rather the coveting of things, position, and power for the gratifying of pride and vain ambition and the resort to unrighteous means to achieve them. 'The Lord created the good things of life to delight those who use them with thanksgiving. Envy makes gratitude impossible, It precludes contentment and joy. Charity Vaunteth Not Itself. To vaunt oneself is to make a vain display, to be hypocritical. Against no sin did the Savior speak more strongly than against hypocrisy. "Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For ye are like unto whited sepulchres, which indeed ap- 645 pear beautiful outward, but are within full of dead men's bones and of all uncleanness. Even so ye also outwardly appear righteous unto men, but within ye are full of hypocrisy and iniquity." He wants us to appear as we really are, to be genuine and sincere. Charity... Is Not Puffed Up. This is to be conceited, to have an exaggerated opinion of oneself. It is the antithesis of meekness and humility. The parable of the Pharisee and the publican who went into the temple to pray contrasts the vanity of a boastful prayer with the justification won by a sincere and humble prayer. It is to the meek, not to the braggarts, the Lord promised the inheritance of the earth. Charity... Doth Not Behave Itself Unscemly. A charitable person exhibits the quality of decorum, doing and saying the right thing at the right time and place. It is the foundation not only of good manners, but also of reverence in sacred places. It is a manifestation of consideration of the feelings of others which lies at the basis of good human relations. Charity.. Seeketh Not Her Own. This is the quality of unselfishness, of losing oneself in the service of others. 'The rewards of this attribute are: "He that findeth his life shall lose it: and he that loseth his life for my sake shall find it.. Whosoever will save his life shall lose it: and whosoever will lose his life for my sake shall find it.... Whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister; and whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant." 646 Charity... Is Not Easily Provoked. One who is provoked displays annoyance and vexation. It is a characteristic of a child quickly to display annoyance and vexation at physical pain, when his feelings are hurt, or when he does not get his way. He has a difficult time projecting himself into the position of another person as a basis for understanding the behavior that gives offense. In strong contrast to the immature response of a child, is the example of the Savior between the time of the great intercessory prayer in Gethsemane and his death on the cross. Not only did he curb any expression of annoyance at the unjust abuse which was heaped upon him, he rebuked Peter for using a sword and prayed forgiveness for his executioners. 'The degree to which we are able to respond to provoking situations in this Christlike manner is a measure of our maturity of thought and action. Paul expresses the maturing process of his own life by saying, "When I was a child, I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child: but when I became a man, I put away childish things." It is not the times when we curbed the impulse to do or speak spitefully that we remember with regret, but the times when we hastily said or did an unkind thing. Charity... Thinketh No Evil. Those who think no evil are the pure in heart. "Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God." Solomon recognized the power of thought on character when he said, "as he thinketh in his heart, so is he." 'The importance which the Savior placed on thought is RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 seen in these teachings, "for out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh. A good man out of the good treasure of the heart bringeth forth good things: and an evil man out of the evil treasure bringeth forth evil things... For out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies: These are the things which defile a man...." By thinking no evil, and using our minds for good thoughts, the dreadful consequences of evil thinking can be avoided. Charity... Rejoiceth Not in Iniquity. 'The vice of rejoicing in iniquity may manifest itself in two ways. One is in finding pleasure in doing sinful acts; the other in having "pleasure in them that do them." There should be little misunderstanding on the part of members of the Church about the importance of finding joy and satisfaction in personal righteousness rather than iniquity. But there are many people who successfully resist the temptation to commit certain sins who seem to find pleasure or satisfaction in those who commit them. It is this trait which underlies gossip, for the gossiper rejoices not only in hearing the account of another's sin but also finds pleasure in spreading the story. The quality of charity demands that there be no rejoicing in iniquity on our own part or on the part of anyone else. Charity... Rejoiceth in the Truth. 'The gospel of Jesus Christ is the truth. The attitude you take toward the commandments and revealed will of the Lord which are CHARITY NEVER FAILETH an integral part of the gospel will determine, quite largely, your response to temptation. If you resent such commandments as thou shalt not steal, bear false witness, covet, or commit immoral acts, or if you view the negative aspects of the Word of Wisdom as encroachments on your personal liberty, you are much more likely to succumb when tempted than if you are sincerely grateful for these principles and regard them as an armor. "Blessed is the man... (whose) delight is in the law of the Lord; and in his law doth he meditate day and night." Charity... Beareth All Things. To bear is to support, sustain, carry. Every man or woman who has had the privilege of working in a position of authority in the Church which involves calling others to serve, knows the importance of the quality some members possess of bearing all things. 'These are they who accept calis willingly, who are anxiously engaged in learning their duty and in doing much good, and who do not limit their activity when they have done their fair share. 'They carry on their appointed tasks to the end and lend enthusiastic support in word and deed to the programs sponsored by the local and General Authorities. This quality is of particular importance to the married women of the Church who are instructed of the Lord to "provoke" or motivate their husbands to good works. The wife who gladly accepts a standard of living which makes the payment of tithes and offerings possible, properly supports her husband in obeying these commandments. She can 647 make it easy for him to perform the ministerial duties that take him from the home, such as ward teaching, administering to the sick, missionary work, council meetings, if she adapts her schedule to his and lets him know by word and deed that she willingly sacrifices his companionship on these occasions. On the other hand, so great is her restraining influence on her husband's success in business and Church affairs, if she puts a barrier in his way, that he rarely passes through it. While the wife of an active Latter-day Saint man necessarily foregoes much in companionship with him, it is a sacrifice that calls forth the blessings of heaven. No other woman can have quite the peace of mind when her husband is away from home that a woman can have when she knows that her husband is engaged in the Lord's work. Charity... Believeth All Things. This is the attribute of faith—in God, in fellow men, in oneself. It characterizes those who declare with Nephi, "I know that the Lord giveth no commandments unto the children of men, save he shall prepare a way for them that they may accomplish the thing which he commandeth them." 'Those who possess this attribute meet and deal with others without suspicion and are quick to forgive those who repent of breaches of the confidence that had been placed in them. Charity... Hopeth All Things. To hope is to desire something with the expectation of getting it, with faith that it can be obtained. Hope is the quality that enables people 648 to surmount discouragement, to maintain zeal and enthusiasm in the face of reverses and failures, to make the best use of things at hand, to resist resentment against conditions which cannot be changed. It sustains the mother through the months of discomfort during pregnancy, through the agony of delivery, through hours of anxiety when illness strikes, through bereavement when loved ones go. It is the way to serenity rather than despair. Charity... Endureth All Things. To endure is to bear great and lasting hardships and evils. 'This quality makes it feasible to be in the world but not of the world and to withstand being persecuted for righteousness' sake without resentment. By cultivation of this quality you can rejoice when men revile you and persecute you and say all manner of RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 evil against you falsely for Christ's sake. It makes you immune to the scorn and ridicule of the unrighteous. And the promised reward is that "he that endureth to the end shall be saved." These, then, are the qualities that constitute charity which never fails in any situation. While Bible scholars do not agree as to the correct rendition of Paul's thought Charity Never Faileth, we can certainly agree that these attributes are based on eternal principles and therefore never end. They are, moreover, divine attributes which all those who hope to gain the celestial kingdom will have to acquire in this life. In acquiring these qualities by application of the relevant eternal principles, we may have complete confidence that we are meeting each situation in the best way, the way of charity, and Charity Never Faileth. Nibley Ta conference of the British Mission, held at Manchester, England, on August 14, 1848, and presided over by Elder Orson Pratt of the Council of the Twelve, it was resolved "that Elder William Howell, of Aberdare, South Wales, late a Baptist minister, go across the British Channel to Bretagne, France, and offer the gospel to the people of that country" (M. S. Vol. 10, p. 254). Elder Howell thus became the first missionary to fill an assignment in France. However, he was delayed in reaching his field of labor, and it was early in July 1849 when he arrived at the port of Le Havre. There, on July 30th, a few weeks after his arrival, he baptized his first convert, a young man thirty years of age, named August Saint d'Anna. At the October conference of the Church held in Salt Lake City, in 1849, Elder John Taylor of the Council of the 'Twelve, was appointed to preside over a new mission to be known as the French Mission. Elders Curtis E. Bolton and John Pack were called to accompany him. These brethren arrived at Boulogne-sur-Mer on June 18, 1850, and began their missionary labors. In 1851 Elder Taylor established a publication in Paris named L'Etoile du Deseret. Branches of the Church were organized in Paris, Boulogne-sur-Mer, and Le Havre. At a conference held July 24, 1853, at St. Heliers, Isle of Jersey, nine branches of the French Mission were represented with a combined membership of 337. The French Mission did not prosper as much as had been hoped, due to severe restrictions and other factors, and in 1864, it was made a district of the British Mission. This condition continued until 1912, when the French Mission, consisting of parts of Belgium, Switzerland, and all of France, was reorganized, with Elder Edgar B. Brossard as president. The work of proselyting has been actively continued since that time. There are today thirty-three branches of the French Mission with approximately 1,300 members. Elder Harold W. Lee is the president, with headquarters in Paris, where the Church has purchased a beautiful mission home. Twenty-seven Relief Society organizations were reported in December 1956, with 231 members. Last Summer Christie L. Coles and Beth C. Johnson HE day was parched and dust filtered. Leaves and foliage at the side of the gravel road were covered with a thick, gray film. The air was still as a waiting breath. Mina sat on the dirt-packed bridge and dangled her feet in the plastic-clear stream, wriggling her toes in its coolness. The sunlight stenciled arabesques upon her brown arms. "Are you really going away, Virginia?" Mina asked her friend who lay flat on her stomach by the stream, cupping water into her hand and catching "skaters" to place on the sand, then watching them hurty back to the water and their endless sliding. Virginia rolled over on her back, the light struck her fair face, and her voice seemed to lie on the dry air, husky and low, as she said, "Seems as though I've been watching these bugs all my life." "We have," Mina murmured softly, "every summer." 'Things didn't seem to change. There were always the celebrations in July, the same hot days, the same coming up here, wading, talking.... As she spoke, Mina had a strange feeling that she was quite invisible, seeing all this with ommniscience. She saw her friend's soft, petulant mouth, and purple-blue eyes; the long, blond braid that lay like a shining rope between her shoulders. An ache went through her for the skinny-legged little girl who used to Page 652 come here with her and later the bigger girl, when the talk had changed from paper dolls, to school, to boys. As though sensing her friend's thoughts, Virginia jumped up quickly and said in a strained voice, "Let's go pick some apples." Mina jumped to her feet, "Let's," she cried. The two of them made a vivid contrast as they ducked through the nearby fence: Mina, small and dark, with dimples that came and went in her tanned cheeks; Virginia, tall and blonde. They came back to the stream with their pockets filled with the red fruit, washed the apples in the stream and rubbed them dry. This is just as it has always been, thought Mina, every motion, the first bite into the crisp apple.... But it wasn't as crisp as it had seemed once, nor as juicy. Virginia must have noticed, too, for she said, "These apples don't taste the same. Do you think the trees are getting old? Maybe they haven't been pruned as they should have been." "What do you know about pruning apple trees?" Mina asked her, leaning against a poplar tree trunk where she could watch the stream, and see her friend. "Me? Why, I'm _ the world's greatest authority, don't you know?" she laughed, and Mina joined in the laughter, until they were laugh- LAST SUMMER ing uncontrollably, as they had often laughed over nothing whatever, until they were rolling over on their stomachs, gasping for breath. For a moment, each of them lay still. Mina saw the brightness in Virginia's eyes as they gazed briefly up the sandy shore at the clear water, the bushes, the deep foliage. She wondered if it could be only laugh-tears as they called them, or if this girl who had suddenly become almost a stranger, knew an ache similar to the one within herself. Why didn't Virginia answer her question? Why didn't she tell her? Papa had heard uptown that her folks were going to move, but Mina had been sure it was a mistake, assuring him, "But Virgie would have told me." INALLY, knowing Mina's thoughts, Virginia raised herself to her elbows, and cupped her chin in her hands. She said, softly, "Dad says we're going.... I couldn't tell you because I didn't believe it.. I still don't. I thought if I said it wasn't so, it wouldn't be." "You can stay with us," Mina suggested, brightly, "at least until they're settled. Oh, please do, Virgie. 'They won't mind." "Maybe I will, at least till school starts," her friend said slowly, "maybe I will. Starved." They washed their hands, dried them on the edge of the dish towel which covered the square, wicker basket; reached for the sandwiches and the hard-boiled eggs; the two bottles of root beer, and began to eat. Let's eat our lunch. I'm 653 "Member the first picnic we ever took," Virginia asked, "when we asked the folks if we could come down here, and they said, 'no,' and we got a lunch anyway, and took it to the Court House lawn?" "Yes, I remember. We weren't more than five, were we? And when they missed us, they had everybody out hunting, and almost dragged the river." The story was usually good for a really big laugh, but they only smiled now and went ahead with their eating. When they had finished, Mina said, ""Let's get some sun." "You're as brown as a nut now," Virginia told her. "I know. And you're just golden. Want some oil?" Mina asked. "In a minute." When they were lying flat, facing the sky, the worn blanket beneath them, neither spoke. It was as though they were already separated, or as though neither dared to speak. They rolled over, closed their eyes sleepily. After awhile Virginia said, "I guess we'd better go. I've got to help Mom pack." Mina picked up the cups, aware _ of the perspiration on her forehead and the dull thudding of her heart. "You will ask them to let you stay?" Virginia nodded, there was a frown between her eyes. And each knew it would not be so. Virginia leaned against a tree and looked into the distance at the little town where she had spent all sixteen of her summers. Her voice was soft 654 and sad as she murmured, "I'll miss all this. I'll miss you most, Mina eel ale. @ Mina didn't need to wonder about the tears now. She knew they were as teal as when Virgie's dog had died, or when her finest doll had been broken. 'Tears filled her own eyes. Her inclination was to throw herself back to the familiar sand, to weep, to hang onto the past, the fun, the goodness that seemed passing in this very instant. She sobbed, "Nothing will ever be the same again. Oh, Virgie." Virginia bent and picked up the picnic basket. Mina kicked a pebble, and they started toward the toad, the sand rising about their feet. When they had gone a short distance, a car of boys they knew from school passed. The boys waved, and the girls waved in return. Their steps quickened ever so slightly. <> Metal World Dorothy J. Roberts Lost in a metal world, the tardy bee, Thirsting, is refused the nectar's drop. Copper, are the clusters on the lilac tree, And bronze, the billowed weeds' unscented crop. The final gold of flowers is pollenless In the Midas-touch of autumn's chilling spear. Through brittle stems and blossoms, bleached to brass, Platinum frost unweaves the petaled year. Left Hands Celia Luce IN right-handed persons, the left hand is a pampered hand. It wears beautiful rings, and it is not expected to do a great share of the work. It mostly just holds things and assists. The night hand gets the callouses. It gets the hard part of every job. But it is also the efficient hand, the useful one we treasure. It does the important work and is the leader. Are too many of us training our children to be like the left hand? Do we do all the work for them, give them beautiful clothes to wear, and make all their decisions for them? If so, they may grow up to be pampered individuals, and then we may wonder why they never become leaders, why they remain selfish, unhappy persons who are making a failure of life. Brave Men and Worthy Patriots (A Narrative Account of Utah's Contribution to the American Civil War) Samuel Chandler Science Librarian, Bigham Young University narrow line of troopers A wound its way out of the West, leaving a thousand miles of telegraph wires and a stream of immigrants to the mercy of a savage wilderness. Soon a hundred grim messages were dumped upon the already loaded desk of the President of the United States. As the President read them, the furrows in his dark brow deepened. "Listen to this, Thomas," he called to his adjutant, " 'March 20, 1862: Indians have destroyed the telegraph station at Pacific Springs!' Here's another, dated April first: 'Renegades have burned the mail stations at Split Rock on the Sweet Water!' And, here's another: April third: "Yesterday a tribe of Blackfeet under Pocatello massacred an immigrant train south of Fort Hall!' " "Why that's terrible, Mr. President," the adjutant said. The President's mouth settled into a hard, firm line. "This situation must be controlled immediately!" "But, Mr. Lincoln," the adjutant sighed, "we can't send men to the West. Already the Southerners outnumber our forces from Kansas to the Potomac." "True," the President replied. "Nevertheless, serious consequences will result, if we lose communication with California and the territories out there." "T wish the Westerners would protect themselves, Sir." "That's it, Thomas," cried the President. "Send a telegram to Colonel Connor in San Francisco ordering him to recruit and train a battalion of men from California and Nevada. Send another to Brigham Young in Salt Lake City requesting him to muster a company of Utah volunteers into the United States Army. Tell him to arm and equip them immediately and send them to protect the area along the North Platte." "Did you say Brigham Young, Sir? Do you really think the Mormons would send men to help the United States Government?" "Yes, yes, I'm sure they will. Brigham Young himself assured me that Utah will remain loyal to the Union. Now hurry!" "Yes, Sir." Upon receipt of the adjutant's telegram, Brigham Young called three officers of the Utah Militia to his office: General Daniel H. Wells, Colonel Robert Burton, and Captain Lot Smith. "Because it is our duty as Americans to obey when our country calls," he said, "I think General Wells should recruit two companies at once, one for Captain Smith to lead to the North Platte immediately, and the other for Colonel Burton to train so that it may protect the area near our territory." Three days later, one hundred six men under the command of Captain Smith marched towards their headquarters at a way station on the Platte River in Wyoming. When they reached the mouth of Utah's Emigration Canyon, they Page 655 656 stopped briefly to hear Brigham Young speak. I desire of the officers and privates of this company, that in this service they will conduct themselves as gentlemen, remembering their allegiance and loyalty to our government, and also not forgetting that they are members of the organization to which they belong, never indulging in intoxicants of any kind, and never associating with bad men or lewd women, always seeking to make peace with the Indians. Aim never to take the life of an Indian or white man, unless compelled to do so in the discharge of duty, or in defense of your own lives, or that of your comrades. Whenever and wherever you can hold councils with their sachems, or peace chiefs, do not fail to embrace the opportunity, and thus win their friendship and prevent the shedding of blood if possible. Another thing I would have you remember is that, although you are United States soldiers you are still members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, and while you have sworn allegiance to the constitution and government of our country, and we have vowed to preserve the Union, the best way to accomplish this high purpose is to shun all evil associations, and remember your prayers, and try to establish peace with the Indians, and always give ready obedience to the orders of your commanding officers. If you will do this, I promise you, as a servant of the Lord, that not one of you shall fall by the hand of an enemy (Margaret M. Fisher, Utah and the Civil War, Salt Lake City, the J. O. Knowlton Post of the G. A. R.. 1920, pp. 25-26). During the next three and a half months this little band performed deeds unsurpassed in American military history. With little thought of personal safety or hope for national acclaim, they tamed Indian tribes that had previously destroyed trained troops of the United States Army. They distributed the United States mail over a vast area. 'They RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 rode with immigrants over terrain infested by treacherous _ thieves. They built bridges, erected wayside stations, and constructed roads along the Oregon and California trails. Of them Brigadier General James Craig said, "The Utah cavalry are the most efficient troops I have in the service, and I propose their service be extended an additional ninety days (Ibid., p. 36). NE of their most interesting experiences started when Captain Smith detailed Lieutenant John Quincy Knowlton and nine others to apprehend five dangerous escapees from Fort Leavenworth, Kansas. The trail left by the criminals led Lieutenant Knowlton and his men to the foot of a grassy knoll near Bear Lake. While resting in this spot, they heard a_blood-curdling scream that sent them to cover where they remained while a band of painted Indians rode past them and out of sight. 'Then the troops moved to the other side of the knoll and found there the massacred bodies of the men they sought. "I guess our work is done," the lieutenant said, "might as well go back to headquarters." Even as he spoke the Indians reappeared, and they proved to be in a nasty mood. Luckily, however, the lieutenant noticed that one of the Indians carried a freshly killed elk behind his saddle. 'Through a soldier who spoke the Bannock language, he said. "You furnish meat, and we'll furnish bread for a feast of peace." 'The Indians looked at the bread and agreed. Notwithstanding the feast, the peace was short lived. As the soldiers BRAVE MEN AND WORTHY PATRIOTS were about to leave the Indians, a sergeant recognized an excellent horse belonging to a citizen of Salt Lake City. "That's Brother Richard's mare," he said to his comrades, and then, without considering the consequences, he roped the animal around the neck. Quickly, while one of their number tackled the sergeant, the Indians moved into a circle around the soldiers. "Get up," the leutenant said to the sergeant. "Now listen all of you, we're in a mess. 'There's no time to mount, so leave your horses and follow me and don't be afraid. If you've lived as President Young directed, you'll be protected." Then, throwing his head high, he walked toward the thick underbrush near the position taken by four or five braves. As the others followed him, they heard the twang of bowstrings and the click of gunlocks. Upon each man's lips was a silent prayer, and in his heart Brigham Young's words rang loudly: "I promise you, as a servant of the Lord, that not one of you shall fall by the hand of an enemy." With this assurance to buoy them, these men walked past the Indians and into the thicket. Hours later when they had reached the camp of Washakee, the peace-loving Chief of the Shoshonies, they knelt and thanked God for his protection. Washakee, upon hearing of their misadventure, sent some of his own braves to recover the horses and to punish the Indian who had stolen Brother Richards' mare. Days later, when Lieutenant Knowlton and his men arrived back in camp, they learned that Captain Smith had led another party into Idaho to recover some property that 657 the Indians had stolen from the Government. For days this group lived upon dry bread and the roots and berries they found. As they attempted to cross a mountain stream, a horse fell into a deep pool, and its rider was drowned before his comrades could reach him. His was the only death sustained by the entire company. While the Smith group was still in Wyoming, the company commanded by Colonel Burton was mustered into the service of the United States by the Governor of Utah Territory. While on duty, this company escorted several notable Westerners across the plains. Because of the spring thaw, their task was extremely arduous. At one point the snow and slush were so thick that they had to accompany a Congressman through an area tuled by a band of lawless renegades, some red, some white. In this area they found over a dozen deserted and pillaged way stations, from which they gathered many sacks of mail and sent them to Salt Lake City for distribution. After turning over their command to Colonel Connor and his soldiers, these brave and peaceful men teturned to their homes, taking with them the thanks of the United States Government. Of them some latter-day chronicler might have written as Helaman wrote of that similar group of Americans whose story is related in the Book of Mormon. 'Never had I seen so great courage.... Now they never had fought, yet they did not fear death; and they did think more upon the liberty of their fathers than they did upon their lives... (Alma 56:45, 47). Alder JEAN INGELOW: Jean Ingelow, the charming English poetess and novelist, is seriously ill and has been very feeble for some time. She lives in a quaint little cottage in Kensington with her bachelor brother, surrounded by her birds and flowers. Her conservatory is twice the size of her dwelling, and one of her favorite pastimes has been to liberate her feathered friends among the flowers while she writes at her desk.... In addition to her books of poems, she has written four novels and various works for children. Her poems are refreshing and sparkling, among the best known of which is "We Are Seven." —Selected HELENE OF MONTENEGRO: Princess Helene of Montenegro who is to marry the Crown Prince of Italy, is a poet, and many of her verses have been set to music and are sung by the peasants in all parts of the principality. —Selected AUTUMN: As the cool weather approaches the pleasure seekers forsake the mountain retreats and lake resorts, and are reopening their houses and making ready for in-door pastimes and amusements. The theatre has already opened its doors and some most delightful plays have been given and two very charming concerts are promised for the present week. —Editorial Note Page 658 GRAND DUCHESS CHARLOTTE is the much-admired tuler of Luxembourg, a grand duchy of 300,000 population, where Mrs. Perle Mesta was the former United States Minister. In 1919, after World War I, the people demanded that Grand Duchess Marie abdicate in favor of her sister Charlotte. That same year the right to vote was granted to both women and men past the age of twenty-one. Charlotte and a cabinet of eight ministers hold the executive power in this spirited country, which is very democratic. Grand Duchess Charlotte is married to Prince Felix of Bourbon Parma and has six children. RS. Page 659 CD EDITORIAL <c—~©2 VOL. 43 OCTOBER 1956 NO. 10 Study Courses Availeth Much GAIN with October, comes the opportunity for women to participate in a formal-type of education as offered in the study courses of Relief Society. Relief Society classes provide women an academic atmosphere in which to gain knowledge in the theological, homemaking, literary, and social science areas of study during the years when their opportunities to attend formal classes are seemingly past. The stimulation which the mind receives in the formal learning process is often neglected as a mother's responsibilities increase with her family. In her busy, unselfish life of meeting the needs of her family, she may be unable to find time to devote to gaining mental growth in some of these various areas of learning. 'Through participating in the weekly classes of Relief Society a woman not only gains mental growth for herself, but acquires knowledge which she can share with her family. Her attitudes concerning her responsible position in the home, which is an important factor involved with the family's happiness, may broaden as she achieves a stimulation in her thinking through the avenue of learning available at Relief Society, and which is designed especially for her. It is a true prinPage 660 ciple as the physical body attains its goals likewise must the spiritual body achieve successes. By studying the literature lessons an insight into the writings of the greatest authors and poets is gained. Information is imparted which will stimulate the mind to a greater enjoyment and comprehension of the masterpieces of literature. The factors of a secure family life and other social aspects are incorporated for study in the social science lessons. Challenges to learning of theological principles are presented. Home management problems, similar to those which often confront a mother in her own home, are discussed and studied. Integrated with the Relief Society study courses are projects and programs in which much of the gained knowledge can be applied. With the acquisition of knowledge comes an eternal blessing. To the Prophet Joseph Smith was revealed: "Whatever principle of intelligence we attain to in this life, it will rise with us in the resurrection" (D. & C. 130:18). The Relief Society presents unlimited opportunities for claiming blessings during this life and through eternity. ~J. N. Healthy, Happy, Lucky You AN UNENDING DEBT 'Be Honest with Yourself | T was the day before Mary's marriage. Her mind was flashing over the exciting occurrences of the day and foretasting the joys of her life ahead. As she anticipated the rich promise, the words of the poster in the ward meetinghouse last Sunday seemed to speak themselves aloud, "Healthy, Happy, Lucky You! Be Honest with Yourself." Never had Mary felt healthier, happier, or luckier than tonight— although she did not feel that the "luckier" was by chance. It was the last four words that caused her mind to check itself and concentrate. "Be Honest with Yourself." Mary's heart sank and then lifted in gratitude as she relived an experience of two years ago. That night had been a turning point in her life. Mary again seemed to hear the warning counsel of her mother, counsel which, until that night, had never called for action on Mary's part. Counsel which then had aroused Mary and brought her through to safety. Mary's heart sang with joy as she realized that the clean, healthy body she had inherited from her parents had been kept pure by her. Being honest with herself made Mary wonder what her life might have been without the teachings of the gospel. And beyond her parents' example she recalled herself as a young child kneeling in family prayer at her grandparents' home. Ahead. For Mary lay health and happiness. She knew she was indebted to many people for this blessed opportunity. Before sleep faded the picture of Bob, the temple, and her family, Mary decided she had found the honest answer. The obligation for obtaining health and happiness was a never-ending chain of conduct and_ teaching, reaching forward to generations unborn. Early Present Shirley Sargent 66 HAT do you want for Christmas?" Neal Hendrickson asked casually on the morning of December eighth, as he watched his wife brush her dark hair. He prided himself on being thoughtful, and last year this foresightedness had paid off in the form cf a mink stole Nan had admired extravagantly. "You." Her reply so disconcerted him that he dropped a cuff link. "Me? You mean you want me to troop downstairs Christmas morning and have the children discover me in a stocking?" "That's about the size of it." Nan's voice was low, grave, and definitely unamused. "Size is right." He tried to recapture the light touch for which he was noted. "Exactly five feet and eleven inches of it and all me. You don't want much." She turned, and her brown eyes were as grave as her tone. "Seemingly too much to ask." "Ask for the moon, my lady, and,"... He hesitated. "You want me for Christmas?" "Something like that, Neal, but you figure it out." At lunch time he tried to do just that. What had Nan meant? He recalled other years' gifts — the mink stole, matching luggage, golf clubs, jewelry, a painting — things he'd bought since the business was successful. Nan was talking nonsense. He could take her away. A weck's cruise perhaps? Then he remembered that last season he had Page 664 arranged for the children to go to his parents while he and Nan had attended a house party. "Never again," she had said on their return. "But those people were important, influential to business." "Your children are more important to me than any position or salary in the world." She hadn't been so sober then; she had sounded angry and impatient. "At least we weren't routed out of bed at five, but, back to the barbarians!" He hadn't meant it to sound that way when he had said it. 'They had two sons, Neal Jr., eleven, and Howard, eight. They were both good boys, but Neal was too busy to see much of them. The remark of Nan's that morning was as imperative as the buzzer that rang on Neal's desk. Was that what Nan wanted, he wondered, later in the day, more of his time? He dictated some letters, then dismissed his secretary. How long had it been since he'd helped the boys with homework or joined them in their home workshop? Neal didn't like the conclusions his thoughts led up to—neglect. But business was for the family. Before, too? And Nan, how often had he done anything with her that wasn't social lately? Not many quiet evenings, nor Saturdays in the yard, his work had swallowed such time. "You figure it out," she had said and, now that he had, he was ashamed that he hadn't realized what he was letting business do to him—to them, EARLY PRESENT It was just two-thirty when he stalked out of the office.
