"I believe in early Christmas Our Cabin Had a Porch Nell Murbarger OST homestead shanties M were about the size and shape of a railroad box car, and just about as inelegant in appearance. A single door, one or two small windows, an unsheathed stovepipe; and not one in a hundred had felt the stroke of a paintbrush. But our homestead home — even though it conformed closely to the general pattern — was a home of distinction. Our cabin had a porch! We always referred to it as "The Front Porch" — a high sounding phrase which seemed to imply that somewhere in the immediate environs there might be also a back porch. But, of back porches there was none; and even The Front Porch was not exactly pretentious. Its roof, tar-papered like the house, ran the full length of our fourteenfoot cabin, and was supported by undressed two-by-four studdings; its front was enclosed by woven wire netting, stretched from floor to roof, and its pine board floor sloped a little to the outer edge so water might drain off more quickly after summer rains, or following the vigorous weekly scrubbings Mother gave it with a broom. After serving through the winter as a semi-protected storage space for stovewood cut in the cedar breaks, The Front Porch came into its own with the first warm days of early summer. Before the end of May, the wire netting front would be Page 666 covered with a heavy green curtain of wild cucumber vines and morning glories. Butterflies and bees, in their everlasting search for pollen and nectar, utilized the vines as their central headquarters; and even tiny hummingbirds _ occasionally sought the cool seclusion of the greenery. After several weeks of coaxing, supported by all sorts of ten-yearold logic, Mother finally would concede that the season was well enough advanced that a little girl might sleep safely out of doors — a decision followed immediately by the delightfully adventuresome business of moving my cot to the narrow, green tunnel of The Front Porch. I doubt if any explorer embarking for darkest Africa was ever more thrilled by that prospect than I would be on this first night of summer freedom as I donned my nightie in the cabin, then hurried outside to slip between the delicious coolness of the smooth muslin sheets! A yellow square of lamplight, pouring through the cabin's east window, would spread across the middle of my cot until Mother and Father sought out their own bed, and the flame in the kerosene lamp was extinguished. FTER that, I would be alone by myself, in my little leafy world; alone, yet never alone. All my friends of the prairie night would OUR CABIN HAD A PORCH be there to keep me company. From the stock dam, in the draw, would be issuing the throaty croak of frogs, and, under the porch boards, crickets would be strumming their fiddles. There would be the gentle, satisfied sounds of cattle and horses stirring in the nearby feed lot; and, if a coyote voiced his lonely wail in some distant coulee, there would be a low, answering whine from Zip, the collie — a sad little whine which seemed to say that she heard and understood this strange call of the wild, and might have responded, could she have done so without forsaking her post of duty at the foot of my cot. Every rustle of leaves meant that some prairie mouse was foraging for crumbs and seeds, or that a drowsy bird was changing his position in the vines; and sometime, during each night, would sound the plaintive, hesitant call of a billy owl. Placing my cupped hands to my lips, in the way Father had taught me, I would answer the little brown creature; and for several minutes we would "talk" back and forth — a prairie girl to a prairie bird. One night, when I was still a very small girl, my mimicry was good enough that I succeeded in calling one of the little owls to the house. Approaching, closer and closer, he finally settled on the porch floor with a soft flutter and turned his head to regard me quizzically, almost as though he were wondering what sort of creature it might be who spoke his language in such atrocious fashion, yet was forever trying to converse with him! Our homestead was situated not 667 far from the Black Hills, and electrical storms occurred frequently throughout the summer months. Mother and Father had exercised great care in impressing upon me the beauty and majesty of a storm, and had never represented it to me as a matter for dread or alarm. As a consequence, I felt no fear of those nocturnal displays of might — not even when jagged lightning snapped and crackled and filled the air with tingling static that seemed to creep into one's very flesh. And bones; nor even when great volumes of thunder rolled across the dark prairie hills to engulf our little cabin in a windy world of fury and violence. These electrical storms generally abated quickly and unproductively; but, now and then, one would bring rain or hailstones. When the windhurled drops began to beat through my leafy curtain, I would hop out of my cozy nest, roll my bedding, and retreat hastily to the dry interior of the cabin. With sunrise, next morning, we would look upon a spanking new land! 'The wild cucumber vines and The Front Porch would be washed clean and bright; and all our small empire would be steeped in the fragrance of wet pine boards, and steaming tar-paper, and rainfreshened prairie grass. I loved the sound of the rain, and the clean, sweet smell it brought to the land. But more than all, I loved the bright mornings that followed after.... A bright morning meant that once again my bed could come out on The Front Porch. Recipes for Bread and Rolls Rhea H. Gardner ENRICHED WHITE BREAD Makes Two Loaves 7 c. Sifted enriched white flour % cake yeast, softened in % c. Lukewarm water 80° to 85° F. Place in mixing bowl: 2%-¢. Scalded milk. 3 tbsp. Sugar 3 tbsp. Shortening 1 tbsp. Salt When milk mixture has cooled to go°F., add 4 c. Sifted flour and beat well. Add the softened yeast. Add more flour, enough to make a soft dough. Mix until the dough forms in an elastic ball in the bowl. Cover and let rest 10 to 15 minutes. This will make the dough easier to knead. Put % c. Flour onto the kneading canvas and tub it into the portion where you will do the kneading. Knead 10 to 15 minutes. Cover the bowl or crock tightly. Keep the fermenting dough in a warm place, 80°F., away from drafts, until it is almost tripled in bulk. 'This will take about one hour and forty or fifty minutes for white dough. Punch it down, turn it over, cover, and let rise for about 1 hour. Mold into loaves and put into pans. Part of the white flour may be substituted with whole-wheat flour. Keep wholewheat dough as soft as you can possibly handle it. Whole wheat dough ferments much faster than does white dough. If it once gets too light, the finished bread will be coarse and crumbly. Harries McNeil Bradshaw Enjoys a Life of Creativity Through Hobbies HE hobbies of Harriet McNeil Bradshaw, seventy-nine, of Salt Lake City, Utah, have provided a satisfying source of creativity. Many of the pieces which she has started as hobbies have been inevitably given to her family and friends. Other articles beautify her home. Ten years after her marriage to John Bradshaw, she owned thirty quilts of her own making, and during the years she has made nearly one hundred and fifty quilt tops. The homes of her six children are beautified by her quilts and other articles of exquisite handwork. She embroiders and crochets pillow cases, doilies, hot pads, and chair sets. A crocheted bedspread is one of the loveliest pieces of her handicraft. Her own designs are worked into many of the articles. She also mends and upholsters furniture and makes rugs. Sister Bradshaw has been active in Relief Society for many years, having served as a counselor in the Francis Ward Relief Society, South Summit Stake, Utah. She has been a visiting teacher for nearly fifty-four years, My Guiding Light Lucile Tournear Y mother was so quiet and unassuming that many of her closest neighbors never really learned to know her; yet she was truly a friend to the friendless, and a comfort to the lonely hearted. My early childhood would have been desolate indeed without her love and devotion. How clearly I remember a conversation that went something like this. "Mamma, will you read to me now? Just a few pages, Mamma." I would carry a book into the kitchen where my mother was ironing, or to the dining room where she sat at her sewing machine. Sometimes I followed her to the back porch where she scrubbed clothes on a washboard. Her explanations that she must first finish her work, were always gentle and patient. Never did she raise her voice in anger or impatience. More often than not, she would leave her work only to finish it later in the evening when I was tucked safely into bed. Due to her kindness and tact, I was eight years old before I realized that I was blind. When a teacher was found to teach me braille, Mother learned braille with me. Since we could see the teacher only once a week, Mother felt that my progress would be too slow with so little help, so my education became another of her many tasks. When I did enter a day school for the blind, I was able to go into the fifth grade with the children in my own age group. Had she merely been the traditional busy housewife, this would have been noteworthy enough, but since Page 670 she was the sole provider for four children, it was remarkable. By taking in washing and sewing, working in the homes of neighbors, and remaking second-hand clothing which friends and relatives contributed, we were able to manage. My mother was often asked why she did not send me away to school. In those days, practically all blind children attended special state institutions. Tio such questions Mother would say: "I want Lucile to have the same love and care that my other children have. Now that she has learned to read, we can manage until the class for the blind in Los Angeles is ready." When the class was finally organized, Mother sold our home in the small town of Compton, where we had always lived, and moved to Los Angeles. This was in 1919, shortly after the close of World War I, and houses were scarce and rents were high. Even in those days people were not anxious to rent to families with children, and widows with children presented a real problem. Then, too, they were afraid the little blind girl would fall and get hurt, and they did not want to be responsible. However, finally we were able to rent an apartment, with the understanding that we would move as soon as possible. Within a month we found a house. I know now that Mother's great faith and fervent prayers were responsible for this. EOPLE wondered how Mother would earn our living in a strange community where we knew no one. She had told no one what MY GUIDING LIGHT her plans were, and, to this day, I am not sure whether she had made any definite decision as to what she would do. However, the problem seemed to solve itself, and on her long walks during the househunting period, she had discovered that many people were renting their spare rooms, and that such rooms were in great demand. Since the school I was to attend was near a university and many students. Needed living accommodations, Mother opened a rooming house. S I made friends with the blind students in my school, we also took some of them into our home. There-was Marguerite the little girl whose parents were in the restaurant business, and were busy until late in the evening. 'Could someone care for the child after school hours until her parents could come. For her? I told my mother what the situation was, and Marguerite practically, became a member of the family. 'This resulted in a beautiful friendship for me which will never die. Marguerite became much closer to my mother than to her own, because she was with my mother during the years of adolescence when a girl needs a mother's companionship most. Since we lived only four blocks from my school, our home became the favorite visiting place for my friends. Mother never minded their noise. She loved the piano playing and singing, no matter how long the music sessions lasted. I know that she was terribly disappointed that I never became a musician, but she never mentioned her disappointment. My friends were sure that when they came to our house, refreshments would be in 671 order.. Mother's homemade cookies and chocolate cake were always a delight. Whenever there was a school picnic, there were always two or three friends ready to share my lunch with me. Mother's deviled eggs and well-filled sandwiches were always popular. I never could have finished high school and college without Mothers help. In the late twenties and early thirties, there were very few textbooks to be had in_ braille. Mother did most of my reading. She also spent long hours dictating French to me, and I transcribed page after page of it into Braille. I wonder now why my teachers did not assign certain paragraphs to me, so that Mother would not have had to spend so many hours dictating the long lessons. Mother never complained, however; she wanted me to read just what the class was reading. She read French beautifully. Though she had only gone to a small country school which took her through the Fifth Reader only, she had learned to speak French at home as her parents spoke no English. Because Mother had read French prayers in her childhood, she never learned to pray in English. Marguerite and I used to tell her she had two voices, one for French and one for English. The French voice had a nostalgic tenderness in it like soft, sad music. Mother never liked to go to bed until all of us were safely tucked in. When I sat up late typing my college notebooks, she would sometimes drop off to sleep out of utter weariness, but before I finished my work, she would always wake up and bring me a steaming cup of cocoa. 672 "You're so tired," she would say anxiously, "you'll kill yourself working so hard." It never occurred to her to say "I'm so tired." Since we had to take in roomers, we never had much privacy as a family. Strangely enough we didn't mind this too much, because Mother had a way of making them seem a part of the household. They all loved her because she was friendly without intruding in their affairs. Mother loved all people. She took Ester Lo, a lonely Chinese girl student into our home, and did what she could to make the strange girl feel at home in a foreign country. She encouraged Ester to bring her Chinese school friends in, and our house often reeked with the odors of strange Chinese foods which she cooked in our kitchen. The unfamiliar guttural sounds of the Cantonese dialect they spoke made us feel that we had indeed been shifted into a strange new world. When Ester presented Mother with a box of candy at Christmas, and a Christmas card came from her boy friend, Mother's holiday season was complete. Though Mother was much too busy to attend clubs or to have hobbies, she did love to go to shows, both the movies and stage plays. We saw some wonderful pictures and plays together. People used to ask my mother how I could enjoy them. "I tell her the pictures and read her the titles on the screen," she answered simply. "The stage plays are easier because she can learn the voices." When talking movies came in, Mother's task was much easier, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 and the pictures took on new life. Nevertheless, due to Mother's careful descriptions, I was able to follow the stories of the silent pictures and enjoy them perfectly. Often we could discuss these pictures at home, and Mother would laughingly tell friends that she had tried so hard to make the pictures clear to me that I could tell the story better than she could. HEN my sisters and I had all married, Mother gave up our old home and divided her time among us. We tried to persuade her to live with a friend, or rent an apartment so that she could have a permanent home, but she would not do this. Her life had been lived so completely for her children that she seemed totally incapable of creating a life for herself. I felt guilty when she lived with my husband and me because she insisted on doing all of the housework. I was always to her "her little girl." It wasn't that she wanted me to be dependent upon her; on the contrary, she was very anxious for me to become self-reliant, knowing that there would come a time when she could not be with me. She went to her heavenly home on a thirty-first of December. How fitting that she should start a new life with a new year! Her work on earth was well done; she would not have wanted to stay here any longer. Because of her, I have never known a world of darkness. Because of her, I have been able to live a busy and happy life. With her as my inspiration, I shall continue to do so. As she always has been, she always will be my guiding light. Helping Hands Flo Whittemore had not invited her to come into my home that morning. I had not even been wishfully thinking (as I have so often since) that she would come. Yet, at nine o'clock, there she Was, energetically scrubbing away on my dirty woodwork and looking as cheerful, | thought to myself, as though she enjoyed it, "Why?" J questioned almost aloud as I watched her from the davenport where I was lying. Then, as if an effort to discover "why" was too much exertion for a body weakened by illness and a mind Weary of trying to solve problems, I said a bit querulously to myself, "Oh, well, if she wants to do it, it's perfectly all tight! Only I don't see why she should enjoy doing it!" She was our very capable, very much loved Relief Society presiWhen I had answered her knock on my door that eventful day, she had smiled pleasantly as she asked: "How are you this morning?" "[t will be nice," | acknowledged, "to have the windows washed, especially this one in front of me. It's so smoky, everything looks gray outside." "I know. Almost gives you a gloomy aspect of life, doesn't it?" she replied cheerily as she proceeded to undo the bundle of cloths she had brought. Hmmm! J thought, "almost!" Why shouldn't I be altogether gloomy just lying here day after day. And I retired again into my morbid thoughts. I had known Lola as president of Relief Society; I had been a visiting teacher for nearly two years. When I became ill, she had called, bringing me a bouquet of blooms from her rose garden. | loved those! But why should she suddenly take a notion to come into my house and clean it up? My conscience was beginning to prick a little—but | don't care, I told myself, how dirty it is. It doesn't matter to me; I'm just too tired. But she doesn't need to act as if she so much enjoyed doing it. I'm sure | shouldn't enjoy cleaning up somebody else's dirty house. Oh, well! People are different, | guess, And then I became fascinated as I watched her quick, vigorous movemeuts: up and down and across, not a stroke wasted. Lola was hike that in everything she did. Without saying a word, she radiated life and good cheer. Deftly, almost gracefully, I thought, she bent to wring the water out of the scrub cloth as she wiped the clean white wood Page 673 674 with clear water before polishing it with a dry cloth. E. Didn't talk; I was too tired. But it seemed to me only a matter of a few minutes until all the woodwork in the living room was spotless. "Tt does look better," I acknowledged aloud; "I didn't realize it was so dingy." "Well, with a coal fire, it doesn't take long," Lola answered as she picked up the pans of dirty water. Then, stepping quickly into the kitchen, she got a smaller pan of clean water and soap and returned to the living room window. "Oh!" I exclaimed, as she squeezed some of the water out of the cloth and started washing the glass, "I have some window-cleaner. It's easier." But before I could get my slippers on, she stopped me. "Never mind," she said, "I like this way better. Guess I'm just old-fashioned." And she laughed good-naturedly. Then, as an afterthought, she added: "Unless you'd rather I used the glass-cleaner." "Oh, no! It makes no difference to me," I replied, and sank back with a sigh onto my pillow. Secretly, I thought: That's strange. She not only enjoys working, but evidently likes to do things the hard way.. But hard way or not, in a very short while she had both of the windows and the glass in the door so clean and shining that one could almost believe there was no glass in the frames at all! For the first time since she had come, I think I smiled, and something deep down inside me fluttered RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 ever so slightly. I felt it, but refused to give happiness a chance. Instead, I pulled down the corners of my mouth again and turned my face to the wall. If Lola was disappointed, she gave no sign; but resolutely filling her pans with clean, warm water, she began scrubbing the woodwork in the bedroom, all the while whistling or humming a cheery accompaniment to the rhythmic movements of her hands. Listening, my thoughts went back many years to a sunny morning at my grandmother's home in a little town in Utah when I had first met Estella Wight, who became a cherished and lifelong friend. She was gaily singing as she scrubbed out a wash on the board. A girl of ten years, I looked at her with wonder, to be singing on wash day! Now I was far away from Estella, but here was another person much like her, cheerily singing her way into my life, whether I would or not. Then I happened to glance at the clock. It said "11:30." Lola will be hungry, working as she has all morning, I thought. Maybe I could get some lunch ready. I arose and went into the kitchen, and, by the time lunch was on the table, Lola had finished the woodwork and windows in bedroom and bath. I don't remember what I prepared for lunch or what we talked about as we ate; nothing very personal, anyway. Then Lola washed the dishes while I wiped them. HELPING HANDS "Now you'd better lie down again," she said, "you've been sick a long time and you are not strong yet. You must remember to take it easy for awhile. Don't try to do everything all at once when you can get up and around." Her smile, her sympathy, warmed my heart, and I went back to the davenport gladly, with not the least desire to argue. (How I'd changed! ) Two hours or so later, my small kitchen was spick and span: walls, cabinets, floor, doors, and windows. As Lola prepared to leave, I got up to thank her. I expressed appreciation, in a matter-of-fact way, for her efforts to help me, and I was glad to have my house clean, too. "It was nice of you to do it," I said. And then, as she chatted happily about making some bright ruffled curtains for the kitchen windows, the miracle happened. I glanced down at her hands that must have been lovely when she came to my house that morning. I could see that they were small and beautifully shaped with tapering fingers that looked more like they 675 should be skimming over piano keys than scrubbing dirty woodwork. But now they were red, rough, and scratched, the nails cracked and broken. Dismayed and ashamed, I would have cried out, but before I could say a word, Lola was gone. Remembering the diamonds in the bands that circled her finger, I knew she did not have to do the menial tasks that she had done so willingly in my home. For me—to help lift me up out of the discouragement and despair into which I had fallen and give me a new hold on life for love of me, she had scrubbed and scoured, not caring, not thinking for a moment what was happening to her hands. They looked so sore, they must have hurt her, but there was no word of complaint—just song! At that moment, it was as though a spring shower had suddenly descended upon my spirit and was cleansing it of all the accumulation of doubt and despair and weakness that had piled up during months of illness. And in the swift upsurge of spirit, I prayed to be worthy of the ministry of hands! Words Ida Isaacson Tablets of stone may waste away— Leaving an image of decay. A word leaves an imprint on the mind That may inflame or bless mankind. An innocent child hears an evil word, And forever after his memory is stirred. Words are the stepping stones of thought, And over a word battles are fought. The mind selects the intent it will use; The tongue reveals the mind's hidden views. So mighty are words they never die; And time makes no difference to a lie. So Dear to My Heart Ruth Young revisited you, old chapel, out at West Jordan last night. Fortyone years you have served the people—you dear, rambling, old chapel. Some have called you ugly —with your steep narrow stairways and four stories of classrooms. To me you have ever been beautiful and comforting—my Balm of Gilead —with your stone entrance ways thrown wide like arms stretched forth to greet me. My ancestors helped to build you, hauling granite stones by wagon down from nearby Little Cottonwood Canyon for your huge foundation. By the way you were constructed, they must have believed you would endure forever. But now —just a stone's throw south of here—there stands a splendid, shiny, very, very modern new chapel, with stairs designed for easy walking, lower ceilings, and a good heating system. But you have a personality —you dear, old, friendly building. Once you had three huge stainedglass windows one to the east... One to the north... And one to the south. Their subject was an ebony bowl of sky-blue flowers against an amber and violet and green background. How easy it is to remember long years back when I was a skinny little girl sitting on a bench—feet not quite touching the floor. It had been a Fast Day—and my tummy was being gnawed by hunger pains; but the people kept getting up "bearing their testmonies." I had long ceased to listen, and was eagerly watching the floor beneath my bench. When the Page 676 sun shone upon a certain section of brightly colored green glass in the window it would appear on a certain section of the wood floor. Then it would be time for the bishop to stand up and end the meeting. I had learned this through many Fast Days. It was my own private sundial long before I could read a clock. Then—one Sunday morning just four years ago, we were shocked to discover that some boys had spent the night throwing boulders through your beautiful sky-blue flower windows, absolutely destroying the north and south ones, Next week you were repaired—but with plain, ugly glass instead; but, the glory that once was yours still looked eastward toward the morning sun. I was baptized in your little "boiler room" and confirmed on the front bench of your chapel, one lovely morning in May. I remember sitting there awaiting my turn, looking upward at the peaceful figure of Jesus in the big oil painting which Your malt assembly too™ was magnificent, ith its SO igh ceiling ay way UP Je sat on long wooden The visibility was perfect! I call it Rho Sigma. But why the blank looks? Had I said N. L. U. Or Idaho Club or Y. C.'s there would have been recognition in your eyes. You may think that it is a new unit. It is, here on the Brgham Young University campus. 'This is its third year, but I am surprised that you haven't heard of it, for it has been in existence since 1842 and is known all over the world! Yes, I mean world, for there are few countries and languages which do not know Rho Sigma. It is not a religious unit, or a service unit, or a departmental or social unit, but is a well-balanced combination of all four. In fact, we may say that the Thirteenth Article of Faith is our creed: "We believe in being honest, true, chaste, benevolent, virtuous, and in doing good to all men...." Indeed, true charity is the soul of our unit.... "If there is anything virtuous, lovely, or of good report or praiseworthy, we seek after these things." In this unit I have found those things which every true Latter-day Saint seeks: a strengthening of my testimony through reading and studying the Scriptures, and an appreciation and deepening of my testimony through hearing the testimonies and experiences of others. Have you ever heard of a unit which converts others to the Church? Mine has converted many. One of our members had her Page 678 [ von to the best unit in the testimony strengthened and renewed by attending our meetings. She enjoyed our unit and used the principles to such good advantage that her roommate who was not a member became curious and was impressed to ask more about the Church. After attending some of our meetings and being thrilled by what we were doing, she gradually became better acquainted with the Church and soon joined it. But this is more than a religious unit, we offer service, too. In fact, service is emphasized at all times. We are interested in the welfare of the individuals in our group and in helping them we strengthen the group as a whole, for we are not just a name but an active organization. 'Those who receive as well as those who give in this unit are benefited morally and spiritually. UT, in addition to these praiseworthy characteristics of religion and service, we offer a departmental program. We _ better ourselves through the great literature, sociological, and domestic knowledge of the world. Over a period of time we cover the world's best literature. In the field of sociology we have studied ntan's problems, psychology, politics, and our relations with others. We prepare ourselves to be better wives and mothers through the best ways to manage a household and understanding what constitutes a real home. We were given an example one day in meeting THE LORD'S UNIT of how an economical, practical, and versatile wife can be a profit to her husband. He would have to invest $40,000 in order to receive in dividends each year the money his wife could save him. That shows how important a capable wife is. ES, here we learn of those things virtuous, lovely, and of good report. But what of some recreation and social life? Doesn't all work and no play make Rho Sigma a dull unit? Oh, but we have a social side, too. Almost any day of any week we can join with members of the Phi Epsilon unit in making and preparing articles for those who are less fortunate than we. We have an organized singing group which sings at parties and programs. We have dinner dances, buffet suppers, bake sales, and exchanges with the PhiEpsilon unit. So, you see this unit combines all the good of the social, departmental, religious, and service units into one well-balanced whole which keeps the unit always interesting, yet always changing. This well-balanced combination of social activities, service, and knowledge is not just for my benefit here at school. I can belong to my unit and benefit from it the rest of my life. It will broaden my spiritual and mental capacity, and thus make me a fitting partner for my companion and help me become a worthy Latter-day Saint. It. Has been said, "When you educate a man, you educate an individual, but when you educate a woman you educate a family." Men need to 679 learn specialized work to enable them to support their families, but we women should learn all we can in the most important fields, if we want to take our part well and strengthen our husband's place in the community. We are the hub of the home, and our duties are to rear families, to teach our children correct principles to live by, and to give them broad backgrounds and strong foundations with which to meet the world. We are prepared for this very well by my unit, for it gives us many opportunities to become well-rounded individuals. Through my affiliation with this unit, I will find members wherever I go during my life, for we can belong all our lives wherever we are, and can receive instructions from headquarters and induce others to join. One of our members, after graduation, was married to a man whose work took them to a foreign country. They didn't know anyone and had no connection with the community except through the husband's work. 'The wife was very lonesome and bored, and you can imagine her joy and surprise, when members of the unit called on her and invited her to join them in the same effective, uplifting program she had known during her college days. Surely, such a comprehensive unit with all these benefits, should be very selective and limit its members. It doesn't. Every girl on campus can belong. 'There needs be no selection, for this unit appeals to only the best girls. There is no initiation; the lack of money is no barrier; in fact this unit is the least expensive of any unit or sorority in 680 the world. A half dollar will pay for all the activities in one year. There are no "secret sisters"; all will be "helpful sisters," who will help me be my best and not hinder me because they want the higher positions. 'There will be no falling away because of the demands of families or because we grow old and do not resemble so much the former coeds; no disappointments at college reunions that others have grown so old and uninteresting or seem to be pursuing their lost youth. For those who grow old in this unit gain wisdom and knowledge and hidden stores of spiritual beauty which grow more lovely and desired with the years. The unit does not weaken at graduation with a few alumni meetings which become fewer and fewer with the affiliation becoming RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 smaller. Instead, it grows stronger and stronger with the years, and the membership grows with it. It grows into a true sisterhood, with love and charity for all, and those who temain true to this unit remain true to the ideals of Christ. You can see I really have something! A unit which is a combination of social growth, education, religion, and service. It is so beneficial that its effects will be with me forever, and every woman in the Church can belong to it everywhere. Where else would you get a combination just like this, to interest a girl in her teens and a wife and mother in her later years? To promote the common good and personal welfare of all? Where else but in Rho Sigma, or by its better known name: RELIEF SOCIETY. —e Po Prelude to Winter Miranda Snow Walton The purple grapes hang heavy on the vine, A pumpkin patch lies bursting with its load: The pasture fence is blue with columbine, And goldenrod grows tall beside the road. The whir of combine and of reaper calls Across the ripened fields, and sheaves of wheat Stand waiting, while the hazy sunlight falls Upon a land whose harvest is complete. But when the ground lies barren in the snow, And ghosts of roses only dream rebirth, When frost has seared the fields, and wet winds blow, What recompense can winter bring to earth? The answer comes with each succeeding day: The joy of work well done, the quiet peace Of softly falling snow, the hearth fire's ray, And faith which gives a saddened soul release. Yes, he who sows good seed, need have no feat When harvesting is done and winter near. Heart's Bounty CHAPTER 5 Deone R. Sutherland Synopsis: Annie Griffith, whose father, with his family, has been called on a mission to the mountains to cut stone for the temple, is living with the Williams family in Salt Lake City, where she is being educated, with Marie Williams, under the direction of a private tutor. Light-hearted Marie is an _ indifferent scholar, but Annie makes a fine record in all her studies. Both girls are interested in Parker Josephson, a neighbor, who returns from three years of study in the east to find the girls grown up. Marie has assumed that Parker is in love with her, and that eventually they will marry. However, it is Annie whom he seeks out. Arrangements are made for Parker to teach at the university, but he receives a call to fulfill a mission in the Hawaiian Islands, and leaves for three years. Annie is offered a teaching position at Walton Academy in Salt Lake City, but, since her parents have moved back from the mountains to their farm north of Salt Lake, Annie returns home and becomes a teacher in the Davisville school. At Christmastime Annie attends Marie's martriage to Billy Johnson. HE following winter Aaron Davis, old Mrs. Davis' grandson, returned home from a mission to England. His grandmother had once been employed by the Queen of England. After she and her husband had joined the Church and decided to travel to America and then West to Zion, the Queen reluctantly had let her go. But she gave Mrs. Davis a pension for life, and even now old Mrs. Davis received her publications and mail from England. So she was more than thrilled when one of her favorite grandsons fulfilled a mission in her native country. Needless to say, she was proud and happy to see him return home. His father operated a small mill and farm in the settlement just below the old Davis house. Annie grew more used to her role as school mistress for her little school. The children were alert and responded eagerly to Annie's guidance. The second year was offering more rich rewards than Annie had hoped. She really felt that these children would someday bring credit to their heritage. Aaron Davis stopped in at the school to bring his thirteen-year-old sister home with him on his horse. Sister Davis had introduced him to Annie. At first Annie had felt great timidity toward the crusty, stiff little lady from England, but, gradually, she had found the generous heart beneath, "T want to present my grandson, Aaron." The old lady had smiled. "Annie has heard us talk of nothing but you for months, Aaron." "T've heard very nice things about Sister Griffith," Aaron had replied in turn. After that there were frequent accidental meetings between Aaron Davis and Annie Griffith. She greeted him at church, and he met her family. He asked once if he might accompany her to church, but she assured him that it would be out of his way, and, since her parents always attended, there was no necessity for him to make the long trip. Aaron Davis danced with Annie as many times as she allowed at the ward parties, but there was no quesPage 68] 682 tion but that she would just as soon dance with her brothers. One afternoon Annie sent her brothers home immediately after school to help their father with the chores. She remained as she felt the room should be straightened and some work made ready for classes on the next day. After some time she looked up with a start and realized that it was almost dark. By now, no doubt, her father was carrying in the milk pails and helping her mother spread the cheesecloth and strain the milk. She thought of the steam curling up from the pans on the back porch. They would certainly be finished with dinner before she got home. She put on her coat and mittens and wound her heavy woolen scarf about her head and throat. The snow had been coming down intermittently all day. She had better get started at once. UDDENLY, Aaron Davis was standing in the schoolroom door. "I've been waiting to ride home with you, Annie. The snow might be a little deep for your Baldy to cope with." "There's no need,' Annie protested, feeling the color in her cheeks. "I've ridden home in deeper snow than this." "Grandmother said you should stay the night, but doubted if you would. So it will really make her feel better, if I don't let you go off alone. It's a little later than you usually leave, and she's afraid it will be quite dark before you get home." Aaron Davis wound his muffler tighter and pulled on his gloves. There was nothing for Annie to do RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 but follow him out to the barn for their horses. The snow was deep, and, except for shouted comments on the best path to follow and how deep the snow in the gulch looked, there was little conversation. When Annie reached her own home, both she and her horse were quite exhausted. "Will you come in and warm up a little before you start back?" Annie asked. "With pleasure. Care of the horses." Aaron put them in the barn while Annie removed her boots on the back porch and went in to warm herself. In a few minutes Aaron Davis followed. The boys enjoyed Aaron's jokes, and her mother and father appreciated company any time. When he was asked to eat supper with Annie, he never hesitated. The boys were shooed off to: bed, and Brother and Sister Griffith sat in their rockers by the fire and enjoyed the stories Aaron had to tell about England and the many converts he had met. When he rose reluctantly to start back, Annie's parents spoke warmly of how much they had enjoyed his company. "T should like to come again," Aaron said to Annie at the door. "T'm sure my parents would be very happy to have you visit any time."" Annie could not look at him. "What of you, Annie?" Aaron Davis waited a moment for her reply. In a very low voice Annie said, "IT am not sure that it would be honest of me to urge you to visit " me, y Here, Ill take HEART'S BOUNTY "You are engaged to someone else?" Aaron asked in surprise. "No, but I met someone else once, and I haven't forgotten him. I have little reason to hope that he remembers me, but it wouldn't be fair to you to let you think...." "T'm willing to take my chances," Aaron said firmly. "T can't do anything else except wait for him," Annie said miserably. "T'm sorry, Aaron." "Tm going to say goodnight," Aaron said. "But I can't pretend that I don't hope that things will turn out differently from the way you indicate they may now. I have had a wonderful, if dashing, evening anyway." He managed to smile and shake her hand briefly in parting. ANNIE worked very hard with her teaching the rest of the year. One of her most promising older students was beginning a preparatory course for higher education. He hoped someday to become a doctor in order to serve his community, and Annie worked very hard with him, giving him personal help far beyond her strength or time allowed. She wanted him to be able to go out as well prepared or better prepared, perhaps, than other students with whom he might compete. — "You are wearing yourself out," Mrs. Davis said indignantly to Annie when she was later and _ later getting away from the school. Annie's face had paled, and her thinness showed in her face and hands. "Summer will be good for you. All work and no play is not what our Church recommends for anyone, young lady. You are not 683 being fair to yourself. And you are not fair to the young men who would enjoy dancing with you and calling at your home. You know I have the finest grandson...." Annie spoke in a very low voice, "That's what my parents tell me all the time, Sister Davis." The old woman cleared her throat. "Well, don't let me add to any of the problems you're already wrestling with. 'The spring sunshine, perhaps, will change your heart." Annie rode her horse slowly home. Her solitary figure going through the fields of snow had now become an accustomed sight for the farming people. 'Tonight she rode slowly because she felt she must think. The snow was at last beginning to thaw. It was a late spring. Her parents had begun to urge, more strongly than ever, that she be not so blind to the good qualities of Aaron Davis. And, if to him, then not to be blind to the virtues of other young men who were equally worthy. Marie had written of the many undreamed joys she had discovered with the birth of her first baby. And now she was expecting her second. Annie knew she could not deny herself the richness of life that was to be found only in a family of her own, but what of Parker? It was already a month past the expected date of his arrival home, and there had been no word of him, no sign. Annie felt somehow that if he really had come home to Zion, her heart would know it. He had been delayed. Perhaps they needed him in Hawaii for a longer time than was expected. It was a long time to 684 remember a person anyway. She should have forgotten him as he must have forgotten her. How untroubled he had been over Marie's marriage; how did she know but that he would be equally untroubled over her own? Her heart protested at the thought. NNIE corrected papers at the kitchen table while her mother fried mush for their supper. None of them claimed it as a favorite dish, but, when too much was made in the morning, they had to eat it at night. No food was ever wasted. Annie leaned her chin on her palm and closed her eyes. She was almost too weary to see the columns of figures before her. 'The children were so discouraging sometimes, and then, at other times, so rewarding they made her want to shout for joy. This was one of the discouraging times. Perhaps her own hidden agitation reflected somehow in the work her students had done that day. "The ward is having a May Day picnic and a dance in the evening." Her mother leaned over the stove. "TJ think we should all go and enjoy ourselves." "Of course," Annie said. The waiting must come to an end sometime. On Saturday Annie drove her father's team and wagon into the settlement to pick up a part of his plow he was having repaired. He could not spare the time, and Annie had an errand to do for her mother, anyway. The spring thaw had really set in now, spring had rushed upon them pell-mell in its eagerness to make up for lost time. The mud in the roads was more than RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 ankle deep in places. She walked carefully along the board sidewalk holding her dress up from the brown spattered path. The blacksmith loaded her father's plow repair on the back of the wagon, and then helped her up. Just as she swung into her seat, Sister Showers from the General Store hurried out, tying her bonnet as she came. "Annie, Annie, wait a moment." She stopped at the edge of the sidewalk. "Brother Showers says there was a man here not more than an hour ago asking for you. He asked where you lived, he did." Sister Showers' eyes were bright with curiosity. Annie's heart had given a sudden leap, but then she forced back the surge of joy she had felt for a moment. "Thank you very much. It was probably someone about Talbert Wilson's scholarship next year. Yes, that must be it." Sister Showers nodded her head slowly. "Probably that was what he wanted. Said he'd come from Great Salt Lake City. He was a mighty fine looking fellow, Father said. He's probably on his way out to your farm now. So long, see you May Day, Annie." Annie backed the wagon slowly and started the trip back. The plow part rattled lonely in the back of the wagon. She refused to let herself consider that it might be Parker Josephson. And yet she could not bear to think that it might not be he. NNIE heard Parker's voice the moment she entered the house. She leaned against the back door listening to the murmur of voices coming from the little parlor. Her HEART'S BOUNTY heart hammered so that she could not trust herself to move forward. Her hand brushed at her windblown hair. She was standing like that when Parker came to the door and saw her. Her mother was calling out. "Annie, is that you? Here's a friend of yours who has come quite a distance to see you." Parker stood in the doorway, looking across the kitchen, across three years into her eyes. Annie leaned against the door, with the color high in her cheeks and her dark hair curling against her forehead. She was filled with incredible shyness. 'Then Parker came to her and took her hands in greeting. Why, Parker's hands were as cold as her own! She looked up to meet the laughter dancing in his eyes. 'The day was full of joy. Parker was home, really home. 'T've been telling your mother about myself. It seems you haven't told her nearly enough about me. Or perhaps I took too much for granted?" "No, you did not," Annie replied softly. She tried to move away, 685 but Parker still held her hands. He was peering so intently at her face that she could not look away. "Well. " Annie's mother stirred in her chair. "I'll just go start our dinner. I hope you'll stay and join in our dinner with us?" "I would like to very much," Parker said, as he followed Annie into the parlor. "I've been looking forward to this meal for over three years, so you can see how much I'll appreciate it." "Well, you just make yourself at home." Annie's mother was already thinking about what vegetables she would need out of the dirt cellar. "T have a feeling I'm home at last," Parker smiled at Annie. "Come on, we'll help your mother cook a homecoming dinner." Annie's mother watched them making their way to the dirt cellar, jumping the puddles hand in hand. Such young laughter, thought Annie's mother. She nodded her head contentedly. So full of happiness that sound was that it made her smile to hear it. She now understood why Annie had had no interest in other young men.
