Their faces aglow with sunshine, These common yellow flowers Expect no tender care, they flourish Through drouth or freshening showers. In summer, nectar for honey bees; Come autumn, their precious seeds Provide a feast for chickadees; In winter, squirrels feed. Sunflowers, commonplace, you say, Blooming in wild profusion; The Creator with common things This miracle world did fashion. LESSE N DEPARTMENT Sheology—Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon Lesson 44—The Fall of the Nephite Nation As Recorded by Mormon Elder Leland H. Monson (Text: The Book of Mormon: Book of Mormon, chapters 1-7; Moroni, chapters 7-9) For Tuesday, January 8, 1957 Objective: To show how continued wickedness destroys a nation when it does not repent. HE Book of Mormon which follows Fourth Nephi was written by Mormon, the son of Mormon, who was a descendant of Nephi. This same Mormon abridged the large plates of Nephi on gold plates which he himself made and thence the entire abridgment of the history of the Nephites which was translated by the Prophet Joseph Smith goes by the name 'The Book of Mormon. In Mormon's writings on the history of the Nephites which he personally witnessed (from about 322 A. D. To 400 A. D.) Mormon recounts the fall and virtual extinction of the Nephite nation. Records Entrusted to Mormon Mormon was born into an environment that could have made him an unbeliever, a skeptic, a man of the world. During his lifetime the Nephites and the Lamanites Page 692 were living in sin and abomination. Mormon says, *. A continual scene of wickedness and abominations has been before mine eyes ever since I have been sufficient to behold the ways of man" (Mormon 2:18). It was a period of superstition, idolatry, and_ self-indulgence. Witchcraft, sorcery, and magic abounded among the people. It was in this world of magic, human sacrifices, and unrestrained indulgence that Mormon lived, not an environment to encourage the elevation of the human spirit or the expansion of the human mind. Mormon was born about 311 A. D. He was named after the land of Mormon where Alma baptized and established the Church. (See 3 Nephi 5:12.) In 321 a. V. Ammaron, keeper of the sacred records, came to Mormon, who was then ten years of age, and said: LESSON DEPARTMENT I perceive that thou art a sober child, and art quick to observe; Therefore, when ye are about twenty and four years old I would that ye should remember the things that ye have observed concerning this people; and when ye are of that age go to the Jand Antum, unto a hill which shall be called Shim; and there have I deposited unto the Lord all the sacred engravings concerning — this people. And behold, ye shall take the plates of Nephi unto yourself, and the remainder shall ye leave in the place where they are; and ye shall engrave on the plates of Nephi all the things that ye have observed concerning this people (Mormon 1:2-4). The following year when Mormon was eleven, his father took him southward to the land of Zarahemla (Mormon 1:6). It was a densely populated area, with a people who are described as being "... As numerous almost, as it were the sand of the sea" (Mormon 1:7). Mormon Forbidden to Preach Because of the Nephites' Wickedness In that year, a war broke out in the borders of Zarahemla by the waters of Sidon between the Nephites and the Lamanites. The Nephites, with an army of over thirty thousand, overcame the Lamanites and restored peace for a period of four years. Concerning the state of wickedness that existed at that time among the Nephites, Mormon wrote that:.. Wickedness did prevail upon the face of the whole land, insomuch that the Lord did take away his beloved disciples, and the work of miracles and of healing did cease because of the iniquity of the people. And there were no gifts from the Lord, and the Holy Ghost did not come upon 693 any, because of their wickedness and unbelief (Mormon 1:13-14). At fifteen years of age amidst these conditions, Mormon "... Was visited of the Lord, and tasted and knew of the goodness of Jesus" (Mormon 1:15). Mormon tried to preach to the people, but he was forbidden because they had willfully rebelled against God. The Nephites suffered because of the hardness of their hearts and the Lord ¥ cursed the land for their sake." Their treasures ''... Became slippery..." as the Gadianton band was renewed. And it came to pass that there were sorceries, and witchcrafts, and magics; and the power of the evil one was wrought upon all the face of the land, even unto the fulfilling of all the words of Abinadi, and also Samuel the Lamanite (Mormon 1:19). Mormon, large in stature in his sixteenth year, was called to lead the armies of the Nephites. The Nephites retreated before the armies of the Lamanites and lost a fortified city and other lands. Finally, they gathered in the land of Joshua on "... The borders west by the seashore," (Mormon 2:6) in one body. They still refused to repent, even in the midst of "... A revolution throughout all the face of the land" (Mormon 2:8). In 330 a. The Nephites, with an army of 42,000, defeated King Aaron of the Lamanites with an army of 44,000. Then followed a period of repentance from which Mormon took joy: But behold this my joy was vain, for their sorrowings was not unto repentance, because of the goodness of God; but it was rather the sorrowing of the damned, because the Lord would not always suffer them to take happiness in sin. 694 And they did not come unto Jesus with broken hearts and contrite spirits, but they did curse God, and wish to die. Nevertheless they would struggle with the sword for their lives.... My sorrow did return unto me again, and I saw that the day of grace was passed with them, both temporally and spititually; for I saw thousands of them hewn down in open rebellion against their God, and heaped up as dung upon the face of the land. And thus three hundred and forty and four years had passed away (Mormon 2:13-15). Mormon Leads the Nephites By 345 a. P. The Nephites were again fleeing from the Lamanites, this time to the Land of Jashon, near the place where Ammaron had hid the records in the Hill Shim. By this time Mormon had taken the plates of Nephi and had engraved thereon a full account of all the wickedness and abominations, but upon "these plates" [the abridgment] he engraved only a_ part (Mormon 2:18). In the future, Mormon tried to encourage the Nephites to fight. With thirty thousand they defeated a Lamanite army of fifty thousand. By 349 A. V. The Nephites again had possession of the lands of their inheritance. A treaty of peace in 350 A. D., however, divided the inheritance and gave to the Nephites ".,. The land northward, yea, even to the narrow passage which led into the land southward..." (Mormon 2:29). Mormon records: And it came to pass that the Lord did say unto me: Cry unto this people — Repent ye, and come unto me, and be ye baptized, and build up again my church, and ye shall be spared. And I did cry unto this people, but it was in vain; and they did not realize that RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 it was the Lord that had spared them, and gianted unto them a chance for repentance. And behold they did harden their hearts against the Lord their God (Mormon 3:2-3). In 360 aw. The king of the Lamanites sent an epistle to the Nephites telling them that they were preparing to attack the Nephites. Three times Mormon "... Delivered them out of the hands of their enemies..." (Mormon 3:13), but they still refused to repent. In fact, they swore:... By the heavens, and also by the throne of God, that they would go up to battle against their enemies, and would cut them off from the face of the land. And it came to pass that I, Mormon, did utterly refuse from this time forth to be a commander and a leader of this people, because of their wickedness and abomination (Mormon 3:10-11). Nephites to Be Destroyed At this time the voice of the Lord came to Mormon, saying: Vengeance is mine, and I will repay; and because this people repented not after I had delivered them, behold, they shall be cut off from the face of the earth (Mormon 3:15). Mormon writes:... I utterly refused to go up against mine enemies; and I did even as the Lord had commanded me; and I did stand as an idle witness to manifest unto the world the things which I saw and heard (Mormon 3:16). Mormon Addresses Future Generations Therefore, Mormon then says:... I write unto you, Gentiles. Unto you, twelve tribes of Israel, who shall be judged according to your works by the twelve whom Jesus chose to be his disciples in the land of Jerusalem... LESSON DEPARTMENT unto the remnant of this people... That ye may know that ye must all stand before the judgment-seat of Christ, yea, every soul who belongs to the whole human family of Adam... To be judged of your works, whether they be good or evil. And also that ye may believe the gospel of Jesus Christ, which ye shall have among you; and also that the Jews, the covenant people of the Lord, shall have other witness besides him whom they saw and heard, that Jesus, whom they slew, was the very Christ and the very God (Mormon 3:17-21). Nephites Wage War of Revenge In 363 a. V. The Nephites went to battle against the Lamanites, otherwise "... The Lamanites could have had no power over them. But behold, the judgments of God will overtake the wicked; and it is by the wicked that the wicked are punished..." (Mormon 4:4-5). Now Mormon wrote: And it is impossible for the tongue to describe, or for man to write a_ perfect description of the horrible scene of the blood and carnage which was among the people, both of the Nephites and of the Lamanites; and every heart was hardened, so that they delighted in the shedding of blood continually. And there never had been so great wickedness among all the children of Lehi, nor even among all the house of Israel, according to the words of the Lord, as was among this people (Mormon 4:11-12). A Mormon. Seeing that the Lamanites were about to overthrow the land..." (Mormon 4:23) went to the Hill Shim and_ removed ",.. All the records which Ammaron had hid up unto the Lord" (Mormon 4:23). Mormon repented of the oath he had made that he would not help the Nephites any more and again he led their armies. Mormon, 695 however, was without hope, for they would not even call upon God. Record to Testify of Christ Mormon wrote he could not describe the bloodshed and carnage, but he said that:.. These things are written unto the remnant of the house of Jacob.... And behold, they shall come forth according to the commandment of the Lord unto the unbelieving of the Jews; and for this intent shall they go—that they may be persuaded that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of the living God; that the Father may bring about, through his most Beloved, his great and eternal purpose, in restoring the Jews, or all the house of Israel, to the land of their inheritance, which the Lord their God hath given them, unto the fulfilling of his covenant; And also that the seed of this people may more fully believe his gospel, which shall go forth unto them from the Gentiles; for this people shall be scattered, and shall become a dark, a filthy, and a loathsome pcople, beyond the description of that which ever hath been amongst us, yea, even that which hath been among the Lamanites, and this because of their unbelief and idolatry (Mormon 5:12-15). Nephites Fight Last Battle Around Hill Cumorah In 380 aw. The Lamanites came in such great numbers that they defeated the Nephites. When 384 years had passed away since Christ's birth, Mormon, by means of an exchange of letters with the king of the Lamanites, had gathered in all his people around about the Hill Cumorah. 'The Nephites, 230,000 strong, were soon engaged in deadly conflict with the Lamanites. Mormon writes:. When we had gathered in all our people in one to the land of Cumorah, 696 behold I, Mormon, began to: be old; and knowing it to be the last struggle of my people, and having been commanded of the Lord that I should not suffer the records which had been handed down by our fathers, which were sacred, to fall into the hands of the Lamanites, (for the Lamanites would destroy them) therefore I made this record out of the plates of Nephi, and hid up in the hill Cumorah all the records which had been entrusted to me by the hand of the Lord, save it were these few plates which I gave unto my son Moroni (Mormon 6:6). A dreadful battle was waged and, at the conclusion of the battle, all the Nephites had fallen except twenty-four who were with Mormon (including his son Moroni), and a few who had escaped into the south countries and a few who had joined the Lamanites. Mormon uttered an anguished lament as he saw the fallen of his people. (Read Mormon 6:16-22.) Mormon Admonishes Lamanites of Latter Days The seventh chapter of Mormon is addressed to the Lamanites of this day, calling upon them to repent and be baptized and "... Lay hold upon the gospel of Christ, which shall be set before you..." (Mormon 7:8). Chapter eight of the Book of Mormon begins the writings of Moroni, the son of Mormon, who tells us that his father Mormon was killed by the Lamanites. Moroni tells us "Behold, my father hath made this record, and he hath written the intent thereof..." (Mormon 8:5). Mormon's Teachings on Faith, Hope, and Charity In the Book of Moroni, we find that Moroni presents some teachRELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 ings of his father, Mormon, on faith, hope, and charity in Moroni, chapter seven. These teachings and writings reveal the great revelations which came to Mormon on the subjects of faith, hope, and charity, culminating in the statement not found in Paul's epistle to the Corinthians: But charity is the pure love of Christ, and it endureth forever; and whoso is found possessed of it at the last day, it shall be well with him (Moroni 7:47). Two Letters of Mormon to His Son Moroni In addition to writing his abridgment of Nephite history and attaching the small plates of Nephi to his record, Mormon wrote seven chapters of the Book of Mormon and the "Words of Mormon." The Book of Moroni also contains two letters which Mormon wrote to Moroni found in Moroni chapters eight and nine. In chapter eight Mormon states that little children have no need of repentance or baptism; and in chapter nine Mormon, after relating atrocities committed by the Lamanites, gives to Moroni "A Father's last and affectionate admonition." Mormon's Abridgment of the Plates of Nephi Mormon abridged the large plates of Nephi. Making the abridgment was a tedious process. Using the large plates of Nephi as source material, Mormon compiled the _history of the Nephites and Lamanites from the time they left Jerusalem in 600 B. C. Until 385 A. D., a period of almost a thousand years. Mormon did not claim perfection for his work. (See 3 Nephi 5:8-26; LESSON DEPARTMENT Mormon 9:32, 33.) Moroni, Mormon's son, relates that his father used reformed Egyptian because Hebrew required too much space. He further states that if Mormon could have used Hebrew there would have been no imperfection in the record. To Mormon, the saints today owe an eternal debt of gratitude for his work in their behalf in the latter days. 697 Questions on the Lesson 1. Discuss the fulfillment of the prophecies of Samuel and Abinadi. 2. What kind of sorrowing did the Nephites express for sin? 3. What work did Mormon do with records? 4. When does God withdraw his spirit from us? What is the result? 5. Discuss Mormon as a_ scholar? A leader of men? A religious leader? Visiting Seacher Nlessages— Book of Mormon Gems of Truth Lesson 44—"And Wo Be Unto Him That Will Not Hearken Unto the Words of Jesus, and Also to Them Whom He Hath Chosen and Sent Among Them; For Whoso Receiveth Not the Words of Jesus and the Words of Those Whom He Hath Sent Receiveth Not Him; and Therefore He Will Not Receive Them at the Last Day" (3 Nephi 28:34). Leone O. Jacobs For Tuesday, January 8, 1957 Objective: To point out that hearkening to the words of Jesus and to the words of those whom he has chosen to lead the Church are required of Latter-day Saints. N the above quotation Mormon gives us two closely related principles fundamental to our Church. The first one is that if we accept Jesus as the Christ, we must also accept his words and his doctrine. Jesus and his words are inseparable. He is what he has taught. Secondly, it is required that we wholeheartedly accept those who are ordained to act as his representatives and that we accept their words. This acceptance is an indication that we accept the Lord and his words. In the General Church Conference of April 1955, Elder George Q. Morris stated:. It is our most serious duty in life to know him [the Lord] and love him... The Lord Jesus Christ is not on trial before the world.... The world is on trial before the Lord Jesus Christ, and we will have to account for the attitude taken toward him and his message, and we cannot accept him without accepting his principles and his doctrines. Another thing that the world must understand if they will know the truth... Is that those who receive or reject the teachings and testimonies and admonitions of the servants of God receive or reject the Lord Jesus Christ. He said to the seventy when he sent them out to preach the gospel: "He that heareth you heareth me; and he that despiseth you despiseth me..." (Luke 10:16. 125th Annual Conference With Report of Discourses, pp. 101-102). 698 Sometimes the payment of tithes is mentioned as being an indicator of faith and adherence to the commandments of the Lord. Likewise the sustaining of the Authorities of the Church is an indication of faith in the divinity of Christ. It has been stated that the first step to apostasy is criticism of the Authorities. In Discourses of Brigham Young we read: When a man begins to find fault, inquiring in regard to this, that, and the other, saying, "Does this or that look as though the Lord dictated it?'' you may RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 know that that person has more or less of the spirit of apostasy.... If the people would live their religion, there would be no apostasy and we would hear no complaining or fault-finding (Discourses of Brigham Young, pp. 83-84). Let us rejoice that in the Church we have great and good men to lead us — men chosen of God who have his authority to further his purposes. In the Doctrine and Covenants we read:. My word shall not pass away, but shall all be fulfilled, whether by mine own voice or by the voice of my servants, it ls the same (D. & C. 1:38). Work Tleeting— Food Preparation and Service (A Course Recommended for Use by Wards and Branches at Work Meeting) Lesson 4—Breads Rhea H. Gardner For Tuesday, January 8, 1957 HE smell of freshly baked bread in the home once was a common occurrence. 'Today, comparatively few homemakers take the time to make bread, in spite of the fact that homemade bread is still one of the surest routes to a man's heart, and very nutritious. Anyone who is willing to practice and follow a few simple directions can make good bread. Equipment and Supplies Needed The right kind of equipment will help to assure good results. You will want equipment for making accurate measurements. An earthenware bowl or plastic crock helps to keep the temperature of the dough more nearly constant than do metal containers. Fill the container with warm water when you start to make the dough, so it will be warmed through when needed. A canvascovered kneading board makes it easier to work dough without sticking. Keep the dough as soft as possible for each handling. A soft dough makes better bread and rolls than does a stiff one. Rub flour into the canvas or on the board before you start kneading. Ingredients Good bread may be made from hard or from soft wheat flours. Allpurpose or family flours are made from a blend of wheat. Breads made with milk have more food value than do those made with water, and they stay fresh longer. LESSON DEPARTMENT Moreover milk gives the bread a more velvety texture. Fresh liquid milk, evaporated milk, or powdered milk, all make good bread. Fresh milk should be scalded, but evaporated and dried milk do not need to be. Yeast grows best in an even temperature of 80° F. Try to have all the liquids which are used near this temperature and keep dough as near this temperature as possible at all times. Shortening makes the gluten mesh-work of the dough more elastic, so the gas can expand freely and easily. Salt helps control fermentation and improves the flavor. Sugar is the food from which the yeast plant makes the leavening gas and also aids in the development of a good brown crust. One tablespoon for each cup of liquid is sufficient for plain bread. Kneading Proper kneading makes the cell walls thin and tender, as well as more elastic. If you will let the dough rest ten or fifteen minutes after you mix the ingredients together, and before you start kneading, the dough will be less sticky and easier to handle. Learn to knead the dough quickly and easily. If the dough seems tense and hard to handle during the kneading, instead of elastic and pliable, pick it up and throw it hard onto the kneading board a few times. 'This will relax the dough and shorten the kneading time. Continue the kneading rhythm ten or fifteen minutes or until the dough is smooth and satiny and has many little blisters just under the surface, and it feels springy and elastic and does not 699 stick to the canvas nor to your hands. Oil the inside of the bowl or crock with a thin film of melted fat. When the kneading is finished, put the dough into the oiled bowl or crock. Turn the dough over, so there will be a film of fat on the top. Cover tightly and keep away from drafts. 'The dough is ripe and ready to be punched down when doubled in bulk. Punch the dough, all around, a few times with the hand, then turn it over with the smooth side up. Let double in bulk again. Molding Do not put fat on your hands before molding the loaves, or you may have streaks of fat where the dough will not seal together. 'This will leave cracks inside the finished loaf. Place the molded loaves into oiled tins. Cover with a thin damp cloth and let rise until ripe for baking or double in bulk. Keep the cloth moistened while the loaf is rising, so the dough will not dry out. Bake in preheated oven. Baking Time The baking time varies with the altitude. The higher the altitude, the longer will be the baking time. Sweet breads and fancy rolls require a lower baking temperature (375°) than that recommended for plain bread (400°). When bread has baked long enough, it will shrink slightly from the sides of the pan and sounds hollow when you thump it. Remove it from the tins onto cake racks and, when thoroughly cool, store in a cool place. In the mean- 700 time, however, if at least part of a loaf disappears, ask no questions. Hot bread, in company with fresh RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 butter, honey, cold milk, and anyone with an appetite for the best in food, just doesn't keep long. Note to class leader: If possible, arrange for the following: 1. Have the ingredients ready for making a dough to use to demonstrate before the class; 2. Have one batch of bread already mixed ready for kneading; and 3. A loaf of baked bread to show the results of the correct methods of baking. Note "Recipes for Bread and Rolls," by Rhea H. Gardner, page 668, in this issue of the Magazine. Ob iterature—Shakespeare in Our Lives Lesson 4—The Moral Shakespeare Elder Briant S. Jacobs (Text: Shakespeare Major Plays and the Sonnets, by G. B. Harrison, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1948) For Tuesday, January 15, 1957 Objective: To show that in his plays the artist Shakespeare reveals himself as a typical Elizabethan who, among many other values, knew and loved the Bible and its moral teachings; therefore he defined Truth truly. 667 ET'S play house." Thus in unashamed delight our children escape into the never-never world of play. And "make-believe" for them is so charmingly simple, since it comes with complete spontaneity. Without doubt, the world of fantasy feeds their deepest, most real hungers, and the chant, "Mommy, tell me a story" echoes down the ages as proof that humankind, at least, in its unspoiled innocence, has no question about the superior values of living in the play-world which is only a miniature of grownup actuality. Why else do little girls cherish dolls and tiny stoves "that really light up," while little boys mirror their fathers almost to make fathers ashamed, demanding saws and hammers, model trains and planes, submarines and _torpedoes and, now, jets? The Function of Art Whenever we yield and tell our children a story, we fulfill the same relation to them as our artists do to us. It has ever been thus, and, to judge from the booming presentday sale of classical records, radios, TV's, magazines, and books, and attendance at movies and concerts, that need is a consistent one. As modern man's leisure increases, so does his need for entertainment, most of which is concerned with recreating reality in a more personal, condensed, memorable form than our rather monotonous, daily life. Yes, indeed, this is the timeless function of art: to recreate (or to interpret) the shapeless, massive reality which surrounds us, into a new form, which is colored by the artist's own personal perspective and values. Or in Shakespeare's own LESSON DEPARTMENT words, his purpose is "to hold the mirror up to nature, as 'twere." And, inevitably, this mirroring of nature includes his own nature too. A play is more than anything an art-form: it mirrors reality as the author sees it, neither as good nor bad, but as real. Shakespeare is our greatest writer, not because he is our greatest thinker or philosopher, but because he is the fullest, best artist; that is, he understands all humanity deeply, and can express his understanding in living images and language within his chosen medium of expression. But the characters whom he has created are not great because they are true to life: they are immortal because they fulfill their artistic function in the passage or play in which they appear. Most important, the play, as Shakespeare well knew, must be true to its own nature. A great play is "an expanded metaphor," to use Wilson Knight's excellent term. It has a soul, a purpose, a reality of its own which are not the same as those we know in life. In real life we rarely speak soul-to-soul with each other; compared to figures in a drama, real people are quite silent and retiring. And it is the very function of plays to erect this art-work which in fery phrases, sings out in the language of the soul which most of us conceal. Hamlet, for example, could never occur in real life, yet he is the greatest success on the stage, for there he exemplifies within himself almost all human emotions, bewilderingly yet really condensed. Like all of Shakespeare's greatest dramatic creations, he is the poetic, artistic shape given by his creator to 701 a universal conflict, emotion, or thought. Shakespeare's Sources Perhaps the most popular but distracting hobbyhorse in the study of Shakespeare is the attempt to "explain" him. Since he was relatively unschooled, not a nobleman, and had no power nor influence outside the theater, it becomes a great temptation to point out what influences dominated him, and to reveal the sources of his ideas, skills, and beliefs. In Lesson Two a scant introduction into this world was attempted, not in an effort to give Shakespeare sources, but to give ourselves sympathy and understanding. Only after such an introduction can we begin to see that Shakespeare, like every successful artist, cannot escape recording the spirit and texture of his day, but he does this secondarily; all his art and power begin in his own emotion and vision. As he succeeded magnificently in recording himself, then, did he record his age? Yes, evidences of Plato, Ovid, Plutarch, Holinshed, Dante, Copernicus, Machiavelli, Montaigne, Chaucer, and the Bible, have been found in his work; he incorporates all these, and he is none of them only. It is worth noting that, of all these books, only Holinshed's Chronicle and Chaucer are "English"; all sources of his knowledge were derived from other cultures, including the Bible. Although more than ten different translations of the Bible had been made into English since William Tindale's first translation in 1526, the Geneva 702 translation (1560) was the one Shakespeare undoubtedly knew best. We cannot know with certainty whether the Bible was taught in Stratford grammar schools, — or whether he came to know the Bible so well through attending church services and travelling cycle plays, which dramatized those episodes from the Old 'Testament which Shakespeare' used in his __ plays; namely, Dives and Lazarus, Adam and Eve, Cain and Abel, Solomon, Job, Daniel, Herod, Judas and Pilate, the fall of Lucifer, the serpent in the Garden, the Flood, Moses and the Red Sea, etc. Most commentators agree that, as did the average Elizabethan gentleman of his time, Shakespeare knew his Bible well (actually he quoted from or made allusion to forty-two books of the Bible and six of the Apocrypha); they also agree that his images drawn from Biblical history were few in comparison with his extensive use of other image-sources, but that his frequent allusion to Biblical phrases and figures of speech is often passed over by the reader who does not know his Bible as well as Shakespeare obviously did. For example, Shakespeare does not mention Joshua when in King John he alludes to the sun's standing still, or when, in The Tempest, Caliban recalls Jael's driving a nail into the head of Sisera. Richard III prays that the Lord may not hear women complaining with God's appointed leaders in the same tone as Shimei had cursed King David; Richard II contrasts Christ's reception of little children with his advice to the rich young man who asked what he must do to be saved. RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 When Bottom, in A Midsummer Night's Dream, says, "The eye of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not seen, man's hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report, what my dream was" (Act IV. 1:216), he' makes an absurd comparison to I Corinthians, 2:9. In 2 King Henry VI, Il. I.34, the king says "For blessed are the peacemakers on earth," obviously referring to the Sermon on the Mount. Richard IT paraphrases Luke 18:25: As hard to come as for a camel To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.... V.5 Job, Ecclesiasticus, Proverbs, and the Psalms—by the frequency of his quotations from them—seem_ to have been Shakespeare's favorite readings, surely for the pleasure he found in the word, as well as for the beauty of the truth which they contain. And while Shakespeare did not quote from the Bible in any such quantity as did his contemporary, Bacon, Shakespeare's genius is again revealed in the use he did make of quotations used, as exemplified above. Never does he misinterpret the Bible, as did Bacon, but, so accurately did he sense its intent and absorb its spirit, that his writings preserve its original flavor as well as the truth of its great teachings. Shakespeare was also greatly indebted to his predecessors and contemporaries in the history of the English theater—the morality and cycle plays, the interludes, Seneca, Lodge, Nashe, Green, Kyd, Marlowe, Beaumont and Fletcher, but, though he borrowed from some and LESSON DEPARTMENT imitated others, they are not Shakespeare, individually or collectively. His plays are loaded with references to contemporary events and personalities. His largest, most pressing concern was to please a penny-paying audience next and every 'Tuesday; this he succeeded in doing only by making his plays contain the throbbing heart of Elizabethan England. How else could he appeal through the years to a zestful people who loved laughter, boldness, courage, display, and sensation, who were prosperous, hot-headed, industrious, devout, patriotic individuals? The age gave Shakespeare his materials and themes. Yet it was his own high gifts as poet and _playwright which gave these "things" shapes and identities. As he himself tells us of the function of a poet, "And as imagination bodies forth the forms of things unknown, the poet's pen turns them to shapes, and gives to airy nothing A local habitation and a name" (A Midsummer Night's Dream, V. 1:14). The "Real" Shakespeare Genius speaks to genius. One of the most piercing critical comments on Shakespeare is that of John Keats: "Shakespeare led a life of allegory; his works are the comments on it." 'Thus the "real" Shakespeare is the sum total of his plays, his poems, and his sonnets. The "real" Shakespeare is the comprehensive, universal observer who saw into all men's hearts and transmuted his living, contemporary values both of personality and of belief, into immortal art. Surely contemporary accounts are 703 "real." Without exception each recorded description refers to him as "our Shakespeare" or "my Shakespeare." Aubrey, the son of one of his fellow-players spoke of him as "a handsome, well-shaped man, verie good company, and of a verie ready, and pleasant and smooth wit." Ben Johnson disagreed fiercely with Shakespeare's dramatic theories, yet Shakespeare was one of the few friends with whom Ben _ never quarreled, and he said of him, "I loved the man and do honor his memory, on this side idolatry, as much as any." It is important to know that Shakespeare's plays fall into three groups which reveal much of his personal outlook. The first large, experimental period, ending in 1601 when he was thirty-seven, contained Senacan spectacle plays, light comedies and romances, and_histories. 'The second, or dark period, extended from 1602 to 1608, when he wrote but two comedies and all his great tragedies, including Timon of Athens, so bitter in its denunciation of humanity that it is not considered a successful stage-play and is rarely presented. The final period, ending in 1612, includes Cymbeline and The Tempest, two of his happiest, warmest works; this, then, is a period of reaffirmation and expanding belief in the goodness of man, nature, and life. That he stopped writing when he was only forty-eight, right at his peak, when honor, success, and material return were sweetest, is worthy of note. But we must go one step further. If the "real" Shakespeare is to be found only in his plays, to 704 which real Shakespeare do we refer? 'The common error in eighteenth and nineteenth century criticism was to create Shakespeare in the image of the critic's own personality and prejudices, which makes much of this criticism worthless. Even in the present day, he is claimed by every group, but, for every claimant, evidence can be found in the plays which cancels out any such slanted approach. For, if the plays are acceptable evidence, Shakespeare knew Catholicism and Anglicanism and Puritanism; he could have been all or none. No one has been more in love with love, yet no writer has so heartily condemned the shortcomings of woman. Some find in him the stirrings of democracy, yet none feared the undisciplined mob more than he: it merited his entire contempt. His Henry V has been described as the pure epic of English patriotism, yet he uses Falstaff to poke the bitterest fun at all those who honor the military. If Shakespeare is the characters he creates, then in one creation he is honest, in another lying and _ treacherous. In one play he is mad, in the next a fool. But why go on? Any and all are his creations; and insofar as each makes his soul-language contribution to the artistic whole, that character should be considered part of the "real" Shakespeare. The Moral Shakespeare These moral laws Of nature and of nations speak aloud.... Troilus and Cressida, II. 2.184 The more one reads Shakespeare, the more one realizes that: RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 It is not enough to speak, but to speak true. A Midsummer Night's Dream, V. 1.120 In his estimates of what is true in nature and man, Shakespeare has offered that as good which most men who define humanity as optimistic and noble also call good. Often as artist he has been concerned only to present every shade and depth of life without pronouncing moral judgment, yet from his tone and from the imagery which fulfills his unconscious intent, we come to feel that we can know the inner spirit of the man. Not only could he see more of life's contradictions, pleasures, and pains than other men, but he had courage to present with balanced fairness all phases of life. Often in the most dismal of tragic scenes he uses humor as a means of interpreting life and adjusting to it, for instance, the grave digger dialogue in Hamlet. Often, like the Elizabethans for whom he wrote, he has his characters laugh at their own weaknesses. But, in contrast to most of his contemporaries, he is always, in the final analysis, wholesome. Always in Shakespeare: Love surfeits not, lust like a glutton dies. Venus and Adonis, 803 Never is illicit love presented as healthy, nor even as cause for jokes and amusement. Samuel 'Taylor Coleridge, certainly the most important Shakespearean critic of his time, understood who Shakespeare was, for he wrote: Shakespeare has no innocent adulteries, no interesting incests, no virtuous vice; he never renders that amiable which religion and reason alike teach us to detest.... LESSON DEPARTMENT If he occasionally disgusts a keen sense of delicacy, he never injures the mind; he neither excites nor flatters passion in order to degrade the subject of it; he does not use the faulty thing for a faulty purpose, nor carries on warfare against virtue by causing wickedness to appear as no wickedness through the medium of a morbid sympathy with the unfortunate. In Shakespeare vice never walks as in twilight; nothing is purposely out of its place; he inverts not the order of nature and propriety.... Shakespeare saw evil in the world and depicted it honestly as evil. He does not blame sinners; instead he pities them, holding their sins, and indeed, all evils as corrupting diseases on the body of the world, which must be stamped out if the world is to remain normal and good. How well he knew that: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill together (All's Well That Ends Well, IV. 3). Yet in his impersonal artist's approach, he could depict Shylock's cruelty and greed and cunning—all of which Shakespeare hated most— with such sympathy for the man they controlled, with such self-identification with Shylock's suffering that, despite Shylock's brutality, Shakespeare brings us to feel that he was wronged. Such compassionate identification with the vile and evil in man is one of Shakespeare's surest qualities of greatness. Centures before the cult of lipstick triumphed, Shakespeare had Lear's wise fool observe that: There was never yet fair woman But she made mouths in a glass. King Lear, III.2.35 Anyone who knows woman-na- 705 ture this well, cannot surprise us with insights into human nature's moral depths. Sometimes he states his point almost flatly, and often he clothes his abstract concepts of right and wrong in vibrant, cutting imagery: Plate sin with gold And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks. Arm it in rags, a pigmy's straw does pierce it. King Lear, IV.6.169 How well the perceptive Shakespeare knew the frailty of human justice, which is easily blinded by the sins of the wealthy, but prone to jump onto the tiny sins of the defenseless, uninfluential poor. Shakespeare thus remains our greatest writer, not only because of his superb word-skill, but because, knowing mankind so deeply, he defined the true moral truths of man and God as the truths he honored; likewise his definition is that of all moral men in the western tradition of man. Had it been otherwise, Shakespeare could never have become the supreme spokesman for the enduring heart of mankind. In truth, his judgments constantly reflect the great moral values of justice and compassion and humility which represent the English Bible at its best. Perhaps the greatest tribute to Shakespeare is that, increasingly, we feel his constant humility before the task of depicting all humanity. And because he succeeds so well in subduing his I-ness, his works are left free to speak for themselves. Never, as Christopher Marlowe observed, have we had such "infinite 706? Riches in a little room." And perhaps, in this discussion of the soul of Shakespeare, Coleridge, because of his insight and high seriousness, again deserves the last word: I speak reverently, does God choose idiots by whom to convey divine truths to man? RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 Thoughts for Discussion 1. Why may the artist's truth seem truer than "actual" day-to-day truth? 2. Prove that Shakespeare knew the Bible well. 3. Can the "real," enduring Shakespeare ever be pinned down in a definition? 4. How can a writer who is held to be moral still see evil in the world about him and present it unflinchingly in his art? Soca, Science—Latter-day Saint Family Life Lesson 3—The Key Is Turned Elder John Farr Larson For Tuesday, January 22, 1957 Objective: To show significant steps in the organization of the Relief Society and the opportunities for service found in its objectives. And I now turn the key in your behalf in the name of the Lord, and this Society shall rejoice, and knowledge and intelligence shall flow down from this time henceforth.. HE organization of the Relief Society, under the hand of the Prophet Joseph Smith, was in fulfillment of a revelation of the Lord. That its organization was inspired is evidenced by its accomplishments over a century of service. Within its stated objectives are found unlimited opportunities for personal improvement and _ service. The year 1842 was one of great progress for the Latter-day Saints. It is described, in part, by the Prophet Joseph Smith. On March 1, 1842, he wrote his now famous "Wentworth Letter' (Ibid., page 536). In response to a request of Mr. John Wentworth, editor of a Chicago newspaper, the Prophet sketched the history of the Church, and, in summarizing our beliefs, set. (Joseph Smith, April 28, 1842, D. H. C., IV, page 607). Forth our "Articles of Faith." After describing the terrible mob attacks of 1838 he wrote:. We arrived in the state of Illinois in 1839, where we found... A people who were willing to be governed by the principles of law and humanity. We have commenced to build a city called '"'Nauvoo"... We number from six to eight thousand here, besides vast numbers in the country around.... We have a city charter granted us, and charter for a Legion... For a University, for an Agricultural and Manufacturing Society, have our own laws and administrators, and possess all the privileges that other free and enlightened citizens enjoy (D. H. C., IV, page 540). Brief review should now be made of the last lesson in which is described the status of women in the early part of the 19th Century. It LESSON DEPARTMENT was in this setting of limited legal, social, and economic position, with persecution and violence resting, that on March 17, 1842, eighteen women were organized as the Female Relief Society of Nauvoo. Shortly before this time, some of the women had expressed a desire for an organization of their own, and some preliminary steps had been taken by them, even to drafting a constitution and by-laws for a proposed organization. None of them, however, had contemplated the breadth of the Relief Society as envisioned by Joseph Smith. Latter-day Saint Women Unusual Early latter-day Saint women were superior women. Nowhere could there be found another group of women who had endured so much persecution and sorrow, who, in spite of this, were so well tempered by the gospel. The calibre of the women is well described in the Prophet's Annals of March 24, 1842: Our women have always been signalized for their acts of benevolence and kindness... In the midst of their persecution, when the bread has been torn from their helpless offspring by their cruel oppressors, they have always been ready to open their doors to the weary traveler, to divide their scant pittance with the hungry, and from their robbed and impoverished wardrobes, to divide with the more needy and destitute (Ibid., pp. 567-568). He further writes:.. And we are well assured from a knowledge of those pure principles of benevolence that flow spontaneously from their humane and philanthropic bosoms, that with the resources they will have at command, they will fly to the relief of the stranger; they will pour in oil and wine to the wounded heart of the dis- 707 tressed; they will dry up the tears of the orphan and make the widow's heart to rejoice (Ibid., page 567). Characteristic of the Latter-day Saints, complete minutes were kept of the organizational meetings of the Relief Society and much of the information in this lesson has been taken from this source. Significant Observations Three significant observations are noted in the organization of the Relief Society: (1) The importance of authority is shown in its organization under the direction and after a pattern of the Priesthood. (2) Within the circumstances © surrounding the organization we find another principle, that of revelation. (3) The purposes and objectives of the Relief Society, as stated by the Prophet, indicate a keen understanding of the needs of people, and, in light of present-day problems, demonstrate their practical durability. Organized By Priesthood The Relief Society was organized under the direction of the Priesthood of God. The Prophet Joseph Smith, who held the "keys" of the Priesthood, personally conducted the organization. He requested John 'Taylor, who later became President of the Church, to assume © the chair, and appointed Willard Richards to act as scribe. President Smith gave detailed instructions to the women in parliamentary procedures. How strange this would have seemed to other women, not members of the Church, who were seldom recognized in this way. Each person who became a member was voted upon by all other members, thus stressing the importance at- 708 tached to membership and underlining common consent. Emma Smith was selected as President of the Relief Society, and she chose Sarah M. Cleveland as her first counselor, and Elizabeth Ann Whitney as second counselor. Eliza R. Snow was selected secretary. (For further interesting details of the organization see Ibid., pp. 552, 567; A Centenary of Relief Society, pp. 14-18.) Fulfilled Revelation The organization of the Relief Society fulfilled a revelation of the Lord. In addressing the newly organized Female Relief Society— and this was often his forum—the Prophet referred to Section 25 of the Doctrine and Covenants, dated July 1830. This was a revelation of the Lord for the benefit of Emma Smith who at that time was a young woman of twenty-seven years. In the revelation the Lord referred to Emma as an "elect lady" and said that she would be "... Ordained under his hand to expound scriptures, and to exhort the church, according as it shall be given thee by my Spirit" (D. & C. 25:7). The Prophet at the pigenieanen of Relief Society said: I gave much instruction, read in the New Testament, and Book of Doctrine and Covenants, concerning the Elect Lady, and showed that the elect meant to be elected to a certain work, &c., and that the revelation was then fulfilled by Sister Emma's election to the Presidency of the Society (D. H. C., IV, pp. 552- 553)- Other significant words of the Lord are found in this revelation as follows: And verily I say unto thee that thou RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—OCTOBER 1956 shalt lay aside the things of this world, and seek for the things of a better.... Wherefore, lift up thy heart and _ rejoice, and cleave unto the covenants which thou hast made. Continue in the spirit of meekness, and beware of pride. Let thy soul delight in thy husband, and the glory which. Shall come upon him. Keep my commandments continually, and a crown of mghteousness thou shalt receive. And except thou do this, where I am you cannot come. And verily, verily, I say unto you, that this is my voice unto all (D. & C. 25:10, 13-16). Although this revelation was given to Emma Smith, note the Lord's word "... That this is my voice unto all."" These words and this experience must have given great encouragement to these women. Purpose of Relief Society The purposes of the Relief Society, as stated by the Prophet Joseph Smith, have endured the test of time, and today still stand as worthy objectives. At the meeting on March 17, 1842, the Prophet said the Relief Society was organized:. That the Society of the sisters might provoke the brethren to good works in looking to the wants of the poor, searching after objects of charity and in administering to their wants—to assist by correcting the morals and strengthening the virtues of the community, and save the elders the trouble of rebuking; that they may give their time to other duties, etc., in their public teaching (Relief Society Minutes, March 17, 1842, Centenary of Relief Society, page 15). Subsequently he mentioned other objectives, including _ self-improvement, that of reforming individuals, and the practice of holiness. LESSON DEPARTMENT It is interesting to observe that the purposes of the Relief Society are stated in the affirmative while a characteristic of most of the early women's organizations, usually reflected in their name, was that of being ''anti" to some thing or condition. Possibly this might explain why so many of these organizations have long since dissolved and one reason why the Relief Society has continued to be a vital organization through the years. In spite of great sociological advances in the 114 years since the organization of the Relief Society, seldom have there been greater opportunities for service than today. Many service areas, _ particularly those of a temporary nature, have changed very little over the years. For example, the necessity for help when death attends, for encouragement when sickness and sorrow are present, and for teaching the gospel to others, are as vital today as at any previous time. Neither has the need for stimulation to good work and approbation for accomplishment abated. Latter-day Saints have made tremendous inroads in solving many of the social problems of the day. The Gospel Plan throws light upon the solution of others. The challenge of the Relief Society objectives is shown by a consideration of some problems upon the American scene. The comments to follow are intended only to demonstrate the existence of some current vital problems and to stimulate thought on Relief Society objectives. Some Objectives Applied "In looking to the wants of the poor" are we sensitive to needs other than financial? Placing food in 709 the stomach and clothes upon the back should be only the beginning of our concern. What of character, self-reliance, and encouragement? Are all needy receiving attention? If we are truly "searching after objects of charity and administering to their wants" we will lend our stimulation to the search for knowl edge with which to help man. In stretching the life span, new problems have been added to those of the aged. We need to examine their needs in light of our time. The prevalence of mental illness today suggests the need of further research. Little progress has been made in eliminating causes of mental illness, although treatment facilities and technique have made great strides. Disease, as known a century ago, is almost gone, but even a casual observation reveals "gaps" for which knowledge is greatly needed. The development of transportation and communication media have had the effect of breaking down the influence of the home and consequently accentuating the need "to strengthen the virtues of the community." Many communities show a distressing lack of interest, to say nothing of the absence of "know how," in changing or eradicating those conditions which give rise to many evils of this day. The break-down of family life is at a new high, both in divorce and near divorce, with all the heartaches and misery that attend such tragedies. The high incidence of crime, particularly among young people, is a distressing challenge to all. In most communities are found destructive influences, the elimination of which would do much to reduce youth's 710 TWO AND THREE PART Christmas Cantatas FOR WOMENS VOICES icienz) = a a aes.90 pall CHILD OF BETHLEHEM (2)— Walter oo... As a democratic society, we lack an awareness of the power of personal influence, for good and evil. 'The influence of a true Latter-day Saint is more than that of suggesting good conduct, and this is important, but the greater value comes in stimulating inquiry into | the gospel, thus opening the door for others to obtain a knowledge of the truth. Mothers of the Church, who are keeping the commandments, are "practicing Holiness" and personify all of the noble virtues. It is their influence that exerts a tremendous impact "in strengthening the virtues of the community." In a complex society, such as ours, the need for self-improvement is felt by most people. 'The very essence of the gospel suggests self-improvement. Not only in the sense of doing right as opposed to doing wrong, but in being able to do all things better. Whether this is in the art of homemaking, of understanding our children and_ their problems, or of improving our skills and knowledge, it is basic in the Gospel Plan. Self-improvement is consistent with perfection, a goal of the Gospel Plan. Much has been accomplished since the organization of the Relief Society. Much is left to be done. The door of service is open to all who desire to enter. The objectives of the Relief Society have been declared by the Lord, through the Prophet Joseph Smith and his successors. For each member, under the inspirational direction of leaders of the Church, there are limitless opportunities for service and personal growth. LESSON DEPARTMENT Supplementary References 1. What new opportunities did it open up for Latter-day Saint women? 4. Discuss the three significant observations made of the Relief Society organization. 5. Discuss the purposes of the Relief Society and how they have stood the test of time. Do the objectives offer challenges today? Try to get out before the heavy rains begin and the snow covers the dry summer weeds and grasses. Gather armfulls of materials, tie them in bundles, and hang them from the ceiling of your storeroom for future selecting. Look for unusual and interesting pieces of dead wood. If you are near the sea, pick up driftwood. If you are not entirely inspired by nature, drop by the library and look through the innumerable and beautifully illustrated books on dried flower and plant arrangements. Some of the recent Japanese arrangement books are helpful. Simplicity is the key word. Remember this, and you will select from your har- | vest a few choice specimens and arrange them so that they become part of your home and your personality. You will find the effort to be worth the field trips. Often in your home among your possessions you will find choice pieces of china, pottery, or glass which may be used as accessories with your arrangements. A tiny blue horse with a piece of | gray weathered driftwood and stalks of dried barley or wheat in an old glass pitcher are unusually attractive. Try different effects. The colors of dried plants, wood, and grasses are neutral, so they will blend harmoniously with many color schemes. Stewart What is this golden tide of life That flows and falls In golden shallows and the flaming leaf? That spins and curves, Turning and reaching on the crimson vine? These shaken fields, harvested, Hold as in cupped hand the invisible Fountain and the springing air. What is this never-ceasing miracle That holds and molds The autumn, yet frees it from Chains and boundaries and labor? Shocks in the field murmur In wind-whispers, pumpkin carries Its own secret of being, The oak tree shakes down tomorrows. This beautiful moving power Builds and breaks And will not have done with beauty, But burns on hills a thousand Candles, shimmers in nooks, leaps Purple in the evening bracken, moves Through the day-shine, pushing Aside leaves to begin building April. Kaneyama Submitted by Caroline Kilauano Frontispiece Photograph: "Autumn Field," Photograph by Josef Muench Cover Design by Evan Jensen From Near and Sar A friend of mine obtained a copy of the August Relief Society Magazine to tread "Navajo Flute" (the August frontispiece poem). Now, I have reread the poem a number of times. It intrigues me, it is so outstanding — an excellent specimen of rhythmical euphony. It is so typically Indian that one feels it could have been written by one of that race. As Alice Reynolds (former editor of The Relief Society Magazine) would have said, "It has poetic essence." I desire to congratulate Hazel Loomis on the production of such a beautiful achievement. —Grace Ingles Frost Provo, Utah When I opened the August issue of The Relief Society Magazine, I was so impressed seeing the pictures of the wives of the General Authorities of the Church and reading their messages to the women of the Church. Boyer 740 740 Developing Safeguards for Youth Delbert L. Stapley Of the Council of the Twelve Or of the serious problems confronting parents today is a growing tendency of moral laxity among youth. 'Too many parents are not fully aware that such a condition exists. 'Therefore, blind to the evils to which their children are exposed, unsuspectingly, therefore thoughtlessly, they contribute to an increase of immoral and sinful practices among them. Satan is not asleep during this age of freedom from restraints and fast living. But knowing his time is short and how best to attack the weaknesses of youth, he has cunningly schemed to take advantage of them. In a period when their developing emotions and physical attractions for the opposite sex begin to unfold. It is a new sensation and experience for which, with rare exception, young people are not prepared by proper and wise teaching to understand, therefore they have not developed adequate safeguards to control. Yes, Mothers, factual cases reveal an alarming breakdown of the true moral concepts of virtue so sacred and important to Church youth. The concepts of true modesty are disappearing in our present era of freedom in boy-girl relationships with abbreviated styles of dress which expose parts of the bodies that should be clothed as a protection against persons of evil mind and intent, who unscrupulously would take advantage without thought of cost to purity and cleanness of life, also of conscience. Page 718 May I suggest to you mothers the dressing of your daughters modestly. Give your daughters the protection modest dress invites. Immodesty is suggestive and in poor taste for the daughters of Zion. Encircle them always in the armor of righteousness to keep them free from undesired advances. The unrestrained freedom in early association of boys and girls without good teaching, counseling, and controls encourages familiarity and an open display of affection which leads too often to the intimacies of necking, petting, dare games, self-abuse, and immorality. Boys and girls are not only dating at very tender ages, but are pairing off as steadies and doing things together constantly, as monopolizing each other's dances, which build up familiarity, intimacies, and liberties that should signal caution to every parent. A police officer talking to a group said, "If you keep two young people close enough long enough, you are going to have difficulty." Desiring thrills is rather predominant in the lives of youth today. Automobiles used for parking on highways, in lonely places, and even in front of homes, are natural conveniences for necking and petting which induce youth to transgression and sin. Cars can be a curse as well as a blessing and are one of the greatest contributing factors to the downfall of youth in morals and the sacrifice of virtue. Cars and drive-in theaters can and do become DEVELOPING SAFEGUARDS FOR YOUTH brothels of sin to young couples alone in such darkened surroundings, with doors closed and windows up. So many of the motion pictures shown are of poor standard, emphasizing shapeliness of figure and are full of sordid and sexy scenes, which, in such an environment, arouse the physical emotions, and with the example before them on the screen cheapening morality, weaken the powers to resist the urge to sin. Young people are subjected to an abundance of trashy bookstand literature and novels that utterly disregard the commandments of the Lord relative to the relationship and association of the sexes. Modern philosophies of thinking tend toward materialism. As a result, youth become confused and frustrated. Many mothers, worried about the modern ways of courting in cars, are not wisely meeting the problem and question their right to limit and infringe upon the activities and social life of their children. Parents and Church leaders shy away from teaching young people the place of sex in dating and in growing up. Therefore, when emotional conflicts arise in the boy-girl relationships, and being without proper knowledge or understanding of moral principles and good standards of behavior nor fully realizing the consequences for violation of God's law of chastity, they, in a moment of weakness, commit sin. Later, they awake with an alarming realization of its seriousness, causing their souls to be filled with sorrow and remorse. Often they are unable to account for the act, for- 719 getting the emotional situation they had allowed themselves to get into. HIS soulful statement by a young girl is so often true: "We are not taught what chastity and morality really mean until it is too late." 'Then added, "When we girls were little and would ask questions about such things our mothers would say, 'shh, be quiet. You are not supposed to talk about such things.' So we read what we could from whatever source, then exchanged notes and ideas with each other. By the time we had developed physically, and had the urge to experiment and go out with fellows, we didn't go to our folks for help and information — we were afraid of being slapped down — so we just experimented some more until we had gone too far, or at least had guilt feelings, with no place to turn for help." Another girl explained, "Just a simple, honest answer to a few of my questions and problems which were so vital to me then may have made the big difference." Youth who sin often blame parents for not teaching them properly — the home failing to assist them in growing up emotionally, physically, and sexually. The subject is difficult to approach and somewhat distasteful, therefore it is neglected. Parents, no doubt, feel that they are inadequate to discuss such matters with their children because they lack an adequate vocabulary of moral terms that they can employ to advantage in such teachings. The primaty teaching place for standards of morality and chastity is the home. Therefore, parents cannot escape the responsibility of qualifying themselves to inform their children wisely, intelligently, and with understanding on these important, delicate matters, rather than permit them to learn from those whose concepts of right and wrong might be warped. OUTH should be taught early how to handle their emotions, parents revealing to them such facts as good judgment dictates they should know. The gospel with all of its truth should be put to work in a big way by parents when teaching children about these matters. Sex has a place in the gospel, and it is the job of parents properly to interpret it for the understanding of their children to encourage them to keep their bodies clean and pure and used only for the purpose for which God created them. Good teaching and proper motivation are essential in this important area of service to youth. Parents must teach morality as a gospel concept to their children. Virtue is in the great scheme of life as God has furnished the pattern. 'Therefore, teach. The value of the body, that it is an eternal habitation of the spirit. Young people should understand that truth, and thus gain the desire to keep the body clean, morally pure, and always clothed in righteousness, honorably fulfilling the purpose of its creation and thus be assured the joys of purity of life and clean conscience. Teach youth the reasons for the why of living a clean life. We are living in a modern world which cannot be changed. Young people must learn how to live in the presence of these modern conditions and still express a wholesome, integrated response to them. We should help build in each young person a set of standards and life objectives that would cause him to cut out the things that destroy and cultivate those that build security and happiness. Build up meaningfully the value of a clean life and make it desirable, attractive, positive, and inviting. Morality should not be taught always in a negative manner with emphasis upon its evils and _ remorses, but from a positive approach extolling the beauties and satisfactions of a virtuous, clean, moral life, for virtue is its own reward. Parents must recognize that their children are exposed to multiple kinds of activities in this modern world of amusements and commercialism that invite the temptation to sin. So many activities are shining allurements that appear attractive, but whose pathway, if followed, will undermine the _ basic qualities of good character and virtue. Somehow parents must succeed in teaching their sons and daughters chastity as a way of life despite the existence of these and other temptations to which they are constantly subjected. Young girls like to be popular and sought after. Often they falsely assume that in order to "arrive" they must yield to advances and intimacies of boys. What an indictment against parents who fail to teach and fortify their children to resist all advances and thus retain their honor, virtue, and good character which will be to their everlasting joy and happiness, 720 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 DEVELOPING SAFEGUARDS FOR YOUTH Mothers, how close are you to your daughters? Do you pal with them? Do they share their problems and secrets with you, knowing that they shall receive sympathetic understanding and helpful counsel and guidance? Or do they prefer to go to young people of their own age and social group or clique to unburden their hearts concerning personal problems and seek counsel and advice that should come from the home? 'Too many young people are afraid to discuss intimate matters with parents because they are shrugged off for lack of interest, or time, or it is something not to be talked about, when to youth it is important and maybe a pressing matter, a problem with which they are presently faced. A satisfying answer and wise direction may be needed to protect and safeguard them against pitfalls that might be imminent in their lives. Youth require understanding and help in the process of growing up, for it is the most critical and important time in their lives. ARENTS should constantly analyze the home to be sure it is an ideal home according to the highest Church standards, with a proper environment conducive to joyful and fruitful living. Does the home promote love and affection? Is there respect of children toward parents and parents toward children? Are the teachings of the gospel fully lived in the home? What about daily family prayer? Is the recommended weekly family home night religiously followed? Is the family home program of activities and functions occasionally revised 72) to meet the changing needs of children in growing up to enliven interest and promote development and progress in family and social relationships? Is the gospel taught and the principles of morality discussed in language that will interest youth and give them understanding to help them obtain the basic, wholesome satisfactions in life which include deeper fundamental loyalties such as love of God, love of the Savior, love of the gospel, love of the Church, love of fellow men, self-respect, the attainment of a happy marriage and an ideal family life, which provide a bulwark against material and worldly things? Are parents counseling, guiding, and assisting their children to find and cultivate wholesome Church companionships that will as far as possible assure dating with Latter-day Saint boys and girls that eventually will lead to their marrying within the Church, and properly in the temples of our God? Have parents worthily set the example of temple marriage before their children and honorably fulfilled all covenants and obligations received and accepted in the house of the Lord? Can these important responsibilities and opportunities for blessings mean any more to children than to parents? Parents should reflect back upon their own youth and activities. Problems are not so much different between then and now except in today's more modern world of fewer restraints and less inhibitions they are found in diverse and various dress which parents are not excused from knowing if they desire to give wise counsel and guidance to their sons and daughters. Can immorality be a contributing cause to fewer temple marriages? Do young people, and particularly those who have sinned, understand the principle of repentance and how it applies to obtain forgiveness for sins? If not, they may ignorantly assume all is lost and continue in their sins and thus lose opportunity for a fruitful and happy life. Parents should practically apply religion into family relationships and life, developing the art of living with children in love and helpfulness which represents a functional side of our religion. Religion should be on an_ understanding, practical plane where children can live and enjoy it. Parents should be careful not to domineer and unnecessarily restrict the wholesome and beneficial activities of Church, school, and the social life of youth. Admittedly, however, some restraints and rules of conduct for good behavior are required. There also should be a controlled pattern of parent activities to provide a rich home life and full association with children. If parents are out of the home too frequently or do not find opportunities for joint recreation and other satisfying activities with children, the teen-agers of the family are cast adrift and may seek satisfactions elsewhere which may not always be wholesome. Mothers, unless absolutely necessary, Should not obtain employment, but rather fulfill honorably their chief mission of wife, mother, and homemaker. What is more important or could pay greater dividends? 'The answer is obvious. Children should possess a constant feeling of security in the home. Strained relationships within the family or a feeling of insecurity within the home often leads a boy or gitl to seek associations where they feel they are loved and wanted, which could be among questionable associates. Permit children to feel free to bring their friends home to parties and socials after dates, and then the parents welcome and cordially help entertain them when wisdom dictates. It requires kindness, love, and comradeship on the part of the parents to solve the problems of youth. There should always be a close parent-child relationship, one where confidence rules supreme and where the rights and views of children are respected and listened to courteously in the spirit of helpfulness. Parents always must be alert to the needs of their children, and also wisely counsel them on how to protect themselves against sinful advances or compromising situations. > Mountain Range Leslie Savage Clark Silence Is here, and peace; Unmarked, the long years go, And time seems but a gust across The snow. 722 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 Don Knight CHRYSANTHEMUMS FOR THE LATE SEASON Anniversary in Chrysanthemums Maryhale Woolsey Bright in the rain of this November day They stand, their gold and bronze and ruby-red A brilliant canopy above the dead And sodden corse of summer's lush bouquet. I watch through tears—remembering how last You walked the paths chrysanthemums made gay: Caressing every bloom along your way, Smoothing its fringe of petals as you passed. "Childish..."
