Nibley HE work of preaching the gospel in the Hawaiian Islands began in the fall of 1850, when ten elders, who were temporarily located in California, were called to open a mission for the Church in what was then known as "the Sandwich Islands." 'These elders were: Hiram Clark (designated as the mission president), Henry W. Bigler, Thomas Morris, John Dixon, William Farrer, James Hawkins, James Keeler, Thomas Whittle, Hiram Blackwell, and George Q. Cannon. The missionaries sailed from San Pacific Skyways, Ltd. Submitted by Maurine M. Haycock Francisco on November 22, 1850, and arrived in Honolulu harbor on December 12th, after a voyage of twenty days. The day followin their arrival they climbed to the top of "Punch Bowl Hill," an extinct volcano near the harbor, where they built an altar of stones and dedicated the land to the teaching of the gospel and the establishment of the organizations of the Church. The first baptism took place on February 10, 1851, when Elder Clark baptized a native boy about LAUPAHOEHOE (LAVA LEAF), ISLAND OF HAWAII The homes shown in this picture were all swept away during the April 1946 tidal wave. The house on the end of the peninsula belonged to the branch president, Brother Akiona. Page 724 THE HAWAII MISSION Pacific Skyways, Ltd. Submitted by Maurine M. Haycock SNOW-CAPPED MAUNA LOA, ISLAND OF HAWAII sixteen years of age. Other baptisms followed, performed principally by Elder George Q. Cannon on the island of Maui. On August 6, 1851, the first branch of the Church was organized at Kealakou, island of Maui, by Elder Cannon. It was known as the Kula Branch. By September 1, 1851, the membership of the Church in the islands numbered 220; this number increased to 4,000 by the end of the year 1853. In 1854, while still on his mission, George Q. Cannon, assisted by several educated natives, translated The Book of Mormon into the Hawaiian language. The book was 725 published the following year in San Francisco. The work prospered and a temple was built, between 1915-1919, near the settlement of Laie, on the island of Oahu. Two stakes have been organized in recent years, Oahu and Honolulu. Today, there are approximately 7,000 members of the Church in the Hawaii Mission, located in fortythree branches. D. Arthur Haycock is the Mission President. Forty-one Relief Society organizations, with 810 members, were reported in December 1955. Maurine M. Hlaycock presides over the Hawaii Mission Relief Society. Note: The cover for this Magazine is a view of the Kalau Valley, Kokee, Kauai. See also "Recipes From the Hawaii Mission," page 744. Report and Official Instructions President Belle S. Spafford [Digest of an Address Delivered at the Officers Meeting of the Annual General Relief Society Conference, October 3, 1956] of the general Relief Society conference, is to present a brief report of the status of Relief Society as a whole as shown in the annual report, and to give to you sisters who are guiding and directing the work in the stakes and missions of the Church, a few instructions to aid you in the conduct of the work in the units over which you preside. Figures from the 1955 annual report are, in most instances, gratifying to us, as I am sure they will be to you who are responsible, in such large measure, for them. Ox of the important purposes General Board The general board has a present membership of twenty-four sisters, devoted to the work of Relief Society and tireless in their efforts to fulfill their many assignments. Since our last general conference we have lost by death, one of our number, Sister Mary Grant Judd, who served as a member of the general board for sixteen years. We mourn her passing, we miss her association and services, but we express our gratitude for her life and for her magnificent contribution to Relief Society. Organizations and Reorganizations We are gratified by the steady increase in the number of Relief Society organizations. At the close of Page 726 1955 there was a total of 223 stake Relief Societies. There were forty reorganizations in the stakes and seventeen in the missions. We acknowledge with appreciation the services of the sisters who have been released. We welcome those now called to these positions, and wish for them success and joy in their calling. Missions The work of Relief Society is progressing in the missions of the Church. Leadership among the local sisters is being developed. Effort is being made to standardize the work. Relief Society members are gaining in testimony and are happy in the work, according to reports from mission Relief Society presidents and others. Membership Figures for 1955 show a membership of 163,513, an increase over 1954 of 7,213. This was a somewhat smaller increase than was shown on the previous annual report. Our total enrollment represents only 48.82 per cent (less than half) of the potential membership. Average attendance at regular meetings for members represents 35.86 per cent of the enrolled members, a slight decrease under 1954. Membership and attendance are giving us some concern. REPORT AND OFFICIAL INSTRUCTIONS Educational Program I am sure we all recognize that the quality of the regular Relief Society meeting depends, in large measure, upon the quality of the lesson work. Courses of study are carefully planned to meet the needs of Relief Society women and to accomplish the purposes set for the educational program by the general board and the Church. Generally speaking, the more than 13,000 Relief Society class leaders throughout the Church are doing excellent work. The general board notes that an increasing number of classes dealing with Relief Society subject matter are being conducted by persons and organizations other than the general board. While we are happy to have class leaders increase their knowledge of subject matter through study and instruction, we remind you that attendance at special classes is entirely an individual matter, and not a requirement of the Relief Society.. This should be made clear to class leaders. Directives to be followed in teaching the Relief Society lessons come from the general board, approved by the Church Publications Committee, and should not be set aside in favor of instructions from other sources. No instructions should receive consideration over those given by the general board. Subscription to Instructor Not Required There is some misunderstanding with regard to the necessity of Relief Society class leaders subscribing to the Instructor. This is an excellent publication and one that would 727 be helpful to class leaders and profitable reading for all of us. However, it is not required that Relief Society class leaders shall be subscribers to this publication. Book of Mormon Reading Program The theology lessons for 1956-57 mark the conclusion of a six-year course of study on the Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon. It was the aim to have every Relief Society member read The Book of Mormon during this period of study. A record has been kept each year of the number of women who, during the year, read the section of The Book of Mormon covered by the year's lessons. The reports on 1955-56 show that in 1956 there were 49.7% of the sisters who read The Book of Mormon assignment—an increase of 51%. Next year you will be asked for two reports on The Book of Mormon reading program as follows: 1. The number of women who have read during the year the section of The Book of Mormon covered by the lessons for the year. 2. The number of women who during the six-year period or any portion of it have read the book in its entirety. This coming year is the last year to achieve our goal of having every Relief Society member read the entire Book of Mormon during the period of our study of it. We urge you to lend your earnest efforts toward the realization of this goal. Work Meeting Your efforts in behalf of the work meeting continue to bear fruit. For the second successive year it has been second only to the theology meeting in attendance. Visiting Teaching Visiting teaching figures for 1955 show an increase in family visits of more than 163,000 over 1954. Close to three million visits were made— an average of 8.35 per cent of our goal of twelve visits to each Latterday Saint family annually. This is an excellent record. Welfare Compassionate Services: The report of the compassionate services shows that careful attention is being given to these basic services of Relief Society. While there was an increase of only ten in the number of days care of the sick, it is attributed to the present-day trend of hospitalization for the sick. 'There was a decrease of twenty-two in the number of dressings for burial. 'This, too, is in line with decreasing requests for this service. Visits to the sick and homebound, however, showed, as we would expect them to do, a substantial increase of 12,421 or a total of 247,878 visits. Relief Society women are giving continued support to the Church Welfare Program, participating as they are called upon in sewing, in food processing, and in working on other welfare projects. Presidents are assisting the Welfare Program by taking storehouse inventories. Ward presidents made a total of 38,611 initial and follow-up visits to families in need under the direction of their respective bishops. It is important that the Society shall continue to meet its responsibilities in this important program. New Record Book Provisions A new Record Book will go into use in January 1957. With regard to recording participation in the Welfare Program, the new Record Book will call for some new information. In the space provided in the minutes of the monthly work meeting, you are asked to record the number of hours contributed to the Church Welfare Program by all females upon assignment by Relief Society. In crediting hours, any activity, the end result of which is for the General Church Welfare Program, should be counted; i. E., fund-raising events, sewing, food processing. (Hours spent at welfare meetings or in custom canning should not be counted.) Count as one hour any portion of an hour that is thirty minutes or more. Time less than thirty minutes should not be counted. The work director counselor should be made responsible for reporting to the secretary monthly, the total number of hours contributed. This information may be obtained at the completion of an assignment from the chairman or supervisor of the activity, or from the person filling the assignment. In past years, minutes of the last regular meeting in May, all summer work meetings, together with minutes for the October theology and work meetings, have been read at the October literature meeting. This infringes upon the time of the literature lesson in October and does not tend toward precise recording of minutes, since it is difficult for persons attending a meeting to retain details of it in mind for a long 728 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 REPORT AND OFFICIAL INSTRUCTIONS period of time. Therefore, the new Record Book is set up to allow for the reading, at each meeting, of minutes of the meeting immediately preceding. It is recommended that at work meeting, minutes be read following the opening prayer. March and November Sunday Night Programs The program to be presented later in this meeting will be sent to you to distribute to the wards for optional use on the Fast Sunday evening of March 1957. Instructions for presenting the program will be included. This will allow Latterday Saint women everywhere who have been unable to attend the Dedicatory Service of The Relief Society Building, to sense the significance of it and to partake of the spirit of this historic event. We hope the program will be enjoyed by the sisters everywhere who have so loyally supported the building program. The question has been asked as to what may be done where two or more wards meet in the same meeting house and, due to a Fast Meeting being held on the evening of Fast Sunday, time is not available to Relief Society to present the March or November programs. Issued by the general board. Sisters, sacrament meeting or Fast Meeting time has not been granted to Relief Society by the First Presidency. So where time is not available to you on the Sunday evening because of a Fast Meeting being held, you may have to forego the program unless you can present it at some other time. The program for March 1957, to which I have re- 729 ferred, could be used in the weekday Relief Society Anniversary observance. One Bright Star Myrtle M. Dean OE realized with a start that he J had lingered too long, and he had made a promise. He had promised Benjy and Maria, his little brother and sister, that he would hurry home after delivering his papers to help finish the Christmas decorations. They would be disappointed if he were late, for tonight was the last night for the Christmas decoration contest. It was all this brightness and beauty of the Christmasy things in the town that had made him forget; forget to go back to the dim little valley where he lived. It was all the glittering lights and shiny tinsel, the holly wreaths, and the loveliness of the carolers' voices on the streets, and the sight of the wonderful toys in the wide windows of the big stores. All these things had made him forget about Benjy and Maria, but now he suddenly remembered his promise about the star. "Oh, Joey, if we could only have just one really, shiny decoration from the store," Maria had said. "Just one — what would you choose, Maria?" Joey had asked. After a thoughtful moment, Maria had spoken, and her eyes had been wide and luminous. "One bright, silver star, Joey; one that we could put on the top of our tree." "No, we would place it high above our stable door, just like the star of Bethlehem," Benjy had said solemnly. Joe had promised then that he Page 730 would save enough money for a star. 'They would fix the stable, where they had kept a cow when their father was alive, to look like the stable at Bethlehem where the little Christ Child was born. All afternoon before Joey had gone to town for his papers, he and Benjy and Maria had scrubbed and brushed the cement floor until it was as clean as their mother's shining kitchen floor. Old Mr. Shelby had let them have fresh, golden straw to fill the manger and scatter like a carpet over the floor. They had made a shade of pretty blue crepe paper to go over the old lantern, and hung it to the rafters in the stable to cast a soft glow all around. In the manger they had placed a clean, soft blanket, and Maria had suggested that she wrap her big, old doll in her little quilt and place it on the soft straw in the manger. It would seem as if the Baby were there. Tonight was Christmas Eve, and they were going to play that they were really shepherds. Their mother had fashioned shepherd's robes from old bath robes of their father, and had found three bright scarves that she had worn when she was young, to wind about their heads like turbans. 'The boys had carved tall staffs from long oak sticks. "But I'm not a shepherd, I'm only a little girl," Maria had said, with a troubled face. ONE BRIGHT STAR "You can be a little shepherdess," her mother told her, smiling. "Six lambs don't make a very big flock of sheep for three shepherds to tend," Benjy had mused. "Well, we couldn't expect anyone to give us a whole herd of sheep. We were lucky that six orphan lambs strayed from the herd near our place, and the herder let us keep them to raise for our own," Joey declared. At home when they had been planning all this together, Joey had thought what fun it would be and had helped plan with enthusiasm, but now all the loveliness and sparkle, all the eager, bustling crowds in the town carrying gaily wrapped parcels, made a hollow emptiness inside him. He felt a drabness about the little house in the valley that was his home, the valley that was so dim and quiet compared to this bright town. | io forced himself to turn away from the lovely window and hurried inside to buy the silver star. He had carefully kept a quarter to pay for it. He chose a large star and turned it over and over to catch the light upon it. It looked shiny and beautiful. As he hurried down the street homeward, he held the thin parcel tightly in his hand, thinking of Maria's shining eyes when she had asked for the star. At the edge of town he paused briefly to look back. The lights had all been turned on now and the town looked like a Christmas fairyland. Outside the town many of the homes were beautifully decorated. One large place now held him spellbound. Myriads of colored 731 lights were strung over the house and flooded the evergreens and shrubs about the grounds. 'There were groupings of figures about the lawn; shepherds watching — their sheep, three camels carrying Wise Men, who were richly robed. On one side of the walk was a manger scene. In the background soft music was playing recordings of sacred Christmas songs. Joe's spine tingled as he saw it all. He inched closer and stood close to the house with solemn eyes. "Don't come bothering here," he heard a stern voice speaking. "Oh, I didn't mean to bother, Sir, I only wanted to look. It is so pretty." The man leveled an unkind gaze upon him. "You had better be on your way. It's time you were home on Christmas Eve. I don't want anyone standing around. 'The contest judges should be here any minute now." Joe turned away and thought bitterly, why did we think that we could make a decoration for a contest? It takes lots of money to make a beautiful decoration like this one. Maybe the judges won't even come out to the valley. 'There are so many lovely places to see here. Joe hated to have Benjy and Maria disappointed, but now he was hoping that no one would know about their decoration, the old stable, the orphan lambs. Now it seemed silly to call that a decoration. As he neared the sidewalk he almost bumped into three men. He hoped it wasn't someone else who would chide him. He started to hurry on. "Is this your house, Sonny?" one of the men asked. "This is a very nice decoration you have here." "No. Oh, no. This is not my home." The thought of this nice place being his home left him almost speechless. "But I think it is real elegant," he said, stammering over the unfamiliar superlative. "We like it, too. You are a good judge. Have you an elegant decoration at your house? Where do you live?" The man who spoke smiled down at Joe and laid his hand gently upon his shoulder. "I live about a mile down the valley south of here. We couldn't fix a fancy store-bought decoration. Ours is just a stable." Joe's voice was hesitant and slow, as though he were ashamed to tell it. "Just a stable, huh," the man said. 'There was a significance in his voice that the boy did not grasp. "What is your name, lad?" one of the men asked. "Joey Adams, and my brother and sister are Benjy and Maria Adams. Then there is my mother, but my father has been dead now six years." | aoe turned away and moved hurriedly, for the red sun was dimming in the sky, and dusk was gathering over the valley. Soon he turned from the main highway, down the winding road that led to his home. The way seemed lonely and silent, and night was hurrying in over the bare, brown hills, leaving them shadowy. 'The trees stood tall and bare along the roadway, their leaves banked beside the road against the bushes. 'The only sound was the crunching of the dry leaves under Joey's scuffed, roundtoed shoes. A queer, twisting ache stirred in him as he thought of their little house in the lonely valley. He thought of the brave way his mother tried to make Christmas a happy time for all of them. There had been only the bare necessities since their father had gone. Mother works too hard, and sometimes, she looks very pale, Joey thought. Out here in the dusk he felt very unhappy and helpless and young. As he neared the house he saw the shining, white Christmas angel. It was the one decoration they had had for all the years that he could remember. His mother always placed it near the window, and the light shining down upon it made it look almost heavenly. Now it was there, all lovely with its stiff, white dress, edged with shiny tinsel bands. ENJY and Maria stood in the doorway anxiously watching for Joey to come. His mother stood close behind them. She was tall and beautiful, with her blue eyes and raven hair. "Oh, Joey, we thought you would never come. It is almost dark. Did you get the star?" Maria called, then, seeing the parcel, she reached to take it. A look of joy and eagerness was in her eyes. They all watched anxiously as Maria tore away the wrappings and held it before them. Their bright laughter caroled through the room as they caught sight of it. "It came from the big store in the town, didn't it? Now we won't have to cut one from pasteboard and have it uneven at the points. This one is so pretty, Joey," Benjy said. 732 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 ONE BRIGHT STAR Joey watched their delight and thought how dim this star would look to them, if they had seen all the big, brighter stars and all the shining colored lights and the glittering beauty of the town. He started to speak, his words a swift burst of emotion. "The town is so pretty, and there are so many wonderful toys in the store...." The sight of his mother's face checked his words. In her eyes was the hurt of not being able to give her children the joy and satisfaction of all the fine things. A troubled look clouded Joey's eyes for a moment, but his mother placed her arm about his shoulder. She gave him a smile of tenderness and understanding. "Come, we must hurry and place the star above the stable," Benjy said. "But Joey must be hungry, and there is warm stew waiting." His mother hurried to the stove to set him something to eat. "No, Mother, it is getting late. I will go with them to place the star," Joe told her. They fastened the star to a tall, thin willow and nailed the willow stick to the roof of the stable, but in the twilight dimness it did not shine nor sparkle. For a moment, disappointment showed in_ their faces. "It doesn't shine at all like the star of Bethlehem. It is supposed to be brighter than any other star," Benjy spoke dejectedly. "But we know the star is there," Mania tried to cheer them. "Now, if we put on the shepherds' robes and drive the lambs 733 out, we will look like real shepherds, anyway," Joey told them. Their mother helped them don the robes, and when she had wound the scarf turbans about their heads, their bright laughter filled the room, as they paraded before the mirror. The lambs scampered back, startled by the strange figures that came to open the gate of their pen. The children spoke to them, calling them by name. "Come on lambkins; don't be afraid." HE lambs soon quieted and came slowly to the gate, as they heard the friendly, familiar voices. The boys drove them out, and they began nibbling the dry grass near their pen. Suddenly, a bright moon peeked over the hill to the east of them. A white light spread all around, and the sheep looked snowy white and clean. "Oh, see our star, how brightly it shines," Maria cried. "The valley is so beautiful and the lambs are so white," Joey said. He felt happiness and peace creeping into his body. He breathed deeply, and said, '""This is almost like the real shepherds of Bethlehem; the light shining down so brightly and everything so peaceful." 'Then Joey began to repeat very softly, the words his mother read to them from Luke every year. And there were in the same country shepherds abiding in the field, keeping watch over their flock by night. And, lo, the angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord shone round about them: and they were sore afraid. And the angel said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people. For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord. Joey's voice was very solemn, and Benjy and Maria stood silently with lighted faces, their hands clasped tightly together. "Out here it sounds even more beautiful than when Mother reads it to us in the house each Chnistmas," Benjy said. "It is like Bethlehem, only there aren't the angels and the singing," Maria told them. Then they all heard the sound of the music. Softly the strains came to them on the night air. For a moment their eyes turned heavenward, as though they expected to see heavenly angels singing. 'The tune was very familiar. 'They had sung it many times around the fire at Christmas time. It was "Silent Night," and the words were being sung softly, "Silent night, holy night. All is calm, all is bright...." "Tt is Mother," they all chorused with awed voices. "She is playing the organ and singing. It sounds as sweet as an angel.". They looked toward the house where the door was open, and the music coming out to them. "That is Mother's part. We had forgotten Mother would be helping us. Hers is the best part of all." "T feel it all, deep in here," Joey said, as he pressed his hand to his heart. "It's like maybe the angels can really see us, and can hear Mother playing the 'Holy Night' song." VEN the lambs stopped browsing the grass and stood quietly listening. The children had been so engrossed in their own pageantry that they had not noticed three men who had left their car and now stood near the house. 'They had taken off their hats and were silently watching the scene. "Maybe they are the three Wise Men," Maria whispered. No one moved until their mother had finished the song. Then Joey started to move toward the strangers. One of them held up his hand and spoke, "Please, don't move. Let us look longer at this beautiful scene." They all turned toward the stable, and it seemed that the star shone even more brightly, now with the moon full upon it. 'The men came toward the stable and the little shepherds with the sheep. "Are you the really Wise Men?" Maria asked in an awed voice. "No, child, not the really Wise Men, but we hope we are wise enough to recognize the real spirit of Christmas." The man who spoke smiled down at Maria and touched her golden curls that fell below the blue turban that she wore. "Come and see our stable and our star," Benjy invited. "But there is no Christ Child here," he said innocently. They all stood at the stable door. The look on their faces was almost expectant. "No, the Christ Child may not be here, my dears, but his spirit is surely here. We can all feel it in our hearts." It was the oldest of the men who spoke, but the other two nodded their heads in silence. "Why, you are the three men that I saw at the pretty house on 734 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 ONE BRIGHT STAR the edge of town," Joey exclaimed. Now, close to the light, he could see their features plainly. "And you are Joey Adams, the boy who told us about his decoration. 'It is just a stable,' you said. But it is more than that, Joey. We are the judges, you know." Joey looked at them for a moment before he could speak. "I'm glad you took the trouble to come way out here to our place," he said seriously. "I'm sure the lovely place where I saw you got the prize. Is it the one that got it?" "That place was very beautiful, all that art and money could make 735 it, but money cannot buy what we have found here—love and _ peace and good will." It was the kind, older man who spoke again, and the others nodded their heads once more. Joey's eyes were as shining as the lights suddenly turned on a Christmas tree. Now he forgot the brightness of the town and all the toys and gifts. He looked at Benjy and Maria, and the silver star over the stable. He remembered only the words of the angels who sang, "Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward?? Men. She Satted Lace Norma A. Wrathall The lamplight holds in circled radiance The rocking chair, the floor, the fireplace, And finds its sheen upon her head bent low, As in and out her shuttle weaves the lace. Her work-worn fingers move with quiet skill, She smooths the lace across her knee, and then Pauses, plucks faulty stitches, winds the thread And makes the pattern true and fine again. So, through the years, the handmade lace adorned A petticoat a happy bride might wear— A loving gift of doilies—pillow slips— A baby's dress—a handkerchief's white square. And who might guess what dreams or plans were in Those wheels of filigree her shuttle traced? Or know what cares, like broken stitches, were Pondered, and with serenity replaced? I like to think that from a ball of thread Her fingers cast the pattern of her days; And that the tatted lace, of quaint design, Held love, forbearance, faith, that marked her ways. 'That is a process which requires time." Page 737 ITORIAL c~—9© VOL. 43 NOVEMBER 1956 NO. 11 A Home for Reliof Society When we build, let us think that we build forever. Let it not be for present delight nor for present use alone; let it be such work as our descendants will thank us for... (From Seven Lamps of Architecture, by John Ruskin) HE Relief Society Building now stands completed, "a splendor in the sun." Dedicated October 3, 1956, with prayers of gratitude and devotion, hallowed with music, and blessed by prophetic words, this building represents the world-wide sisterhood — their home — and the symbol of the ideals and accomplishments of Relief Society women everywhere.* Built in the beloved valley of Deseret, circled by the high hills and towered mountains, the building rises as a fulfillment of promise "in the shadow of the temple." Strength and beauty are evident in the simplicity of outline and in the shining surface of the polished stone. The steps are wide and inviting, the halls spacious and welcoming, the offices commodious and tasteful, yet expressing in their appointments refinement and immaculate order. The building is designed to meet the needs of an ever-growing society, expressing the ideals and purposes of the many women who believe that "charity never faileth" and strive to live according to the requirements of their high mission. In all the world there is no other building planned by women, constructed in large part by the offerings of women, built for the work of women, yet directed by prophetic counseling of the Priesthood. As Relief Society members, we are grateful to be of the house and of the lineage of eternal builders. As the present guardians of a dearly loved heritage, we stand today in the brief, bright moment of accomplishment, rejoicing in this time of fulfillment. We are as gleaners who have harvested from the past, and we are as sowers who plant the seeds for tomorrow's reaping. We honor and remember those devoted sisters who accepted with humility and thanksgiving the key which the Prophet turned for them. Nauvoo, the barrier plains, the desert valleys, the faraway frontiers— these are the pictures of the past. We look forward to the future, when our daughters and our granddaughters shall be Relief Society builders and shall receive from our hands the precious gifts of sisterhood and service. In that time, in another era, they shall say: "This house our mothers built for us." We are that golden link in time which binds the historic days to the *The proceedings of the dedication of the Relief Society Building will appear in the December issue of The Relief Society Magazine. Page 7/38 EDITORIAL ever-widening years to come. We know that many of the builders of this edifice will never see its shining walls, its spacious rooms, its lovely gifts and adornments which have been sent from afar, but all Relief Society women everywhere will feel the joy of the builders, and the spirit of the house will flow forever into all the stakes and missions, into the far-off branches to the great cities and to the towns — to all places where faithful women meet in the name of the world-wide sisterhood — in all those places where devoted women build the structures of their earthly lives for an everlasting purpose. The replicas of sheaves of wheat which adorn the marble panels on the outside walls of the building are more than decorative motifs. The sheaves are as a joining of large and small treasures, harvested, perhaps, from abundant fields, or smaller garnerings from regions of small 739 harvests. Yet all the sheaves are tich in fulfillment. Even as the faithful sisters once gleaned in the desert fields and stored their wheat for a time of need, even so the women of Relief Society joyfully through all the years have gathered their sheaves of spiritual sustenance and have stored them for a time of need. The sheaves of wheat are a symbol of fulfillment, and they are like the precious grain which will be for the seeding of other fields in years to come. The service and the joys of Relief Society are everlasting; they are forever a reaping and a planting. How beautifully the Psalm has expressed the rejoicing of the daughters: Let mount Zion rejoice, and let the daughters... Be glad.... Walk about Zion, and go round about her: tell the towers thereof. Mark ye well her bulwarks, consider her palaces; that ye may tell it to the generation following (Psalm 48:11-13). —V. P. C. <~eNot Gust the Heart Catherine E. Notes TO THE FIELD New Address for Relief Society As of November 1, 1956, the general offices of Relief Society are located in The Relief Society Building at 76 North Main Street, Salt Lake City 16, Utah. This includes all departments except the Mormon Handicraft Gift Shop, located at 21 West South Temple Street. Dedication of She Reliof Society Building to Be Featured in December Mlagazine The complete proceedings of the dedication of The Relief Society Building will be featured in the December Relief Society Magazine. Included will be a cover picture of the building in four colors, and many other illustrations inside the Magazine, some of them in color. President McKay's dedicatory prayer and addresses by the First Presidency and the general presidency of Relief Society will be presented. Relief Society Souvenir Plate Available The Relief Society Building souvenir plate may now be purchased at the general offices of Relief Society, 76 North Main Street, Salt Lake City 16, Utah, for $3.50, which includes mailing costs. The plate is made of Old English Staffordshire Ware and was especially designed for Relief Society. The center part of the design is a replica of The Relief Society Building. Photographs of the oil paintings of the nine general presidents of Relief Society are circled on the plate, and the whole pattern is bound with replicas of sheaves of wheat—an emblem long dear to Relief Society women. The motto of the society—"Charity Never Faileth"—is engraved on the plate. Page 740 Rozella Stringham Grant lakes Rugs of YUntricate Designs OZELLA Stringham Grant, Glendale, California, has made more than one hundred tugs. Using cast-off woolen materials cut on the bias in three-fourths inch wide strips, she crochets the strips together with carpet warp. Occasionally, she makes rugs of solid color, but finds greater scope for her artistry in using blending and contrasting colors in many all-over and "swirl" designs. In some of the rugs she makes a recurring border motif of colorful figures on a lighter ground, and the edges are made of the same colors as the border motifs. She has also made many braided and hooked rugs, and it is easy for her to see in any home where a colorful homemade rug could be placed to advantage. She believes that a woman's hands are made for homemaking—for making beautiful handwork to beautify her home—and the homes of others. Mrs. Grant, now ninety-four years old, is also an excellent cook, being particularly famous among her friends for her homemade cookies and whole-wheat bread. She is the mother of six children, grandmother to sixteen, and great-grandmother to thirtyfive. She has been a Relief Society secretary, a counselor, and a president, and has lived in her own life the ideals of charity and service which are exemplified in Relief Society work. ~~ Autumn Gene Romolo Like a gorgeous bird of tropic birth With widespread pinions, Splendorous autumn hovers over earth, Deepening the hues of ungirthed gold In sunlit glory Radiating over mountain crests and wold. And when the time comes for autumn's end of duty, Like a topic, molting bird, it sheds its beauty. Page 741 e Honest with Yourself (Beauty Ys lore Shan Shin Deep What is beauty? Who can have it? Ask John Robert Powers, world-famous authority on the subject. After many years of choosing and training beautiful models, he will tell you, though it sounds trite: "There are certain features that most beautiful women have in common"... "a glow of health," "a radiant personality," "a complete Page 742 9> cee self-assurance and naturalness," "intellectual curiosity, integrity, and stability of character." "Beauty comes from within." "It is within the potentialities of almost any girl...." Or look to some authorities of the past. Said Emerson: "Beauty is the soundness of the bones... A peach-ripe complexion; health of constitution that makes the sparkle and power of the eyes." "... Character gives splendor to youth." Sir James Barrie says of charm (the sister of beauty): "If you have it you don't need anything else, and if you don't have it, it doesn't much matter what else you have." Beauty is largely a matter of the thoughts we think, the deeds we do, the food we eat, the interest we show in others. It is the sum of sincerity, enthusiasm, and unselfishness. It is the product of busy days and nights untroubled by guilty regrets. Beauty is obedience to the laws of good and wise and wonderful living of the laws of health and happiness. 'To these add a lively search for eternal truth — for the good things here — for the good things hereafter —and you will surely find beauty in living, and be beautiful yourself. In short, beauty is a reflection of what you are inside yourself. SUKIYAKE 2 Ibs. Chicken, cut from bones 2 bunches green onions 6 tbsp. Shoyu (soy sauce) 1 tsp. Ajinomoto (Accent) 6 tbsp. Sugar salt to taste 1 can Japanese bamboo shoots chicken fat 1 can mushrooms Cut chicken in small pieces. Slice bamboo shoots and mushrooms. Cut green onions (including tops) into one-inch pieces. If it begins to dry out, add a little water, additional sugar, and shoyu (soy sauce). Sukiyake is called "Hekka" in Hawaii. It is served with rice, a green salad, and pickled vegetables. Heart's Bounty Crapter 6 (Conclusion) Deone R. Sutherland Twas on Parker Josephson's second visit to the Griffith farm that he brought with him his grandmother's high, square-cut diamond ring. "Mother's sister inherited the wedding ring, but I'm having one made that will harmonize with this." "Tt's the most beautiful ring I've ever seen. Ill be afraid to wear it," Annie exclaimed. "Well, we're both afraid of something then. I've got to talk to your father tonight." They were standing under the young orchard trees that were budding. The blue sky dipped in streaks of color in the west until it reached the ever-stretching peaceful lake. Annie smiled, "Oh, Parker, Father's always liked you. The first time he ever met you, you did him a kindness." Parker laughed, "Your great dark eyes were so tragic that morning when your father left you at the Williams. I remember I thought to myself, now, there's real material for the stage." Annie laughed with him, but Parker went on, "I never dreamed then that we would be here watching this sunset, planning our lives together. Yet, somehow, I feel that even from that early time, this moment was inevitable." After dinner Parker stayed in the little parlor and talked to Brother Griffith. Annie's father had always felt very warm toward this older Page 750 boy who had been such a good friend to Marie and his daughter. He was overjoyed to give this fine young man his blessing and welcome him into the family. When Parker claimed Annie from the kitchen, he put the diamond ring on her finger for always. That evening Parker and Annie's brothers made popcorn over the kitchen stove. 'Then they all sat around talking and watching the fire burn down. Brother Griffith remarked on how much like a little sister Marie had been, and how fond Annie had been of Parker even when she was young. Annie blushed in the firelight and tried to get her father to stop. Parker reached over and took Annie's hand as though to look at her new ring, but simply continued to hold it instead. "Yes, Marie was always a delightful little sister to me, and I was happy to hear of her marriage. But Annie was the one who crept into my heart and stayed. Annie, I never really dared give up hope Id find you waiting. I forced myself not to consider any other possibility, for my work on my mission had to come first, I felt." Annie murmured, "I never deserved so much.". A coal dropped softly in the stove, and the firelight spattered briefly. BROTHER Williams made a trip to the Griffith home in early May. "My wife wants everything arranged to her complete satisfaction," he laughed, "so she made me come HEART'S BOUNTY in person rather than just trusting to letters. She'll brook no _ refusals, either. And I won't dare to go home unless everyone agrees to what she proposes." The Griffiths could not help but laugh at his good-natured humor. Brother Williams continued, "Now Annie and Parker will be getting married in the Endowment House, my wife and I and Agnes and Marie, and dozens of friends and relatives, think the only thing to do is to have the reception after the marriage in our home. Annie is our second daughter, and we can't bear to miss out on anything that promises so much happiness. Parker's so well thought of (as well as Annie, of course) that we want to do this little thing for them. Oh, the number of girls who've admired your Parker, Annie! We've got to give them a lovely reception to remember." Again Annie and her family could not help but laugh along with Brother Williams, and, finally, everything was settled. The marriage was to take place in June. "Thank goodness, Annie, you've all your linens and a_ proper-sized hope chest." Mrs. Griffiths sighed. "You're so glad I'm going to be using it at last," teased Annie. "T am," said her mother stoutly, and then a cloud passed over her face. "I am, and then I'm not, if you know what I mean." "T do," said Annie softly. "I feel that way myself sometimes." She stroked her mother's worn cheek gently. "We'll do lots of visiting back and forth." Her mother smiled, "Your father was saying a wedding was such a happy occasion, it is odd how there 751 can be a drop of sadness; yet there ise But Annie was already talking about her wedding dress. Marie had sent word that Annie was to use the same dress that she had been married in. They could save it for their children, because she would never have the heart to let it be remodeled into a useful gown. "Sisters often are married in the same dress, and truly I couldn't have a dearer sister. My only regret is that my delicate condition won't let me take any kind of prominent part at your wedding reception, so you must let me enter in the festivities by your doing me the kindness of wearing the dress that brought me more happiness than I dreamed possible in this human life. You have no idea how much better my health has been since dear little Sissy was born." Annie was overjoyed with Marie's long letters. Everyone was far too good to her, she felt. Brother Griffith delivered Annie and her trunk to the Williams in the early part of June. Her mother planned to come to stay a few days before the wedding, but the Williamses insisted Annie come sooner, so alterations could be made on Marie's dress. Annie put on the wedding dress while Aunt Agnes and Mrs. Hemp kneeled with their mouths filled with pins. Sister Williams could not keep from exclaiming again and again at how lovely Annie looked in the heavy satin gown. The material took on almost a white translucent sheen when Annie moved. She caught her breath at the sight of the gown in Sister Williams' oval mirror. The rich ruching of lace at her sleeves and over the shoulder and across her bosom was more beautiful than she had _ temembered. "It's beautiful on you, there's no question about it," Mrs. Hemp muttered, as she bent low to make sure the dress draped properly. HERE was not only the wedding dress to be fitted, but a gown from the Williams was presented to Annie as an early wedding present. That, too, must have the stiffening placed exactly. The crowning gift came just a little over a week before the wedding, from Aunt Agnes. Annie cried when she saw it, but Aunt Agnes gruffly told her, if she didn't have a right to do a little work in secret on a present for their own Annie, she didn't know what the world was coming to. Annie tried on the long blue velvet coat with the white fur at the throat and the matching velvet bonnet. Never had she dreamed she might look so elegant. "You can have one or two things almost as lovely as you, I guess," said Aunt Agnes with satisfaction. "Parker's getting the prettiest bride in the whole valley, and you might as well have a few things to show off his prize with." "But this is far too much," Annie protested, stroking the beautiful velvet with her hand. Annie's mother came down four days before the wedding. She added gifts of petticoats and long warm stockings to the many things Annie already had. She exclaimed unbelievingly over the beautiful clothes, and admired the gifts that were already arriving at the Williams' house in advance of the reception. Parker and Annie took her mother and father to see the house that the Josephsons and Parker had built several blocks east of his father's. The wide, light-colored two-story house seemed unreal to Annie, sitting in the buggy staring at its gleaming windows. "It's a lovely house, Annie," her father said, "and if there's half the love in there that your mother brought to our house, you'll always have a home you can call blessed." Annie felt very humble as she laid her head on her father's shoulder. 'The dresses, the house, perhaps they were a dream, a temporal inconsequentiality. What was important was the love she and Parker had. She sat upright with her back stiff against the buggy seat. "T promise I'll remember what is really important, Papa, all my life." ARKER stopped by to help Annie open more of the gifts that arrived at the Williams. He was pleased that Brother and Sister Griffith had liked the house, he told Annie. Annie looked at him thoughtfully. "How could anyone help but like such a beautiful home?" Parker stroked his hand across the dark wing of her hair. "Of course, we don't have much furniture yet. I'm afraid it will seem pretty bare for awhile. After I begin teaching, we'll be able to do more about...." "Oh, Parker,"' Annie cried, "don't you realize that it could be a tepee or a dirt dugout, and it would still be the most wonderful place in the world as long as you were there." Parker's eyes darkened, and he moved to take Annie in his arms, 752 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 HEART'S BOUNTY but she was already to the stairs and smiling down at him. Aunt Agnes came in the door. Parker turned to her in exasperation. 'Here I always thought Marie was the little minx, but I believe I'm marrying the tease after all." Agnes smiled, "Well, you're martying the deep one, that I know." Annie laughed and waved, "Mama is helping me upstairs, and here I go." She blew a kiss to Parker and disappeared. "Am I the luckiest man in the world or not, Aunt Agnes?" He put an arm around her waist and waltzed her around. Aunt Agnes came down on her heels in a determined hurry as soon as she caught her balance. "You're both lucky, but you're the kind who make your own luck with the good Lord's blessings." Parker looked at her seriously. "Tm thankful for my blessings and humbled by them. You know that, don't you, Aunt Agnes?" "T do." The elderly lady pulled his cheek to hers and kissed him. "T used to do that more often when you were a little shaver skinning your knees climbing trees. And I expect I'll be doing it to your children." HE twenty-first of June was warm and sunny. "We have a beautiful day," Sister Griffith smiled at Marie in the hall. Sissy was dancing around her grandmother's room with her curls bouncing with golden sunlight. "She's so like Marie." Sister Williams beamed at Sissy as she caught her hand to take her down to breakfast. 753 Annie stood looking out of the window of her bedroom. Her dark hair tumbled down her back. Her white nightgown was caught in ruffles at the wrist. She must start getting ready. Yet she knew if she made a sound, her room would be filled with women helping her dress, urging her to eat. Surely, she had just a moment left. She could see the Josephsons' yard. Was Parker still asleep? What was he thinking about this morning? After today no longer would she be Annie Griffith. How much of her identity besides her name would she lose? She leaned her cheek against the warm window pane. Of what does a person think on this morning of all mornings? Was she feeling a little sad? Dismayed? She waited for the happiness of the past months to come tumbling in upon her. She felt nothing for a moment. Then the back door of the Josephson house opened. Parker was out walking in the yard. She leaned her head again to the window. He was fully dressed in his good dark suit. She should not be looking at him like this. She drew back a little from the window. But just then Ruff, his dog, came bounding around the house. He leaped eagetly against Parker, and there was Parker going down on one knee to stroke Ruff. She saw him bury his face against the dog's soft fur. "Oh, Parker, Parker." She shook her head, smiling through her tears. How could she ever make up for all that was so dear in Parker that was to be hers? She must dress quickly. Parker was to be with her for all time and eternity, and she had no extra time to be wasted. Cover. Place in pan half full of simmering water on top of stove or in oven. Steam for about 35 to 40 minutes or until done. Take care that water is kept at simmering temperature. If it boils the pudding will be watery and have holes. Carefully loosen sides of pudding, unmold on hot platter. Serve with creamed vegetables, chicken, or just by itself with a crisp salad. Drain. Make sauce with butter, flour, seasonings, and milk. Cook sauce over low heat, stirring constantly until thick, and smooth. Remove from heat. Add ham, cheese, and noodles and mix well. Jackson reports the success of this unusual bazaar: "The bazaar presented an excellent display of handwork and other items. 'The sisters made several hundred dollars, and the bazaar included everything from wonderful New England recipe books made by Relief Society members, to fresh honey from the hives belonging to one of the members. The unique thing about the bazaar, I felt, was the way the sisters worked to get ready for it. They decided in advance what they wanted the bazaar to include. They then divided the work into as many months as there were left until the time of the bazaar. They mimeographed copies of their plans and gave a copy to each member. Each work mecting they worked like bees, beginning their quota for that month. Then, at the close of the work period, each member would take some part of the unfinished work home and bring it back to the next meeting. They would then start on the next month's quota. The plans were most perfect in organization and development."
