Millar, President, Boise Stake Relief Society, reports an unusually successful social at which the visiting teachers were honored: "The enclosed account of the closing social of the Boise Fourth Ward Relief Society will enable you to catch the spirit of some of the fine work being done in our stake. I was present at this closing social, and the inspiration that Sister Emma F. Davis had in organizing this program was unique and exceptional." The details of the planning for the social and the working out of the plans are reported by Sister Davis: "When I was asked to prepare the program for the luncheon honoring our visiting teachers, I felt at a loss, as it seemed we had already used every idea there could be. I prayed earnestly for inspiration, and it came to me very distinctly —- why not have the sisters who are visited each month do the honoring? That was the answer. I asked two sisters in each district if they would like to pay tribute to their visiting teachers. 'Their response was one of the most heart-warming experiences I have ever had. The plans were to be a surprise for the visiting teachers, so we seated them at small tables by districts with the two members who were to pay them tribute. As each visiting teacher arose when her name was called, the sister in her district paid her a lovely tribute. Many original verses and sweet sentiments were expressed, which brought tears of joy and warmed the hearts and delighted the souls of our visiting teachers. Even two sweet non-members had enjoyed their visiting teachers very much, and were appreciative of the privilege of attending the social. Every officer and teacher of our Relief Society was also honored that day, to show our appreciation for their untiring efforts in Relief Society work. We feel that the visiting teachers in our ward now know how very much they are appreciated." She Almighty Jessie Dagsland Johannessen The wind is shaking the trees. The leaves tremble. They know the time soon is here for them to leave this Wonderful world of birds, and sweet smell of flowers. They went too fast—spring with its birth This beautiful summer with its laughter and happiness. They are turning yellow now, these leaves, and they try Desperately to let people remember them. They put on their most colorful garments, and to the Music of the wind they tread the last dance— But the people—they hasten—don't stop to see This magnificent work of nature— Except a handful out of the world who look up in wonder, In wonder of him, the Almighty, who made all this possible. Who are we—not to stop and think of him who gave everything, Even his Only Begotten, so that all who believe should not perish— But have everlasting life? And summer— Sheology—Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon Lesson 45—Moroni Explains Principles and Ordinances of the Gospel Elder Leland H. Monson (Text: The Book of Mormon: the Book of Mormon, chapters 8 and g; the Book of Ether, chapters 5 and 12:5-41; the Book of Moroni, chapters 1-7, and chapter 10) For Tuesday, February 5, 1957 Objective: To show ". If the day cometh that the power and gifts of God shall be done away among you, it shall be because of unbelief" (Moroni 10:24). Moroni the Last Nephite Survivor OR a period of at least twentyone years (400-421 A. D.), Moroni, son of Mormon, roamed the wilderness and the plains. As. The last, sad survivor of a once mighty people. (See Mormon 8:3-6.) He was a wayfarer, living a lonesome and a forlorn life; a hunted man, for he knew that if the Lamanites found him they would kill him. The manner of his death is still a mystety. After the battle of Cumorah, fought in 385 A. P., in which Moroni led ten thousand people, he was given custody of the sacred records, the brass plates, the twenty-four gold plates, the large plates of Nephi, and the plates of Mormon, including the small plates of Nephi. Moroni studied the records and familiarized himself with the prophecies foretelling the destruction of his people and with the history of the Nephites and the Jaredites. He engraved an _abridgment of the Jaredites, recorded on the twenty-four gold plates, upon his father's plates. This abridgment, the Book of Ether, was the first book we read in this course of study. It is a summary of a great civilization that suffered extinction because the people sought for blood and revenge (Moroni g:23), and because they refused to serve the God of this land who is Jesus Christ. Moroni Finishes His Father's Book Before engraving the history of the Jaredites on Mormon's plates, Moroni wrote two chapters (chapters eight and nine) to conclude his Page 76] father's book, the Book of Mormon. In these two chapters, he recounts the death of his father and all other Nephites save himself: And my father also was killed by them, and I even remain alone to write the sad tale of the destruction of my people. But behold, they are gone, and I fulfil the commandment of my father. And whether they will slay me, I know not (Mormon ee Conditions in Latter Days Given Moroni relates the conditions that would exist when his father's record would come forth, he gives his testimony concerning the three Nephites and Jesus Christ, and addresses unbelievers. Moroni writes: Behold, I speak unto you as if ye were present, and yet ye are not. But behold, Jesus Christ hath shown you unto me, and I know your doing (Mormon 8:35). There was no question in Moroni's mind about the coming forth of the writings: And no one need say they shall not come, for they surely shall, for the Lord hath spoken it; for out of the earth shall they come, by the hand of the Lord, and none can stay it; and it shall come in a day when it shall be said that miracles are done away; and it shall come even as if one should speak from the dead (Mormon 8:26). Moroni describes the social and religious conditions that would exist at the time of the coming forth of the record: And it shall come in a day when the blood of saints shall cry unto the Lord, because of secret combinations and the works of darkness (Mormon 8:27). He further testifies that: Yea, it shall come in a day when the power of God shall be denied, and churches become defiled and be lifted up in the pride of their hearts; yea, even in a day when leaders of churches and_ teachers shall rise in the pride of their hearts, even to the envying of them who belong to their churches. Yea, it shall come in a day when there shall be heard of fires, and tempests, and vapors of smoke in foreign lands; And there shall also be heard of wars, rumors of wars, and earthquakes in divers places (Mormon 8:28-30). Moroni further notes that the record will come forth in a day when, "... There shall be churches built up that shall say: Come unto me, and for your money you shall be forgiven of your sins" (Mormon 8:32), in a day when churches will have been built "... To get gain...." (Mormon 8:33). And I know that ye do walk in the pride of your hearts; and there are none save a few only who do not lift themselves up in the pride of their hearts, unto the wearing of very fine apparel, unto envying, and strifes, and malice, and persecutions, and all manner of iniquities; and your churches, yea, even every one, have become polluted because of the pride of your hearts. For behold, ye do love money, and your substance, and your fine apparel, and the adorning of your churches, more than ye love the poor and the needy, the sick and the afflicted (Mormon 8:36-37). Address to Unbelievers To the unbelievers, Moroni says:... Turn ye unto the Lord, cry mightily unto the Father in the name of Jesus, that perhaps ye may be found spotless, pure, fair, and white, having been cleansed by the blood of the Lamb, at that great and last day (Mormon 9:6). To those who deny latter-day revelation and the gifts of the spirit, 762 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT he says that they know not the gospel: For do we not read that God is the same yesterday, today, and forever, and in him there is no variableness neither shadow of changing? (Mormon 9:9). Moroni states that the only reason for a lack of miracles is a lack of faith in God. (Mormon 9:20) Recalling the visit of Christ to the Nephites, Moroni calls attention to the fact that Jesus said: And these signs shall follow them that believe—in my name shall they cast out devils; they shall speak with new tongues; they shall take up serpents; and if they drink any deadly thing it shall not hurt them; they shall lay hands on the sick and they shall recover (Mormon 9:24). Moroni calls upon unbelievers, "Be wise in the days of your probation.... See that ye art not baptized unworthily; see that ye partake not of the sacrament of Christ unworthily; but see that ye do all things in worthiness, and do it in the name of Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God; and if ye do this, and endure to the end, ye will in nowise be cast out' (Mormon 9:28-29). In concluding the Book of Mormon, Moroni asks those to whom the record will come: Condemn me not because of mine imperfection, neither my father, because of his imperfection, neither them who have written before him; but rather give thanks unto God that he hath made manifest unto you our imperfections, that ye may learn to be more wise than we have been (Mormon 9:31). Discourse on Faith When Moroni was abridging the Book of Ether, he inserted some of his own teachings and experiences 763 which are inspirational and reveal the greatness of Moroni's character. He addresses chapter 5 of Ether to the future translator of his writings, saying that the plates may be shown unto three by the power of God. In the twelfth chapter of Ether, Moroni gives a discourse on faith:... I would show unto the world that faith is things which are hoped for and not seen; wherefore, dispute not because ye see not, for ye receive no witness until after the trial of your faith. For it was by faith that Christ showed himself unto our fathers, after he had risen from the dead; and he showed not himself unto them until after they had faith in him; wherefore, it must needs be that some had faith in him, for he showed himself not unto the world. Wherefore, by faith was the law of Moses given. But in the gift of his Son hath God prepared a more excellent way; and it is by faith that it hath been fulfilled. For if there be no faith among the children of men God can do no miracle among them; wherefore, he showed not himself until after their faith. Behold, it was the faith of Alma and Amulek that caused the prison to tumble to the earth. Behold, it was the faith of Nephi and Lehi that wrought the change upon the Lamanites, that they were baptized with fire and with the Holy Ghost. Behold, it was the faith of Ammon and his brethren which wrought so great a miracle among the Lamanites. Yea, and even all they who wrought miracles wrought them by faith, even those who were before Christ and also those who were after. And it was by faith that the three disciples obtained a promise that they should not taste of death; and they obtained not the promise until after their faith. And neither at any time hath any wrought miracles until after their faith; wherefore they first believed in the Son of God. And there were many whose faith was so exceeding strong, even before Christ came, who could not be kept from within the veil, but truly saw with their eyes the things which they had beheld with an eye to faith, and they were glad. And behold, we have seen in this record that one of these was the brother of Jared... (Ether 12:6-7, 11-20). Moroni points out that it was by faith that his ancestors obtained the promise that the record should come to their brethren through the Gentiles, and he expresses a fear which he told the Lord that the Gentiles would mock, when they would receive the record, because of the Nephites' weakness in writing. Moroni then states that the Lord had made the Nephites... Mighty in word by faith..." (Ether 12:23), but not in writing:. Because of the awkwardness of our hands. Behold, thou hast not made us mighty in writing like unto the brother of Jared, for thou madest him that the things which he wrote were mighty even as thou art, unto the overpowering of man to read them. Thou hast also made our words powerful and great, even that we cannot write them; wherefore, when we write we behold our weakness, and stumble because of the placing of our words; and I fear lest the Gentiles shall mock at our words. And when I had said this, the Lord spake unto me, saying: Fools mock, but they shall mourn; and my grace is sufficient for the meek, that they shall take no advantage of your weakness.... I give unto men weakness that they may be humble.. Behold, I will show unto the Gentiles their weakness, and I will show unto them that faith, hope and charity bringeth unto me—the fountain of all mghteousness (Ether 12:24-28). And Moroni says that he was comforted. He recalled that the brother of Jared removed a mountain by faith, "... Wherefore thou workest after men have faith. And I also remember... Man must hope, or he cannot receive an inheritance in the place which thou hast prepared" (Ether 12:30, 32). And again, I remember that thou hast said that thou hast loved the world, even unto the laying down of thy life for the world, that thou mightest take it again to prepare a place for the children of men. And now I know that this love which thou hast had for the children of men is charity; wherefore, except men shall have charity they cannot inherit that place which thou hast prepared in the mansions of thy Father. Wherefore, I know by this thing which thou hast said, that if the Gentiles have not charity, because of our weakness, that thou wilt prove them, and take away their talent, yea, even that which they have received, and give unto them who shall have more abundantly. And it came to pass that I prayed unto the Lord that he would give unto the Gentiles grace, that they might have charity. And it came to pass that the Lord said unto me: If they have not charity it mattereth not unto thee, thou hast been faithful; wherefore, thy garments shall be made clean. And because thou hast seen thy weakness thou shalt be made strong, even unto the sitting down in the place which I have prepared in the mansions of my Father. And now I, Moroni, bid farewell unto the Gentiles, yea, and also unto my brethren whom I love, until we shall meet before the judgment-seat of Christ, where all men shall know that my garments are not spotted with your blood. And then shall ye know that I have 764 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT seen Jesus, and that he hath talked with me face to face, and that he told me in plain humility, even as a man telleth another in mine own language concerning these things; And only a few have I written, because of my weakness in writing. And now, I would commend you to seek this Jesus of whom the prophets and apostles have written, that the grace of God the Father, and also the Lord Jesus Christ, and the Holy Ghost, which beareth record of them, may be and abide in you forever. Amen (Ether 12:33-41). Teachings of the Book of Moroni In beginning the Book of Moroni, Moroni says: Now I, Moroni, after having made an end of abridging the account of the people of Jared, I had supposed not to have written more, but I have not as yet perished; and I make not myself known to the Lamanites lest they should destroy me (Moroni 1:1). Moroni then discusses principles and ordinances of the gospel. He informs us that he writes these things:... That perhaps they may be of worth unto my brethren, the Lamanites, in some future day, according to the will of the Lord (Moroni 1:4). Moroni tells them concerning the bestowal of the Holy Ghost by the Nephite twelve. He writes concerning the ordination of priests and teachers. Moroni also gives the two prayers used by the Nephites in administering the bread and wine, both of which we use today in our sacramental service. Finally, he specifies the conditions and mode of baptism. People were not baptized except "... They came forth with a broken heart and a contrite spirit, and witnessed unto the 765 church that they truly repented of all their sins" (Moroni 6:2). After this ordinance was performed they were numbered among the people of the Church. The people met together frequently:... To fast and to pray, and to speak one with another concerning the welfare of their souls.... And... To partake of bread and wine, in remembrance of the Lord Jesus (Moroni 6:5-6). These people:. Were strict to observe that there should be no iniquity among them; and whoso was found to commit iniquity, and three witnesses of the church did condemn them before the elders, and if they repented not, and confessed not, their names were blotted out.... But as oft as they repented and sought forgiveness, with real imtent, they were forgiven (Moroni 6:7-8). Obtaining a Testimony of The Book of Mormon Moroni, finally, closes his book and, of course, The Book of Mormon, writing to his brethren, the Lamanites, and giving some specific instructions on how a testimony of the truth of The Book of Mormon may be obtained: Behold, I would exhort you that when ye shall read these things, if it be wisdom in God that ye should read them, that ye would remember how merciful the Lord hath been unto the children of men, from the creation of Adam even down until the time that ye shall receive these things, and ponder it in your hearts. And when ye shall receive these tidings, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall ask with a sincere heart, with teal intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost. And by the power of the Holy Ghost ye may know the truth of all things (Moroni 10:3-5). Moroni's Farewell Exhortation Moroni further exhorts the Lamanites not to deny the gifts of God, one of which is given to one man and another of which is given to another man. One man, however, may have several gifts, "... According as he will" (Moroni 10:17). And I would exhort you, my beloved brethren, that ye remember that every good gift cometh of Christ. And I would exhort you, my beloved brethren, that ye remember that he is the same yesterday, today, and forever, and that all these gifts of which I have spoken, which are spiritual, never will be done away, even as long as the world shall stand, only according to the unbelief of the children of men. Wherefore, there must be faith; and if there must be faith there must also be hope; and if there must be hope there must also be charity. And except ye have charity ye can in nowise be saved in the kingdom of God; neither can ye be saved in the kingdom of God if ye have not faith; neither can ye if ye have no hope.... And now I speak unto all the ends of the earth — that if the day cometh that the power and gifts of God shall be done away among you, it shall be because of unbelief (Moroni 10:18-21, 24). Moroni closes his record with words that ring with assurance: And I exhort you to remember these things; for the time speedily cometh that ye shall know that I lie not, for ye shall see me at the bar of God; and the Lord God will say unto you: Did I not declare my words unto you, which were written by this man, like as one crying from the dead, yea, even as one speaking out of the dust? (Moroni 10:27). And now I bid unto all, farewell. I soon go to rest in the paradise of God, until my spirit and body shall again reunite, and I am brought forth triumphant through the air, to meet you before the pleasing bar of the great Jehovah, the Eternal Judge of both quick and dead. Amen (Moroni 10:34). Questions on the Lesson 1. What records did Moroni have? 2. What was the condition of the Lamanites and Nephites in his day? 3. What were the attitudes of Mormon and Moroni toward the gifts of the Spirit? 4. What social and religious conditions did Moroni foretell would prevail when the Nephite record would be brought forth? Autumn Mood Vesta N. Lukei Bright maple leaves, and oak, gold-washed with sun, That grew beside a stream an hour ago Now fill my home with autumn's benison, Epitomize the whole day's vibrant glow. So, too, some slightest thing we shared can hold Our happiness, and while we are apart Keep memory as bright as autumn gold And love a burning flame within my heart. 766 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 Visiting Sleacher ITlessages— Book of Mormon Gems of Truth Lesson 45—"And It Came to Pass That There Was No Contention in the Land Because of the Love of God Which Did Dwell in the Hearts of the People" (4 Nephi 15). Leone O. Jacobs For Tuesday, February 5, 1957 Objective: To give encouragement for eliminating contention through having the love of God in our hearts. N the world as it exists today we can only try to imagine what it would be like if it were devoid of all contention. Surely it would seem near unto heaven. Yet such a condition is possible to achieve and was achieved by the Nephites on this hemisphere over 1900 years ago. A state of peace and harmony existed among them for almost 200 years. The Book of Mormon states regarding this unique _ period, "... And surely there could not be a happier people among all the people who had been created by the hand of God" (4 Nephi 16). Was it any magic formula or unknown code of conduct which brought about this happy state? No, the formula has been known throughout the centuries, and_ is known to us today. It was given very clearly and briefly when Nephi recorded "... There was no contention in the land, because of the love of God which did dwell in the hearts of the people." Throughout the scriptures we read much concerning the love of God, indicating that it should rule our lives. When one of the Pharisees, a lawyer, inquired of Jesus, "Master, which is the great commandment in the law?" Jesus answered:... Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind. This is the first and great commandment (Mt. 22:37-38). We can cultivate and prove our love of God only by doing his will. Christ said, "If ye love me, keep my commandments" (John 14:15). The extent to which we love God is made manifest in our behavior toward our fellow men. We cannot truly love God and mistreat our fellow men. Relief Society sisters have an excellent opportunity to develop love of God, both through their compassionate services within the organization and also in their homes. To a great extent it is within the power of mothers to make of their homes sanctuaries of peace and harmony. By a mother's good example and patient but firm guidance, the love of God can be cultivated. Such helpful influences as family prayer, participation in family activities, cooperation in work assignments, and generous amounts of praise and encouragement help to bring about Page 767 family unity and love. The proverb, "A soft answer turneth away wrath," can be practiced to good advantage. The love of God is a stronger force than that which breeds contention. 'Thus it is comforting to know that strife and discord can be conquered by this great power. Vork Mleeting— Food Preparation and Service (A Course Recommended for Use by Wards and Branches at Work Meeting) Lesson 5—Cheese Rhea H. Gardner For Tuesday, February 12, 1957 HEESE is one of the oldest foods known to humanity, so incredibly old that its origins are shrouded in legend, so universal that it appears wherever man _ has grazed animals and used their milk. The Greeks ate and appreciated cheese. 'The diet of athletes training for the Olympics was largely cheese. The Romans ate large quantities of cheese and brought it to England, where some of the world's best varieties of cheese, Cheddar and Stilton, are still made. Monks made Roquefort cheese as early as A. D. 1070. Its discovery is another accident. A shepherd had left his lunch of bread and cheese in the famous Roquefort caves. When he came back, weeks later, he found that the bread had molded and that the cheese looked different. However, the cheese had a delicious taste, and the shepherd told the monks about it. The popular blue or Roquefort cheese we now have is the result. Camembert became famous when Napoleon discovered it in an obscure country in Normandy. He is said to have been so pleased that he kissed the hand of Madame Horel, the maker. Camembert became the most famous of France's reputed 450 cheeses. Italian cheeses, too, are very ancient. Parmesan cheese was a main part of the diet of many in the fourteenth century. The Swiss have made cheese since the sixteenth century. 'There were sections of the country where, at the birth of a child, a wheel of Swiss cheese was made and put away marked with the child's name. For the ceremonial occasions of his life, such as christening and marriage, slices of his own cheese were cut and served, and, at his death, the mourners consumed the last pieces in his memory. When the pilgrims sailed on the Mayflower, cheese was one of the foods they took along. Until 1850, all the cheese in America was made on the farms. Most of it was cottage cheese, though some farmers also made Cheddar in the way they had made it in their native England. The first cheese factory was started in Oneida County, New York, in 1851. Until the early nineteen hundreds, the manufacturers of cheese traveled westward, especially to Wisconsin, where surroundings for cheese-making were neatly perfect. 'Today, cheese is made in almost every state of the Union. The world's largest 768 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT Swiss cheese factory is located in beautiful Cache Valley in northern Utah. But Wisconsin is still the most important cheese-making state, making about fifty per cent of all American-made cheese. Like the milk it is made from, cheese is a nearly perfect food. In a pound of American Cheddar cheese you get the equivalent of the milk fat contained in four quarts of milk and the protein in two and four-fifths quarts of milk. 'The butterfat in cheese is a good source of vitamin A. Cheese contains other necessary vitamins, too, but to a lesser extent. It is an excellent food for children and for adults. The old story that cheese is hard to digest has been disproved by tests made over the years by the United States Department of Agriculture and a large number of scientific institutions. It has been proved that cheese is ninety to ninety-nine per cent digestible. Cheese is an economical food compared to the nourishment and eating pleasure it gives. Cheese is also one of our most versatile foods, not only fitting into the main course of breakfast and every course of luncheon or dinner, but fitting every budget. It is an excellent item for freezing. Always cook a food containing cheese at a low temperature, if it has to cook for any length of time. Higher temperatures may be used if the cooking time is very short. Overcooking gives cheese a bad texture and may decrease the ease of digestion. When cheese is cut or shredded into fine bits and mixed 769 with other foods, there is less danger of overcooking it. Well - ripened Cheddar blends more readily than that which is underripened, and cheese that has a high fat content melts better than others. If cheese is to be served as such, remove it from the refrigerator an hour or more before it is to be served, so its full goodness will be released. Cheese, like some people, is a good mixer. When mixed with bland foods, such as macaroni, it adds flavor and zest to the dish. Sharp or strong-flavored cheese served with fruit is an excellent combination for dessert, or with the addition of a roll or slice of toast, as a main luncheon dish. Frozen fruit salad, with cheese as an accompaniment, is delightful. Melted cheese in white sauce is delicious when combined with vegetables, toast, or crackers. Practically all soups are very much improved if they are topped with plenty of grated cheese. Cream soups, especially, are improved when a cheese topping is added. Cheese that is well aged and sharp is best for this. A cheese tray is a very popular last course for dinner in many European countries, or for a buffet luncheon, supper, or a midnight snack in America. Have a variety of cheeses for a variety of tastes. These are but a few suggestions for the use of cheese. If you are one who has limited the use of cheese to sandwiches and macaroni and cheese, you have a great thrill waiting you as you expand the use of this near-perfect food. Jacobs (Text: Shakespeare Major Plays and the Sonnets, by G. B. Harrison, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1948) For Tuesday, February 19, 1957 Objective: To learn more fully that the two-edged sword of justice cuts those who do not extend mercy just as it cuts those to whom mercy is not extended. How far that little candle throws his beams! So shines a good deed in a naughty world. The Merchant of Venice, V. 1. Go, 91 Wilt thou draw near the nature of the gods? Draw near them then in being merciful: Sweet mercy is nobility's true badge. Titus Andronicus, I, 1, 117-119 A good moral, my Lord. It is not enough to speak, but to speak true. A Midsummer Night's Dream, V. 1, 120, 121 OW wise was the late Dr. Carl F. Eyring in his observation that "Each generation must renew itself." How discerning was Ralph Waldo Emerson when he wrote in his essay, "Experience": "I think I will never read any but the commonest books — the Bible, Homer, Dante, Shakespeare, and Milton." Combining these two thoughts, then, how inevitable that those who today would earn greater wisdom within their world and greater insight within themselves must read Shakespeare long, deep, often. Just as great art verifies itself in other great works of art which contain the same great truths, so, through time, great souls speak to great listeners, regardless of whether they live in 1950 or 1590. But since ours is a different world than Shakespeare's, his works, in part at least, are often interpreted differently toPage 770 day. Likewise each of us is free to see Shakespeare in a different manner than his neighbor. Therefore, of necessity, a stream of books giving fresh interpretation to Shakespeare pours from our presses, thus reminding us that the last word on Shakespeare will never be said. The Merchant of Venice The play was probably written in 1594, and was acted many times previous to its presentation before King James I, in 1605. He enjoyed it so much that it was again presented at court two days later. We have no record of its being performed again for almost one hundred years after King James' command performance. From 1701 to 1741 Shylock was presented as a farcical, comic rogue; after 1741 he achieved status and depth at the hands of more perceptive interpret- LESSON DEPARTMENT ers. During the nineteenth and twentieth centuries his role was coveted by great Shakespearean actors. The Merchant of Venice has been most popular, both with audiences and actors. Traditionally, its appeal has not been questioned; why it appeals is still a matter of controversy. Some critics feel Shylock to be entirely alien to the play, a hard, bitter miser of another species who intrudes gratingly upon the sweet music and romantic adventures of a delightful Shakespearean comedy. For others, this light tone, beauty, and "happy ending" merely provide continuity and a chance for members of Shakespeare's acting company to perform this moral essay dealing with justice, mercy, tolerance, ways of getting money, and unselfish friendship. Since Shakespeare's works have been all things to all men, this issue remains unresolved. Plot The setting of the play is in Venice, Italy, and provides a return to the land of the classics which held such glamor and excitement for Elizabethan Englishmen interested in new learning and world-wide culture. Antonio, an honest bachelor merchant, is approached by a handsome, spendthrift Bassanio, his best friend, who needs three thousand ducats to woo Portia, the beautiful, witty, wealthy lady of Belmont. Because Antonio's money is tied up in shipping, he finds it necessary to ask the Jewish moneylender Shylock for the loan, offering his ships and cargoes as security. Because he hates usury so intensely (and hence Shylock) Antonio always loaned his own money with- 77 out charging interest, and, likewise, did not believe in paying interest; but Bassanio's urgent need forced him to make an exception. As a gesture of friendship toward Christian Antonio, who had but recently spat upon him, Shylock agrees to make the loan without charging interest, but "in merry sport" suggests Antonio sign a bond for security which will permit Shylock to cut a pound of flesh wherever he chooses from Antonio's body, if the loan is not repaid within three months. Feeling that Shylock has even been kind, and confident that at least one of his vessels will return soon, Antonio signs the bond and gives Bassanio the money, who leaves at once for Belmont with his friend Gratiano to renew his acquaintance with Portia and try to win her hand. Before the death of Portia's wise and wealthy father he had devised a test for selecting her husband. All her many suitors are to be shown three small caskets. On the gold one is written, "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire." The silver casket carries the promise, "Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves," while the lead casket warns, "Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath." If the suitor unlocks the casket which contains Portia's portrait, she becomes his bride. The gold casket contains a skull, the silver casket the portrait of a blinking idiot, while the leaden casket, which Bassanio chooses because of hints contained in a song which is sung as he deliberates, contains Portia's portrait. As symbol of her love, Portia gives him a ring, which he promises to wear forever; likewise her maid Nerissa gives a ring to Gratiano, who has just wooed and won her. Lorenzo, another of Bassanio's friends, arrives at Belmont with lovely, fiery Jessica, daughter of Shylock, who has just deserted her lone father, taking jewelry and several bags of his ducats as she elopes with her Christian husband. The marriage vows are scarcely pronounced when word comes that none of Antonio's ships has arrived, and Shylock has appealed to the justice of the Venice court for his pound of flesh. Bassanio and Gratiano leave their wives in the care of Lorenzo, and return to Venice to help Antonio. But Portia refuses to be left out, so, disguising herself as a young lawyer with Nerissa disguised as her clerk, she artives at the trial just as things are going badly for Antonio. Assuming the name of Balthasar, a young doctor of Rome, Portia acts as judge, first attempting to soften Shylock in her famous speech on mercy. Unsuccessful, she awards Shylock the pound of flesh, instructs Antonio to bare his bosom to Shylock's knife—when gallant Bassanio offers to take Antonio's place and give his life for his friend. Then Portia, calling attention to the requirements of the bond, forbids Shylock to take one drop of blood on pain of death. Shylock relents. 'Then Portia states the Venetian law which permits the state to seize half the property of anyone conspiring to murder, but Antonio refuses to take his legal half on condition that Shylock become a Christian and leave his property to Lorenzo and Jessica at his death. Portia charges no fee for saving Antonio, but, instead, accepts the rings of Bassanio, her husband, and Gratiano, as tokens of gratitude. All return to Belmont where, as they return, Lorenzo and_ Jessica speak lyric lines in praise of love and night. The wives tease their husbands about the absent rings, denying them their love until they prove the rings were not given to rivals, but Portia soon relents, tells Bassanio that she was the doctor at the trial, produces the rings, and the play ends happily, as word comes that three of Antonio's rich cargo vessels have just arrived. The three interwoven plots, revolving about the caskets, the pound of flesh, and the rings, are deftly worked together by the craftsman Shakespeare. 'Though in its final resolution the play is a romantic comedy, the dramatic climax contained in the long trial scene in Act IV reveals Shakespeare's major interest within the play to be a moral one. It must not be forgotten that Act V contains lines of great and simple beauty, reminiscent of Romeo and Juliet: The moon shines bright. In such a night as this, When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise.... VV. Mweas3 How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank! Here will we sit and let the sounds of music Creep in our ears, night Become the touches of sweet harmony. Sit, Jessica. Look how the floor of heaven Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold. There's not the smallest orb which thou behold'st Soft stillness and the 772 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT But in his motion like an angel sings, Still quiring to the young-eyed cherubins. Such harmony is in immortal souls, But whilst this muddy vesture of decay Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it. V. 1. 54-65 The man that hath no music in himself, Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds, Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils. V. 1. 83-85 Such exquisite lines of word-music again remind us that, primarily, Shakespeare is the poet; also they condemn the rasping harshness of Shylock's words: Hear you me, Jessica. Lock up my doors, and when you hear the drum And ae vile squealing of the wry-necked €, Clamber not you up to the casements then.... II. 5. 28-31 The Universal Shakespeare In this play Shakespeare creates his first really complex character— Shylock. But in presenting him to us, he raises many of the questions which vexed his contemporaries and teased them into attempting answers just as they vex and tease us today. For example, what questions can be more pertinent for our own day than the following: (a) Is money to be gained in life at the expense of higher values? (b) For a Christian or for a Jew is it "honorable" to gain money—by usury, by leaving a father but taking his wealth, by a court decision which is more just than merciful? (c) Can it be that some of us are daily being seduced by the golden casket to choose it, rather than the unglamorous lead casket? Shakespeare does not pretend to answer these and other soul-search- 773 ing questions in the play; he does embody such questions in characters and relationships, that we may see artistic reality and judge for ourselves. He leads us to a larger understanding of the people concerned, that we may judge more wisely. Most of these questions are focused most sharply in_ three characters: Antonio, Portia, Shylock. Each deserves consideration, brief as it must be. Antonio In the opening speech of the play, Antonio is wearied by a sadness which he cannot resist or explain. When Salario suggests that he worries about his scattered ships, or that he is in love, Antonio denies any truth to these reasons. During the play Shakespeare reveals to us two other qualities in him: he is loyal and generous to Bassanio, and he hates Shylock with such passion that, when questioned by the surprised Shylock about his sudden change in tactics — whereas yesterday he spat on Shylock and called him dog — Antonio loses his temper in his reply: I am as like to call thee so again, To spit on thee again, to spurn thee too. If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not As to thy friends, for when did friendship take A breed [increase] for barren metal of his friend? But lend it rather to thine enemy, Who if he break, thou mayst with better face Exact the penalty. To which Shylock replies that he desires to be his friend, and to lend him money without interest, which both agree to, with the "pound of flesh" bond added later. Just as I. 3. 131-138 Shylock has trouble later defining the source of his hatred for Antonio, now it seems difficult to account for Antonio's hatred for the Jew. However, since Antonio has revealed himself as somewhat of an idealist by refusing to borrow or lend at interest, his hatred may be more for Shylock's usury than for Shylock himself. We should also remember that for hundreds of years Jews had been denied legal residence in England, nor could they vote, own property, or attend schools. Largely, they were tolerated because rulers found them useful: they loaned money. Antonio's farewell speech at the end of the scene reveals him peaceful and hopeful: Hie thee, gentle Jew. The Hebrew will turn Christian. He grows kind. I. 3. 178-179 Portia Intelligent, witty, beautiful, rich, desired ardently by gentlemen and kings throughout the world, Portia considers herself worthy of such pursuit, and yet her "little body is aweary of this great world"; she has too much of everything, yet lacks the will power to accomplish and do: If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do, chapels had been churches and poor men's cottages princes' palaces. It is a good divine that follows his own instructions. I can easier teach twenty what were good to be done than be one of the twenty to follow mine own teaching. The brain may devise laws for the blood, but a hot temper leaps o'er a cold dewree (I° 2. 19-26). (Read as much of Act 1, Scene 2, as time permits. ) How fully Portia speaks for the new concept of Renaissance man. Whereas formerly man attained virtue by obeying reason, now virtue comes through long experience which proves to the good man that his highest principles and his own instinct mutually support each othCk Portia's boredom ends abruptly when Bassanio comes to choose the casket. She delays his stay until they can become better acquainted, then has a song sung as he chooses, a song with a verse pattern which thymes with lead. Her marriage promises all joy, but before such joy can be realized a messenger brings news of Antonio's plight. It is Portia who rushes her husband off to his aid, she being completely loyal to his loyalties. Then, almost instantly she decides to attend the trial in disguise: here is a chance for being seen, being heard, a time for excitement and spectacular shifts in logic and attack until the almost insane Shylock is robbed of his prey. The intense courtroom scene is the heart of the entire play (read Act IV, Scene 1 as time permits), and Portia is the center of all light and strength. Her words dazzle, her quick mind-shifts are brilliant, and her sense of drama and timing no less than perfect when she agrees that Shylock shall have his flesh and waits while he brings scales to weigh the flesh, and sharpens his knife. Then reverses everything in her deft speech beginning, "Tarry a little." In her leisurely, self-confident manner she forbids Shylock to take one drop of blood, and he is thwarted and Portia is identified with her great speech on mercy, probably 774 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT the best-known speech in Shakespeare aside from Hamlet's "To be or not to be." After Antonio confesses that he owes Shylock, Portia then turns to Shylock to tell him he must be merciful. Already bullied, robbed, taunted, and pushed beyond endurances, Shylock demands to know why his mercy is to be compelled. This brings Portia up sharp, forcing her to acknowledge that any mercy seemingly forced, cannot be mercy. For a moment Portia transcends herself when she couples beauty of language and simple tone to the ideal beauty which should relate man to man: The quality of mercy is not strained, It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath. It is twice blest; It blesseth him that gives, and him that takes. Tis mightiest in the mightiest. It becomes The throned monarch better than his crown. His scepter shows the force of temporal power, The attribute to awe and majesty. Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings. But mercy is above this sceptered sway, It is enthroned in the hearts of kings, It is an attribute to God himself, And earthly power doth then show likest God's When mercy seasons justice. IV. 1. 184-197 But this sublime passage ends abruptly in her next words, '""Therefore, Jew," which is legal, rigid, and just, containing a complete change of tone. Throughout the rest of the trial it is Portia being tried, not Shylock. Will she be motivated by her own exalted definition of mercy, or will she be merely literal and legal? Here Portia fails; here, knowing better, she yields to justice, 7715 and it remains for the Duke and Antonio to extend some degree of mercy to the bewildered, distraught Jew. Notwithstanding, Portia is one of Shakespeare's most delightful, most beloved characters, despite her tendency to overdramatize, and her failure, as she predicted of herself earlier, to act on the higher truth she had stated with such spontaneous ease and beauty. Shylock Here is the complexity of life itself. All will agree that in justice and under the law Shylock received what he deserved, and yet, just though it may be, something within us whispers deep down, "that man was wronged." His revenge is a vicious one, but what is the source of his bitterness, since in his first scenes of the play he is frugal, concerned with business, stern but not mean, and not thinking to ask for his pound of flesh until his daughter Jessica and his malicious countryman Tubal torture him into his desperate, vindictive frame of mind which characterizes the trial scene. Early in the play Shylock recalls the patience with which he has borne abuse, isolation, and spitting, since "Sufferance is the badge of all our tribe." Antonio feels his kindness, his desire to belong, to have a friend, but then the series of blows begin to fall which unhinge him, possibly because each is given him by a Christian who confesses to all virtue while reviling Shylock as a fellow human. How dearly he loves his Jessica, as Lorenzo well knows, even as he steals her while insulting her lineage: If e'er the Jew her father come to Heaven, It will be for his gentle daughter's sake. 776 And never dare misfortune cross her foot Unless she do it under this excuse, That she is issue to a faithless Jew., Il. 4. 33-38 When Shylock realizes that Jessica has deserted him, he becomes distraught, and with an impassioned but numb repetition, he rants through the streets calling out: My daughter! Oh, my ducats! Oh, my daughter! Fled with a Christian! Oh, my Christian ducats! Justice! The law! My ducats, and my daughter! II. 8. 15-17 Which Salanio describes: I never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable, As the dog Jew did utter in the Streets.... Il. 8. 12-14 Shylock resents the assumed innocence of those who helped spirit Jessica away when they ask him where his daughter is, and Tubal tortures him with visions of the ting his wife had given him before their marriage. Now Shylock descends to the lowest depths: if Christians call me dog, I'll be one, and "'beware my fangs... I'll have my bond." And midway in his suffering he reminds us that he, too, is mortal and sensitive, as he describes why Antonio has hated him: And what's his reason? I am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? Fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, hall we not revenge? If we are like you RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 in the rest, we will resemble you in that. If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility? Revenge. If a Christian wrong a Jew, what should his sufferance be by Christian example? Why, revenge. The villainy you teach me I will execute, and it shall go hard but I will better the instruction. Ill. 1. 60-76 Or in other words, if I am hard and cruel, I but improve on the instruction you have already taught me so effectively. 'Thus, in his trial scene, at first he pushes his advantage relentlessly, just as his Christian persecutors do later by taking his goods from him and robbing him of his identity within his group by rather mockingly forcing him to accept Christianity. No wonder, in that magnificent understatement, "T am not well" Shylock tells far more than he says. He is entirely broken, alone, scorned. And, as a final blow, Gratiano speaks of his christening in less than gentle tones, asking instead for a jury and gallows: In christening shalt thou have two godfathers. Had I been judge, thou shouldst have had ten more, To bring thee to the gallows, not the font. IV. 1. 398-400 Surely Shakespeare is here showing us Christian vindictiveness which, even though merely echoing Shylock's well-earned lesson, is a far cry from that "mercy which droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven." In truth here is that "mob in the heart" which Emily Dickinson sees and fears in each of us, and not without some justification. Here Shylock wounds us so deeply that Shakespeare gives us an entire final act filled with irresistible pre- LESSON DEPARTMENT scription for forgetting: music, lyric beauty, young love, teasing, repentance, jest, and merry company of a moonlight night. Thoughts for Discussion 1. Do you feel that in this play Shakespeare is saying that "the love of money is the root of all evil'? Discuss. 777 2. An eminent Shakespearean critic has written his opinion that he cannot "see how a Jew can read The Merchant of © Venice without pain and_ indignation." Is this critic right or wrong? Does such a view apply to Jews only? 3. It is always more difficult to do the good than to know what the good is? Do the main characters in this play know the good? How can this be proved by their actions? Social Science—Latter-day Saint Family Life Lesson 4—Women and the Priesthood Elder John Farr Larson For Tuesday, February 26, 1957 Objective: connection with the Priesthood. HE success of the Relief Society was assured by its significant inception under the direction of the Priesthood of God. Inspiration from the same source during each of the 115 years of its existence has built an organization, strong but sensitive to need, and willing to serve. We shall now consider specific teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith regarding the relationship of women to the Priesthood, and the application of these teachings in present-day living. Instructions Through the Priesthood At an early meeting of the Relief Society the Prophet Joseph Smith clearly stated that the activities of the organization would always be directed by the Priesthood. You will receive instructions through the order of the Priesthood which God has established, through the medium of To show the role and responsibilities of Latter-day Saint women in those appointed to lead, guide and direct the affairs of the Church in this last dispensation (D. H. C. IV, page 607). The sisters sensed the importance of his directions and were eager to follow the Prophet's wise counsel during the formative years of the Relief Society's development. During his lifetime the Prophet, with other General Authorities, met with them often, giving refinements of the original instructions and timely suggestions to meet new situations which arose. A close-working relationship existed between them, and the women soon learned that their greatest strength stemmed from their willingness to serve as aids to the Priesthood. The members of the first Relief Society presidency were called to their respective offices by the Priesthood who set them apart individually, blessed them, and gave instructions regarding their new duties. 'This was carefully completed before "president Emma Smith and her counselors took the chair." This procedure remains unchanged _today, and is a great spiritual blessing to women of the Church, regardless of the capacity in which they are called to serve. Women Share Priesthood Blessings In April 1842, the Prophet gave a significant lecture on the Priesthood to the Relief Society. A synopsis of it, reported by Eliza R. Snow, concludes with this comment: "The Spirit of the Lord was poured out in a very powerful manner, never to be forgotten by those present on this interesting occasion" (Ibid., page 607). The Prophet explained how women of the Church would come into possession of the blessings of the Priesthood. He spoke of delivering the keys of the Priesthood to the Church, and said that the faithful members of the Relief Society should receive them in connection with their husbands.... He exhorted the sisters always to concentrate their faith and prayers for, and place confidence in their husbands, whom God has appointed for them to honor, and in those faithful men whom God has placed at the head of the Church to lead His people; that we should arm and sustain them with our prayers.... You must put down iniquity, and by your own good example, stimulate the Elders to good works (Ibid., IV, pp. 604-605). He emphasized that women might attain the blessings of the Priesthood "'by a virtuous life... And diligence in keeping all the commandments." He also cautioned: All must act in concert, or nothing can be done, and should move according to the ancient Priesthood; hence the Saints should be a select people, separate from the evils of the world—choice, virtuous, and holy (Ibid., IV, page 570). The late Elder John A. Widtsoe has written of the sharing by Latter-day Saint women in the blessings of the Priesthood: The Priesthood is for the benefit of all members of the Church. Men have no greater claim than women upon the blessings that issue from the Priesthood and accompany its possession.... The man holds the Priesthood, performs the priestly duties of the Church, but his wife enjoys with him every other privilege derived from the possession of the Priesthood. This is made clear, as an example, in the Temple service of the Church. The ordinances of the Temple are distinctly of Priesthood character, yet women have access to all of them, and the highest blessings of the Temple are conferred only upon a man and his wife jointly (Priesthood and Church Government, page 83). The fact that women are not ordained to the Priesthood should not be regarded as a denial of a blessing. The different and distinct roles of man and woman entitle them to different blessings, for indeed, "... Male and female created he them" (Gen. 1:27). Latter-day Saint women who do not have members of their families who hold the Priesthood, can still enjoy blessings of the Priesthood by calling upon the elders as need may arise to administer to their spiritual needs, and through Church service they may be directed by the Priesthood in their various callings. Perhaps the rarest gift within the power of God to bestow, that of motherhood, is a blessing only women can enjoy. If they devote themselves to this sacred responsibility, whether mothering their own children or children of others, they will neither feel nor express any resent- 778 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT ment for gifts or authority they do not have. Rather, they will consider their calling the greatest and the best suited to their natures. Women find satisfying expression for many of their talents, but no other pursuit is as full of rich blessings and opportunities as that of being mothers in Zion. 'Their mission as mothers should be regarded as their most important responsibility. Although man and woman were created to fill distinctly different missions on earth, it was not intended that one be inferior to the other. "Neither is the man without the woman, neither the woman without the man, in the Lord" (I Cor. 11:11). Children, reared in a home where the father assumes the role as head of the house worthily and the mother honors her husband's Priesthood, are fortunate indeed. The example of parents truly living their religion provides children with inspiration for a similar venture. Herein lies opportunity to influence favorably the lives of children. 'They learn from childhood the patriarchal order in the kingdom of God and will grow to maturity with a desire to pattern their own homes after the Lord's plan. A wife and children should take great pride in observing their husband and father officiate in the important ordinances involving the family, such as the blessing and naming of his children, baptizing, confirming, and ordaining them in the Priesthood. 'The way he presides at the table and at family prayer will also leave a lasting impression. 'These sacred moments are sermons in themselves, and their influence cannot be overemphasized. 779 Pleasant memories of experiences shared together unify the family group. There are abundant opportunities for women to make fond memories of experiences in which the Priesthood is involved. Special occasions should be made of ordinations and advancements of sons in the Priesthood. In this way a mother can impress on her sons the divine nature of the authority they receive and show her pride in seeing them officiate in Priesthood assignments. How commendable it is for a mother to plan the dinner to suit the liking of her son on his ordination day, or for the family to plan a special home evening in his honor. Such signs of interest will never be forgotten by a faithful son. Mothers should impress upon their daughters the importance of encouraging the Priesthood bearers of the family in their Priesthood assignments, atranging the affairs of the household so they will not interfere with such appointments as weekly Priesthood meetings, ward teaching, welfare assignments, leadership meetings, etc. Such training, absorbed from the mother's example, will establish a proper pattern for young girls and will give them a desire to seek mates who hold, honor, and magnify the Priesthood. Women As Help Mates When the first woman was created by the Lord, she was designated as "'an help meet" to her husband. This placed upon woman a responsibility which has remained unchanged. 'The woman who encourages her husband to perform all his Priesthood duties is honoring this responsibility. Unless this is done, the full measure of her Priesthood blessings will not be realized. On many occasions the Prophet acknowledged his wife's devotion with gratitude and affection. She was his constant companion, regardless of the dangers to be encountered. In addition, she assumed responsible leadership as president of the Nauvoo Relief Society, with grace and dignity. She maintained a home which was the gathering place of her husband's friends. They were always made welcome, whether on brief visits or extended stays. One guest described her as the Prophet's "excellent wife, a woman of superior ability." Realizing the importance of every woman's assistance to her husband, the Prophet gave the following specific instructions to the Relief Society: Let this Society teach women how to behave towards their husbands, to treat them with mildness and affection. When a man is borne down with trouble, when he is perplexed with care and difficulty, if he can meet a smile instead of an argument or a murmur — if he can meet with mildness, it will calm down his soul and soothe his feelings; when the mind is going to despair, it needs a solace of affection and kindness (D. H. C. IV, pp. 606-607). When you go home, never give a cross or unkind word to your husbands, but let kindness, charity and love crown your works henceforward... (Ibid., page 607). You need not be teasing your husbands because of their deeds, but let the weight of your innocence, kindness and affection be felt, which is more mighty than a millstone hung about the neck; not war, not jangle, not contradiction, or dispute, but meekness, love, purity—these are the things that should magnify you in the eyes of all good men (Ibid., page 605). These instructions infer that woman's influence has no limit if exerted in the proper manner, and Latter-day Saint''women everywhere would do well to follow these instructions religiously. Relief Society Supports the Priesthood The Nauvoo Female Relief Society became a source of great strength to the early Church leadership. This same support is felt today, in wards and stakes throughout the Church, wherever smoothly operated Relief Society organizations are functioning. When the women of the Church assume their full load, it becomes possible for the elders to "give their time to other duties, etc., in their public teachings" as the Prophet suggested. A unique experience in the Nauvoo Relief Society illustrates the support that organization gave to the Prophet Joseph personally: About the last of July, 1842, when some of the officials of Missouri were taking measures to drag President Joseph Smith from Illinois by an illegal process, the F. R. [Female Relief] Society sent a petition to Thomas Carlin, Governor of Illinois, in behalf of President Smith, claiming his protection as chief magistrate. The petition was signed by every member of the Society, and presented by its President, Mrs. Emma Smith, accompanied by Mrs. Amanda Smith and Miss E. R. Snow. The Governor's residence was in Quincy, fifty miles south from Nauvoo (Woman's Exponent, Vol. 1, No. 2). In July 1842, the Prophet Joseph wrote: The "Ladies Relief Society" also drew up a petition signed by about one thousand ladies, speaking in the highest terms of the virtue, philanthropy and benevo- 780 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—NOVEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT lence of Joseph Smith, begging that he might not be injured, and that they and their families might have the privilege of enjoying their peaceable rights (D. H. C., V, page 71). On August 31, 1842, the Prophet Joseph Smith attended the Relief Society meeting and thanked the women for their interest and activity in his behalf. The Female Relief Society have taken a most active part in my welfare against my enemies, in petitioning to the governor in my behalf. These measures were all necessary.... If these measures had not been taken, more serious consequences would have resulted. I have come here to bless you. The Society have done well: their principles are to practice holiness. God loves you and your prayers in my behalf shall avail much; let them not cease to ascend to God continually in my behalf (D. H. C., V, pp. 140-141). The Prophet also expressed his appreciation to the Governor in a letter dated July 30, 1842: I cannot let this opportunity pass without tendering to you my warmest thanks for the friendly treatment my lady as well as those with her received at your hands during the late visit, and also for the friendly feelings breathed forth in your letter... (D. H. C., V, page 83). The Prophet could always expect the full support of the Nauvoo Relief Society with respect to their official assignment in the Church. They regarded most seriously the charges given them by the Priesthood. Many instances in Relief Society history since that time illustrate how the Priesthood and Relief Society, when working together effectively, have been of reciprocal benefit. President Joseph F. Smith has said. There are people fond of saying that women are the weaker vessels. I don't believe it. Physically, they may be; but spiritually, morally, religiously and in faith, what man can match a woman who is really convinced?... They are always more willing to make sacrifices, and are the peers of men in stability, Godliness, morality and faith... (President Joseph Fielding Smith, Priesthood and Church Government, page 86). Upholding Church Leaders Relief Society members are not only expected to sustain their husbands and sons in their Priesthood callings, but to uphold those who preside over the Church, whether they be General Authorities, stake officers, or ward leaders. Latter-day Saint women are given the opportunity in Church assemblies to cast a sustaining vote for the leaders of the Church. A vote to sustain and honor the leadership of the Church is a pledge to uphold those who preside. In the home, children should never hear criticism of Church leaders from the lips of their parents. Such an attitude might plant a seed which will not only destroy the child's confidence in the Authorities of the Church, but lessen his respect for parents who display such disloyalty. Abundant happiness and_blessings are found in the Latter-day Saint home where the husband and wife, with mutual affection, honor and sustain each other in their respective callings. Of what significance is the "setting apart" ordinance in performing Church assignments? 5. How can women of the Church sustain their husbands and sons in Priesthood callings? Madsen Members, General Board of Relief Society Thy blessing on this house, dear Lord, And bless the earth on which it stands; For here is a witness to our faith in thee, A testament of willing hands; a dream— A cherished dream come true. Let thy protecting spirit arm its sturdy walls, Defending them from harm. Beneath its sheltering roof O let there be peace as proof That harmony and love abide within— That love and harmony abide within. For Jesus said, "Ye shall do the work Which ye see me do." Help us, Lord, to ever keep, Thy great command to "feed my sheep," That angels shall companion us Who serve thee in thy holy cause, And truth and knowledge ever flow In promised blessings on our heads. O let thy spirit ever be With those who build this house to thee, That all may grow in faith and love And glorify thy holy name, Thy holy name, O Lord!
