Madsen Elder Alexander Schreiner at the Organ Dedicatory Prayer of the Relief Society Building PRESIDENT Davin O. McKay Presented in The Relief Society Building, Salt Lake City, October 3, 1956 OD) ur Heavenly and Eternal Father, the Giver of all Good, the Bestower of all Blessings, "Hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done in earth, as it is in heaven." We are grateful that thou hast revealed Thyself again to the children of men in this age of the world; that to the Prophet Joseph Smith thou didst appear as a Personal Being, and authoritatively introduced Jesus The Christ, saying "This is my Beloved Son, Hear Him." For this, one of the greatest Revelations of all Time, in behalf of thy sincere children everywhere, we express deep gratitude. We are grateful that through the bestowal of the Holy Priesthood, Thou didst authorize men to represent Thee on earth; that by that divine authority the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints was organized as when Christ was on the earth with Apostles, Prophets, Pastors, Teachers, Evangelists, etc., "for the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the ministry, for the edifying of the body of Christ: "Till we all come in the unity of the faith, and of the knowledge of the Son of God, unto a perfect man, unto the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ." More potent for the good and happiness of the Church members than we realize are the Priesthood Quorums for the men, and the Auxiliary organizations for the women. These Thou hast placed in the Church for mutual service. In serving one another, we serve our Lord and Savior, who himself hath said: "Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me." On this memorable occasion, we praise thy name for the organization of the Relief Society of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, for the thousands of loyal, faithful, beautiful women who compose its membership. Their devotion to duty is never-ending; their loyalty to Thee and to Thy Priesthood unquestioned; their administrations to the sick and to the needy, untiring; their sympathetic, gentle services give hope to the dying, comfort and faith to the bereaved. O Father, bless these, thy choice, beloved Handmaidens! We ask especially for thy divine guidance to continue to attend President Belle S. Spafford in her great responsibilities, not only in the Church but in the Nation. Likewise bless her able, efficient Counselors, Sister Marianne C. Sharp, and Sister Velma N. Simonsen, and each and every Board Member, and their successors throughout the coming years. Bless also the Stake and Ward Presidents of Relief Societies throughout Page 788 the Church, including those in the Missions and Branches. We thank Thee for their faith and service. Wilt thou sustain them while they continue in their work of administering to the sick and to the afflicted and in bringing light and wisdom to the women of the Church. To make more effective their service to the needy and suffering to those in the Church and in the World, the Relief Society has erected with the aid of the Church membership this beautiful Relief Society home in which the Presidency and members of the General Board may function more effectively in instructing, guiding, and rendering helpful aid to the Stakes, Wards, and Missionary Branches wherever organized. To aid in the erection of this edifice, in its utility and beauty, contributions have come from individuals and groups in Nations throughout the world wherever the Church is organized. For their generosity, self-sacrifice and love of a glorious Cause, O Lord, bless the givers fourfold. And now, representing them, and by the authority of the Holy Priesthood, we dedicate this building of the Relief Society of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints unto Thee, Holy Father, and set it apart to be used for the purposes for which it has been erected. Accept it, O Lord, and hallow it by Thy protecting influence. Shield it from destructive elements, and may it stand undefaced, a solid structure from foundation to roof, until its every purpose shall have been accomplished. To this end, we dedicate every room; every hallway; every stairway on every floor from basement to garret, with all the furnishings, gifts of art, draperies, and other things supplied for the comfort and need of those who labor within these walls. We dedicate the plumbing, heating and cooling systems, the electric wiring in its entirety, and all other appurtenances, and pray that the custodians in charge may be ever alert, watchful, and wise. May the offices occupied by the Presidency and Board Members be hallowed by the sweet influence of the Holy Spirit; likewise, the rooms occupied by the faithful women employed in making Holy garments, or occupied in secretarial duties, or associated in any manner with the Relief Society Magazine. We dedicate the grounds. May the building and surroundings radiate a hallowed influence even to passersby, as perfume is wafted from sweet-scented flowers. Help us, O Lord, to overcome our weaknesses; strengthen us wherein we are weak; that we may more ably and effectively discharge the responsibilities that Thou hast placed upon us. As we dedicate this edifice, we also dedicate our lives to Thy service, and pray for divine assistance in all our efforts to serve Thee by serving Thy children. This dedication, this expression of our deep gratitude, this re-commitment to Thy service, we humbly render unto Thee this day, in the name of Thy Beloved Son, Jesus Christ, Amen. DEDICATORY PRAYER 789 Dedicatory Service of the Relief Society Building Held in the Tabernacle and Relief Society Building October 3, 1956 President Spafford: These Dedicatory Services for The Relief Society Building are under the direction of the First Presidency of the Church with President David O. McKay presiding. President McKay has kindly requested me to conduct the meeting. We are grateful for the presence today of all three members of the First Presidency — President David O. McKay, President Stephen L Richards, and President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. We acknowledge with gratitude the presence of other General Authorities of the Church. We appreciate the attendance of a number of other prominent Church leaders including representatives of the other auxiliary general boards. We are honored by the presence of distinguished State, county, and city officials. We are pleased to have with us Sister Emma Ray McKay, the wife of our President, and also Sister Irene Richards. Sister Richards' grandmother was the fourth general president of Relief Society. We are happy to have with us the wives of Genera] Authorities. We are pleased to have with us the wives of mission presidents from the North American missions, along with many devoted officers and members of Relief Society from both the stakes and missions of Church. We are very happy to have with us our former general president, Sister Amy Brown Lyman. Page 790 We welcome all who are assembled here today, together with those assembled in the Assembly Hall and Barrett Hall where the service is being televised. We appreciate the services of KSL-T'V in televising this program to these buildings. We have received many messages from Relief Societies and friends expressing their gratitude for this great occasion for Relief Society. Time will not permit us to read these messages. We will open the meeting by the combined chorus of Singing Mothers from the Bear River, Malad, North Box Elder, South Bear River, South Box Elder, Ben Lomond, East Ogden, Farr West, Lake View, Lorin Farr, Mount Ogden, North Weber, Ogden, Riverdale, South Ogden, Weber, Summit, and South Carolina Stakes singing "Home, Sweet Home." The singing this afternoon will be conducted by Sister Florence Jepperson Madsen, member of the general board, with Elder Alexander Schreiner accompanying the singing at the organ. Following the singing, in recognition of Relief Societies everywhere which have worked together as one to bring to fulfillment the desire for a Relief Society Building, sisters representing the nations of the world where Relief Societies are organized, will assemble. When the sisters are seated, Elder Mark E. Petersen, member of the Council of the Twelve, and an ad- DEDICATORY SERVICE 791 visor to the general board of Relief The Singing Mothers chorus sang Society, will offer the invocation, "Home, Sweet Home." Invocation— Dedicatory Service Exper Mark E. PETERSEN Of the Council of the Twelve OM) on Heavenly and Eternal Father, as thy humble children, we have gathered here this afternoon to worship thee and to thank thee for thy bounteous blessings to us. We have met this afternoon at the conclusion of a great enterprise undertaken by the Relief Society sisters of thy great Church. And at this time, we honor them and thank thee for them. We are grateful for the mighty mission they carry forward here in the earth. In all humility, we thank thee for their faith and their devotion and for the outstanding influence they have here in the earth, in their families and homes, in the Church, and also in the communities in which they live. They are, indeed, thine handmaidens here in the earth. They have with them a divine power. We acknowledge it; we thank thee for them. We thank thee for the great Relief Society organization, and for the women who have headed it and who carry on in the various wards and stakes and missions and in the general board. We thank thee that thou didst inspire the great Prophet, Joseph Smith, to organize this society, and we are grateful that it has carried on over the years and fulfilled such a great mission. Our Father, we this afternoon are to conduct this program in connection with the dedication of the beautiful new headquarters of the Relief Society; and thy great servant, President McKay, has come here to dedicate this great building — The Relief Society Building. We humbly ask that thou wilt inspire him as he does so. We pray that thou wilt be with all who take part in this dedicatory service, that all may be done under the direction of thy Holy Spirit. We are thankful for all of the women who have contributed for the construction of this Building and for its beautification. And now, Father, we pray that as the Building is about to be dedicated, that we may all be dedicated in our hearts to further service in thy great cause. And we ask thine especial blessings on the entire Relief Society organization, that it may be prospered, that it may grow, that it may bring a message of conversion, conviction, and of happiness and of comfort to the many, many thousands who will be the recipients of the labors of the sisters. Father in heaven, we now pray that thou wilt be with us during these services, guide all that is done, accept our gratitude for all thou hast given, and we do it all in the name of the Lord, Jesus Christ. Amen. President Spafford: The Singing Mothers will now sing "If Ye Love Me, Keep My Commandments." 'This anthem is a composition of Sister Florence Jepperson Madsen. Following the singing, Sister Marianne C. Sharp, Counselor in the general presidency of Relief Society and Chairman of the Building Committee from the beginning, will give a brief report of the building program. The Singing Mothers chorus sang "If Ye Love Me, Keep My Commandments." Report of Relief Society Building Activities Counselor Marianne C. Sharp T has been eleven years since || Sister Spafford, with the approval of the First Presidency, proposed to the members of Relief Society convened in the Relief Society general conference of 1945, that they undertake the erection of a Relief Society Building. The proposition was enthusiastically approved. In 1947, two years later, at the general Relief Society conference, a financial plan, approved by the First Presidency, was presented and adopted whereby the sisters within a year would raise half a million dollars for the Building, with the understanding that the Church would match this amount. Every member of Relief Society in the stakes was expected to contribute five dollars—for this was to be an undertaking of the many. In addition, each stake board was asked to contribute half of its funds on hand as of January 1947. No quotas were given to the missions by the general board. Participation was left entirely to the discretion of the respective mission presidents. 'The European missions, in the aftermath of war, were not expected to contribute at all. When the sisters gathered for the 1948 Relief Society general conference, one year later, they came rejoicing. All stakes in the Church (at that time numbering 172) were recognized for filling their quotas. As of October 1948 there was contributed by the membership of Relief Society in stakes over $457,000; from stake board funds over $36,000; with a few very generous contributions from individuals. 'The missions outside Europe, under the direction of their mission presidents, had entered into this undertaking 722 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 with great enthusiasm also, and a total of nearly $48,000 was contributed within that year by the missions of the Church. The great goal of half a million dollars had been reached and exceeded by nearly $70,000. In the years which have elapsed since October 1948, contributions in money have come in from European missions. Many missions located in foreign countries have also sent a beautiful object of art representing the respective countries. These now beautify the building. And, during the past few months, many stakes have presented lovely and useful gifts to add that woman's touch to make The Relief Society Building truly the embodiment of the culture, tasteful furnishings, and bounteous living which we, as Latter-day Saint women, enjoy in our own individual homes. The Church had agreed to match Relief Society funds to half a million dollars. The million dollars was all needed for the erection as prices had gone up and there still remained the Building to be furnished. The general board, you will recall, had contributions of over a half million dollars. Back we went to the First Presidency. Would they now be so generous as to match collected funds, including accrued interest, and reserve funds to a total of $100,000 — thus allowing $200,000 for furnishings and equipment and to include any overtun on the Building? HE First Presidency were most considerate and generous and agreed to match this additional $100,000 dollars. The costs here related do not include the value of the site. The site, "in the shadow of the temple" which was our first choice for a site, was granted to us by the First Presidency in October 1952. Ground for the Building was broken on October 1, 1953. 'The cornerstone was laid on September 30, 1954. In it were placed materials of historic interest and the names of all contributors to The Relief Society Building. A copy of these names is today bound in two volumes in the Building. A third volume will contain pictures of gifts which have been contributed with the names of the donors. And so today, in the hearts of all Relief Society members, there is a feeling of humble gratitude for the Church, for its understanding of the needs and desires of the women of the Church. All Relief Society members throughout the lands of the earth are with us today in spirit as they have been with us in contributing of their means with sacrifice for The Relief Society Building. In deep humility we thank our Heavenly Father for numberless blessings and we do so in the name of his son, our Savior, Jesus Christ. Sharp; President Belle S. Spafford; Counselor Velma N. Simonsen. Page 798 We Built As One President Belle S. Spafford T is a choice privilege to be here today and to participate in this long-awaited and important event in the history of Relief Society—the Dedication of 'The Relief Society Building. It has been eleven years since Relief Society women took upon themselves, by vote of the sisters assembled in a general Relief Society conference, the task of erecting a Relief Society Building, one that should be montumental, beautiful, and adequate to serve the society, not only for the present, but in the years to come. Even as the sisters raised their hands in support of the proposal, the magnitude of the undertaking was recognized, but inspired by dreams of the past, urged by present needs, moved by devotion to Relief Society, imbued with indomitable faith and courage and, above all, having the support and approval of the First Presidency, the Relief Society sisters launched a building program that, in so far as I know, has no precedent among organized women. Today the building stands completed—strong in its construction, beautiful in its furnishings, functional in its arrangement. I invite your attention to the simple elegance of its classic design, the beauty of the materials of which it is built—its stones, bronze, marbles, and woods; the convenient arrangement of its rooms; the expert craftsmanship in evidence throughout the structure; its artistic decor; its inviting portal; its spirit of love and peace—all uniting to form the kind of Relief Society home envisioned in the long ago. As the building program has progressed, there have been both happy and anxious days. It was a happy day when the financial goal of onehalf million dollars, to be raised by Relief Society members for erecting the building, was reached. We rejoiced when the First Presidency granted to us the choice building site, literally in the shadow of the temple. We were delighted when ground was broken, and a year later when the cornerstone was set. As we watched the walls rise and the building take shape, our happiness was superseded only by our gratitude. Anxious days accompanied the study and approval of the building plans, the making of countless important decisions incident to the erection and furnishing of the building, and the management of the trusted funds. Uncertainties assailed us at times. One day we wondered if we had built too large, only to wonder the following day if we had built large enough. The pronounced awareness of the tesponsibilities entrusted to us and the far-reaching effects of our decisions have been with us continually and have sent us often to our Father in heaven in earnest prayer. Regardless of the responsibilities and worries, however, there has never been a moment when we have felt to regret the decision to build or when we have wished that we Page 799 might turn back in our course. Always there has been within our hearts the assurance that the undertaking was right, and the conviction that this was the day when, in the kind providence of the Lord, Relief Society was to have a home of its own. FE, have been immeasurably sustained in the undertaking from the beginning by the encouragement, counsel, and support of the First Presidency and the other General Authorities of the Church and by the devotion to the program of the Relief Society sisters. Talented professional _ persons, skilled craftsmen, gifted artisans, workmen with expert technical knowledge and proficiency have assisted us in the realization of our building goal. I mention the services of Bishop George Cannon Young, architect, and his associate, Brother Richard Wood; the contractors; the late Brother Frank J. Fullmer and his sons, Brothers Frank H. Fullmer and David H. Fullmer, with their associate, Brother Willard L. Fullmer; also the construction foreman, Brother Harry Mabey. I mention, also, the services of the decorator, Miss Marian Cornwall. We express our thanks to each of these, as well as to those who have been associated with them. Also, I express thanks to the former and present Church Building Committees. We acknowledge with appreciation the assistance given us by the Church Purchasing Department, as well as that given us by other departments of the Church. Humbling indeed has been the devotion of Relief Society sisters to the program as evidenced by their interest in it and their contributions toward it—all clear and unmistakable evidence of their love for and devotion to Relief Society. Readily they met, by individual and collective effort, their great assignment to raise one-half million dollars within a period of one year. 'To this have been added, voluntarily, gifts of funds ranging from a small handful of pennies contributed by a faithful and loving sister to larger gifts from individual sisters, from groups of sisters, and from ward and stake, mission and branch Relief Societies —all faithful and devoted sisters. These gifts were contributed to the end that there might be in their Relief Society home some special article of beauty or usefulness that otherwise might have been denied. Choice gifts of handwork, even precious heirlooms, have been presented to the building, expressions of love for Relief Society from Relief Society sisters. RARE gifts of beauty and artistry representative of the culture of the nations of the earth where Relief Societies are organized, adorn the building. 'These are there because 800 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 WE BUILT AS ONE of the love of Relief Society sisters in faraway lands for their organization and because of their desire to have their Relief Society Building, so far removed from them, reflect the aesthetic creations of their homelands. The building program has been a cohesive, unifying force within the Relief Societies. From far north lands to the sunny south, from the little villages in the islands of the sea to the great metropolitan centers, it has sealed together as one the sisterhood of Relief Society. Out of this program have come untold blessings of immeasurable worth. HE fire of enthusiasm for the program has touched the hearts of many kind friends, not members of Relief Society, whose interest and generosity have been both encouraging and helpful. Many sisters, long since departed from among us, are memorialized by gifts and contributions of funds. Today we are happy and grateful to present to the First Presidency for dedication, a building which we feel fittingly represents the enduring qualities of Relief Society, one which we feel represents the spirit and character of Latter-day Saint womanhood in its strength, its beauty, and its usefulness. Humbly and gratefully we express thanks to our Heavenly Father for the completion of our Relief 801 Society home and for his boundless blessings unto Relief Society. We pray that all that shall go forth from our Relief Society home shall enrich the lives and lead toward the eternal well-being of the daughters of our Heavenly Father. We pray that the new building may facilitate the work of our divinely inspired, Priesthood-directed society, and enable the sisters to serve effectively as the handmaids of the Priesthood in the great work of the Church. That the choice blessings of the Lord may ever rest upon Relief Society, upon this home which we dedicate today, and upon each of us I sincerely pray. He will be followed by President Richards. Motherhood President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. M: brethren, and especially my sisters, wives and daughters of the Priesthood, I can think of this gathering as a gathering of the household of the Church, the Priesthood represented as it is, and those who help them, those who make the homes, build the families, and lead them, for the individuals and for the Church. This was the first companion, this Relief Society, which the Lord gave to the Priesthood organization in these the latter-days. To that first companion have been added others, as we have gone forward in the history and the making of the Church. Our Heavenly Father sees that we worship today in the midst of the nations as signified by these flags in witness of the world-wide organization of the Church. Even as we witness that so we must understand, zhat we have our responsibilities, not alone here nor in this country but throughout the world. I am impressed today with this thought: The mother of Jesus the Christ was mortal; his Father was divine. Out of the untold myriads and myriads of spirits Mary was chosen to come here, to be the mother of the Christ—a privilege granted to no other woman-spirit in all the history of the world. As there was one Christ, so there was one mother of Christ. And that motherhood, the spirit of it, carries over to each of you who are members of the Relief Society, as we address you today. Page 802 Out of that lesson should come, as it seems to me, a sanctification not only but a dedication upon the part of each and every sister in the Church, a dedication to fulfill for some spirit waiting to come to this earth, the same service that Mary performed in bringing to us this Jesus the Christ. How transcendent is the mission, how glorious is the purpose, how fruitful is the result! God give us strength, each of us, us of the Priesthood, the fathermembers of our Church household; you, the mothers of that great Church household, give to each of us the spirit we need to carry on, to build this great Church, to take care of the needs, you sisters, of those who suffer, give you the strength to carry out the divine purposes declared by the Prophet Joseph when he organized you. Leaving with you my witness that God lives, that he loves us, that he answers prayers; that Jesus is the Christ, that he lived, was resurrected, the Atoner for the Fall of Adam, our Savior; that we have the restored gospel and the restored Priesthood, and that from the Prophet Joseph until now the head of the Church, the President of the Church has had the keys, the powers, and the authorities conferred upon the Prophet Joseph—leaving that witness with you I close, praying God to bless you all, in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen, An Enduring Tribute to Visiting 'Teachers President Stephen L Richards RESIDENT McKay, President P Clark, Sister Spafford and Counselors, members and friends of Relief Society: I propose to take just a few moments on this impressive occasion to tell you about a picture. I trust that it may not be inappropriate for the occasion. The picture I have in mind is one of the most famous in our land. It is the painting called "The Doctor." Most of you have seen it. I saw it staged in heroic style with artificial characters at a World's Fair in Chicago. It depicts, as you will remember, a room scantily furnished in the home of a poor man. All the surroundings tell you he is poor. The focus of interest is a little sick child lying on an improvised bed made on chairs. A mother is near, with sad, weeping countenance, and the father also, with an expression of deep anxiety and fear. Over the little child bends the professional figure of "The Doctor," intently watching and waiting. The implements of his profession—his satchel and medicine bottles—are near at hand, but at the moment he is not using any of them. Apparently he has done what he could, and is now watching and waiting. He could be praying, also. This picture has won universal acclaim not only among the medical profession, but with all people who can read its meaning. It is meant to portray the dedication of science to human relief from suffering and pain, even among the lowliest. It shows a man with the insignia of his professional training in a day that has passed — a black Prince Albert coat, immaculately groomed, with an expression of compassion and sympathy, giving not only his skill but his heart, to a poor sick child. HAT picture reminds me forcefully of something about this dedication. If I had the skill of an artist I could substitute for the doctor in the picture two modest women, perhaps untrained scientifically, but filled with human compassion and skilled in the art of extending love and sympathy, and material aid, also, to the sick and the needy. I would replace the medical satchel with a basket filled with substantial tokens of sympathy, but covered with a shawl to make it less conspicuous. Such substitutions would make a picture of a real scene which has been enacted over and over again for more than a century of time in the homes of the sick and of the distressed in all the communities where the Latter-day Saints have been established. I would call the picture, "The Visiting Teachers." I like to think of this beautiful building to be dedicated this day by the President of the Church, although it is monumental and imposing in its architecture and embellishments, as being in large measure a merited recognition of, and an enduring tribute to the Visiting Teachers of the Relief Societies of Page 803 the Church, who epitomize the heart and soul, the compassion, the mercy, and the Christ-like service of this great organization. It is the personal touch in a day of ever-increasing institutional and_ professional charity. I hope it may never vanish nor weaken, and I could wish that some artistic representation on canvas, in art glass or in bronze, might be procured for suitable placement in the building to accentuate and perpetuate enduring esteem for this lovely feature of Relief Society work. Extend congratulations to the officers and members of the Relief Society in this great accomplishment Contributions to the erection of the building were solicited on such a wide base that the whole membership may feel a_ personal interest in the building. I trust and I pray that it may prove a boon to the noble work of the society, that it may bring honor and respect to the Church of Christ, that above all, through its facilities increased impetus may be brought to the work of ministering to the needs of family life, assisting and encouraging mothers in particular and the home in general to achieve its lofty station as the stabilizing factor of society and the forerunner of exaltation in the Celestial Kingdom of our Father. God bless you, my sisters, I ask humbly in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen. President Spafford: It is now our privilege and blessing to hear from our beloved Prophet and President, President David O. McKay. Following President McKay's address, the congregation will sing "We Thank Thee, O God, for a Prophet," during which President McKay, accompanied by President Richards and President Clark, will retire to The Relief Society Building where President McKay will offer the Dedicatory Prayer from the General Board Room on the main floor of the Building. William Beal 804 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 Women's Influence and Responsibility President David O. McKay RESIDENT Richards, President Clark, President Spafford and Counselors, members of the General Board of Relief Society, brethren and sisters: When one contemplates what the Creator expects and receives from his most precious creation, one is thoroughly convinced that woman has his divine trust and favor. The poet 'Tennyson's statement —"The Mother Makes Us Most' — has now become, at least throughout the Western civilization, a truism. Sow a thought, reap an act, Sow an act, reap a habit, Sow a habit, reap a character, Sow a character, reap an eternal destiny. "Not only individuals, but Nations are such stuff as thoughts are made of." Mothers sow the seeds in childhood that determine to a great extent life's harvests in adulthood. Motherhood, therefore, is the greatest potential influence either for good or ill in human life. The mother's image is the first that stamps itself upon the unwritten page of the young child's mind. It is her caress that first awakens a sense of security; her kiss, the first realization of affection; her sympathy and tenderness, the first assurance that there is love in the world. 'True, there comes a time when Father takes his place as exemplar in the young child's mind; and in the latter's budding ambition to develop manly traits, he outwardly seems to turn from the more gentle and tender virtues engendered by the mother. But that ever-directing and restraining influence implanted during the first years of his childhood lingers with him and permeates his thoughts and memory as distinctively as perfume clings to each particular flower. In more than one instance in the life of fiery youth, this lingering influence has proved a safeguard in the hour of temptation—an influence in its restraining power greater than the threat of the law of the land, the ostracism of society, or the fear of violating a command of God. In a moment of youthful recklessness the youth might defy one or all of these forces, and do what his hot blood bade, but at the critical moment, the flash of a mother's confiding trust, the realization of her sorrow if he fail to be true to it have given him power to refrain from indulgence that might blight his entire career. Not only the mother, but the entire influence of home also influences society. Indeed, home is the foundation of civilized society. Words uttered and the doctrines taught around the fireside are the influences that shape the destinies of empires. The cultivation of home influence, the need of harmony in the home, are contributing factors to a successful democratic government. To be destitute of this sentiment is almost as great a misfortune, says Page 805 one man, as to be destitute of the religious sentiment. "What a mighty responsibility," I quote, "rests upon him who essays to make a home, for the founding of a home is as sacred a work as the founding of a church. Indeed, every home should be a temple dedicated to divine worship, where human beings through life should worship God through the service of mutual love—the highest tribute man can pay to the divine." "Of all human influences those of home are the most far-reaching in their results." ARRIAGE and subsequent home life are ordained of God. Home is based in the very constitution of human nature, and so vital is the relation which it sustains to our needs, that every heart must have a home. "It may not be of brick or wood or stone," says a writer in "Our Home." "It may not have a 'local habitation and a name.' But if not, out of the airy timbers of its own fancy the heart will rear the structure which it demands as a necessity of its being. We are aware that there are thousands who are called homeless; but their hearts' demand is at least partially met by the possession of an ideal home (in their minds). The body may exist without a home, but the heart, never. The world called Howard Payne a homeless wanderer; yet kings and peasants have implored entrance at the vine-wreathed threshold of that home which he reared in the airy dreamland of poesy." And that song "Home, Sweet Home," was sung today by these blessed mothers under the masterful baton of Sister Madsen more impressively than perhaps we shall ever hear it again. Of all human influences those around home contribute to the welfare of humanity. "There are many men who owe their honor, their integrity, and their manhood to the influence of pure minded sisters. Sisters usually have it in their power to shape the character of their brothers as they choose. It is natural for all brothers to feel and believe that in some way their sisters are purer and better than others, and sisters also believe that their brothers are nobler than the brothers of their associates. 'This sentiment is so universal that we cannot help believing it was ordained for a wise purpose. "Morals, manners, methods—" writes the author from whom I quoted, "the principal concomitants of character—have their inception and largely their development within the home. It is at once one of the most civilizing and demoralizing of human agencies. It may be a lazar house of vice, strife, improvidence, unfaith, prostituting every budding power, or it may be the sanctuary of domestic felicity, kindness, truthfulness, philanthropy, bestowing continued benedictions upon each member and radiating the light of human joy." I have dwelt thus at length upon the influence and responsibility of motherhood and of the home to emphasize the added responsibility given to these precious women to bless humankind. Not any of the duties of motherhood, not any, was proscribed—none of the responsibilities of the home limited—when on March 17, 1842, the Female Relief Society of Nauvoo was 806 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 WOMEN'S INFLUENCE AND RESPONSIBILITY organized. The work of the Relief Society was to be performed in addition to the duties of motherhood and home. Do you wonder, I say, that woman has not only the trust but the blessing of Almighty God. "T now turn the key in your behalf in the name of the Lord, and this Society shall rejoice, and knowledge and intelligence shall flow down from this time henceforth; this is the beginning of better days to the poor and needy, who shall be made to rejoice and pour forth blessings on your heads," said the Prophet Joseph Smith, when he organized the Female Relief Society of the Church. Eliza R. Snow put in rhyme the duties as follows: It is an institution formed to bless The poor, the widow and the fatherless. To clothe the naked, and the hungry feed, And in the holy paths of virtue lead. To seek out sorrow, grief and mute despair, And light the lamp of hope eternal, there; To try the strength of consolation's art By breathing comfort to the aching heart. To chase the clouds that shade the aspect where Distress presides, and wake up pleasures there. With open hearts, extend the fnendly hand To hail the stranger from a distant land. To stamp a vetoing impress on each move That virtue's present dictates disapprove; To put the tattler's coinage scandal down, And make corruption feel its withering frown. To give instruction where instruction's voice Will guard the feet and make the heart rejoice; To turn the wayward from their recklessness, And lead them in the path of happiness. "Tis an order fitted and designed To meet the wants of body and of mind; To seek the wretched in their true abode, 807 Supply their wants, and raise their hearts to God. Y divine decree, the women in the Church are assigned the noble mission of being exemplars and leaders to mankind in the two most worthwhile accomplishments in mortal life. First, the development of character. That is done in the home principally. Second, willingness and ability to render helpful service—that through the organized Relief Society. These two accomplishments, by the way, are all that we shall take with us when, at the end of our earthly career, we pass through the portals called Death into the realm of the Eternal—Character and Service. God bless you, beloved of the Lord, the most precious of his creations, that you may fulfill to his satisfaction his purposes designed for the members of the Female Rehief Society, I humbly pray in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen. The congregation sang "We Thank Thee, O God, for a Prophet." Benediction—Dedicatory Service PRESIDENT JOSEPH FIELDING SmITH Of the Council of the Twelve Ol) 2 Father in heaven, we have now come to the conclusion of these inspired services—the dedication of the building for the Relief Societies. We pray thee, Father, that thy spirit may rest upon these sisters who will occupy this building. They have done a wonderful work from the days of the Prophet until now. Be with those who preside, the members of their general board, that they may go forth in the power of thy spirit, building up and strengthening the sisters of the Church. Guide them, we pray thee, by the counsels of the Holy Priesthood, and in their labors by the guidance of thy Holy Spirit. Help them and direct them in all things in their wonderful labors in mercy and in wisdom. We bless them, our Father, and pray that thy spirit may be with them constantly, that they may appreciate in the fullness the privileges which are theirs, in the name of the Lord, Jesus Christ. Amen. GARFF, IN 1945 WHEN BUILDING PROGRAM WAS LAUNCHED Page 811 Annual General Relief Society Conference—1956 Margaret C. Pickering, General Secretary-Treasurer HE annual general Relief T Society conference was held in Salt Lake City, Wednesday and Thursday, October 3 and 4. There were 232 of the 233 stakes and twenty-one of the forty-five missions represented. In recognition of the active part which the missions of the Church took in support of the erection of 'The Relief Society Building, Relief Society mission presidents in North America and Central America were invited by the First Presidency to attend this conference, the highlight of which was the Dedicatory Service of The Relief Society Building. The Dedicatory Service replaced the usual general session of the conference. At the Officers Meeting, Wednesday morning in the 'Tabernacle, President Spafford gave her Report and Official Instructions, and the sustaining of general board members and the roll call were conducted by Secretary-Treasurer Margaret C. Pickering. Counselor Velma N. Simonsen gave an inspirational talk introducing the dramatic program, "Portrait of a Dream." 'This impressive dramatization written by Alberta H. Christensen, using slides, portrayed incidents leading up to and including the erection of the new building, and served as a prelude to the Dedicatory Service. A song, "Lord, We Dedicate 'This House to Thee," composed specially for this occasion, words by Sister Page 812 Christensen and music by Florence J. Madsen, was sung by a special Singing Mothers chorus from the Provo stakes and vicinity. The Dedicatory Service, Wednesday afternoon, to which the public was invited, was held in the Tabernacle and televised to the Assembly Hall and Barratt Hall. President David O. McKay presided and President Belle S. Spafford conducted the meeting. Most of the General Authorities were present. The Singing Mothers from Bear River, Ben Lomond, East Ogden, Farr West, Lake View, Lorin Farr, Malad, Mount Ogden, North Box Elder, North Weber, Ogden, Riverdale, South Bear River, South Box Elder, South Ogden, Summit, Weber, and South Carolina Stakes made up the chorus. 'Two large spheres, one in the shape of the motto of Relief Society "Charity Never Faileth,' and the other depicting the globe with the words, "World Sisterhood," decorated the front of the center pipes of the Tabernacle organ. 'To further emphasize the international scope of the society and the spirit of world sisterhood, representatives of thirtytwo nations, in costume, carrying their national flags, marched down through the aisles of the choir section and placed their flags at each side of the rostrum. 'The invocation was offered by Elder Mark E. Petersen, of the Council of the Twelve and an advisor to Relief Society. Counselor Marianne C. Sharp gave a brief report of The Relief Society Building activities, followed by an address by President Belle S. Spafford. After the singing of "Thy Blessing on This House, Dear Lord," also specially composed for this occasion by Sisters Christensen and Madsen, and sung by the combined Singing Mothers chorus, President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., President Stephen L Richards, and President David O. McKay addressed the meeting, in that order. While the congregation sang "We Thank Thee, O God, for a Prophet," the First Presidency went to The Relief Society Building, where the Dedicatory Prayer was offered by President David O. McKay, and was transmitted by radio to the Tabernacle, Assembly Hall, and Barratt Hall. 'The congregation sang ""The Spirit of God Like a Fire Is Burning," and the benediction was offered by President Joseph Fielding Smith, President of the Council of the Twelve and an advisor to Relief Society. The annual reception for stake and mission officers was held Wednesday evening in The Relief Society Building and was a beautiful and memorable occasion attended by approximately three thousand persons. Simultaneous departmental _ sessions for executive, music, The Relief Society Magazine, theology, visiting teaching, work, literature, and social science leaders were held Thursday morning in various meetinghouses throughout the city. HE music of the entire conference was unusually beautiful and impressive. Elder Alexander Schreiner was organist. 'The large Singing Mothers chorus also furnished music at the Friday sessions of the semi-annual conference of the Church, and, at President McKay's request, sang "Thy Blessings on This House, Dear Lord,' so that the conference visitors might hear this inspiring dedicatory hymn. No meetings were held 'Thursday afternoon, but tours of The Relief Society Building were conducted from 2:00 to 7:00 P. M. To enable Relief Society conference visitors to see it. Additional tours were held for Church conference visitors Friday and Saturday, October 6 and 7, also Monday and Tuesday, October 8 and 9g, for any who desired to see the beautiful new home for Relief Society. Prior to the dedication, tours were conducted for special guests and_ stake groups. The Report and Official Instructions of President Spafford appeared in the November issue of the Magazine. 'This issue contains the complete Dedicatory Service, with pictures of 'The Relief Society Building and the address of Counselor Velma N. Simonsen, ANNUAL GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 813 Loving, United Effort Availeth Much Counselor Valine N. Simonsen [Address Delivered at the Officers Meeting of the Annual General Relief Society Conference, October 3, 1956.| stand before you today with the deepest feelings of gratitude in my heart for the blessings of the Lord unto me, and with a greater realization of these blessings, than I have ever known before in my life. Within the past week the words of one of old have gone through my mind repeatedly: "What shall I render unto the Lord for all his goodness unto me?" | know that the most acceptable gratitude is shown in service, so I pray that throughout my life, in whatever circumstances I may be, I will be able to express my gratitude through service. You sisters here today, the leadership of Relief Society, from the amazingly widespread stakes and missions of the Church, as evidenced by the roll call just completed, are here for one purpose, that is, to equip yourselves better spiritually and intellectually, for the positions which you hold, that you may be able to serve your Father in heaven better by teaching his gospel to his daughters and in helping to establish his kingdom here upon the earth. General Relief Society conference is always a time of rejoicing. It is always a spiritual feast. Why? Because you sisters come with this singleness of purpose, united in faith and in testimony. It is a Page 814 spiritual feast because we receive instructions from our general Relief Society officers, counsel from the Priesthood through the General Authorities of the Church, and, above all else, because the spirit of our Father in heaven is with us here. This conference of October 1956 is of special significance to us. It witnesses the fulfillment of a dream which has persisted in the heart of Relief Society for many, many years —the dream of having a functional and beautiful building of its own. The dream began early in Church history, even in Nauvoo, and continued with the sisters through their forced move from the beautiful city of Nauvoo to the uninviting West, where the sisters continued their work of benevolence, unselfish sharing, and effective service in the Lord's work. And the dream to have their own building, like a golden thread, ran through all activities, as is shown by the minutes of the general Relief Society conference held October 3, 1896. Let me read you an excerpt from these minutes: President Zina D. Young, in her remarks, opened out upon the subject of a house for the Relief Society, to be owned by them. Women had done so much to help build other public buildings and temples that they had no means to build one for the Relief Society. Presi- LOVING, UNITED EFFORT AVAILETH MUCH dent C. O. Card had said when they lacked the means to go on with the Logan Temple and the men were to be discharged because there was no means to pay them for their work, Sister Jane S. Richards raised five hundred dollars in the Relief Society of Weber County to keep the men working, and that stands as a memento to the sisters forever. Vice President Sarah M. Kimball confined her remarks to the subject of a house for the Society. She felt it a humiliation to be without a place of our own; we had contributed to all public places and all times. Now we want to have a house and we want land to build it on and it should be in the shadow of the temple. It should be a place to receive strangers in when they came, a place where letters can be written from, and information given.... Their plans called for kitchens, pantries, banqueting hall, cooking utensils, a furnace and closets and a room for the janitor, and offices upstairs, "with a library and bureau of information, that will be in the best sense educational, and where lectures may be given by distinguished professors in all branches of science, art and literature, and on general topics." UR building, which is now completed, more than fulfills the dreams of all of us. As you view this magnificent building, both inside and out, you will realize the great amount of hard work, trained professional help, and loving and prayerful planning that have gone into the building. You will know that the inspiration of the Lord has 815 been over it all. It was designed and will be equipped to meet the many and varied services which Relief Society offers to the Church mempbership—and it is beautiful. This building not only meets the specific needs of a great and growing organization divinely inspired; it represents the individuality and love of the Relief Society women throughout the world, through the contributions they have made for its construction and the many decorative and useful pieces which are the gifts of individuals, and stake and mission Relief Societies. The Lord knows, and we all know, that many of these contributions were made through sacrifice, but all were made freely and through love. A sister living a great distance from Salt Lake City said to President Spafford, "At first I thought, why, in my lifetime I have given many gifts which I never expect to use myself, and now it gives me great joy to know that I have a share in that beautiful building." The first day the building was open for inspection two little sisters stood at the entrance to the lounge room, their eyes shining in admiration. One turned to the other and said, "We didn't know our five dollarswould buy so much, did we?" Surely loving, united effort availeth much. This building is, indeed, a dream fulfilled. Sister Emma Ray Riggs McKay, wife of President David O. McKay, admires a gift in The Relief Society Building. The Meissen vase is a gift from the Swiss-Austrian Mission. Page 816 QD EDITORIAL <9 VOL. 43 DECEMBER 1956 NO. 12 A Dedicated Home for Relief Society [ began as a dream, or even before the dream took form, it was a longing deep-planted in woman's heart, to have a home, to have one spot designated particularly and set apart around which, as a warming fire, Relief Society workers might gather. It was an insistent urge companioning Latter-day Saint women as they were driven from their own hearthsides again and again. And now at last on the third day of October, one thousand, nine hundred and fifty-six, the seeding and garnering are over, and the harvest has fulfilled the dream. It was the practice in early days, for the sisters to provide their own meeting places in the wards. In 1897 President Zina D. H. Young said "she was pleased with the exertions of the sisters in getting houses to meet in." Relief Society Halls—so named—provided homes for Relief Societies in metropolitan centers, in verdant valleys, and in bleak, sparsely settled communities. The sisters had Relief Society homes and, in addition, through obedience to the voice of their prophets, they had granaries guarding life-sustaining wheat. The practice changed. Relief Society Halls were abandoned as room for Relief Society work was provided in meetinghouses. Individual granaries, not always satisfactory storage places, were emptied, and later great Church elevators were filled as the result of thousands of small loads of Relief Society wheat. But while ward Relief Socicties were provided with meeting places, what of the Central Board of Relief Society? They had no place of their own in which to meet; they had to borrow a meeting room; and there was no place for the preservation of general Relief Society records. And so the dream of one functional and beautiful home in which the work of Relief Society throughout the world might be conceived and from which it might be directed was born, and is today a reality. A home of the heart of Relief Society of which every Relief Society member is a part. A home containing the loveliest offerings of the world-wide sisterhood. Unitedly, through sacrifice, and with the assistance of the Church, The Relief Society Building stands an ensign to women. In the present and future years this symbol of the devotion of Relief Society women and of. Their lofty destiny in the gospel plan will speak to the sojourners from other countries and remote civilizations: "We, the members of Relief Society of the restored Church of Christ, built this home through sacrifice with the help and under the guidance of the Priesthood of God. No other women in all the world are blessed as are we. Relief Society Page 817 came into being through the inspiration of the Lord to his Prophet Joseph Smith in 1842. Another prophet in 1956 dedicated this our home to the Lord. We are continually guided and sustained by his servants. This Building is magnificent, but its beauty has been fashioned as that of the virtuous woman of Solomon's Proverb. Those who labor in Relief Society do so in a spirit of service, of deep humility, thankfulness, and dedication. We are nurtured through the compassion we extend to others. We follow our grand key words, "Said Jesus, "Ye shall do the work which ye see me do.'" Arrogance in possessions has no place in our home. The 'offering reflects the refinement, graciousness, intelligence, and strength of faith possessed by the early sisters, exemplified in Lucy Mack Smith, by the staunch and true pioneer member, and the member of today and tomorrow, the bedrock of whose character has remained the same — selfishness, compassion, charity, and love. Relief Society today through humility and service and with the help of the Lord, will earn the blessing invoked for the Building by President David O. McKay in his glorious Dedicatory Prayer when he asked "May the building and sursoundings radiate a hallowed influence even to passersby, as perfume is wafted from sweet-scented flowers." From this spirit will blossom a rededication to service for the poor both in spirit and means; for the needy, for the afflicted, and sorrowing. 'Thus the Building may and must be hallowed. —M. C. S. She One Hundred Twenty-Seventh Semi-Annual Church Conference For behold, this is my work and my glory — to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man (Pearl of Great Price, Moses 1:39, quoted by President McKay in his opening address). GAIN, at the One Hundred Twenty - Seventh Semi - Annual Conference of the Church, held in the historic Tabernacle on 'Temple Square on October 5, 6, and 7, 1956, the saints received instruction, inspiration, and a renewal of their faith. Truth seekers the world over were invited to learn of the restored gospel and its eternal message. That Jesus is the Christ, the power of The Book of Mormon as a witness for Jesus the Christ, the importance and effectiveness of humility and faith, ways of perfecting the saints, reverence in houses of worship, the Word of Wisdom, tithing, chastity, kindness, patience, charity, honesty, peace for the individual and for the world, and obedience to all the principles and ordinances of the gospel, were teachings given special emphasis. President David O. McKay presided and conducted all mectings. The general sessions were broadcast by radio and television over a wide 818 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 EDITORIAL network in the Western States, and the Saturday evening Priesthood meeting proceedings were carried on a closed circuit to some eighty assemblages of the Priesthood gathered in chapels throughout Utah and in many other parts of the United States. All members of the General Authorities spoke during the conference except Elder 'Thomas E. McKay, Assistant to the Council of the Twelve, who, however, was well enough to attend some of the meetings, and Elder Milton R. Hunter of the First Council of the Seventy, who was confined to his home as a result of a recent illness. N his opening address, President McKay reviewed the material progress of the Church, the increase in membership and _ activities, the many new chapels, the great expenditure of means and effort, all directed towards "perfecting the soul." President McKay then asked: "Have we progressed spiritually as well as in these physical and teaching organizations?" He defined spirituality as: Every noble impulse, every unselfish expression of love, every brave suffering for the mght; every surrender of self to something higher than self; every loyalty to an ideal; every unselfish devotion to principle; every helpfulness to humanity; every act of self-control; every fine courage of the soul, undefeated by pretense or policy, but by being, doing, and _ living the good for the very good's sake — that is spirituality. President Stephen L_ Richards spoke of the request from "a distant foreign country" for a statement of the beliefs and purposes of the Church. A reply was submitted, which included a copy of the thir- 819 teen Articles of Faith, and this statement of the objectives of the Church: The objectives of the Church are to bear witness to the divinity of the Lord Jesus Chnist; to teach all men the principles of his Gospel; and to convert and persuade them to follow in his ways and keep the commandments of God, that they may thus advance the Kingdom of God in the earth, to bring brotherhood and peace to men and nations, and earn exaltation for themselves. A warning against the influence of doctrines and cults not in harmony with the gospel of Jesus Christ was expressed by President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. He spoke of the "Olivet Discourse" of the Savior and its divine implications. President Clark summarized his testimony of the gospel in words of strength and simplicity: Jesus did live. First, there was the great plan in heaven; that did actually occur.... The earth was formed, Adam came, the human family followed. We came here to prove ourselves. Finally, Christ was born in the meridian of time. He lived. He taught. He gave imstructions. He was crucified. Then on the morning of the third day, he was resurtected, thus bringing to each and every one of us the blessings of the resurrection. As members of Relief Society, we feel especially grateful and uplifted by the conference messages which gave inspiration and direction for us in our homemaking activities, in our responsibilities as wives and mothers, and as workers in the auxiharies of the Church. May we manifest these blessings in our lives and share them with our friends and neighbors. —V. P. C. Thou didst not lay these things to the heart, neither didst remember the latter end of it...." (Isaiah 47:7). Be Honest with Yourself ANY women are grieved because they do not consider themselves beautiful. When such thoughts come to us, we may be looking at only one facet of the many-sided gem which is our life. For beauty, through the ages, has been a changing value, depending upon the transient preferences of individuals and of groups. It sometimes happens that those who were not thought of as lovely to look upon in their youth, become more beautiful with each passing year, and their thoughts and their attitudes are reflected in radiance on their faces. Some women are as beautiful in their maturity as is the autumn, which must inevitably follow the blossoms of summer. And the testament written upon the faces of the aged often reveals gentleness and courage, endurance and serenity, while the youthful face must await the sculpturing of time to give it the lineaments of completed harmony. We must accept our earthly bodies as they have come to us through our inheritance, rejoicing if we are strong and well, and seeking to overcome our incapacities. There is much that can be done to maintain health, to be neat and clean, to wear appropriate and_becoming clothing, perhaps to gild and polish. But even when all this is done, we still need the comfort and the wisdom of the saying: "Beauty is as beauty does." Perhaps it has taken some of us many years to realize the enduring verity of this proverb. Gratitude for our own particular gifts is said to be the beginning of wisdom, for truly our Heavenly Father has bestowed a multitude of gifts upon his daughters, and the choicest of these are the talents and abilities which require effort, practice, experience for their full fruition. They are the lovely "provisional" gifts that may be infinitely added upon, that may be polished to a shining luster — music, painting, poetry, sculpture; the particularly feminine gifts of homemaking, the "graces beyond the reach of art"; and those most precious of all talents of the uplifted spirit, which, forgetting self, can direct its energies toward those works of charity and benevolence that are forever beautiful. BE HONEST WITH YOURSELF Page 827 The Loan Hazel K. Todd P on the ridge I could see all | | the pine trees where my dad and I had always cut the Christmas tree and dragged it home through the snow. My heart beat in big jumps when I thought of the excitement that was always mixed up with the Christmas tree. Then I remembered that we weren't going to have a tree this year, or anything else, I guessed. Because my dad had told me I was too big to be thinking about Christmas trees. And all the time I knew that wasn't the real reason, for I could think of lots of people that were older than nine and they still had Christmas trees. 'The only ones I knew who didn't always have a Christmas tree were the Durphys who lived in the shack on the river road. I knew that the reason for our not having a Christmas tree was that ever since Susan, my little sister, had died last spring, nothing had ever been the same. I would come home from school and mother would be sitting by the window, and she wouldn't even know I was there. And when I would ask my dad to wrestle with me like he had always done, he would put me aside and say, "Some other time, Son." And that was the end because I had learned by now that there would never be some other time. Things were so different when Susan was alive. Mother didn't cry then. But now I would see her in Susan's room that was right across the hall from mine. She would have Susan's doll or dress or Page 828 something, and she would be crying over it. It used to be fun to find daddy kissing mother, because Susan and I would run and get mixed up in the pie, and then they would have to kiss us, too. I loved Susan very much, too. She had such shiny curls and soft dimples, and she was so warm and cuddly. But there was only a week left before Christmas, and it was plain as the nose on your face that there wouldn't be any Christmas unless something happened. I thought once that maybe when Aunt Jane came she could make things right. She was daddy's sister who always came a week before Christmas. She would put on big boots and would go with dad and me to drag the Christmas tree down, and she would say so many funny things that I would have to laugh until I fell over in the snow. But when I asked mother one day, when was Aunt Jane coming, she looked at me funny and said Aunt Jane wasn't coming this year. "But," I said to dad, "couldn't we just find a little tree? We could drag it down." Dad just looked away somewhere. "No, Jerry," he said. "We didn't ask her to come." 'Then he put his hand on my head. "Don't you think you could forget about Christmas this year?" I guess grownups can forget things easier than smaller ones, because no matter how hard I tried to forget I couldn't. THE LOAN ONE night when I woke up after I had been dreaming about Christmas, I thought I couldn't bear it. I could hear the wind blowing down the canyon and I knew the Christmas tree ridge would be all covered with fresh snow. While I was thinking about how much fun it would be in the new snow, suddenly I realized the light was on in Susan's room. I wondered if mother had gone to sleep in there. I waited awhile, but I couldn't hear a sound so I tiptoed to the door. I had a strange, fearful feeling, because I didn't ever go in Susan's room any more. It made me feel too bad to see all her things around. Anyway, Susan's room had come to seem like it all belonged to mother. I knocked softly on the door and called, "Mother," but there was no answer, so I opened it and looked in. She was not there. I could see Susan's pink ruffled dress. And then I thought of something. If we just had another little girl like Susan to wear her things, maybe mother would feel better and daddy would get the tree, and we could have Christmas as we had always done. Back in my own bed, I went over in my mind all the little girls I could think of. I decided Priscilla Jackson would be the best, she was so pretty. She was the only child the Jacksons had, but Mrs. Jackson wouldn't mind letting us take her just one Christmas, when she had her all the rest of the time. So I went to sleep feeling better than I had for so long, while the wind whooped it up outside. Sure enough, in the morning there was snow all over the ground. When I looked out my window I could 829 see the Christmas tree ridge shining in the sun like a sea of silver nickels. And it made me so glad I had thought of a plan. At breakfast daddy said, "It really snowed last night. Jerry, don't forget to wear your boots." Mother was looking out of the window. She wasn't eating anything. She turned and looked at Susan's coat and boots that were still in the hall. "Yes, Jerry," she said, without looking at me, "wear your warm wraps." Priscilla Jackson sat right behind me, so when the teacher stepped out for a minute I turned and asked her quickly, "Priscilla, would your mother let you come and _ have Christmas with us, because my mother and daddy feel so bad that Susan is gone?" Priscilla looked at me as if I was a toad or something. She flipped her curls in the air as though she was a princess. "Indeed, Jerry Morris, my mother will not let me spend Christmas with you! Why, don't you know I'm going to have a Toni doll, and a writing desk and a beautiful new doll buggy and a hundred other things; and the biggest tree there is in town! I don't want to spend Christmas with you, so there!" I didn't think I would ever try to borrow a little girl again. THE days kept passing until there was only one day left until it would be Christmas Five. I felt so miserable I went outside and _ sat on the garden bench in the snow, and wished I'd freeze into ice, so I wouldn't have to think of it any more. Pretty soon Dad came along. He stopped a minute when he saw me, and then he came over. "Isn't it pretty cold here?" he asked. "No," I said without looking at him. He stood there awhile, then he said, "You're a big boy now, Jerry and know all about Santa Claus. Would you like to have your presents now?" That did it. I burst out crying, even if I was a big boy and knew all about Santa Claus. "No," I said. "IT don't wany any Christmas presents!" I didn't want daddy to see me crying, so I turned and ran down the path to the river road. I had a hard time to quit crying, but pretty soon the sobs quit jerking me so much and I looked up and found that I was clear down by the river and I could see the Durphy shack. I could see by the window that they didn't have any Christmas tree this year. I began to wonder what so many of them did in such a little house, and all of a sudden an idea hit me with such a jolt that I sat down in the snow to think. Mrs. Durphy had so many children that she wouldn't even miss one, and with Mr. Durphy gone so much, nobody knew where, I'm sure they wouldn't be getting Toni dolls and desks and everything else. The ideas began racing up and down me so fast like pins sticking in me. I was so excited I scrambled to my feet without even shaking the snow from my pants. 'There was a lot of noise inside the house, and I could hear a baby crying. But I went up and knocked on the door. There was a hush inside for awhile, then the door opened, not too wide. Mrs. Durphy had the crying baby in her arms. It was barefoot, and she tried to wrap the ragged blanket around its little feet. She looked so tired and worried that I thought she must have been working awful hard. "Yes?" she said holding the door from coming clear open. "What do you want?" "Mrs. Durphy," I said, "I want to borrow something." She hesitated a minute like she didn't know what to do, then she opened the door wider. "Come in. I walked in. There were children all over the floor, and they stared at me with big eyes. Over in the corner I could see the one. 'Two little girls were sitting by a piece of paper and some broken crayons. The littlest one must have been the same size as Susan. Her hair was all tangled up, and her face was very dirty. ' "MBS. Durphy," I said, "I want to borrow a little girl for Christmas." Mrs. Durphy looked at me as if she didn't understand what I said. And all the kids opened their mouths like they could hear with them, too. "What did you say?" Mrs. Durphy asked, still looking as if she hadn't heard. "T want to borrow a little girl for Christmas," I repeated from the words still stuck in my throat. She must have been very tired because she sat down on the old chair there. "A —a little girl?" I nodded my head solemnly. "I — I don't understand." And then she seemed to suddenly make up her mind. "You'd better run along home," she said. But I couldn't go home. I thought desperately and remembered some- 830 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 THE LOAN thing. "Please, Mrs. Durphy," I said, "if you will lend us a little girl my dad will buy her a Toni doll and a writing desk and a lot of other things, and we will have the biggest tree in town!" She started talking to herself then about one child having Christmas anyway or something, and then she said, "Well — I — I guess it would be all right. Which one did you want?" "That one," I said, pointing to the little one with tangled hair. "Rosalie?" Mrs. Durphy_ said. "Rosalie — Rosalie gets so frightened." But one of the bigger girls said, "You want a dolly, don't you, Rosalie? You won't get scared, will you?" "No get scared, no get scared!" the little girl chirped, dropping a handful of crayons and coming forward. "We — well, I guess I'd better be going," I said, with all the children looking at me. The other little girl had gone whimpering to her mother, something about wanting a dolly, too, and I thought I'd better be going before they all wanted to come. Mrs. Durphy brought a ragged coat. Then she looked at Rosalie's old shoes. "She has no boots," she said hesitantly. "Her feet will get wet." I could see she was about to change her mind. "I will carry her piggy-back," I said quickly. "I used to carry Susan all the time." With her ragged shoes tucked securely into my pockets, I turned to Mrs. Durphy. "Thank you, Mrs. Durphy," I said. ""Vhank you very much for the loan." 831 ROSALIE looked so pretty when I put the pink ruffly dress and the pink ribbons on her, that I squeezed her to see if she was as cuddly as Susan. But I think she was too bony. Anyway, she pushed me away. She was crying a little so I showed her in the mirror how pretty she looked, and she felt better. But on the stairs before mother and daddy I thought something awful was going to happen. Mother turned as white as the Christmas tree ridge when she looked at Rosalie. I thought she was going to say something, but she just sat there staring. Dad stood up and then he said, "Jerry, what have you been doing? Who is this child?" "It's Rosalie," I said, "one of the Durphy children. I borrowed her! J? Rosalie must have known that something was wrong, because she slid down on the stairs and grabbed my leg and burst into tears. I tried to pat her head, but she only clutched my leg tighter. "I want my mommy!" she cried. Mother just sat there staring at the dress and ribbons. And dad had the most peculiar look on his face. Rosalie was screaming by now so loud I couldn't explain anything, and no matter how I tried I couldn't pry her away from my leg. Just when I thought the whole world was going to tumble in, the door opened and there stood Aunt Jane. I was so glad to see her I would have run and hugged her with all my might if I could have got loose. Aunt Jane stood there a minute looking as if she wanted to fight somebody, and then she said, "Well, aren't you even going to ask me to take off my hat?" Then dad said, "Take it off," as though he was too tired to care whether she took it off or not. "Seems to me somebody's got some explaining to do," she said, taking off her hat and clutching it in her hand. "Here it is only one day left to get that tree down and all the other things, and not a word said to me about coming." Mother was holding onto the arms of her chair very hard. Finally dad said, "Well, Jane, without Susan...." Aunt Jane pursed her lips into a straight line. "James Morris," she said, "it's about time somebody told you two a thing or two." She pulled the feather off her hat without even looking what she was doing, and twisted it around her finger. And then I guess she told them the thing or two, something about Christmas being the time to think of others and to be happy for what Jesus did for us. She looked squarely at me. "What about Jerry?" Doesn't he want any Christmas either? If he doesn't, he's different from all the other kids I know." I couldn't look at mother and daddy. My throat was so full of lumps I couldn't swallow them all. And then Rosalie started in again louder than ever. She hung onto my leg like a leech. "I want my mommy! I want my mommy!" she wailed, while the tears ran all over the pink ruffles. "Jerry, who is this child?" Aunt Jane asked. But I couldn't stand it any longer. All the miserable, lonely feelings I had saved up since Susan died seemed to break and run down my face in tears. UNT Jane came over and unfastened Rosalie somehow from my leg and sat down with her in the rocking chair. "Now, Jerry," she said, "you go ahead and cry for awhile and then you tell me what this is all about." So pretty soon I could talk. "She's one of the Durphy children. I borrowed her because there wasn't going to be any Christmas 'cause Susan is dead. So I thought if I could get a little girl to take Susan's place we could have Christmas, and get a tree and do all the things we've done...." And then I turned to run upstairs, because I felt so ashamed that I had cried so much when I was a big boy nine years old. But there was mother in front of me. Her eyes were full of shining tears. "Jerry," she said, and pulled me down onto her lap on the stairs. She held my head against her dress, and it felt so good because it was the first time since Susan's funeral, and I cried a little bit more. Then I felt her lips on my forehead, and it was wonderful. "Jerry, will you please forgive me?" she said, and all I could do was put my arms around her neck and hug her tight. Rosalie was fussing again. "I want my mommy," she whimpered. "Tt seems this child wants her mother," Aunt Jane said. "Somebody'd better take her home." Then I remembered. I slid off mother's lap and stood on the stairs. "But I promised Mrs. Durphy we would buy her a Toni doll and a writing desk and a lot of other things," I said. Daddy came over and put one hand on my shoulder and the other around mother. "I guess at least 832 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 THE LOAN part of that can be arranged, Son," he said. Aunt Jane winked at me. "T don't want a dolly. I want my mommy, " wept Rosalie. "Jerry," Aunt Jane asked, "is this one of those children who live down by the river?" "Yes," I said. "Aren't there a lot of other children down there?" "The whole house them," I said. "T think there are eight," mother said. "We shall bring them all up is full of for Christmas." "Jerry," Aunt Jennie said, "it looks 833 as though you and I had better take Rosalie home tonight and tell Mrs. Durphy to get ready for Christmas." I looked at the ruffly dress and ribbons. "I'd better go take these off," I said. "No, Jerry," mother said quickly. "Tell Mrs. Durphy that Rosalie may have them. And ['ll fix a box tomorrow with some more of Susan's things. She could probably use them." As I closed the door I could see daddy's arms around mother, and I guess he was going to kiss her, but there wasn't time for me to get mixed up in the pie now.
