SPAFFORD, General President of Relief Society, in October, attended meetings of two national groups in New York City. She first attended meetings of the American Mothers Committee, the organization which selects the American Mother of the Year. The meetings stressed the importance of a more spiritual observance of Mother's Day and more effective religious training in the home, in harmony with the slogan of the Committee: "A Bible in Every Home." At the biennial meetings of the National Council of Women, of which President Spafford has been second vicepresident for the past nine years, she was elected a member at large of the Executive Committee. President Spafford reported on the activities of Relief Society and of the American Mothers Committee. She opened the second day's meetings with prayer, presided at the luncheon, and paid a tribute to Mrs. Charlotte Leyden, retiring President of the Council, who was also elected a member at large. MILY H. BENNETT, First Counselor, Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association, also attended the meetings of the National Council of Women and presented a report of the activities of the Y. W. M. I. A., which holds membership in the Council. Mrs. Page 836 Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon Bennett had the honor of offering the invocation at the first meting and of participating actively in the panel discussions. N Cairo, Egypt, today, many women, hiding behind veils not long since, are as modern in dress, living conditions, and outlook as are American women. Leading feminist educators, such as Madame Nahid Sirry, President of the Feminist Union, and Madame Karima Said, of the Egyptian Ministry of Education, have labored assiduously for these improved conditions. Women are doing much excellent social welfare work throughout Egypt, are holding more and more government offices, and are numerous employees in the Ministries of Public Health, Education, and Social Affairs. A larger-than-life-size bronze statue of Eliza R. Snow, the great pioneer woman leader, second General President of Relief Society, who gave so untiringly of her fine mind and talents to the women of the Church, now stands in the garden of the Daughters of Utah Pioneers Memorial Building, 304 North Main Street, Salt Lake City, Utah. It was carved by Ortho Fairbanks and presented by the Nicholas G. Morgan Foundation. N DEPARTMENT Sheology—Characters and Teachings of The Book of Mormon Lesson 46—Prophecies Concerning the Jews, Gentiles, and Lamanites in the Latter Days Elder Leland H. Monson For Tuesday, March 5, 1957 Objective: being fulfilled. HE Book of Mormon is rather explicit in what it has to say about the Gentiles, the Jews, and the Lamanites. Various prophets looked into the future and wrote concerning these three groups of people. Concerning the Gentiles The Gentiles, according to The Book of Mormon, were to be given the privilege of unveiling this great land of America after it had been hidden from the nations of the world for hundreds of years. Nephi wrote: And I looked and beheld a man among the Gentiles, who was separated from the seed of my brethren by the many waters; and I beheld the Spirit of God, that it came down and wrought upon the man; and he went forth upon the many waters, even unto the seed of my brethren, who were in the promised land.... And it came to pass that I beheld many multitudes of the Gentiles upon the land To show that the prophecies made by Book of Mormon prophets are of promise; and I beheld the wrath of God, that it was upon the seed of my brethren; and they were scattered before the Gentiles and were smitten (1 Nephi 13:12, 14). This quotation undoubtedly refers to the discovery of America by Columbus, and to the fact that many Gentiles would follow in his wake. Nephi also saw that a great and marvelous work would be accomplished among these Gentiles, for they were to receive the Nephite records (2 Nephi 29:3) and to take the contents to the remnant of the Nephite and Lamanite civilization in the latter days. Nephi wrote: And it came to pass that the angel of the Lord spake unto me, saying Behold, saith the Lamb of God, after I have visited the remnant of the house of Israel — and this remnant of whom I speak is the seed of thy father—wherefore, after I have visited them in judgment, and smitten them by the hand of the Gentiles and after the Gentiles do stumble exceedingly, Page 837 because of the most plain and precious parts of the gospel of the Lamb which have been kept back by that abominable church, which is the mother of harlots, saith the Lamb — I will be merciful unto the Gentiles in that day, insomuch that I will bring forth unto them, in mine own power, much of my gospel, which shall be plain and precious, saith the Lamb (I Nephi 13:34). Writing again on this same subject, Nephi pointed out: And after our seed is scattered the Lord God will proceed to do a marvelous work among the Gentiles, which shall be of great worth unto our seed; wherefore, it is likened unto their being nourished by the Gentiles and being carried in their arms and upon their shoulders (1 Nephi 22:8). On another occasion, Nephi prophesied that the Gentiles should carry the message of the record to a remnant of his seed: And then shall the remnant of our seed know concerning us, how that we came out from Jerusalem, and that they are descendants of the Jews. And the gospel of Jesus Christ shall be declared among them... (2 Nephi 30:4-5; see also 3 Nephi 26:8). But it was not the Nephite record alone that the Gentiles were to give to a remnant of Nephi's people, for Nephi saw that the Gentiles would take the Jewish record to a remnant of his seed: Therefore repent, and be baptized in the name of Jesus, and lay hold upon the gospel of Christ, which shall be set before you, not only in this record but also in the record which shall come unto the Gentiles from the Jews, which record shall come from the Gentiles unto you (Mormon 7:8). And it came to pass that I beheld the remnant of the seed of my brethren, and also the book of the Lamb of God, which had proceeded forth from the mouth of the Jew, that it came forth from the Gentiles unto the remnant of the seed of my brethren (1 Nephi 13:38). It was further to be the mission of the Gentiles to scatter a remnant of the house of Israel. (See 1 Nephi 15:17; 2 Nephi 10:18.) The Book of Mormon indicates, too, that there should be a great Gentile nation built upon this land: And it meaneth that the time cometh that after all the house of Israel have been scattered and confounded, that the Lord God will raise up a mighty nation among the Gentiles, yea, even upon the face of this land; and by them shall our seed be scattered (1 Nephi 22:7). But behold, this land, said God, shall be a land of thine inheritance, and the Gentiles shall be blessed upon the land. And this land shall be a land of liberty unto the Gentiles, and there shall be no kings upon the land, who shall raise up unto the Gentiles (2 Nephi 10:10-11). A glorious promise is also held out to these Gentiles, for Nephi says:... That if the Gentiles shall hearken unto the Lamb of God in that day that he shall manifest himself unto them in word, and also in power, in very deed, unto the taking away of their stumbling blocks— And harden not their hearts against the Lamb of God, they shall be numbered among the seed of thy father; yea, they shall be numbered among the house of Israel; and they shall be a blessed people upon the promised land forever... (1 Nephi 14:1-2; see also 2 Nephi 30:2). Concerning the Lamanites Book of Mormon prophets, interested as they were in these Gentiles, also showed great concern over the 838 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT Lamanites. 'There were periods in the Lamanite history when they were righteous as indicated by the conversions among them by the sons of Mosiah, the preachings of Samuel the Lamanite, and _ the merging of the Nephite and Lamanite civilizations after the appearance of the Christ when the Nephites and Lamanites had all things in common. (Helaman 6:1). 'There were more periods, however, when the Lamanites were unrighteous. But we are not concerned with this history here, for we want to know what promises the Lord held out for the Lamanites in the last days. Just before sealing up his father's record, Moroni wrote a few words to his Lamanite brethren of the future concerning the record the Gentiles would give unto them. He wrote:. And I write unto my brethren, the Lamanites; and I would that they should know that more than four hundred and twenty years have passed away since the sign was given of the coming of Christ. And I seal up these records, after I have spoken a few words by way of exhortation unto you. And when ye shall receive these things, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, the Eternal Father in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall ask with a sincere heart, with real intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost (Moroni 10:1-2, 4). Moroni further encouraged these Lamanites not to deny the gifts of God—the gift of knowledge, the gift of faith, the gift of healing, the gift of prophecy, and the others. He seems to be pleading with them to accept the gospel in the last days 839 when it would be presented to them. Moroni appears to have directed his entire writings in the Book of Moroni to the Lamanites. (See Moroni 1:4.) It was to the Lamanites that he wrote when he discussed the ordinances of the gospel and gave the two prayers for administering the sacrament, the mode of bestowing the Holy Ghost, and the ordination of priests and teachers. One of the early Book of Mormon prophets, Enos, prayed "with many long strugglings" for the Lamanites: And now behold, this was the desire which I desired of him — that if it should so be, that my people, the Nephites, should fall into transgression, and by any means be destroyed, and the Lamanites should not be destroyed that the Lord God would preserve a record of my people, the Nephites; even if it so be by the power of his holy arm, that it might be brought forth at some future day unto the Lamanites, that, perhaps, they might be brought unto salvation— And I had faith, and I did cry unto God that he would preserve the records; and he covenanted with me that he would bring them forth unto the Lamanites in his own due time (Enos 13, 16). Helaman later held forth promises for the Lamanites of the last days. Helaman wrote: Yea, I say unto you, that in the latter times the promises of the Lord have been extended to our brethren, the Lamanites; and notwithstanding the many afflictions which they shall have, and notwithstanding they shall be driven to and fro upon the face of the earth, and be hunted, and shall be smitten and scattered abroad, having no place for refuge, the Lord shall be merciful unto them. And this is according to the prophecy, that they shall be brought to the true 840 knowledge, which is the knowledge of their Redeemer, and their great and true shepherd, and be numbered among _his sheep (Helaman 15:12-13). Mormon also called upon the Lamanites in the last days to repent, as quoted previously: Therefore repent, and be baptized in the name of Jesus, and lay hold upon the gospel of Christ, which shall be set before you, not only in this record but also in the record which shall come unto the Gentiles from the Jews, which record shall come from the Gentiles unto you (Mormon 7:8). Concerning the Jews The Book of Mormon prophets also wrote much about the Jews and the promises of the Lord to them in the last days. Lehi brought with him from Jerusalem the brass plates, the record of the Jews. Nephi speaks of making a record "... In the language of my father, which consists of the learning of the Jews and the language of the Egyptians" (1 Nephi 1:2). The Book of Mormon makes it clear that the Jews were responsible for the crucifixion of the Christ (2 Nephi 10:3), and that they would become a hated and despised people. Nephi wrote: And as for those who are at Jerusalem, saith the prophet, they shall be scourged by all people, because they crucify the God of Israel, and turn their hearts aside, rejecting signs and wonders, and the power and glory of the God of Israel. And because they turn their hearts aside, saith the prophet, and have despised the Holy One of Israel, they shall wander in the flesh, and perish, and become a hiss and a by-word, and be hated among all nations (1 Nephi 19:13-14). Wherefore, the Jews shall be scattered RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—1956 among all nations; yea, and also Babylon shall be destroyed; wherefore, the Jews shall be scattered by other nations. And after they have been scattered, and the Lord God hath scourged them by other nations for the space of many generations, yea, even down from generation to generation until they shall be persuaded to believe in Christ, the Son of God, and the atonement, which is infinite for all mankind — and when that day shall come that they shall believe in Christ, and worship the Father in his name, with pure hearts and clean hands, and look not forward any more for another Messiah, then, at that time, the day will come that it must needs be expedient that they should believe these things. And the Lord will set his hand again the second time to restore his people from their lost and fallen state. Wherefore, he will proceed to do a marvelous work and a wonder among the children of men. Wherefore, he shall bring forth his words unto them, which words shall judge them at the last day, for they shall be given them for the purpose of convincing them of the true Messiah, who was rejected by them; and unto the convincing of them that they need not look forward any more for a Messiah to come, for there should not any come, save it should be a false Messiah which should deceive the people; for there is save one Messiah spoken of by the prophets, and that Messiah is he who should be rejected of the Jews (2 Nephi 25:15-18). Nephi knew that in the last days the Jews (as well as the nations of the Gentiles) would become "... Drunken with iniquity and all manner of abominations" (2 Nephi 27:1). Despite this condition, Nephi also saw that the Nephite record and the record of the lost tribes of Israel would come to the Jews. (See 2 Nephi 29:13.) Nephi also said:... As many of the Jews as will not repent shall be cast off; for the Lord LESSON DEPARTMENT covenanteth with none save it be with them that repent and believe in his Son, who is the Holy One of Israel (2 Nephi 30:2). However, Nephi promised: And it shall come to pass that the Jews which are scattered also shall begin to believe in Christ; and they shall begin to gather in upon the face of the land; and as many as shall believe in Christ shall also become a delightsome people (2 Nephi 30:7). Jacob saw the day when the Jews "... Because of their iniquities..." would suffer from destruction, famines, pestilences, and bloodshed; "... And they who shall not be destroyed shall be scattered among all nations" (2 Nephi 10:6). He prophesied, however, that:... When the day cometh that they shall believe in me, that I am Christ, then have I covenanted with their fathers that they shall be restored in the flesh, upon the earth, unto the lands of their inheritance (2 Nephi 10:7). Mormon, a later prophet, was interested in seeing that in the last days the Jews:... The covenant people of the Lord, shall have other witness besides him whom they saw and heard, that Jesus, whom they slew, was the very Christ and the very God (Mormon 3:21). 841 Mormon knew, of course, that his record would be a witness. Mormon, cognizant of what the attitude of people would be towards the Jews in the last days, urged us not to glory in persecuting them. He wrote:... Ye need not any longer hiss, nor spurn, nor make game of the Jews, nor any of the remnant of the house of Israel; for behold, the Lord remembereth his covenant unto them, and he will do unto them according to that which he hath sworn (3 Nephi 29:8). Book of Mormon prophets were solicitous of the future welfare of these groups of people, the Gentiles, Lamanites, and Jews, and wrote to encourage them to accept the gospel in the last days. They promised a rich reward to all who would accept it. Questions on the Lesson 1. What are the promises to the Gentiles, if they repent? 2. What are the promises to the Lamanites of the last days? 3. Discuss how the prophecies in The Book of Mormon concerning the Jews are coming to pass? 4. If Book of Mormon prophets were concerned with these people, what is our responsibility? Visiting eacher I lessages— Book of Mormon Gems of Truth Lesson 46—"And Now, My Beloved Son, Notwithstanding Their [The Nephites] Hardness, Let Us Labor Diligently; For If We Should Cease to Labor, We Should Be Brought Under Condemnation; For We Have a Labor to Perform Whilst in This Tabernacle of Clay That We May Conquer the Enemy of All Righteousness and Rest Our Souls in the Kingdom of God" (Moroni 9:6). Leone O. Jacobs For Tuesday, March 5, 1957 Objective: To remind us that we as individuals must never cease laboring to bring souls to Christ. [' is well for each of us to bear in mind that we do have a labor to perform while here in mortality, and to realize what that labor is. We are not here to drift aimlessly with the tide of circumstance, for there is purpose in our existence. We are on earth for two specific reasons: to work out our individual salvation — to "conquer the enemy of all righteousness" as Mormon states, and as individuals to spread the gospel of Jesus Christ. The Church of Jesus Christ embodies a great missionary system. The truth of the gospel must be offered to all the world, and each of us has an obligation to do all in his power to contribute to this effort. Not all Church members receive formal missionary calls, but, nevertheless, all can and should participate in this vital work of spreading the gospel. One stake has instituted a project whereby the Church members contact their nonmember friends and inquire how much they know of our Church principles, and ask if they would be Page 842 interested in knowing more. It was found that nearly fifty per cent of those questioned said they were interested in learning more. Brigham Young said:... There is neither man or woman in this Church who is not on a mission. That mission will last as long as they live, and it is to do good, to promote righteousness, to teach the principles of truth, and to prevail upon themselves and everybody around them to live those principles that they may obtain eternal life (Discourses of Brigham Young, page 322). There are different types of missionary work: among them, that which is accomplished by the influence of good example; that done through formal missionary labors; that which is done by discussion with friends and neighbors during day by day association, and others. Mormon brings out an important point concerning the teaching of the gospel. Though some people seem unreceptive to the gospel, we should not feel justified in discontinuing our efforts in their behalf, else we ourselves may come under LESSON DEPARTMENT condemnation. Individual personalities and backgrounds differ widely and some people cannot accept the gospel as readily as others. Some may have been prejudiced against the Church by the poor example of a Church member or have been given false information. Neverthe- 843 less, it is our responsibility to continue to persuade with patience and love. Let us use every noble means at our command to bring souls unto the Lord. "Remember the worth of souls is great in the sight of God" (D. & C, 18:10). Work Mlecting— Food Preparation and Service (A Course Recommended for Use by Wards and Branches at Work Meeting) Lesson 6 — Desserts Rhea H. Gardner For Tuesday, March 12, 1957 ESSERT originally meant food served after the table had been cleared or deserted of everything, even the cloth removed. In Europe, "dessert" still means fruit served at the end of the meal. Americans are responsible for giving the sweet the place of honor at the end of the meal. The right dessert complements a meal. That is, it adds what is needed to make the meal complete or give it perfect balance. If the main course is a sumptuous and filling one, top it off with something light and easily digested. When the rest of the meal skimps on calories and protein, you have a chance to do your bit nutritionally by including a satisfying dessert. The easiest of all desserts to prepare is a bowl heaped with colorful fruit which has been washed, dried, and chilled. Cheese and crisp, unsweetened crackers are natural affinities, or crisp cookies are pleasant accompaniments, Cake is one of the most popular desserts. Many would say that no one can claim to be a really good cook unless she can make a featherlight, mouth-watering cake. As the altitude increases the air pressure becomes less. 'This requires some slight changes in the recipe that basically is still as good as ever. For cakes containing shortening and two cups flour, it is necessary to reduce the baking powder one-fourth to one-half teaspoon for every rise in altitude of 2500 feet. A reduction of about two tablespoons of sugar for each cup and a slight increase in liquid may also be necessary for perfect texture, for each rise in altitude of 2500 feet. When one goes to a lower altitude, additions of the same amounts should be made, if your recipe gave perfect results where you were. All-purpose flour will not yield as fine and light a product as will cake flour. If you use all-purpose flour, remove two tablespoons of flour for each cupful used and add in its place two tablespoons of cornstarch. Ingredients which are room temperature make a better textured cake than those taken directly from the refrigerator. A uniform temperature near seventy to seventy-five degrees Fahrenheit is considered best. This is particularly important when making sponge-type cakes. Egg whites that are room temperature when used give a lighter, more tender cake of greater volume and finer texture. Ingredients that are too warm, however, can also spoil the cake. Warm, oily fat will not cream satisfactorily, will not incorporate air and build up a smooth, creamy mixture and will produce a coarse textured cake. It is almost impossible to beat the shortening, sugar, and egg mixture too much. When cakes requiring these ingredients are being made, thorough mixing in these stages is all to the good of the cake. Once you start adding the liquid and dry ingredients, stir gently to blend, but do not beat the batter more than necessary for perfect blending of ingredients. Pie is the real American dessert. Shells which are filled and then baked, should be served as soon as possible after they have cooled to be just warm. If baking must be done several days in advance of serving, there are two alternatives. You may freeze the ready-to-bake pies so they can be removed from the freezer and baked as needed, or you may bake the pastry shells in regular tins or on the back of muffin tins. Pre-baked shells may be kept for weeks, if stored in a covered container in a cool place. Most cream and_ custard-type fillings such as pumpkin or any of the cream fillings may be stored in covered containers in the refrigerator for a week or two. When ready to serve your pie, freshen the pastry by placing it in a warm oven for a few minutes to give it that just-out-of-the-oven freshness. One of the most popular wintertime desserts is steamed carrot and fruit pudding. It is easily and quickly made and is fairly inexpensive. If kept in a tightly covered container in a cool place, it keeps for weeks. When processed in glass jars or cans and sealed air tight, it will keep for a year or more. Prepared in this way, it makes a perfect dessert when unexpected company calls, for a Sunday dinner, and for those extra busy days any month of the year when the menu calls for a nutritious and satisfying dessert. The right sauce complements the pudding but never dwarfs the delicate flavor of it. Choose the sauce carefully for your pudding by first deciding what the pudding needs to enhance the eating quality of it. One pudding may need a low calorie tart sauce made of a blend of fruit juice; another one, a sauce wherein a pleasing blend of spices predominates; while for others, a rich, hard sauce is a must. In every instance, make sure that the sauce plays a supporting role and not the role of the main character of your dessert. Increase the fun of meal preparation by including a dessert surprise on the family dinner menu at least every week or two. Get off the 844 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT beaten track dessert-wise, and you will discover more appetizing food to serve your family than you ever dreamed of before. Such a practice, not only with desserts but with all other foods, does much to re- 845 place boredom with adventure and fun in food preparation. Reference: "Cake Baking at High Altitude," Utah State Agricultural College Extension Service, Logan, Utah, 10c per copy. OL iterature—Shakespeare in Our Lives Lesson 6—Romeo and Juliet Elder Briant S. Jacobs (Text: Shakespeare Major Plays and the Sonnets, by G. B. Harrison, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1948) For Tuesday, March 19, 1957 Objective: To witness the great beauty of the poetic expression and dramatic skill of Shakespeare in depicting the love of Romeo and Juliet. Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague! See what a scourge is laid upon your hate That Heaven finds means to kill your joys with love!.... All are punished. S common as it is true, is the old saying, "All the world loves a lover." And no lovers have been more widely known and loved than Romeo and Juliet, surely because of all lovers in literature theirs is the pure love which each of us desires to possess and experience personally and ideally. By the very fact, then, that from its first presentation Romeo and Juliet has been one of Shakespeare's most popular _ triumphs, we may justly assume that in its words and motions we find embodied our own "best'' loves, but loves condensed, purified, and exalted through the genius of the poet Shakespeare. It must then also follow that together we should read Shakespeare as he "Holds the mirror up to nature, as 'twere," if we would come to know more deeply the movV. 3. 291-295 ingly strange powers of love which dominate, at least, our hopes, if not our lives. The fraternity of lovers is one of the best and largest our world can offer. Shakespeare acts as scribe. Only those who have been initiated know the truth of love's logic as stated in the first lines of his sonnet 138: When my love swears that she is made of truth, I do believe her, though I know she lies. For the uninitiated and the selfish, such a paradox is only sheer nonsense. Likewise they can never know that: Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs; Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes; 846 Being vexed, a sea nourished with lovers' tears. What is it else? A madness most discreet, A choking gall and a preserving sweet. I. 1. 196-200 Save for Shakespeare's addition to the nurse and his new emphasis and characterization on some figures, he lifted the entire substance of the plot directly from Arthur Broke's poem, The Tragical Historie of Romeo and Juliet, published in 1562, itself deeply indebted to Bandell, an Italian novelist. But while in his source many weeks of wooing precede the wedding, 'Tybalt is not slain until several months later, and Romeo's exile lasts from Easter through September, Shakespeare achieves his power of impact by condensing all these events into three or four days. It was by thus rearranging this plot and people that Shakespeare first created a wellknit plot which enabled "live" characters to create themselves into reality. 'This plot has a jewel precision which, through its superb craftsmanship, itself gives pleasure. The chief fault of the play is the posing artificiality of Romeo in the early scenes, and such long dry runs as Friar Laurence's long discourse on herbs (II. 3) or Lady Capulet's rather artificial comparison of Paris to a book (I. 3). Plot The play begins in the streets of Verona, where the flashing swords and malice of Tybalt once more enflame the ancient vendetta feud between the two wealthy houses of Montague and Capulet. Immediately sensing the danger, Prince Escalus decrees death as the punishment to the next person who RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—1956 starts a street-brawl. 'The Montague Romeo loves Rosaline, but when he masks and attends the Capulet ball, he instantly loves Juliet, their only daughter. After the ball he secretly enters her garden to hear her vowing her love for him. Out of the shadows he replies, and they agree to be married secretly the next day by Friar Laurence. Soon after their marriage, Romeo meets 'Tybalt, now his relative by marriage. Romeo cannot now dare to defend his honor when Tybalt insults him, so Mercutio, his gallant friend, fights Tybalt and is slain. Seeing his dearest friend killed, Romeo slays Tybalt and is banished from the city for life. Meanwhile, unaware that their daughter is already a wife, the Capulets arrange for Juliet to marry Paris, a wealthy, older suitor. Desperately frightened by his ardor and their approaching marriage, Juliet appeals to Friar Laurence for help, after both her nurse and her mother advise the marriage. 'The priest gives her a potion to drink which will make her appear dead for fortytwo hours. After she is placed in the family vault, Friar Laurence expects to summon Romeo from Mantua to the Capulet family tomb where he is to steal away his drugged bride. But fate prevents the messenger from finding Romeo in Mantua; instead, Romeo learns only that his bride is dead. After hastily buying poison he returns to her tomb, where he is discovered by Juliet's promised husband, Paris. In their encounter Romeo kills Paris, sees Juliet apparently dead, then drinks the poison as he dies in her arms. LESSON DEPARTMENT Alarmed, the Friar comes minutes later to awaken Juliet. Sensing at once what has happened she stabs herself. The two families arrive to find their children dead, and over their bodies the Capulet§ and Montagues bemoan their mutual blindness and hatred and vow to be friends henceforth. Tragedy vs. Pathos In Romeo and Juliet Shakespeare reveals how heavily he is still influenced by the medieval concept of tragedy, which held that mortals come to disastrous ends because an irresistible Fate has thus decreed. (See "Ordered Universe" Lesson 2.) The Prologue to Act I tells how: A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life, Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Do with their death bury their parents' strife. Prologue 6-8 More than fifteen passages within the play constantly remind us that their love is "death-market" that "froward fortune," "fortune's cruel will" and "false fortune" have predetermined the disastrous end of their love before it began. When, at their first impassioned meeting, Juliet seeks to know the identity of her lover, she says: Go ask his name. If he be married, My grave is like to be my wedding bed. I. 5. 136-137 Early in the play Romeo tells his dear friend Mercutio that he had "dreamed a dream," and even before meeting Juliet at the feast of the Capulets, Romeo has a great foreboding: I fear, too early. For my mind misgives 847 Some consequence, yet hanging in the stars, Shall bitterly begin his fearful date With this night's revels, and expire the term Of a despised life closed in my breast By some vile forfeit of untimely death. But He that hath the steerage of my course, Direct my sail! I. 4. 106-113 In the final scene Romeo tells how "I dreamed my lady came and found me dead" (V.1. 6), just as Romeo's servant dreams that his master is fighting within the tomb, which also prophesied an actual happening. But such a definition of tragedy is no nearer tragedy than is the play itself. In his Poetics, Aristotle defines tragedy as "a form of drama exciting the emotions of pity and fear. Its action should be single and complete, presenting a reversal of fortune, involving persons _ renowned and of superior attainments...." 'Tragedy has always involved man's own inner struggle and a conflict of will. 'Tragedy involves a disastrous end to some great person through his own inner weaknesses. In the highest tragedy, defects may be either of will or moral strength. Romeo and Juliet, therefore, falls short of containing high tragedy, since its disastrous end is produced, not by inner struggle or weakness within the characters, but by a series of unfortunate coincidences. It was just bad luck which brought together Mercutio and Tybalt, as it was bad luck that the messenger to Romeo was sealed up in a house filled with plague. And if only Friar Laurence could have arrived at the tomb one minute before Romeo drank the poison! 'These are ele- ments of chance, not of tragedy; therefore, they comprise a level of secondary importance within the play. The elements of tragedy, though present, are here dominated by pathos, or the quality of awakening sympathy, pity, and sorrow. Never do we feel a fear resulting from any conflict within anyone. We are carried along on the same currents of hope and despair which alternately carry the lovers to heights and depths—indeed one of the play's strongest appeals is that Shakespeare enables his audience to become Romeo and Juliet. The dominant reality throughout the play is the magnificent irresistibility of pure love. In the suddenness of their passion lies the weakness from which all disaster stems. So suddenly are they met and mated, so impulsively do they disregard all lesser reality than their great love, that suffering is bound to follow. Even Juliet, for a moment, is distressed by their union which is:... Too rash, too unadvised, too sudden, Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say "It lightens." II. 2. 118-120 Father Laurence, in his maturity, sees the impassioned lovers as they themselves cannot. How sad to see them disregard his wise advice: These violent delights have violent ends, And in their triumph die, like fire and powder Which as they kiss consume. The sweetest honey Is loathsome in his own deliciousness, And in the taste confounds the appetite. Therefore, love moderately, long love doth so, Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow. II. 6. 9-15 (Read Act II, Scene 6.) In our concern over details of plot, definition, and weakness, we must never forget that, despite all, for those of all ages in love with love, this is their best-loved Shakespearean play (for such persons, greatness is not the basis of judgment). In fairness to the play, as a whole, we must then proceed to point out three of its triumphs. 1. Triumph Over Falseness Just as the great theme of the play is the triumph of love, so Shakespeare has filled almost every scene with love's imagery and music. In his complete fairness, Shakespeare's all-seeing eye has defined love as seen from many points of view. 'Thus through Mercutio's eyes love is "sex'' and a clever game; for the nurse, love is earthly, bawdy, and a practical means of ensuring property and position; for Juliet's parents, love is a rash, unnecessary pain which, in no way, should be the concern of their daughter, particularly since her father is so eminently capable of choosing for her a husband who can guarantee her prestige, wealth, security. Furthermore, her father himself was a "mouse-hunter" (modern: wolf) in his younger years. None of these understand the world into which Romeo and Juliet have entered, since, in each case, their definition of love is partial or false. 'The lovers are most nearly able to share themselves with Friar Laurence, yet, even he, fills his first speeches with erotic symbols. 'Thus, by all those nearest them, they are tempted to love partially, or for the wrong reasons. The great glory of the 848 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT play is that never do they yield to these pressures. Through both their words and the shape of the entire play, love is cut off from the usual world with its usual definitions of love, and exalted into its own high realm where love speaks of love and thus creates itself. All attempts to debase love into something less than holy are thwarted. It is significant that the first intense conversation between Romeo and Juliet is filled with the religious imagery which alone expressed what they felt for each other: Rom. If I profane with my unworthiest hand This holy shrine, the gentle fine [punishment] is this, My lips, too blushing pilgrims, ready stand To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss. Jul. Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss. Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too? Jul. Aye, pilgrim, lips that they must use In prayer. Oh then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do. They pray. Grant thou, lest faith turn to despair. 1.5. 95-106 Would that all first kisses might be surrounded with such an aura! For Romeo and Juliet it makes them impregnable to stern lesser realities; literally their love makes them thrice armed and_ fearless, They are, therefore, able to triumph over everything less than love. Rom. Rom. 2. Triumph Over Flatness When most of us feel the oc- 849 casional need to break our self-imposed chains and express emotion for a loved one, we smile, hold hands, send flowers or a commercial sentiment, or even say, "I love you." Largely we feel only, because we cannot say. Romeo and Juliet provides invincible proof that great love is created and sustained by using the tongue to capture and enthrall those more direct avenues to the soul: the eye and the ear. As Hazelton Spencer has phrased it so well, "Romeo and Juliet is made of music." It is a_ lyrical hymn to love which bestows exciting magic upon its devotees. Contrast for example, how stiff and contrived are Romeo's lovewords addressed to Rosaline: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair To merit bliss by making me despair. She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow Do I live dead, that live to tell it now. I. 1. 227-230 This is a word-play, love-making for amusement and wit. Now feel Romeo's rich imagery as he describes Juliet whom he has just seen for the first time: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright! It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night Like a rich jewel in an Ethiop's ear— Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear! I. 5. 46-49 One of the most famous scenes in all literature, and justly so, is Act II, Scene 2. (Read as much of this scene as time permits.) It is night. Romeo has broken into the Capulet orchard where, concealed by shadows, he sees Juliet at the window above him: Rom. It is my lady, oh, it is my lovel.... The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night. See how she leans her cheek upon her hand! Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek! Jul. Aye me! Rom. She speaks. Oh, speak again, bright angel! For thou art As glorious to this night, being o'er my head, As is a winged messenger of Heaven Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds And sails upon the bosom of the air. Jul. O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name, Of, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love And [ll no longer be a Capui _— Rom. I take thee at thy word. Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized. Henceforth I never will be Romeo.... Jul. My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words Of thy tongue's uttering, yet I know the sound. Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague? Rom. Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike. II. 2. 10, 19-36, 49-51, 58-61 It is such words as these which clothe in immortal substance the very texture of love. It is these words, too, which transform Romeo from somewhat of a literary fop into an entire man enraptured with new love, while Juliet in her innocent frankness speaks into her words every nuance of her womanly awareness and response. In these words Shakespeare's triumph over the most difficult medium of words is well-nigh complete; likewise the lover's triumph over shallowness, triviality, and self, is well-nigh perfect. Other passages which should be noted for their beauty and read aloud are IT. 3. 33-38 and III. 5. 1-36. Triumph Over Death How much stronger is our conviction that love is good, when we know those involved, as now we know Romeo and Juliet. From one practical viewpoint their love destroyed them. But then we have a right to ask, is that the reason they live forever in the hearts of mankind? We grieve as we read the final act of the play, yet, despite the grip of pain and sorrow upon us, still there glows within us a satisfying warmth at the memory of so great a love which once was. And ever shall be. When Romeo breaks into the Capulet vault to discover Juliet dead, he pictures Death as his rival lover:... Ah, dear Juliet, Why art thou yet so fair? Shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorred monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour? For fear of that, I still will stay with thee, 850 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT And never from this palace of dim night Depart again. V. 3. 101-108 Thus Shakespeare brings before our eyes his belief that a love made great in life need not end at death. Thus, in his deep wisdom and keen seeing, in his lyrical beauty and his entire fairness, he allows us to see the mysteries of love through his 851 eyes, that we might know greater happiness and security upon returning to ourselves. Thoughts for Discussion 1. How can a literary love, which never actually happened, contain for us anything of truth? 2. How does pathos differ from tragedy? Just as Romeo and Juliet's great strength is in their love, what is the weakness in their love? Social Science—Latter-day Saint Family Life Lesson 5—Unto the Least of These" Elder John Farr Larson For Tuesday, March 26, 1957 Objective: To show that salvation is the ultimate aim in all service to the needy. HE Prophet Joseph Smith clearly enunciated a philosophy of dealing with those unfortunate persons who find themselves in trouble or wanting the essentials of life. His teachings, based upon and consistent with those of Christ, nevertheless were somewhat strange and different for his day. 'They stressed the importance of the individual and his progression, salvation, and exaltation. He urged the sisters to develop certain characteristics within themselves which are now recognized as important in dealing with people who have problems. Basically, the Gospel Plan was taught. He emphasized the importance of mercy, understanding, and acceptance of the human weakness, as well as the necessity of being forgiving and refraining from judgment. He observed, time and again, that the worth of souls is great in the eyes of God. Everything he suggested was calculated to improve the individual. The basic objective of his teachings, that of individual salvation, is a guiding principle in all service. It is applicable whether the service be to the sick, the poor, the bereaved, the troubled, the discouraged, or the spiritually weak. The Prophet's teachings were specific and practical. He seemed to reject the philosophy of the day, 1.¢., that the "poor" were basically criminal in nature, and his emphasis on the individual was at variance with the idea that all should be treated alike. His charge to "seek out objects of charity" represented a change from the desire of most people to avoid responsibility for the poor. Conditions of want and the pinch of poverty were not unfamiliar to the Prophet. His mother describes instances when the family had few of the essentials. The Prophet knew what it was to be without a home and without food. 'That he had been concerned with the poor prior to the organization of the Relief Society is indicated in his annals. The general conditions of the poor and the treatment of persons involved in crime were undoubtedly known to him. As an astute observer, he had a knowledge of the programs dealing with these matters. His experiences and knowledge, together with his understanding of people, and the inspiration which was his, magnificently equipped him to recognize the errors and injustices and to give advice to correct this service to others. Early Welfare Philosophy in the United States The early philosophy and statutes relating to the poor were based upon the English Poor Relief Society Act of 1601. The treatment of the poor by local communities was basic to this system. As a result, needs were met by a makeshift pattern, entirely lacking in uniformity. 'The principal concern of the law was to prevent nonresident indigents from obtaining residence, and provision was made for their removal from the community, as criminals. Many indigents were forced from one community to another, particularly the mentally impaired and the chronically ill. The "overseers of the poor" had the power to remove dependent children from their parents and "indenture" them to an employer who would support them in return for their labor. Often this became virtual slavery. In the administration of the law little concern was given to individual differences in need, the attitude being that all should be treated alike. Josiah Quincy, a contemporary of the Prophet, in reporting on the Pauper Laws of Massachusetts, wrote of providing for the poor by letting them out to the lowest bidder. He inserted in his report the following statement which illustrates this method of care:... The average expense of supporting adults and children is about one dollar and thirty cents per head per week; this we consider a large sum, but the poor being sometimes boarded with those who are in want themselves, it is not lost to the town (Massachusetts, General Court, Committee on Pauper Laws, Report, 1821). In the early part of the 19th Century there was a trend towards caring for the poor in almshouses, particularly in large cities. These institutions were generally overcrowded, poorly ventilated hovels, containing the human driftwood of the time, unsegregated as to sex or physical condition. They were crowded with the mentally ill, the sick of all kinds, the aged, and children. Medical care, if available at all, was available on an emergency basis. The food was meager and the clothing was inadequate. From 1837 to 1843 the United States was in a severe economic depression. During this period there was extreme suffering. Horace Greeley wrote in the "New Yorker," on January 20, 1838, that approximately one-third of the 200,000 wage earners in New York City were unemployed. In speaking of their plight he wrote: Some of these subsist on the scanty earnings of former days, some are aided by relatives or personal friends, and some manage to avoid starvation with the few 852 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 LESSON DEPARTMENT shillings which partial and precarious employment or still more uncertain beggary afford them; but there are still thousands... Who are in utter and hopeless distress, with no means of surviving the winter but those afforded by the charity of their fellow citizens. It was in this period, following a meeting of 5000 indigent persons who listened to inciting speeches, that the "flour riots" broke out, in which hungry people broke into flour storage facilities in New York. This added confirmation to the popular belief that the poor were also criminal. "Unbending harshness" best described the criminal code of that time. There was no "individualized justice" as we know it today. Extenuating circumstances rarely were considered by the Courts. The concept of punishment as a deterrent to crime gave birth to the Pennsylvania and Auburn Systems of Prisons. Under the former, prisoners were separately confined throughout their term, while under the Auburn System complete solitary was had during the night and silence during the day. The failure of these systems later brought penal reforms. The Individual Recognized Our present enlightened attitude towards social problems developed slowly. Along the road there were valiant pioneers, with Joseph Smith in the vanguard. His teachings on this subject were, in reality, refinements and specific applications of the Gospel Plan. Because of their focus on the individual and _ his spiritual, physical, social, and economic betterment, they stand out as an early unequivocal step in the development of programs and _philosophy of human betterment. In 853 1842 John Augustus (1784-1859), a Boston shoemaker, was just beginning his work of reforming convicted criminals. After observing the futility of fines and imprisonment in reformation, he asked and was given the opportunity of working personally with those who were considered hopeless. His success in the middle of the igth Century founded the professional service of Probation. In New York in 1843, the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor was organized to urge relief on a personal basis with emphasis on moral rather than material aid. The contributions of Jane Addams (1860-1935) and Mary Richmond (1861-1928) will not soon be forgotten. Jane Addams will be rembered as the founder of "Hull House." She was a crusader, a philosopher who had as her objective a better life for all people everywhere. Mary Richmond was a technician, the pioneer in bringing together a body of principles for use by professional social workers. Each of these contributions brought to light the favorable potentialities of the individual. 'The work of each of these pioneers, Joseph Smith, Jane Addams, John Augustus, and Mary Richmond, was characterized by the following: (1) an awareness of the existence of unsavory conditions; (2) a determination to correct; and (3) sufficient initiative to take the necessary corrective measures. Herein lies a "key" to social progress. The Prophet's Teachings The concluding statement of the Prophet Joseph after he turned the key at the organization of Relief Society was: 854... This is the beginning of better days to the poor and needy, who shall be made to rejoice and pour forth blessings on your heads (D. H. C. IV, page 607). In giving a general direction to the women of the Relief Society, the Prophet made this statement: Said Jesus, "Ye shall do the work which ye see me do." 'These are the grand keywords for the society to act upon (D. H. C. V, page 20). Nowhere could be found a better foundation for this work than in the teachings of Jesus. 'The forgiving, understanding attitude of Christ, and the lessons he taught, by parables and by his actions, provide a philosophy of dealing with others, unparalleled in history. Its effectiveness has been shown time and again. The objectives of the Relief Society, as previously discussed, made it clear that service to the unfortunate is of major importance to the organization. In one of his talks to the Relief Society, Joseph Smith laid down a fundamental axiom: The best measure or principle to bring the poor to repentance is to administer to their wants. The Ladies' Relief Society is not only to relieve the poor, but to save souls (Ibid., V, pages 24-25). This admonition implies more than a concern for the physical wants — it suggests a higher objective, that of individual salvation. We lift the soul of man by administering to his wants, material and spiritual. The first step is that of meeting the basic needs of food, clothing, and shelter. 'This is seen as a simple process, but an important one. 'The way these needs are met often determines whether or not further needs can be met. Some persons in need are difficult RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE—DECEMBER 1956 to find. They are often too proud, or too ashamed, to admit a need. Consequently, the objective of the Relief Society in "searching after objects of charity and in administering to their wants" becomes meaningful. In this connection an excerpt from the Handbook of the Relief Society, will be of interest: At the second meeting of the Society, on March 24, 1842, the President, Emma Smith, suggested the propriety of appointing persons who might wait upon the poor. No action in the matter was taken, however, until the next year, cases of need meanwhile being reported by anyone discovermg them. On July 28, 1843, a committee of sixteen was appointed "to search out the poor and suffering, to call upon the rich for aid, and thus, as far as possible, relieve the wants of all." They were told that the spirit of the Lord would bless them in their labors and stimulate the hearts of the well-to-do (Handbook of Relief Society 1931, page 29). Thus, the "Necessity Committee" became the forerunner of the visiting teachers. Visiting teachers, 60,639 of them, in 1954 made a total of 2,634,185 visits. It is important for them to continue to "search out the poor" so that needs may be met through the program of the Church. 'The Prophet observed at one meeting that the women had now been placed "in a situation in which you can act according to those sympathies which God has planted in your bosoms" (D. H. C. IV, page 605). 'These, he said, were feelings of charity and benevolence. The Prophet taught that women must be merciful to one another and overlook small things. He spoke of being "armed with mercy" (D. H. C. V, page 19). On another occasion he put it this way: As you increase in innocence and virtue, LESSON DEPARTMENT as you increase in goodness, let your hearts expand, let them be enlarged towards others; you must. Be long-suffering, and bear with the faults and errors of mankind. How precious are the souls of men! The female part of the community are apt to be contracted in their views. You must not be contracted, but you must be lberal in your feelings (D. H. C. IV, page 606). The Prophet always stressed the importance of personal influence on others to deter wrongdoing. In one Relief Society meeting he said: It is the object of this society to reform persons, not to take those that are corrupt and foster them in their wickedness; but if they repent, we are bound to take them, and by kindness sanctify and cleanse them from all unrighteousness by our influence in watching over them.... Nothing is so much calculated to lead people to forsake sin as to take them by the hand, and watch over them with tenderness. When persons manifest the least kindness and love to me, O what power it has over my mind, while the opposite course has a tendency to harrow up all the harsh feelings and depress the human mind (D. H. C. V, pp. 23-24). Example of Service Service to others, in the Prophet's life, was a daily reality. His mother describes one occasion in the spring of 1839: As the season advanced, the brethren began to feel the effects of the hardships which they had endured, and also the unhealthiness of the climate in which we were then situated. They came down with the agues and bilious fevers to such an extent that there were whole families in which not one was able to help himself to a drink of cold water.... Joseph and Emma, seeing the distress, commenced taking the sick into their own house, with the view of taking care of them and making them more comfortable. This they continued to do until their house became so crowded that they were compelled to spread a tent for that part 855 AS Op VY i\\ Organ Books for Church and Home —_ AT THE CONSOLE—Felton.......... 2.00 a CHANCEL ECHOES—Felton........ 2.50 as. Teachings Applied The teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith created a surge of brotherly love and kindness that has characterized the Church and the Relief Society from that time to the present. The story of service within the Relief Society is a thrilling one. Each chapter has resulted from an application of the wise counsel of the first President of the Church. Instances of service to individuals are largely unwritten because of their personal nature. They are nonetheless a part of the Relief Society story. The women of the Church, through their organization, have constantly applied the teachings of the Prophet. At their first meeting they commenced to raise funds to care for the poor and to "search out objects of charity." 'They participated in disaster relief in San Francisco following the 1906 earthquake; famine relief to China in 1907; and during both world wars aided and assisted those needing their help. Since the establishment of the Church Welfare Plan they have continued their service by aiding the Priesthood in effectuating the purposes of the Church Welfare Plan. The leadership of the Relief Society has brought stimulation to the field of social services in nurse recruitment and training programs, the founding of hospitals, from its operation of the Relief Society Home, through the operation of the Social Service and Child Welfare Department. In addition to this they have encouraged social work education and training through LESSON DEPARTMENT scholarships and loans to deserving students. (See yee of Relief Society, pp. 22, 27, 28, 30, 31, 41, 42, 45-49.) Spiritual Development The Church Welfare Program has provided Relief Society members with endless opportunities for service. 'This service can only be fully effective if the sisters go about their work with the approach suggested by the comments of President David O. McKay, made in General Conference on October 3, 1936. In speaking of the Church Welfare Program he said: The development of our spiritual nature should concern us most. Spirituality is the highest acquisition of the soul, the divine in man; "the supreme, crowning gift that makes him king of all created things." It is the consciousness of victory over self and of communion with the infinite. It is spirituality alone which really gives one the best in life (107th SemiAnnual Conference, with Report of Discourses, page 103). Supplementary References. "Individual Welfare in a Time of Plenty" -—- Bishop Carl W. Buehner, Relief Society Magazine, January 1954, page 4. 2. "Charity — A Gem of Many Facets" — Velma N. Simonsen, Relief Society Magazine, October 1953, page 722. 3. "Be Ye an Example" — Velma N. Simonsen, Relief Society Magazine, November 1954, page 724. Questions for Discussion 1. Contrast the Prophet's welfare philosophy with that of his day. How did he begin "better days for the poor'? 2. Who were some of the Prophet's contemporaries who made _ outstanding contributions to the field of social work? What characterized the work of all these pioneers? 3. What was the Prophet's greatest contribution to the philosophy of welfare work? 857 COSTUMES We will be able to supply any of the costumes for Relief Society plays and pageants. INR = PED Kee Wd —, PL AAAI es NEWEST LDS BOOKS FOR Christmas Givin 1. TEACHINGS OF THE NEW TESTAMENT Dr. Lowell L. Bennion This is a book which provokes thought and arouses enthusiasm for the teachings of Jesus Christ as found in the New Testament. In his inimitable way, Dr. Bennion has made an additional contribution to the Latter-day Saint concepts of our Lord and Savior. His analysis of Jesus' divine instructions and their application to the lives of people in modern times makes this book a MUST for Latter-day Saints and all others who would learn of the everlasting truths Jesus taught. $3.50 2. TEACHINGS OF THE DOCTRINE AND COVENANTS William E. Berrett Dr. Berrett's book provides stimulating reading on latter-day revelations contained in the Doctrine and Covenants. These revelations provide personal directives to members of the Church in. Their manner of living as well as providing the basis of Church government as restored in the Dispensation of the Fulness of Times. Since the Doctrine and Covenants is one of the standard works of the Church, Latter-day Saints should be eager to study what it contains. Teachings of the Doctrine and Covenants is a book that will point the way to a better understanding of. The restored gospel. $3.00 3. DISCOURSES OF THE PROPHET JOSEPH SMITH Compiled by Alma P. Burton Discourses of the Prophet Joseph Smith proves itself a welcome source book which gives increased understanding of the Prophet. To read the Prophet's own words on the salient doctrines reveals the vigor of his personality as well as the strength of his character. This book fills a long-felt need to learn more from the Prophet's own words what he thought and felt about the principles that had been revealed to him. The straightforwardness of his style of writing affords delight in reading his material. What is included in this book enhances the revelations recorded in the Doctrine and Covenants. $3.00 OFFICIAL PUBLISHERS TO THE LDS CHURCH 44 East South Temple Deseret Book Company 44 East South Temple ec ° Deseret BOO Co. -- Salt Lake City Utah Salt Lake City, Utah Name Genlemen: Enclosed you will find ( ) check ( ) money order (_ ) charge to my account the folAddress lowing amount: $0000.00. \ for the encircled (numbered) City.... Christensen Music—Florence J. Madsen Members, General Board of Relief Society With contrite hearts, Almighty Lord, We sing thy praise with one accord, And dedicate this house to thee, An offering in humility. O may thy benediction fall In kind protection over all Who faithfully thy words proclaim Through service, rendered in thy name, Choral Reader: May harmony and peace abide within this house; peace through understanding; harmony through unity of purpose. It is a testament to our faith in thee, witnessing the devotion of this great sisterhood. Willing hands have brought to fulfillment this cherished dream. We shall remember, Lord, and ever keep thy great commandment, "Feed my sheep." 'The labors of our hands will bless the widow and the motherless, and we will take thy healing words to comfort those who grieve. Father in heaven, Lord of the earth—May this house forever be an avenue of light from thee; that through its open doors shall flow truths of thy gospel — to strengthen faith, inspire to righteous living, to enlarge our compassion, one for another. O may this house forever be an avenue of light from thee! O may this house forever be A pathway, Lord, of light from thee, That all—all who enter in shall know From whence all light and goodness flow. As we more lofty heights attain May thine approving love sustain. And faithfully thy words we shall proclaim Through service, rendered in thy name. Page 860 (ON SECOND FLOOR) LIBRARY (ON.
